description: Boston

title: Back in Houston, Lin Already Feels at Home
description: HOUSTON  The schedule says it all. The Houston Rockets, coming off a 34-32 season but with Jeremy Lin now a member of the team, have a nationally televised Christmas-night game in Chicago this season. Anyone wonder why?

title: Lean Times in Greece as Government Cuts More Spending
description: The Greek government presented its 2013 budget to Parliament on Monday, which contained millions of Euros in spending cuts.

title: Prisoners Letters Offer a Window Into Lives Spent Alone in Tiny Cells
description: The handwritten letters arrived by the dozens, from men who described in flawed but poignant language what it was like to lose their minds. I feel like I am developing some kind of skitsophrinia behaviors, one man wrote. I hear voices echoing as I try to fall asleep.

title: The Opening Statement
description: Ladies and gentlemen, Id like to use the opening minutes of this debate a little differently. Id like to say that I wish everybody could have known my father, George Romney. He was a great public servant and Ive always tried to live up to his example. The problem is that you get caught up in the competitiveness of a campaign and all the consultants want to make you something youre not.

title: Trembling Before Mitt
description: Disregard todays column. It wont impress you.

title: Mr. Romneys Government Handout
description: The biggest beneficiaries of government largess are not those who struggle along on Social Security payments, Medicare or Medicaid benefits, or earned-income tax credits, despite what Mitt Romney has told his donors. Rather, they are those at the highest end of the income scale: government contractors, corporate farmers and very rich individuals who have figured out how to exploit the countrys poorly written tax code for their benefit.

title: Its My Birthday Too, Yeah
description: By an amazing coincidence my sister, Cathy, and my Aunt Vere have the same birthday: April 4.

title: To Combat Modern Slavery
description: Though much remains to be done, the Obama administration has begun meaningful new initiatives against human trafficking  a worldwide injustice that exposes more than 20 million poor and vulnerable individuals, especially women and children, to exploitation and degradation. The most notable of these is a strong executive order aimed at ending human trafficking activities by government contractors and subcontractors.

title: List of Global Brands Keeps Coke on Top, and Apple Jumps Up
description: AS Advertising Week 2012 continues in New York, a widely discussed topic is how to generate measurable business results for the brands sold by marketers. Coincidentally, a study to be released on Tuesday addresses the value of powerful brands  and the problems of brands whose value is diminishing.

title: New Brooklyn Arena Serves as a Test: Will Fans Accept Smaller Sodas?
description: At the amenity-laden Barclays Center in Brooklyn, hungry concertgoers can dine on fresh-from-Maine lobster rolls, gourmet barbecue brisket and slices of cheesecake from Juniors on nearby Flatbush Avenue.

title: Unlucky on Planes, but Its All Part of the Commute
description: I HAVE been flying for business since about 1980. I just think of it as another commute. I drive two hours a day just to get to and from work, and that can be just as much of a hassle, or sometimes more of a hassle, than jumping on a plane.

title: The South's Enduring Conservativism
How Karzai Could Make Himself a Hero
description: Washington

title: For Jets, Two Quarterbacks but No Easy Answers
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The day after a blowout loss that exposed the limitations of their roster, the Jets reacted by making two personnel moves. Neither involved a quarterback.

title: California Is Latest Stage for Election Battle Over Unions
description: LOS ANGELES  The battle to curb labors political clout has moved from Wisconsin to California, where wealthy conservatives are championing a ballot measure that would bar unions from donating to candidates. Labor leaders describe it as the starkest threat they have faced in a year of nationwide challenges to diminish their once-formidable power.

title: Conflict Over Love Hotel Sale
description: KAWAGOE, Japan  Several years ago, an investment subsidiary of the agricultural giant Cargill bought a group of so-called love hotels, which typically rent rooms by the hour, including the neon-lit Hotel Shine in this sprawling Tokyo suburb.

title: State Pays $2 Million to Settle Mans Wrongful Conviction
description: An apprentice elevator mechanic whose murder conviction was overturned after he had spent nearly 11 years in prison has been paid $2 million by New York State to settle a wrongful conviction lawsuit he filed.

title: Ordinary Lies, Damn Lies and the Debates
description: Consumer warning: The claims you hear in Wednesday nights presidential debate may be hazardous, if not to your health, then to your relationship to reality.

title: Loss to Rays Shrinks Orioles Margin for Errors
description: St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: How Punch Protected The Times
description: In 1969, shares of The New York Times Company began to be listed on the American Stock Exchange.

title: A New Sign of Distress as Irans Currency Falls
description: Irans already fragile currency, the rial, has fallen in value by about 40 percent over the past week, battered by a combination of potent Western sanctions over the disputed Iranian nuclear program and new anxieties among Iranians about their governments economic stewardship, analysts said.

title: In Queens, an Oasis Neglected by the City
description: She is not one of New Yorks Grande Dame parks, those Olmsted beauties with Victorian park houses, manicured lawns, rolling hills and forest glades. She lacks the high-stepping strut of Central Park and the hipster slouch of Prospect Park.

title: Schools Failure to Improve May Lead to More Closings
description: New York Citys Education Department may step up its efforts to close schools after more than 150 of them posted a third straight year of mediocre results on their annual progress reports.

title: Leaders at Work on Plan to Avert Mandatory Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Senate leaders are closing in on a path for dealing with the fiscal cliff facing the country in January, opting to try to use a postelection session of Congress to reach agreement on a comprehensive deficit reduction deal rather than a short-term solution.

title: Judge Rules That Mass Arrests at a 2004 Protest Were Illegal
description: A federal judge has ruled that the New York Police Department illegally arrested large numbers of demonstrators at a protest in Lower Manhattan during the 2004 Republican National Convention. But the judge upheld aspects of how the city had handled the protesters arrests.

title: Lottery Numbers
Combating Boredom, a Locked-Out Player Finally Heads Overseas
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Inside a tiny ice rink in this citys suburbs, one of the N.H.L.s most promising young talents was playing in a weekly recreation hockey league.

title: Knicks Executives Project Confidence in Off-Season Moves
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  When Glen Grunwald, the Knicks general manager, and Mike Woodson, the teams coach, sat down next to each other on Monday to finally discuss the personnel decisions the team has made over the last four months, it took only two questions to get to some unfinished business about Jeremy Lin.

title: The Gangs All Here
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I thought this one was wheelie interesting. Im sorry, Ill try again: I never once grew tired of doing Ethan Coopers puzzle. Darn it, its only the first paragraph and already Im stealing all of your puns. Im not worried, though; I know youll come up with at least a few of your own.

title: Corrections: October 2, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Mets Keeping Coaches in 2013
description: MIAMI  The Mets will retain their entire coaching staff for the 2013 season, Manager Terry Collins said Monday as the team prepared for its final series of the year.

title: Lured by Promises of Wealth, F.B.I. Agent Was Drawn Into Fraud Scheme, Prosecutors Say
description: As he approached retirement this year, an F.B.I. agent in New York told a friend in an e-mail that his decades of work in law enforcement were finally about to pay off.

title: Connecticut Court Orders Retrial for Man Convicted in 87 Murder
description: Year after year, appeal after appeal, lawyers and fervent supporters of a Connecticut dishwasher, Richard Lapointe, contended that he was mentally and physically unable to commit the rape, arson and murder for which he was sentenced to life without parole 20 years ago.

title: U.S. Abandoning Hopes for Taliban Peace Deal
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With the surge of American troops over and the Taliban still a potent threat, American generals and civilian officials acknowledge that they have all but written off what was once one of the cornerstones of their strategy to end the war here: battering the Taliban into a peace deal.

title: A Day to Speak Out on Fire Dept. Bias Case
description: After years of legal maneuvering in a case that accuses the New York Fire Department of discriminating against minority applicants, the people who would be most directly affected by the outcome got their day in court on Monday, and the testimony was largely predictable.

title: Swiss Cows Send Texts to Announce Theyre in Heat
description: ZOLLIKOFEN, Switzerland  When Christian Oesch was a boy on his familys hog farm, cellphones were a thing of the future. Now, Mr. Oesch tends a herd of dairy cattle and carries a smartphone wherever he goes. Occasionally he gets an SMS from one of his cows.

title: Giants Learn That Late Rallies Are Not a Sure Thing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said he needed only to look into the eyes of his players to understand the hurt stemming from a 19-17 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday night that left the defending Super Bowl champions 0-2 in the N.F.C. East for the first time since 1996.

title: Fighting and Chaos Spread Through Syrian City, as Services Vanish
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Chaos continued to spread in Syrias largest city, Aleppo, on Monday, as rebels attacked the towering municipality building with rockets, sending civil servants fleeing from one of the few government buildings still functioning as dozens of soldiers worked to defend the city center.

title: Video Seems to Show American Journalist Being Held by Islamists in Syria
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A Web site that supports the Syrian government publicized a video clip on Monday that showed Austin Tice, an American freelance journalist, to be alive but held hostage by what appeared to be Islamist militants. It was the first glimpse of Mr. Tice since Aug. 13.

title: Nets Coach Is Welcoming the Pressure to Win
description: Insomnia can come in many forms and from many sources: anxiety, frustration, doubt, hopelessness. Avery Johnson sampled them all for two years, his circadian rhythm wrecked by the sad futility of his team, the Nets.

title: Yankees Rout Boston to Take One-Game Lead
description: As the Yankees ran onto the field Monday night for their most anticipated game of the season, the atmosphere at Yankee Stadium was decidedly more electric than it was over the weekend at the cavernous, half-empty dome in Toronto, where the Yankees looked flat and uninspired during much of their four-game split.

title: Colombia: President to Undergo Surgery for Prostate Cancer
description: President Juan Manuel Santos said Monday that he would undergo surgery for prostate cancer this week. The president, 61, said that the cancer had been detected at an early stage and that doctors told him that he had a 97 percent chance of a full recovery. One of his doctors was quoted in Colombian media reports as saying that neither chemotherapy nor radiation therapy would be needed after the surgery, which will remove Mr. Santoss prostate. Meanwhile, the Colombian government is preparing to open peace talks this month with the countrys largest guerrilla group. The talks are to begin in Oslo and later move to Havana.

title: Texas Fishing Contests Lure Competitors and Fraud
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex.  Late on a Saturday afternoon this summer, dozens of boats  Reel Madness, Miss Directed, Knot at Work  were rushing toward land as part of an annual womens fishing tournament here. The trouble started when state game wardens noticed that the catch aboard the Nice Tails boat was not so nice.

title: New Polls Raise Chance of Electoral College Tie
description: As of Mondays FiveThirtyEight forecast, there were 21 states that Barack Obama was projected to have at least an 85 percent chance of winning on Nov. 6. The list includes three important states, Ohio, Wisconsin and New Hampshire, where Mr. Obamas polling has improved by an especially clear margin since the Democratic convention. It did not include several others, however, where he is favored, but less definitively so, such as Virginia, Iowa, Nevada, Colorado and Florida.

title: A Lost, and Possibly Last, Season for Valentine
description: Bobby Valentine leaned against the railing alongside the visiting dugout at Yankee Stadium on Monday night and closed his eyes when asked to sum up the 2012 season. Valentine was back in New York, the scene of his greatest managerial triumphs, and in about two hours, his Boston Red Sox, losers of 90 games for the first time since 1966, would play the first of what were expected to be three meaningful games.

title: Carlos Moseley, Philharmonic Manager, Dies at 98
description: Carlos Moseley, who took the New York Philharmonic into Lincoln Center a half-century ago, and then into the citys parks and neighborhoods while presiding over enormous growth as the orchestras managing director, president and chairman, died on Monday at his home in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 98.

title: 7 Crew Members Are Detained in Deadly Collision of 2 Boats in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  As the Hong Kong police announced arrests on Tuesday in the deadly collision of two boats in Victoria Harbor, relatives of those killed tossed spirit money into the wind at the scene of the disaster and survivors described a terrifying ordeal.

title: Doctor Visits Dropping, New Census Figures Show
description: WASHINGTON  Americans of working age are going to the doctor less frequently than they were 10 years ago, according to a new report by the Census Bureau.

title: With a Transition Near, New Questions in China
description: BEIJING  With only six weeks to go before the formal unveiling of a new set of leaders for China, Communist Party elders and senior officials are still deciding who will ascend to the top ruling bodies and what policy direction they will adopt for the new team, political insiders and analysts say.

title: James E. Burke, 87, Dies; Candid Ex-Chief of Johnson & Johnson
description: James E. Burke, whose leadership of Johnson & Johnson during the Tylenol poisonings in the 1980s is regarded as a textbook example of how to handle a public relations crisis, died on Friday at a health care facility near New Brunswick, N.J. He was 87.

title: Offshore Tactics Helped Increase Romneys Wealth
description: Buried deep in the tax returns released by Mitt Romneys presidential campaign are references to dozens of offshore holdings with names like Ursa Funding (Luxembourg) S..r.l. and Sankaty Credit Opportunities Investors (Offshore) IV, based in the Cayman Islands.

title: Brown and Warren Clash in Spirited Massachusetts Senate Debate
description: LOWELL, Mass.  Elizabeth Warren and Senator Scott P. Brown clashed Monday night in a spirited debate held, appropriately enough, in a massive hockey arena here with 5,000 people in the audience cheering them on as if they were gladiators jousting in a pit.

title: Why Go Offshore?
description: An explainer of the onshore and offshore structure of Bain Capitals funds:

title: Before a Loss, a Much Bigger Win for Nationals
description: WASHINGTON  After a brief fete in their clubhouse on Monday, the Nationals decided to celebrate their National League East title with a few thousand friends.

title: Playing Roles of Referee and, Increasingly, Target During Debates
description: When Jim Lehrer takes the stage in Denver on Wednesday night, the tens of millions of people watching will see the same imperturbable voice of reason they have come to know in his quarter century as the countrys go-to referee for the presidential debates.

title: Q & A with N.A.S.L. Commissioner David Downs
description: The eight-team North American Soccer League has reached the semifinal round of the playoffs as it looks ahead to next season.

title: Report Sees Less Impact in New Autism Definition
description: Proposed changes to the official diagnosis of autism will not reduce the proportion of children found to have it as steeply as many have feared, scientists reported on Tuesday, in an analysis that contradicts several previous studies.

title: Manhattan Apartment Sales Rose Last Quarter, Reports Find
description: Manhattan apartment sales rose in the third quarter of 2012 to the highest level since the financial crisis began, despite low inventory, as demand and consumer confidence strengthened, according to reports that will be released by New York Citys major brokerage firms on Tuesday.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 2, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Next Act for Superstar: Conquering New York.

title: Word of the Day | artifact
description: artifact \r-ti-fakt\ adjective

title: Administration Advises States to Expand Medicaid or Risk Losing Federal Money
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is putting pressure on states to expand Medicaid, telling them they may lose federal money if they delay.

title: Experts See Signs of El Nio, but a Weak One
description: WASHINGTON  A season of warmer ocean waters that has been expected to produce a Nio episode and perhaps bring relief from the continuing drought may turn out to be a bit weaker than advertised, according to climate experts.

title: Tennessee: Meningitis Kills Two Who Received Steroid Injections
description: Two people in Tennessee have died and nine others are ill after an outbreak of meningitis among patients given steroid injections in the spinal region for pain at the Saint Thomas Outpatient Neurosurgery Center in Nashville. A patient who received the same type of treatment in North Carolina is sick, and health officials say patients in other states may be affected. Meningitis is an infection involving the lining of the brain and central nervous system. The outbreak is an unusual type caused by a fungus and is not spread from person to person. Doctors think the infections were caused by contamination of the steroid with the fungus, known as aspergillus. One lot of the medication has been recalled, and more than 700 patients who received the shots at the Nashville clinic, which has closed, have been notified.

title: In Search for Drugs, Something Unexpected
description: When the police showed up at the Brooklyn home of Michael and Alisa Volpe on Monday to execute a search warrant, they found what they were looking for: guns and drugs.

title: Sabathias Groove Returns at Right Time for Yankees
description: Three months ago against the Boston Red Sox, C. C. Sabathia was battered for six runs and eight hits in six innings of an 8-6 Yankees loss. It was his worst outing of the season, but the seven starts that followed were not exactly pristine. For much of August and September, Sabathia battled injury and ineffectiveness, a concerning mix with the playoffs looming.

title: Another Critic Is Silenced in Cambodia
description: HONG KONG  A court in Cambodia has sentenced a 71-year-old radio journalist to 20 years in prison for allegedly encouraging a secessionist movement in a remote eastern village.

title: Happy Gandhi Jayanti
News Quiz | October 2, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Georgias President Concedes Defeat in Parliamentary Election
description: TBILISI, Georgia  President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia conceded defeat in parliamentary elections on Tuesday and declared himself an opposition politician, an extraordinary event in a country whose other post-Soviet leaders have left office under pressure from chanting crowds and the threat of civil war.

title: Flimflam Fever Goes VSP
description: Way back in 2010 I took a real look at Paul Ryans much-praised plan, and quickly determined that it was essentially a fraud. I pronounced him a flimflam man. And according to my sources, the Very Serious People of Washington were greatly annoyed. They had decided that Ryan was a Brave Truth-Teller; you werent supposed to question that premise. Indeed, months later Ryan received a Fiscy award for fiscal responsibility.

title: Bowlesing Toward Betrayal
description: So, is my timing good or not? Right after I warn about the risk that Democrats, including the president, might betray the mandate they seem likely to get for preserving the safety net, we learn that Senate leaders are at work on a plan based around, well, you guessed it:

title: Tattoos to Remember
description: WHY did Eli Sagir get a tattoo with the number 157622 inked on her forearm?WHY might this tattooing practice be unsettling or offensive to some?WHY did people in the camps treat with respect the numbers from 30,000 to 80,000, according to Primo Levi?

title: If You Like Dion. . .
description: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to music of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Snoopy Comes to Life
description: It was 62 years ago today that the comic strip Peanuts was first published. I used to be a huge comic strip fan, but these days, Im down to reading four: Doonesbury, Baby Blues, For Better or Worse and Peanuts, which set the standard in this world. Though its creator, Charles M. Schulz, died in 2000, the strip continued to appear in my local paper as Peanuts Classics. I may have read some of them before, but if so, Ive forgotten  one of the rare good things about getting older and losing your memory.

title: Challenging Offensive Language in the Office
The Mitt Romney Who Might Have Been
description: It was almost exactly four years ago that Mitt Romney watched up close as John McCain agonized over how he should respond to Americas spiraling financial crisis. What McCain ultimately chose to do, six weeks before the election, was to suspend his campaign and return to Washington to meet with President Bush and Congressional leaders. But that strategic gamble  which now takes its place in the annals of political misfires  came as a result of a somber meeting earlier that day with his economic team at a Hilton hotel in Midtown Manhattan. The attendees included several of the candidates big donors in the finance industry, a few political advisers and Romney.

title: Taking Shots in the Ring
description: As two fighters surged toward one another, bright lights flared in Brian Franks lens. The colors around him were garish, and commotion in the ring made focusing nearly impossible. On the mat, the fighters sweaty limbs were locked and tense, prodding each other, searching for vulnerabilities. Mr. Frank could only point, click the shutter and hope.

title: To What Company Would You Write a Letter of Complaint or Admiration?
description: In the Sunday Review, the novelist Gary Shteyngart writes about a terrible airline experience he recently had. His piece begins, You, American Airlines, should no longer be flying across the Atlantic.

title: In Malaysia, Court Backs Right to Print a Newspaper
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Obtaining permission to publish a newspaper in Malaysia, where the print media are dominated by government-linked publications, is likely to become easier after a court ruled that the right to freedom of expression includes the right to publish and is a fundamental liberty, a lawyer said on Tuesday.

title: The Early Word: Offshore
description: Todays Times

title: Formula E Racing Goes Hunting for Respect, and a Market
description: For years, efforts to bring a Formula One race to the streets of an American city have failed in part over residents objections to noisy gas guzzlers whizzing past their homes. Alejandro Agag thinks he has a solution: Race electric cars instead.

title: The Fiscal Cliff Opportunity
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Part 2: Answers to Readers Questions About Scholarships
description: Updated: Mr. Kantrowitz is no longer taking questions.

title: Counselors Calendar | October Checklist for Juniors
description: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselors Calendar, which is designed to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: Barclays Continues to Remake Executive Team
description: LONDON  Barclays announced on Tuesday that it had added two new members to its executive committee as it continued to reshape itself in the wake of a rate-rigging scandal.

title: Oh, to Be Jewish in China
description: BEIJING  When I tell people in China that I am Jewish, I often get the same response. Ah, so clever! the Chinese person will say with a nudge. So good with money! The Chinese and the Jews  we have so much in common!

title: Birk vs. Kluwe: Gay Marriage Debate Plays Out in N.F.L.
description: Maryland and Minnesota are battlegrounds on the issue of gay marriage. And now, surprisingly, so is the N.F.L.

title: Europes Banks Urged to Keep Trading and Lending Operations Separate
description: BRUSSELS  Banks in the European Union should quarantine their risky trading activities from their everyday savings and lending operations, as a way to safeguard the financial system and avoid future bailouts at taxpayers expense, a panel of financial experts recommended Tuesday.

title: Why Your Car Isnt Electric
description: It will come as no surprise to hear that only a tiny fraction  less than 1 percent  of cars driving along American roads are fully electric. What might be more surprising is the fact that this wasnt always the case. In 1900, 34 percent of cars in New York, Boston and Chicago were powered by electric motors. Nearly half had steam engines. What happened? Why do we end up embracing one technology while another, better one struggles or fails?

title: What if Web Users Could Sell Their Own Data?
description: Two-thirds of Americans dont want advertisers tracking them on the Internet, according to researchers at the University of Pennsylvaniaand the University of California. But that hasnt slowed the growth of online behavioral advertising, the industry that harvests data about Web habits and uses it to target individual consumers with ads.

title: Lawyers Seek to Block Muslim Clerics Extradition to U.S.
description: LONDON  Lawyers for a Muslim cleric wanted in the United States on terrorism charges said on Tuesday that the preacher, Abu Hamza al-Masri, was physically unfit to face the accusations against him and that it would be oppressive to extradite him under the terms of British law.

title: Underway in Barcelona: the Global Clean Energy Forum
description: The International Herald Tribune published a Clean Energy special report on Tuesday with articles on hydrogen-fueled autorickshaws, compressed air as a way to store energy, ways to capture wave energy from the sea, geothermal power mining in Japan and renewable energy in Saudi Arabia.

title: Daily Report: Seattle Police Turn to Twitter for Crime Reports
description: The Seattle Police Department, which presides over one of the nations more tech-savvy cities, is diving into a project that uses 51 hyper-local neighborhood Twitter accounts to provide moment-to-moment crime reports, reports Kirk Johnson in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: Q&A: Running Windows XP, Virtually
description: Q.

title: Romney Ad Has New Take on Whether Obama Raised Taxes
description: 10:25 a.m. | Updated Mitt Romney seems to have changed his mind about whether President Obama has already raised taxes.

title: Furniture That Is Quirky but Functional
description: Quirky, the design collective whose products are often true to its name, has melded milk crate shelving, Lego blocks and hipster design to create Crates, a modular shelving system with dorm rooms in mind.

title: Now Streaming | Valentino Spring 2013 Womens Collection
description: The Spring 2013 womens collection show from Valentino at Paris Fashion Week. Delays may occur.

title: A Dead Smartphone Underground and a Connection to Make
description: Dear Diary:

title: Whos That Again?
description: Youre reading a long, well-reported Times article, full of cogent observations from knowledgeable, on-the-record sources. Somewhere near the end, you read something like: Ms. Jones said the problem had grown more acute in recent years. And you wonder.

title: U.S. Presidential Debate 2012
description: In this preview, sound bites, quips and body language become the issues of the presidential debate between President Obama and Mitt Romney.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Debate Moderators in Spotlight, and Testing Green Marketing
description: The referees are under the spotlight again, and this time not on the football field. As the first presidential debate approaches Wednesday night, the moderators have inevitably become part of the story, Jeremy Peters writes in The Times, as they get caught up in the partisan give-and-take that characterizes the campaigns. A role that once stood as a crowning journalistic achievement has become more scrutinized and stressful than ever. Mind you, every morning I wake up, I want to throw up thinking about it, said CNNs Candy Crowley, who will moderate a debate on Oct. 16.

title: Opinion Report: Protests in Europe
description: From the editorial page

title: Tuesday Reading: When Doctors Stop Taking Insurance
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: At N.F.L. Quarter Pole, Matt Ryan Is Most Valuable
description: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

title: Films That Look Forward and Back
description: As the New York Film Festival celebrates its 50th anniversary, its rich, heady brew of nostalgia and anticipation evokes the opening words of T. S. Eliots poem Burnt Norton: Time present and time past/Are both perhaps present in time future.

title: Saint Laurent: Back at the Chateau Marmont
description: The house that Yves Saint Laurent founded with Pierre Berge has a new, punchier name and a new designer  Hedi Slimane  but in many ways its the same old French label.

title: On Our Radar: A Yosemite Valley, Restored?
description: Voters in San Francisco will vote next month on a proposal to commission an $8 million study on the possibility of draining the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in Yosemite National Park and turning it back into a second Yosemite Valley with green meadows, rich forests and waterfalls. Scientists suggest that it can be done. [The Contra Costa Times]

title: License to Care
description: JERUSALEM  Last month I took my wife to Al Makassed Islamic Charitable Hospital in East Jerusalem to have the head of the orthopedic ward, Dr. Rustom Nammari, examine her arm; she broke it this summer during a hike in Scotland. Since its establishment in 1968, this hospital has been the medical institution of choice for Palestinians in the West Bank.

title: Mortgage Task Force Targets JPMorgan
description: Mortgage Task Force Targets JPMorgan | Those financial crisis deals just keep coming back to haunt banks. Last week, Bank of America settled a lawsuit over its acquisition of Merrill Lynch. Now, JPMorgan Chase is facing fresh claims related to Bear Stearns.

title: Nest, the High-Tech Thermostat, Gets Slimmer and Smarter
description: Nest, the company founded by the former Apple designer Tony Fadell, has a new version of its self-learning thermostat coming out this month. The company said on Tuesday that it had upgraded both the hardware and software of the device to make it thinner, smarter and more compatible with different types of heating and cooling systems.

title: Question Marks on Europes Nuclear Safety
description: LONDON  How safe is nuclear power? The question has again been highlighted by a leaked official report that indicates nearly all of the nuclear power plants in Europe have safety failings that will cost billions of euros to put right.

title: Readers Wont Benefit if Times Bans the Term Illegal Immigrant
description: For two weeks, Ive been listening to people and reading about the term illegal immigrant. I have gathered information from readers, advocates, reporters and editors. I even had a face-to-face meeting with the most visible proponent of a change to undocumented, Jose Antonio Vargas, whom I found to be intelligent, passionate and charming.

title: With a New M.T.A. Ad Policy, Thinking About the First Amendment
description: Should you wish to place an advertisement in the subways or on buses, there are a few things you need to know.

title: Beasts of the Southern Wild Ineligible for SAG Awards
description: It was the dream of Hushpuppy, the young protagonist of Beasts of the Southern Wild, that future generations would some day learn of the adventures she shared with her father in the mythical community they called the Bathtub. But her triumphs and tragedies will not be recorded in the annals of the Screen Actors Guild, which has declared the film ineligible for its annual Screen Actors Guild Awards, The Hollywood Reporter said.

title: Goals Give You Confidence
description: Short and sweet and straight at goal.

title: What Were Reading
description: Summer Tomato: Apparently, weve come full circle: Heres advice on how to cook non-locally, with non-seasonal produce.  Julia Moskin

title: Thiel Fund Leads Investment in Brazilian Start-Up
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Peter Thiels Valar Ventures Management has made its first foray in Brazil, leading an investment in an e-commerce start-up that is trying to shake up the traditional furniture market here and take on an established retailer recently acquired by the Carlyle Group.

title: Voter-Approved Marriage
description: No state has ever legalized same-sex marriage through a referenduman invaluable fact for marriage-equality opponents, who argue that judges and lawmakers have imposed a radical redefinition of a traditional institution on an unwilling population.

title: Regulator Urges Appeal of Dodd-Frank Court Ruling
description: A financial regulator on Tuesday assailed a recent court ruling that overturned limits on speculative trading, calling the decision deeply flawed and vulnerable to appeal.

title: With Addition of 573,000 Accords, Total Number of Hondas Recalled for Fire Hazard Reaches 1.1 Million
description: As part of the fourth recall relating to the problem, Honda announced it would recall about 573,000 Accords from the 2003-7 model years equipped with V-6 engines because of a potential fire hazard. The recall plan was submitted in a report (PDF) to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Thursday.

title: MetroPCS Spikes on Deal Speculation
description: Shares in MetroPCS Communications shot up on Tuesday on speculation it was nearing a deal with Deutsche Telekom.

title: Voter ID Rules Fail Court Tests Across Country
description: A Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday blocked the key component of a highly contested state law requiring strict photographic identification to vote in next months election, saying the authorities had not done enough to ensure that voters had access to the new documents.

title: Chanel: Spring 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Bookshelf | New York State of Mind
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Model-Morphosis | Katlin Aas at Chanel
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Katlin Aas for Marilyn Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Peter Philips and hair by Sam McKnight.

title: Hands on a Hardbody Sets Broadway Opening Date
description: Another new movie-turned-musical has confirmed its opening for the 2012-13 Broadway season: Hands on a Hardbody, about a group of Texans in an endurance contest to win a new truck, will begin preview performances on Feb. 23 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater and open on Mar. 21, the producers said on Tuesday. The Broadway cast will be the same performers from last springs production of Hardbody at La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego, including Keith Carradine (a Tony nominee for the title role in The Will Rogers Follies), Hunter Foster (Urinetown), Mary Gordon Murray (a Tony nominee in 1982 for Little Me) and Connie Ray (Next Fall).

title: Netanyahu Appears to Be Shifting Israels Iran Policy Toward More Sanctions
description: JERUSALEM  Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, plans to travel to Europe before the end of the year, among other things to press for a toughening of sanctions against Tehran, Israeli officials said Tuesday. The plans appeared to be another indication of a shifting Israeli emphasis, at least for now, toward efforts to stop the Iranian nuclear program by means other than military action.

title: A Distressed Property
description: Cargill finds trouble in Japanese 'love hotel' deal. | Why Americans could pay higher taxes come January. | American Express to pay refunds over debt collection practices.

title: Business Day Live: Conflict Over Love Hotel Sale
description: Cargill finds trouble in Japanese love hotel deal. | Why Americans could pay higher taxes come January. | American Express to pay refunds over debt collection practices.

title: Supreme Court to Investigate Police Killings in Manipur
description: Indias Supreme Court appointed on Monday an independent investigator to look into allegations that security forces in Manipur summarily executed people, after a human rights group documented 1,528 cases of extrajudicial killings in the state over the past five years.

title: Even With Referees Back, Mondays Game Was Tough to Watch
description: A week after the pivotal Monday Night Football game that ended the referees lockout, we were bound for a letdown. Its hard to top a game-deciding call gone so spectacularly wrong that it kneecapped the most powerful league in sports in a labor negotiation. So this week, you had to settle for the quarterback train wreck watch between Dallass Tony Romo and Chicagos Jay Cutler, which Romo won in a landslide. Cutler competed strongly only in the sideline pouting category.

title: The Playoff Picture: Rating the A.L. Rotations
description: On Monday we took a look at the top three starters of the expected National League playoff teams. Today, we look at the corresponding rotations in the American League, with the Detroit Tigers seemingly having a rotation most capable of taking over a playoff series.

title: The Journey to White Mars
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Time to Give Charles Portis His Due
description: It has been a rough few years for Southern literature, with a spate of deaths, including that ofHarry Crewsin March. Now, at last, comes some excellent news: the appearance of Escape Velocity: A Charles Portis Miscellany, a collection of short fiction, reportage, memoir and more from the author of the novels True Grit, Norwood and, my favorite, The Dog of the South. Portis, whom Jonathan Lethem reportedly has called everybodys favorite least-known great novelist, is the subject of my column in the latest One-Page Magazine.

title: Baryshnikov to Dance in New Mark Morris Work
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Mark Morris are reuniting once again. The acclaimed dancer will perform in a new work by Mr. Morris during its world premiere on Thursday in Seattle. A Wooden Tree, to music and words by Ivor Cutler, will be performed as part of On the Boards in a program that also includes Mr. Morriss Muir, Petrichor and Grand Duo.

title: The Deadly Threat of Silent Heart Attacks
description: For more than six months, Harriett Cooke had been uncommonly tired, panting when she walked her sixth grade science class to the cafeteria and struggling to keep her eyes open when she drove home at night.

title: Clip: Wake in Fright
description: A scene from the 1971 Australian thriller Wake in Fright, which opens at Film Forum on Oct. 5.

title: August Changes Sent Dodgers and Giants in Unexpected Directions
description: LOS ANGELES  Don Mattingly was reasonably loose Monday, considering he was a manager staring down a must-win game for his Los Angeles Dodgers against the San Francisco Giants. It was the final series of a roller coaster season and, mathematically at least, his team had a chance to scratch its way into a wild-card slot.

title: Weekly Reader: Desegregation for the Disabled, Marriage, Background TV and Cat Videos
description: Ending Segregation for the Disabled: States are moving hundreds of mentally disabled adults out of institutions and into group homes within the community, and families who had felt unable to do anything other than institutionalize their children are seeing their lives change as adults. The writer Rachel L. Swarns perfectly captures the emotions of the transitions.

title: Einhorn Bets Against Chipotle
description: The share price of Chipotle Mexican Grill is dropping like a lead burrito after the hedge fund manager David Einhorn called the fast-food chain overvalued.

title: Calvin Trillin Wins Thurber Prize for American Humor
description: The Thurber Prize for American Humor was awarded to Calvin Trillin, the author and New Yorker staff writer, for his book Quite Enough of Calvin Trillin: Forty Years of Funny Stuff (Random House). Mr. Trillin, the author of 20 books including About Alice and Obliviously On He Sails, will release a new book in December, Dogfight: An Occasionally Interrupted Narrative Poem About the Presidential Campaign. Thurber House, a nonprofit literary group named after the New Yorker writer and cartoonist James Thurber, gave the annual award for an outstanding book of humor writing published in the United States in 2011. The winner also receives a $5,000 prize. Previous winners include David Sedaris, Jon Stewart and the writers of The Daily Show and David Rakoff.

title: In JPMorgan Case, the Martin Act Rides Again
description: The New York attorney generals new lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase over mortgage-backed securities showcases one of the legal weapons most feared on Wall Street: the Martin Act.

title: Syria Berates Hamas Chief, an Old Ally, on State TV
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  State television in Syria issued a withering attack late Monday on a longtime ally, the leader of the Palestinian militant group Hamas, Khaled Meshal, addressing him as if he were an ungrateful child, saying he was having a romantic emotional crisis over the Syrian uprising and accusing him of selling out resistance for power.

title: Fixing a Credit Card Mix-Up for Stay-at-Home Spouses
description: More than a year ago, I wrote a Bucks post about a provision of the Credit CARD Act of 2009, which was created to protect consumers but also ended up restricting access to credit for stay-at-home wives and husbands.

title: Girardi Rests His Bullpen as Sabathia Goes 8
description: When the Yankees took a 9-0 lead in the second inning Monday night against Boston, the same thought quickly went through the minds of some reporters covering the game. Should Manager Joe Girardi remove C.C. Sabathia earlier than usual in case he wanted to pitch him on three days rest in a possible wild-card game on Friday?

title: Oct. 1: Is the Presidential Race Tightening Heading Into the Debates?
description: There are two basic types of information that were looking to discern out of each poll. One is simply the raw number: how much does the poll have President Obama leading or trailing Mitt Romney by? The other is the trendline: does the poll show toward a shift toward either candidate from previous editions of the same survey?

title: A War of Words
description: The attack on Fort Sumter didnt start the Civil War in 1861; the war began 10 years earlier, with the publication of Harriet Beecher Stowes anti-slavery novel Uncle Toms Cabin. At least, thats what Abraham Lincoln claimed, when he met Stowe in 1862 and reportedly greeted her as the little woman who wrote the book that started this great war.

title: T-Mobile Looks to Buy MetroPCS
description: 9:06 p.m. | Updated The parent company of T-Mobile USA, the struggling cellphone service provider, is in talks to buy MetroPCS  as it fights to compete against two bigger rivals.

title: Time Warner Cable to Charge Modem Rental Fee
description: 1:45 p.m. | Updated  Adding more details about buying a modem.

title: Postcard: A Climate Communication Retreat in the North Carolina Hills
description: Bill Chameides, the dean of the Nicholas School of the Environment at Duke University, somehow finds time to balance pedagogy, research and communication, via his quirkily named blog, The Green Grok. He mentioned a recent retreat his school held to explore how to engage both the analytic and emotional sides of the human brain on the challenges posed by human-driven climate change. I invited him to send a Dot Earth Postcard, and here it is:

title: Auto Sales Are Highest in 4 Years
description: DETROIT  Unemployment is still high and the so-called fiscal cliff is looming, but those worries didnt slow down the nations car and truck buyers in September.

title: Photos of The Moment | Sacai
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Tods Classic Handbags, in Brighter Colors
description: Walking into the fabulous Italian Embassy on the Rue de Varenne, not far from the Rodin museum, for a presentation of Tods new Signature collection on Monday, I was surprised to hear, of all things, Hip Hop Hooray by Naughty by Nature.

title: Fallout Over Voter Efforts
description: Republican Party leaders in four more states have fired a consulting firm that was hired to register new voters, after suspect forms linked to the company were discovered in Florida.

title: U.S. Is Tracking Killers in Attack on Libya Mission
description: WASHINGTON  The United States is laying the groundwork for operations to kill or capture militants implicated in the deadly attack on a diplomatic mission in Libya, senior military and counterterrorism officials said Tuesday, as the weak Libyan government appears unable to arrest or even question fighters involved in the assault.

title: G.O.P. Aims to Remake Florida Supreme Court
description: MIAMI  In a bid to remake Floridas judiciary, Republicans are asking voters to oust three state Supreme Court justices and give the Legislature greater power over Supreme Court appointments and judicial rules of procedure.

title: Sites That Pay the Shopper for Being a Seller
description: Julie Medeiros thinks her taste in fashion is worth something. Turns out it is: about $50 a month.

title: In Las Vegas, a Big Rig Races the Clock
description: LAS VEGASMine Expo International 2012, a convention of manufacturers and service providers, filled 12 exposition halls here until last Wednesday. Teams continue to race a Friday deadline to disassemble and remove monumental displays from the Las Vegas Convention Center.

title: Revisiting President Obamas Small-Business Tax Cut Claims
description: This summer, the number 18 has crept into President Obamas campaign speeches  as in, Weve cut taxes for small businesses 18 times. (Thats from a speech in Melbourne, Fla., last month.) The first lady, Michelle Obama, mentions it, too. And, of course, it came up frequently at the Democratic National Convention a few weeks ago, where it caught the attention of a regular Youre The Boss commenter who calls himself Einstein. (No, not that Einstein.)

title: A Flagrant Conflict of Interest
description: Last Friday, a state trial judge stayed Pennsylvanias execution of Terrance Williamsscheduled for this Wednesdayand ordered a new sentencing hearing. In response to a motion from Philadelphias district attorney, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court could overturn the stay and order, putting the execution back on schedule. Yet the courts chief justice has no business judging this case.

title: State of the Race: Yankees Have an Edge as Season Winds Down
description: The Yankees have been in first place in the American League East for 112 straight days and are tied with the Texas Rangers for the best record in the A.L.

title: Added Security in Libya Was Rejected, G.O.P. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on the House oversight committee on Tuesday accused officials in Washington of turning down repeated requests for increased security in Benghazi, Libya, before the fatal attack on the diplomatic compound there last month.

title: Temporary Voter Relief in Pennsylvania
description: A state judge on Tuesday brought some temporary relief to the democratic process in Pennsylvania, ruling that voters there will be able to cast a ballot for president next month even if they lack an ID card. If the ruling holds up, it will mean the failure, for now, of a Republican effort to disenfranchise minority and low-income voters likely to support President Obama.

title: 17 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Mojo
description: Mojo is my favorite magazine in the world. It has a Web site, but most of its content is available only in its glorious, sumptuous print edition. The November issue cost me $10.99 at a West Village newsstand, and it was worth every penny. Heres what I learned:

title: Photos of The Moment | Valentino
