Was that James just now, one of the subjects  a perpetrator  who participated in the making of this book, a documentary project on child sexual abuse?

title: Why Wont You Tell Us What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Update: Oct. 15, 2012: Thank you to those who wrote in praising our blog in general: believe us, we loved those comments. But we noticed that, even with our plea, very few posted answers to the question, What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?, so weve decided to keep it as a question just for our Summer Reading Contest. We hope youll participate next summer. For now, youll find a fresh Student Opinion question every Monday through Friday. Thank you!

title: What Words or Phrases Do You Think Are Overused?
description: The Times TV critic Neil Genzlinger is disgusted that a snarky use of the one-word response Really? is popping up everywhere on television these days. Because TV influences how we speak, he notes that that same use of Really? is spreading to everyday life. Have you noticed this?

title: New Yorker, Fired by Hotel in Israel, Kills Co-Worker
description: JERUSALEM  A New York man who was fired from a hotel in the Israeli resort city of Eilat on Thursday returned there on Friday morning and opened fire amid a crowd of tourists, then killed a kitchen worker before being shot to death by police officers, the authorities said.

title: British Judges Approve Extradition of Muslim Cleric to U.S. on Terrorism Charges
description: LONDON  Five terrorism suspects, including the fiery Islamic preacher Abu Hamza al-Masri, were sent to the United States on Friday night to face an array of terrorism charges. Their extradition came after a British court ruled they had exhausted their final appeal, ending years of legal battles that tested the balance between civil liberties and national security.

title: Britains Gap Trap
description: And now for something completely different  actually just a quick note. The always interesting Izabella Kaminska points us to a study suggesting that Britains output gap  the difference between real GDP and the economys capacity  is much bigger than the official estimates. This is actually a theme Ive heard from a number of people.

title: In the Eyes of the Beholden
description: MADRID  Last week, through the paper-thin walls of my apartment, I overheard my neighbor, a septuagenarian retiree, shouting on the telephone while she was cooking dinner.

title: In New York, Ford Holds Forth on Cars and Architecture
description: The Ford Fusion has become a Manhattan habitu of late. There it was in Chelsea in August, rubbing elbows with the art gallery set. It kept company with Ryan Seacrest and Alan R. Mulally, the Ford chief executive, in Times Square last month. And on Wednesday, a cool green Fusion Hybrid was deployed to Greenwich Village, where it preened in front of the Center for Architecture.

title: Wagering on Waves
description: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes.

title: 36 Hours in Gothenburg, Sweden
description: THE industrial port city of Gothenburg, on Swedens west coast, has little of the glamour that graces the countrys capital, Stockholm. But this once resolutely working-class city is nevertheless making a name for itself as a new hive of the creative arts, with its homegrown fashion labels and upstart indie bands, its rollicking craft beer bars and alternative arts scene. Gothenburg (Goteborg in Swedish) is also the fitting host to Scandinavias leading film festival and hugely popular music festivals, including Summerburst and Way Out West. These days, the cool cultural revival happening in Swedens second-largest city appears well under way.

title: Going to Gothenburg, Sweden
description: In this port city, see a restaurant affiliated with a star chef and a bar that urges drinkers to stay away from the dishwater.

title: Oct. 4: Too Soon to Gauge Impact of Debate on Polls
description: This might be bad for business  but you probably ought not to pay too much attention to the numbers you see in the right-hand column of this blog over the next day or two.

title: Your Suggestions for Renaming the Hitler Store in Gujarat
description: Last month, India Ink called for suggestions for new names for Hitler, a clothing store in Ahmedabad, Gujarat. Our readers sent in dozens of ideas, ranging from serious to funny.

description: A look at Senate candidates who are aggressively calling out their Republican rivals for skepticism about climate change. [Climate Progress]

description: Q.

title: The Makeunder | John Derian
Fears Persist Among Venezuelan Voters Ahead of Election
description: CUMAN, Venezuela  Hugo Chvez, a polarizing president who has led Venezuela for nearly 14 years, has many advantages over the opposition candidate trying to unseat him on Sunday, from the airwaves he controls to the government largess he doles out with abandon. But one especially potent weapon in Mr. Chvezs arsenal is what might be called the fear factor.

description: Falcons (4-0) at Redskins (2-2) Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Falcons by 3

description: Dear Diary:

title: The I.P.O. Blues
description: The I.P.O. Blues | The market was not kind to young companies trying to go public this week. The latest casualty came on Thursday, when Dave & Busters Entertainment, the restaurant-and-arcade chain, withdrew plans for an I.P.O. The chief executive, Steve King, cited the usual reasons: current market conditions are not optimal.

title: Drop in Jobless Figure Gives Jolt to Race for President
description: The jobless rate abruptly dropped in September to its lowest level since the month President Obama took office, indicating a steadier recovery than previously thought and delivering another jolt to the presidential campaign.

title: What I Thought of Rahul Gandhis Visit to Kashmir
description: I saw Rahul Gandhi in an earlier televised speech, during which he said that he wants to hear the deep voices of Kashmiri youth and wants to solve their problems. I was a bit interested. I wanted to tell him what my heart says.

title: Daily Report: Google Deal Gives Publishers a Choice to Digitize or Not
description: After seven years of litigation, Google and book publishers said on Thursday that they had reached a settlement to allow publishers to choose whether Google digitizes their books and journals, reports Claire Cain Miller in Fridays New York Times.It was a small step forward for Googles plan to digitize every book and make them readable and searchable online, known as the Google Library Project, but it did not resolve the much bigger issue standing in Googles way  litigation between Google and authors.

title: One Report, Diverging Perspectives
description: Fridays jobs report is the second-to-last of the presidential campaign.

title: It Was 50 Years Ago Today: Bond and the Beatles
description: LONDON  Friday is Global James Bond Day, marking the 50th anniversary of the date when Britains most celebrated superspy first made it to the screen.

title: Good Enough to Eat
description: In the last decade or so, Dutch designers became famous for their bold reimaginings and remixings of traditional porcelain decoration. This year, the Amsterdam-based husband-and-wife team of Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings took that much-copied idea in a more abstract  and strikingly beautiful  direction. Scholten and Baijingss Colour Porcelain dinnerware collection was commissioned by 1616/Arita Japan, a new brand named for the town on the Southern Japanese island of Kyushu that has produced hand-painted porcelain from a stone-based grayish-white clay since the 17th century. Under the creative direction of the up-and-coming young designer Teruhiro Yanagihara, 1616/Arita is putting a contemporary spin on that history. Scholten and Baijings looked at traditional Arita porcelain decoration, deconstructing it into a palette that was surprisingly like their own, which favors tones like aquarelle blue, red-orange and yellow. But instead of applying color just for, say, flowers or figures, they colored entire plates. The way we used it, said Baijings of the palette, it became a lot of color. Its us, but its also Japanese. The collection is based on three degrees of complexity: the monochromatic Minimal; Colourful, with two or three colors; and Extraordinary, with applied grids, lines and layered colors. These variations make stacking the plates a visual treat. The entire set is also available in plain white, for purists. But those who arent afraid of a little color will want to go for the rainbow. From about $22 (for a small white plate) to $675 (for a platter with a grid pattern). Available from Thomas Eyck at thomaseyck.com.

title: What I Thought Of Rahul Gandhis Visit to Kashmir
description: Everybody in the Kashmir University auditorium was excited, as I was, to interact with Rahul Gandhi and other business tycoons accompanying him on Friday.

title: From Jack Welch, a Conspiracy Theory
description: 9:50 a.m. | Updated

title: Okinawa Military Base
description: Editorial cartoonist Heng on the Okinawa military base.

title: Friday Reading: Letting Patients Read the Doctors Notes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Breakfast Meeting: A New Bin Laden Film in the Election Cycle, and Google Settles With Publishers
description: Osama bin Laden has moved back into the election cycle. Brian Stelter reports in The Times that a film about the raid that killed bin Laden will be shown by the National Geographic Channel on Nov. 4, two days before the presidential election. Netflix will stream the film a day later. The development seems sure to revive the controversy over whether a dramatization of the 2011 raid so close to the voting could help President Obamas re-election chances. The raid is considered one of his signature achievements.

title: After Huge Trading Loss, JPMorgan Continues to Revamp
description: 3:00 p.m. | Updated Two senior executives at JPMorgan Chase are expected to leave by the end of the year, in the latest round of management reshuffling after the banks multibillion-dollar trading loss.

title: What Were Reading
description: Newsweek: Reindeer lichen, black grouse, lingonberries, juniper branches, trout roe, dried pigs blood  these are a few of Magnus Nilssons favorite things at his Fviken restaurant in Sweden. Hes doing a United States tour for his new cookbook (yes, Fviken  from Phaidon Press) based on the woodsy foraging of a hunter/chef. Can you say mosquito bites?  Glenn Collins

title: Coming Together (Not Apart) in a Tuscan Village
description: PANZANO IN CHIANTI, Italy  In his recent book, Coming Apart, the American conservative scholar Charles Murray advocates that the best and brightest, who tend to cleave together into geographic clusters in the United States, spread out and serve as the pillars of far-flung communities.

title: Oct. 7  13
description: HIM, a new play by DAISY FOOTE that opens Tuesday at the 59E59 Theaters, is a drama set in small-town New Hampshire about two siblings trying to keep the family business going. The subject seems unusually apt, since Ms. Foote is the daughter of the great playwright Horton Foote, who died in 2009, and one of the stars of Him is Daisys sister Hallie Foote. The family business for the Foote family was the theater, and Hallie and Daisy Foote are doing their part to help keep it a going concern.

title: The Swan Song of Pina Bausch
description: THE unending search for love, movement as a weapon, wonder, love of the earth, yearning, grief. These are some of the words and phrases that Pina Bausch told her dancers as they rehearsed a new work in the first six months of 2009.

title: Jobs Report Brings Unexpected Good News for Obama
description: 11:56 a.m. | Updated After a lackluster debate, President Obama faced the prospect of a second piece of bad political news with Friday mornings jobs report. Instead, Mr. Obama  and the economy  received some unexpected good news.

title: Where the Magic Lurks
description: WHEN Netia Jones was about 10 and growing up in England, she saw her first opera. It was Benjamin Brittens Peter Grimes, and it changed her life.

title: Wages, Prices, Depressions, Deficits (Wonkish)
description: I mentioned the piece by Capital Economics arguing that policy makers in Britain are greatly understating the output gap, the amount of excess capacity in the economy, which is leading to badly skewed policies. This actually raises a whole set of related issues, with bearing on the US as well. So heres a longish, wonkish discussion.

title: Trouble Ahead
description: Twenty years ago, Irvine Welsh roared onto the British literary scene with Trainspotting, a first novel that traced the exuberant depravities of Scottish drug fiends. What marked the book as original wasnt its subject  artists have been mining the manic energies of addiction since well before the age of Hogarth  but the unlikely poetry of its language, a droll brogue Welsh transcribed in precise phonetics. A few years later, the filmmaker Danny Boyle adapted the book for the screen, and a franchise was born.

title: The Hunters and the Hunted
description: America never got over the 60s. The deep social divisions that emerged during that decade remain, for the most part, the divisions that define modern American politics. The battle lines are still so painfully visible that 50 years after the beginning of the Vietnam War and the Free Speech Movement at the University of California, Berkeley, the presidential race this year will come down to a contest between a former community organizer pilloried for supposed ties to 60s radicals and a former Stanford student who protested against campus antiwar demonstrations.

title: Shes a Graduate of an Unusual Film School
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Rendering and Remembering
description: It had become a preoccupation of his  almost an obsession  working out how the war had changed him; other people, too, of course. The war is World War I and he is Paul Tarrant, a character in Pat Barkers new novel, Tobys Room. But the obsession belongs equally to Barker, who has pursued it through a remarkable series of novels: the much-admired Regeneration trilogy (Regeneration, The Eye in the Door and The Ghost Road), Life Class and now Tobys Room.

title: The Secret Gardener
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Small-Business Issue the Candidates Are Not Talking About
description: This weeks presidential debate disappointed me. We heard a lot of references to small businesses, regulatory relief, health care, deficits and especially tax rates. But neither candidate thought to mention one critical ingredient to economic growth: capital. If small-business owners and entrepreneurs cant get their hands on capital at affordable prices, their tax rates wont matter because they wont be able to produce any profits  or jobs.

title: After Small Sales Decline This Season, High Prices for Yankees Playoff Tickets
description: The Mets may have lost five out of six games to the Yankees this year, but they did beat their crosstown rivals in one perverse way: They endured a smaller decline at the turnstiles. The Mets sold 109,793 fewer tickets this year at Citi Field, while the Yankees saw a decline of 111,274.

title: Power Shifts
description: Those who forget geography can never defeat it. That is the mantra of Robert D. Kaplans new book, The Revenge of Geography: What the Map Tells Us About Coming Conflicts and the Battle Against Fate.Each chapter begins with a reading of the lineaments of territory in the way a fortuneteller reads the lines on a palm, a mapping of mountains, rivers and plains as determinants of destiny. But just as the text starts to teeter under the weight of geographical determinism, Kaplan quickly shifts ground, arguing for the partial determinism we all need (italics in the original). He retreats to the far more moderate view that geography is an indispensable backdrop to the human drama of ideas, will and chance.

title: Father and Son
description: The couch where my father died was also the couch where he taught me to read, Marco Roth writes in The Scientists. I might as well start there: my alphas and his omega joined by a piece of furniture. The 12-foot-tall bookcases that loomed large in the Roth familys Central Park West apartment posed a silent challenge to an only child eager to please his father, a hematologist with pitilessly highbrow cultural and intellectual standards. Eugene Roth Jr. was a difficult man: cold, withholding, judgmental, prone to rages. But he was also a generous tutor and giver of books, pressing Turgenev, Goncharov, Mann and others into his sons hands. For the younger Roth, a founder of the literary journal n+1, revisiting these books became a way of decoding the troubling mysteries surrounding his fathers life and death, and provides one of the focal points for this affecting memoir.

title: Consider the Writer
description: It is highly likely that while reading Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story, D. T. Maxs biography of David Foster Wallace, you will experience both of the following elbow-y, oxygen-consuming thoughts, or perhaps we should call them emotions.

title: True Grit
description: In 2001 the novelist Charles Portis sat for a rare interview. A modest fellow who normally declines to talk to reporters about himself or his writing, he made an exception for an oral history project about The Arkansas Gazette, a newspaper for which he worked after he had served as a Marine during the Korean War and before he went off to New York to make his fortune. The interview, in which Portis ranges with his usual charm and trenchancy over the six years he spent in the newspaper business before turning to fiction, is included as an epilogue in Escape Velocity, a collection of his reporting, essays, short stories and drama. At the end, the interviewer asks if Portis has anything else to say. No, Portis answers, that pretty well does it.

title: A Lift for the Worst Off
description: The American economy may be starting to help some of those who need it the most.

title: Portrait of Detective in Shooting: Hero, but Subject of Suits
description: The New York City police detective who killed an unarmed driver who twice cut off two police trucks on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens early Thursday has been hailed for bravery on the job, but also named in two lawsuits claiming police abuse.

title: Inside the List
description: THE FORECASTER: Statisticians dont tend to have large popular followings. But the numbers cruncher Nate Silver, whose political blog FiveThirtyEight runs on NYTimes.com, is an exception. His detailed Moneyball analyses of poll results routinely draw hundreds of comments, and in 2009  five months after he correctly predicted the outcome of the presidential race in 49 of the 50 states (and nailed every Senate race)  Time magazine named him one of the worlds 100 most influential people. He was 31 years old.

title: Defending Tagore
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A Building Code With Room for Innovation
description: Jeff Whitney, the head building inspector in Grand County, Utah came by the straw bale construction site in Moab where my wife and I are volunteering. He needed to inspect the flashing and some other details before we applied our first coat of plaster to the exposed bales.

title: In N.H.L., the Damage Begins
description: We interrupt your enjoyment of the best part of the baseball season to remind you that the N.H.L. has locked out its players. Again. We feel the need to remind you of this because, although the league canceled the first two weeks of its season Thursday, the news was greeted in the greater sports universe with a collective shrug. O.K., a few people sighed. There were some rolled eyes. But it was quickly forgotten amid the discussion of whether the Braves Kris Medlen could continue his incredible streak, or whether calling the Rangers choking dogs was an insult to choking dogs.

title: Dreams of Utopia, Dreams of Solitude
description: EVERYWHERE new utopias are possible, a narrator declares in the short film Slow Action by the British artist Ben Rivers. Many of Mr. Riverss movies, which combine elements of portraiture, landscape film, ethnography and travelogue while largely ignoring the rules of each genre, are about people who put that statement to the test.

title: Political Fight Over Jobs Numbers Begins Anew
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  The monthly ritual of plumbing the employment report for political advantage began anew on Friday, with Mitt Romney and other Republicans lamenting what one leader called the new normal of high unemployment while the White House said the lower jobless rate was proof that its policies were working.

title: Common Core Practice | Floating Buddhas, MacArthur Geniuses and Fracking
description: Welcome to our third week of Common Core practice prompts, each classroom-created and tested by our teacher-collaborators, Jonathan Olsen and Sarah Gross, and the ninth grade humanities class they team teach.

title: One Fish, Two Fish, Dead Fish, New Fish
description: Alaskas yearly show of millions of sockeye salmon returning to spawn and die.

title: One Fish, Two Fish, Dead Fish, New Fish
description: One of the most breathtaking shows in Alaska opens every summer and extends into fall, when millions of sockeye salmon (known locally as reds) return from their saltwater habitat to spawn and die in rivers with names like Kvichak, Ugashik and Nushagak. Tourists gather to watch; bears, ignoring them, eat their fill. The Bristol Bay region is the largest sockeye spawning ground in the world, and the fish is the states most commercially important salmon species: last years catch was worth $296 million. When the fish first come in, theres an electricity in the air  you can see all the classic things youve heard about salmon, like their leaping up waterfalls, says Robert Begich, a biologist with the Alaska Department of Fish and Game. And you can catch some yourself.

title: Who Made That Escape Key?
description: Its the Hey, you! Listen to me key, says Jack Dennerlein of the Harvard School of Public Health. According to Dennerlein, an expert on how humans interact with computers, the escape key helped drive the computer revolution of the 1970s and 80s. It says to the computer: Stop what youre doing. I need to take control.  In other words, it reminds the machine that it has a human master. If the astronauts in 2001: A Space Odyssey had an ESC key, Dennerlein points out, they could have stopped the rogue computer Hal in an instant.

title: The Revenge of Alfred Hitchcocks Muse
description: The new HBO movie The Girl depicts your relationship with Alfred Hitchcock, who, after giving you your first movie role in The Birds, plants an unwanted kiss on you, tries to blackmail you for sex and stalks you. Why would he do these things?  He was a misogynist. That man was physically so unattractive. I think to have a mind that thought of himself as an attractive, romantic man and then to wake up in the morning and look at that face and that body was tough. I think he had a whole lot of problems.

title: Profiles in Commuting
description: Im a white male. When I take the Long Island Rail Road, I prefer the aisle seat or window seat  few take the center seat by choice. When only center seats are left on a crowded train, I try to pick a seat where one of the other passengers is black. Why? Because, whether I am traveling to or from the city, the train generally stops at Jamaica Station  and there is a better chance my seatmate will get off there, and I can slide into one of my preferred seats. Am I guilty of racial profiling? Well, yes  in the literal sense I am. But is there anything unethical about it? Its not for some nefarious purpose  if I disliked black people, I would probably not choose to sit with them. JEFF, JERICHO, N.Y.

title: My Stepfather Steps Up
description: Daddys not here too much anymore. Moms dating. Shes dating ministers. Shes dating rabbis. Shes dating Bob Hirschfield (great guy). Shes dating Louis Begley (sweet guy). She has made me man of the house, and I have my eye out for whos going to cut the mustard and pay the bills.

title: Remixing Philip Glass
description: Anticipating his 75th birthday, Philip Glass approached Beck about finding artists interested in reinventing pieces from the Glass catalog. Rework: Philip Glass Remixed features tracks by Amon Tobin, Tyondai Braxton, Beck and others. Glass and Beck met up recently at the Los Angeles home of Elyse and Stanley Grinstein, art collectors and philanthropists who befriended Glass decades ago.

title: The One-Page Magazine
description: THE BIG PROFILE: SARAH WAYNE CALLIES

title: Wheels Calendar for Oct. 5-7
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Shopping List: Tuna, Detergent, a Warhol
description: Along with the bales of toilet paper and drums of tomato sauce that Costco customers load into their online shopping carts, they can now add an original Warhol or Matisse, a result of this giant discount retailers recent decision to re-enter the fine-art market.

title: Cant Get Tickets? Watch Jay-Z Concert Online
description: If you have missed all of Jay-Zs sold-out concerts at Barclays Center, worry not. The rapper plans to stream his last performance at the new Brooklyn arena online, making the show the official start of his new YouTube channel, The Associated Press reported.

title: Game Times Are Set for First Two Yankees Games
description: The Yankees do not know whom they will be playing on Sunday night, but they at least know now when they will be playing.

title: Should Studies Trump a Teenagers Part-Time Job?
description: This weeks quandary, as it happens, dovetails nicely into last weeks. Deciding what an allowance is for is one part of teaching money management. Teaching children what its like to work for their money is another. Recently, L. wrote asking how to handle the quandary of her daughters part-time job:

title: Examining Job Growth
description: Business Day Live, October 5th, 2012: Economist Michelle Girard on why the jobless rate fell to 7.8 percent. | Start-ups get leaner and meaner  and create fewer jobs.

title: Business Day Live: Jobless Rate Falls to 7.8%, Lowest Since January 2009
description: The economist Michelle Girard on why the jobless rate fell to 7.8 percent. | Start-ups get leaner and meaner  and create fewer jobs.

title: In Armenia, Art in the Shadow of Ararat
description: THE show was about to begin at a Soviet-era playhouse with olive-green seats, antique Caucasian rugs and a tiled ceiling, in Yerevan, the Armenian capital. I was with a man almost 50 years my senior who, while giving me a tour of an experimental art center in a former disco that morning, had asked if I would join him at the State Theater of the Young Spectator that night.

title: Scenes From Yerevan, Armenia
description: A look inside the capital of a country thats barely on the radar of tourists.

title: In Kashmir, Rahul Gandhi Talks Business, But Disappoints Students
description: Rifat Mohidin, a journalism student, was disappointed after her first interaction with Rahul Gandhi, Congress Partys general secretary, at Kashmir University on Friday. Ms. Mohidin, 19, wanted to ask Mr. Gandhi about providing security to Kashmiris when they traveled to other parts of India.

title: Channel Surfing:  30 Rock Skewers Its Favorite Target, NBC
description: This season, the critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger are checking out favorite shows and seeing how they hold up. Previous entries in this series include posts on New Girl, NCIS, Scandal and The Good Wife.

title: Paperback Row
description: LIFE ITSELF: A Memoir,  by Roger Ebert. (Grand Central, $15.99.) In this kaleidoscopic personal history, Ebert, the Pulitzer Prize-winning film critic for The Chicago Sun-Times  and for 23 years the dueling co-host of Siskel & Ebert  ambles through his working-class childhood in Illinois; his early days in Chicagos hard-boiled newspaper world; memorable encounters with actors and directors; and his devastating battle with cancer.

title: Decisive Game 1s Could Add to the Drama
description: The new wild-card format, with two teams from each league playing single games to determine which one advances, means that on the first day of the 2012 postseason we will have two elimination games. Over the years, deciding games have produced some of baseballs finest moments, some so famous that they require no introduction or explanation. You just need to see a certain pitcher on the mound or a certain runner on base and you know what is about to happen.

title: Editors Choice
description: I AM THE CHANGE: Barack Obama and the Crisis of Liberalism,  by Charles R. Kesler. (Broadside/HarperCollins, $25.95.) Kesler sees President Obama as an embodiment of the visionary prophet-statesman of the Progressives, bent on our Swedenization.

title: Up Front
description: The author and journalist Matt Taibbi has written about corruption in some of the worlds most powerful and secretive institutions. He knows something about Seth Rosenfelds struggles. The author of Subversives, which Taibbi reviews this week, sued the F.B.I. four times over 30 years to obtain records under the Freedom of Information Act. The F.B.I. spent close to a million dollars opposing him but eventually released 300,000 pages.

title: Personal Days
description: Reading Office Girl, Joe Menos quasi-experimental novel about former art-school students in late-90s Chicago, I honestly couldnt tell if the author intended for us to cheer for or laugh knowingly at the lead character  a beautiful, alienated waif named Odile, who likes to deface advertisements with doodles of hairy genitals. On the one hand, the novel, Menos sixth, reads as a parody of self-obsessed art-school types, complete with Serge Gainsbourg posters, self-cut bangs and Velvet Underground records. On the other, it reads as a tribute to their devil-may-care spirit. The books alternate titles, Bohemians and Young People on Bicycles Doing Troubling Things, only add to the confusion, insofar as both seem to wink at the reader.

title: Halcyon Years
description: At last, the story can be told: of the love of a man for a woman so strong that it can leap class barriers and religious taboos; of a talented ingnues struggle to flout corrupt critics and float to Broadway stardom; of the valiant actions of a band of brothers fighting the Hun in occupied France; and of the moral courage of regular guys in peacetime, driven by their yearning for justice, law and order to stand up against New Yorks brutish Mafia. Their attack comes with the blessing (and, more usefully, the munitions) of a quirky retired millionaire whos devoting his golden years to founding the C.I.A. Its incredible that this story  or, to be more precise, these stories  hasnt been told before. Except that, of course, it has, and they have . . . though never before in more than 700 consecutive pages, between the covers of one book.

title: More Notes on Camp
description: Gay men and lesbians are now integrated into mainstream culture to a degree that would once have seemed unimaginable. Television sitcoms feature gay dads proving they can be just as cloying as their heterosexual counterparts. J. C. Penney, a department store not known for outr fashion or radical politics, hired Ellen DeGeneres, an open lesbian, as its spokeswoman and included a page in its Mothers Day catalog featuring lesbian moms.

title: Straight Out of Brooklyn
description: Barbra Streisands story may be the most triumphant case of revenge in show business history. In the wake of the white-bread, conformist 1950s, Streisand was the ridiculed young misfit whose every move shrieked defiance. Singing in nightclubs and on television, she faced down audiences with her crossed eyes, beaklike nose and thrift-store costumes. Her voice  big, nasal, braying and edged with her native Brooklynese  was seldom pretty, but it was unmistakably hers, and it riveted the ear with its reckless intensity. Torch songs like Cry Me a River and When the Sun Comes Out became roller coasters of psychodrama, yet she never played the victim; one felt her ferociousness every time she lurched for a high note, then seized it as though she had scaled the Matterhorn. To her fellow outcasts, from unattractive girls to gay men, Streisand, at 21, was a symbol of victory.

title: Fear Factor
description: This book is misleadingly titled. 500 Days: Secrets and Lies in the Terror Wars seeks to provide a global account of the period after 9/11, leaping from a prison cell in Syria to the nightclub bombing in Bali, but its best and most informative when depicting how the Bush administration, and especially its lawyers, suffered a protracted nervous breakdown during that time. In that respect, it is an ambitious undertaking and a valuable resource.

title: Doomed to Repeat It
description: The giddy modern brides and grooms who exchange vows in magnificent antebellum mansions may fancy themselves Southern gentry coming home to reclaim their lost birthright  but theres a good chance some of the guests will feel like field slaves trespassing on forbidden ground. Thats the eerie sense of dislocation Attica Locke effortlessly captures in her second novel, THE CUTTING SEASON (Dennis Lehane/HarperCollins, $25.99), which is set in the present day at Belle Vie, a restored plantation on the Mississippi River.

title: Leather Chairs With a Rock Pedigree
description: Jordan Betten, founder of the leather company Lost Art, has cranked up the volume in five new chairs he designed for McGuire.

title: A Star Is Made
description: If Emma Straub were pitching her book to Hollywood, shed have a ready-made, if optimistic, log line:  The Last Tycoon meets A Star Is Born.  Both Fitzgeralds unfinished novel about Hollywoods Golden Age and the film with Judy Garland as an ingnue transformed for the screen cast overwhelming shadows over Laura Lamonts Life in Pictures, Straubs carefully observed first novel about fame, family drama and personal identity.

title: Running the Asylum
description: Victor LaValles publishers have made the curious decision to market his third novel, The Devil in Silver, as a horror thriller. But it doesnt really fit either part of that label; it isnt much interested in making your pulse race, and it wont scare the pants off anyone. Its simply too bighearted, too gentle, too kind, too culturally observant and too idiosyncratic to squash into the small cupboard of any one genre, or even two.

title: Gandhi Family Member Accused of Illegal Land Deals
description: Anti-corruption activists on Friday accused Robert Vadra, the son-in-law of the Congress Party president Sonia Gandhi, of being involved in illegal land deals with a major real estate company.

For Northwestern Running Back Mark, No Shortage of Motivation
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Venric Mark is too small to be a college football running back.

description: If youve served in the military but have dreams of one day earning your college degree, weve gathered some admissions intel that may prove helpful to you.

title: Seeking the Right to Be Female in Malaysia
description: SEREMBAN, Malaysia  The feminine figure dressed in jeans and a T-shirt, makeup carefully applied, drew little attention from other customers at the fast-food restaurant in Seremban, a city about an hours drive south of Kuala Lumpur.

description: This week, Kevin Powers discusses his novel The Yellow Birds; Matt Taibbi talks about Seth Rosenfelds Subversives; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Parul Sehgal is the host.

title: Experts Advice to the Goal- Oriented: Dont Overdo It
description: IVE never liked the idea of a bucket list  that increasingly popular concept that we should tally up all the things we want to do before we die and, well, do them.

title: New Zealands Hobbit Trail
description: THE hill is perfect  steep, shaggy and as green as a radioactive shamrock, like the matching hills around it. The sheep seem pretty idyllic themselves: polite little nibblers who only sometimes block the road.

title: Planning for Retirement? Dont Forget Health Care Costs
description: ITS not news that health care costs are increasing. Yet several recent studies show that few people factor those rising costs into their retirement plans.

title: Tolkien Tourism
description: Hop from Hobbiton to Wellington to see what a Hobbit-themed trip to New Zealand reveals.

title: Adele Releases New Bond Theme Song
description: Early on Friday morning, Adele released Skyfall, the haunting theme song she co-wrote and sang for the new James Bond movie of the same name, and within hours it was in the Top 3 on the iTunes singles chart, rivaling Taylor Swifts Red and PSYs K-pop hit Gangnam Style.

title: Cash Flows Are Critical for Tesla
description: In his debate on Wednesday night with President Obama, Mitt Romney referred to the electric-car maker Tesla Motors as a loser. He put it in the same group as Solyndra, the solar panel company that collapsed last year owing the federal government $535 million.

title: Pyramids by the Nile. Egypt? No, Sudan.
description: HOW much for your fastest camel? I asked the tall man with the large turban and the drooping mustache.

title: In Singapore, a Stylish Update
description: ALONG narrow Yong Siak Street in Tiong Bahru, one of Singapores oldest residential neighborhoods, two stores jammed side by side say it all. One is an old dusty-looking drinks wholesaler that is crammed with crates of soda and beer. The other is Open Door Policy (19 Yong Siak Street; 65-6221-9307; odpsingapore.com), a new bistro that serves up steak tartare with truffle mayonnaise along with peach Bellinis and affogatos.

title: Hotel Review: The Sultan in Singapore
description: UPSHOT

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Fleeced by Fees? (Sept. 23), thank you for your excellent article on modern-day travel. I travel frequently and am constantly on alert about any service being offered. I might recognize a particular service as having been free in the past, but today? I always check. I too am fed up with fees that have a generic description and are nothing other than a money grab. How can we make our displeasure known? Maybe we travelers should all stay at home for one week as a form of strike against all these fees. As one person I must admit to feeling powerless most of the time when it comes to travel. Not a nice feeling.Gerard A. WardWinnipeg, Manitoba

description: Two of Britains finest exports had their premieres on this day, one musical and one hysterical.

description: Whether you go for biking or kayaking, beer or tea, tiny Tofino delivers.

title: Rise of the Reluctant Part-Timer Class
description: The unemployment rate fell substantially in September, but a large part of that increase appears to reflect people who found part-time work when they really wanted full-time work.

title: Recall of 820,000 Pilots and Civics Caps a Rough Week for Honda
description: In a week that Honda would surely rather forget, the automaker added 820,000 vehicles to a recall that began in March relating to faulty headlight wiring. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has also initiated an investigation of about 577,000 Pilot S.U.V.s and Odyssey minivans after reports that their Park interlocks failed, allowing them to roll away.

description: Tia Fuller

title: Making a Comedy About Friends Making Babies
description: HES gay. Shes straight. Theyre best friends. And theyre having a baby the old-fashioned way. Thats the premise of Gayby (Oct. 12), a comedy that may bear some resemblance to the sitcom Will & Grace, though it places its lead characters in far more intimate situations. But the films writer and director, Jonathan Lisecki, did not look to that NBC series for inspiration.

title: The Heartbeat, and the Twang, of a City
description: NASHVILLE

title: Dick Wolfs Drama: This Is His Story
description: A COUPLE of writers on Law & Order: Special Victims Unit huddled with a casting director. What we need is the girl who looks like the adorable big sister, but then she turns out to be a pedophiles accomplice, an executive producer, Warren Leight, told his team.

description: Why write a dog book?

title: Bront Quiz: Cathy Dies. Then What?
description: The new Wuthering Heights film by the British director Andrea Arnold opens in the United States and Australia in early October, making it the latest in at least 15 adaptations for film or television in the last 80 years. But some scholars feel that the book has been enormously misrepresented, especially since many versions only focus on the first half of the book, which ends with the death of Cathy after confessing her love for Heathcliff.

title: Traveling Because of a Plotline
description: Weve posted an article about how New Zealand, where the Lord of the Rings movies were filmed, has become a destination for vacationers searching for hobbit holes and other vestiges of Middle-earth. description: Goatober is part of the No Goat Left Behind initiative to benefit goat farms in the Northeast. Heritage Foods USA is joining with New York chefs and restaurants to benefit the project. On Friday, Sam Richman of Gran Electrica in Dumbo, Brooklyn, is holding a cooking demo and tasting where he will prepare birria, a Mexican stew, at the Astor Center, 399 Lafayette Street (East Fourth Street), in NoHo, from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. Tickets, available online, are $40 per person.

title: Book Review Podcast: A Soldiers War Novel
description: This week in the New York Times Book Review, Benjamin Percy reviews The Yellow Birds, a novel by Kevin Powers that follows a soldier through his duty in Iraq and his struggles to adjust once back home. Mr. Percy writes:

title: From Union to Freedom
description: On Sept. 22, 1862, Abraham Lincoln promulgated the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, which set the stage to free all slaves in territory controlled by Confederate forces. It changed the nature of the Civil War. But did it, as many say, suddenly turn a war to preserve the Union into a war to create freedom? Answering that question requires an understanding of the Preliminary Proclamation in the context of events that had been developing for many months.

title: Jobs Picture Improves for Boomers
description: The September unemployment figures for baby boomers  the single largest voting group  are the most encouraging in more than three years.

title: Ill Take Manhattans, the Sequel
description: As I explain in my latest Drink column, I may be a stickler where the martini is concerned, but Ive got an open mind (and palate) when it comes to manhattans. I offer two more choices here. One is made with bourbon and is not at all shy with the vermouth. The other is rye-based and considerably drier. One is stirred, the other shaken. Both are delicious.

title: Frenemies: A Love Story
description: Boston

title: Following a Nazi Who Was Following Orders
description: Every week The Shot offers a photo of the people, places or things of our generation. Do you have memories related to this image? Share them with us in the comments.

title: In a Visit to an Exhibit, Recalling a Date With History in 1941
description: The small, old-fashioned radio at the entrance was a time machine for my father, Lester Bernstein, 92, who was getting a preview of the World War II & NYC exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.

title: High Yields Arent So High
description: A record $79 billion in high-yield corporate bonds were sold in the United States in the third quarter, as investors poured money into mutual funds buying those bonds. The flood of money has sent bond prices up, and yields down.

title: New Zealand Prime Minister Makes Sales Pitch to Hollywood
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  There was John Key, the prime minister of New Zealand, looking resolute and serious in a dark suit and tie on Thursday afternoon as he addressed a small group of similarly dark-suited members of the media in front of the Sheraton Universal hotel.

title: The Shadow of Steve Jobs in Apples Maps Push
description: Steven P. Jobs could hardly have hoped for a better legacy than the performance since his death of Apple, the company he co-founded and dominated. Its revenue, profit and share price have hit records. Its the worlds largest company by market capitalization.

description: A significant auction devoted to the promotion of preserved classics was held on Monday at the Simeone Foundation Automotive Museum in Philadelphia.

title: Camera Angling to Reconcile Then and Now
description: AMID the new and old footage, still photos and wobbly recollections that make up Ross McElwees latest film, Photographic Memory, is a scene of his son, Adrian, at the age of 7, baiting a hook and being asked why he likes to fish. The deep surprise of the ocean, he replies sagely, providing a metaphor not only for life, but also for his fathers brand of filmmaking.

title: Whats the Best Climate Question to Debate?
description: A lot of the post-debate buzz about President Obamas soporific performance (as Jon Stewart made clear, it was not the Denver altitude!) may have been rendered moot by todays jobs data. But theres still plenty to discuss.

title: Avon Chairwoman to Quit Earlier Than Expected
description: Andrea Jung, who resigned as chief executive of Avon Products late last year, announced on Friday that she would step down as executive chairwoman at the end of the year, further cutting her ties with a beauty products company for which she long served as its glamorous public face.

title: Wall Street Regulator Ramps Up Enforcement
description: Wall Streets smallest watchdog is starting to show its fangs.

title: Superweeds, Superpests: The Legacy of Pesticides
description: The rapid adoption of a single weed-killer for the vast majority of crops harvested in the United States has given rise to superweeds and greater pesticide use, a new study suggests. And while crops engineered to manufacture an insect-killing toxin have reduced the use of pesticides in those fields, the emergence of newly resistant insects now threatens to reverse that trend.

title: Preserving Classics, Wrinkles and All
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: City Tried to Bill Dead Man for Damage to Police Car That Struck and Killed Him
description: Late last month, Laverne Dobbinson received a letter, addressed to her son, from a law firm notifying him that it had been retained by the City of New York to collect money for damages to a police car.

title: All Hail the Moderate Mitt
description: Ever since Mitt Romneys performance at the presidential debate in Denver on Wednesday night, moderate Republicans have been celebrating the return of the moderate Mitt, who was kept in an undisclosed location during the primaries and long into convention season.

title: A Taste of Fall in a Bottle of Hard Cider
description: A FEW years ago, I spent a month in a tiny village in Normandy. Up the road, past an ancient apple orchard, was a dairy farm run by Monsieur Bernard, a wiry, weathered, hard-working fellow who looked to be in his mid to late 60s.

title: Assuring Care of a Family Member With Special Needs
description: With each passing election season, the conversations about the cost of government-provided health care and Social Security get more urgent.

title: Portraits of a Moderate Economy
description: The mostly upbeat jobs data reported on Friday, as Shaila Dewan writes, follow a string of economic reports that indicate consumers are growing a bit stronger and a bit more willing to spend as the housing market stabilizes and as their investments grow. Businesses, however, express more reluctance to spend and hire as they await election results, contemplate the fiscal cliff and the direction of American tax policy, and see weakness abroad. Several recent interviews help capture some of these views.

title: Romney Says Jobs Numbers Are Not True Sign of Growth
description: ABINGDON, Va.  Mitt Romney sought to play down the latest jobs numbers  a 7.8 percent unemployment rate, the lowest since 2009  at stop in coal country here, telling the crowd that the rate had come down very, very slowly. The improving employment numbers, he said, were the result of people dropping out of the work force and not a true sign of job growth.

title: Preview: Red Bulls vs. Chicago
description: The Red Bulls might or might not clinch a playoff berth on Saturday.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Green Lantern Corps Tops the List
description: Three new books are at the top of the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week. They are from DC Comics, but thats about all they have in common. Green Lantern Corps, Volume 1, at No. 1, is part of the companys New 52 initiative, which last year reintroduced its characters as if for the first time. Some heroes, like Firestorm, were totally remade; some were significantly adjusted (Batgirl can walk again!); and others continued pretty much as they had been. Green Lantern Corps is largely in that last category: it was and continues to be a galactic police organization trying to bring justice to every corner of the universe.

title: Books to Teach Children About Alzheimers
description: I stopped at a childrens bookshop in Manhattan last week and asked to see books on Alzheimers disease. The store stocked at least half a dozen, with titles like Whats Wrong with Grandma? and Whats Happening to Grandpa?

title: In N.H.L. Lockout, Echoes of 2004
description: After Thursdays cancellation of the first two weeks of the N.H.L. season, much of the reaction among commentators and locked-out players has focused on the hard line taken in negotiations by Gary Bettman and the owners.

title: Paris Fashion Week Model Diary | Aymeline Valade
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bad Girls Crashing the Manor
description: THERE are three great brands in the British cinema, each associated with a specific product line: Ealing comedies, Hammer horror films and Gainsborough melodramas. The Ealing comedies, like Robert Hamers Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949) and Alexander Mackendricks Man in the White Suit (1951), have long been critical and popular favorites on both sides of the Atlantic. The Hammer horrors, with their juiced-up, living-color reinterpretations of classic horror themes in films like Terence Fishers Curse of Frankenstein (1957) and Freddie Franciss Dracula Has Risen From the Grave (1968), were resisted by the cultural gatekeepers but have since found legions of fans worldwide.

title: New Yorkers, Its Tree Planting Season
description: The Bloomberg administrations initiative to plant one million new trees in New York City is past the halfway mark but still has a long way to go. To broaden a canopy that beautifies the city while also filtering pollution and reducing stormwater runoff, the New York Restoration Project has scheduled tree giveaways in all five boroughs in October and November.

title: The Best Financial Move You Made for Your Special Needs Relative
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I turned to financial advisers and lawyers who were themselves parents to or siblings of people with special needs and asked them to offer basic advice for families who are getting started with their own financial planning in this area.

title: Patrick Abner and Thomas Roberts
description: EVEN news anchors with matinee-idol looks can get a case of the jitters.

title: A New Twist to N.F.L. Breast Cancer Awareness: A Pink Tutu
description: By this point, most football fans have probably noticed the N.F.L.s pink theme  including everything from socks to towels to the referees whistle  that is in place as part of Octobers National Breast Cancer Awareness month.

title: Illusion Meets Inspiration
description: FASHION shows exist for several reasons: to convey a mood or image; to entertain people; to bring an end to a creative journey so a designer, like the Greek with his rock, can do it all again in six months. But after a long season, youre conscious of how much beautiful work is lost in the blur of images or never has a chance to be seen by a wider audience.

title: As Its Economy Sags, India Asks a Critic to Come Home and Help Out
description: NEW DELHI  In April, the economist Raghuram G. Rajan gave a speech to a group of graduating Indian students in which he criticized the countrys policy makers for repeating failed experiment after failed experiment, rather than learning from the experiences of other countries. A week later, he assailed the government again, this time in a speech attended by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh.

title: Its Snowing in Minnesota! Yes, October Is Early for That
description: Early Friday morning, the temperature in Houston was gradually cooling from a high of 88 degrees, part of a Texas summer that just will not quit. Meanwhile, more than 1,000 miles to the north in Minnesota, a different kind of cooling was taking place: More than a foot of snow was coming down.

title: Trial by Rental
description: JUDITH AND SCOTT FROST lived with their two young daughters in an apartment on West 86th Street, its 1,100 square feet festooned with decorative molding and topped by high ceilings. Mr. Frost works in finance, and Ms. Frost runs an Upper West Side organization called Little Global Village where small children can learn a foreign language. Both loved the pace of urban life. But as with many families, the prospect of an additional child altered the picture.

title: Friday Night Music: The Glamorous Life
description: Hey, its night where I am, which is sort of the point of this video  its pack up the suitcase, la la la time. (Glamorous Life starts around 4:00).

title: Commission on Presidential Debates Defends Jim Lehrer
description: Just about everyone has weighed in against Jim Lehrers performance as presidential debate moderator on Wednesday night  Democrats, political commentators, and even on Thursday night, Jimmy Fallon.

title: Trouble in Talks to Merge EADS and BAE Systems
description: PARIS  Britain, France and Germany failed on Friday to reach an agreement on the proposed $45 billion merger of the European aerospace groups EADS and BAE Systems, people close to the negotiations said.

title: Taming Volatile Raw Data for Jobs Reports
description: 7:32 p.m. | Updated The unemployment rate fell to 7.8 percent in September, its lowest level since President Obama took office. With just a month to go before the election, the news seemed too good to be true, at least for some Mitt Romney supporters.

title: Wheelies: The Remapped Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Sharp but Cowardly Tongue
description: My hair is always an issue; its quite unruly. So I frequently change styles and colors. Recently, my mother-in-law said: Your hair looks good. Do you like it? I told her I did. To which, she replied: I was just wondering, because when we were looking at pictures from Pennys party, she said you look like a witch with your hair straightened. I confronted Penny immediately. She apologized for about 30 minutes. Another sister-in-law told me her mothers comment hadnt come out right. But my mother-in-law never apologized. How would you have handled this?

title: G.M.A.s Sam Champion to Wed Rubem Robierb
description: Sam Champion, the weather anchor of ABCs Good Morning America, said Friday that he planned to marry his fianc, Rubem Robierb, at the end of the year.

title: Nokias New Lumia Is an AT&T Exclusive Again
description: Nokias new flagship smartphone, the Lumia 920, will go on the market next month, and in the United States it will be available onlyon AT&T.

title: Co-op vs. Condo: The Differences Are Narrowing
description: MOST people looking to buy an apartment in New York City know the basic trade-offs between a co-op and a condominium: the approval process and building rules are usually stricter with a co-op, but co-ops make up a much bigger percentage of the citys housing stock, and they tend to be less expensive than condos.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $19.5 Million
description: An enormous duplex at 740 Park Avenue, the epitome of luxury landmark addresses ever since John D. Rockefeller Jr. occupied a 34-room residence there, sold for $19.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: The Caucus Click: A Last-Minute Read
Facebooks 5% Solution in Data Centers
description: Forget the way we live and share on Facebook. The biggest innovation at the social network may be in back-end plumbing and innovative pricing. It is starting to affect the rest of the tech industry.

title: New TV Shows, Old Ratings Woes
description: The arrival of a new crop of fall television shows also inevitably means the early exit for a select few that fail to find audiences. A perusal of the Nielsen ratings for the past week suggests that each major network already has a candidate for possible cancellation.

title: High Volume | Nick Cave
description: Nick Cave is into fabulous. Take the black marks that scar the floor of his 3,500-square-foot loft in Chicago. Fabulous, he says. Or the haunting portrait by the English artist John Kirby that Cave found at an art fair. Isnt it fabulous? So is the porcupine-needle vestment from Cameroon that serves as a dividing screen in Caves living room, and the framed quilt backed with love letters in his bedroom, where artworks hung on a yellow wall create so much visual excitement its hard to imagine getting any rest.

title: Week in Review: Private Equity Firms Counting Cash
description: Buyout firms in Europe are hustling for cash. | A cellphone deal is turning up the heat on Sprint. | Campaign ads are focusing on ties to Wall Street, no matter how thin. | Andrew Ross Sorkin said the private equity world had more money than it knew what to do with.

title: Better Performers
description: How three of the stronger performers of the third quarter fared against the overall market  and against their peer groups of funds.

title: A Warm Welcome Back for Hard Cider
description: This weeks City Kitchen column embraces apples, pairing them with pork chops in a cider-enhanced sauce.

title: ESPN3 Will Carry K.H.L. Games
description: Hockey fans will be able to watch big-league action on television after all, only the big league wont be the N.H.L.  itll be the Russian K.H.L.

title: Riviera, a Clean Break for G.M., Is Still Fashionable at 50
description: FIFTY years ago this month, General Motors cast off the overchromed tailfinned excesses of its postwar auto designs and shocked the Paris auto salon by slipping into a clean, crisply tailored new suit. The 1963 Buick Riviera made its world debut, winning rave reviews even from Europeans who had been scornful of Detroits irrational exuberance in the 1950s.

title: A High-Style Buick at a Reasonable Price
description: THE 1963 Buick Riviera made its debut on Oct. 4, 1962, with a price of $4,333. Adjusting for inflation, that would be about $33,000 in 2012 dollars, near the high end of what a collector might pay for one today.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Girl in a Coma Solved
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to try their hand at solving the case of a comatose young woman dropped off at the emergency room by her friends after attending a concert the previous night. More than 350 people wrote in, and more than 90 of you were able to figure it out. The first person to guess the correct diagnosis was Dr. Laura Fochtmann, a psychiatrist and professor at Stony Brook University School of Medicine on Long Island, who in her response carefully spelled out how she got the right answer.

title: Everything You Thought Was Hard Is Easy
description: At the American Enterprise Institute on Tuesday, Justice Antonin Scalia delivered what event organizers described as valuable insights into the interpretive methods by which judges should decide statutory cases and attorneys should argue them.

title: The Getaway: Airport Security
description: A look at two programs designed to accelerate screening at airports.

title: D.C. May Have to Decide Between Pastimes
description: With the Major League Baseball playoffs finally set, Washington could be forced to make a tough choice in 2012, but not the one everyone has been talking about for the past 18 months.

title: Your Favorite Neil Young Song Is . . .
description: The Analytics graphic below will appear on the Reply All page in the magazines Oct. 7 issue.

title: 21, Autistic and Having a Party
description: For his 21st birthday, my son received cards from friends, relatives and a favorite elementary-school teacher, yet few of these well wishes were printed with his age. In searching out my own card for him, I soon learned why. Tag lines that start, So youre 21?  often end with instructions to go out and tie one on; as my son is on the autism spectrum, such advice would have been in dubious taste. Yet as much as I appreciated the senders thoughtfulness, I found myself thinking: another difference. Again.

title: Those Nagging Eternals, Politics and Greed
description: Everybody wants something. If you lose the thread of a conversation in Both Your Houses  and once or twice you will  just remember that statement. Itll keep you on track.

title: Presidents Play the Garden
description: In addition to hosting political conventions, Madison Square Garden has provided a stage for presidential speeches and even birthday celebrations.

title: Helping a Child to Come Out
description: THURSDAY, Oct. 11, is National Coming-Out Day, an annual celebration of living openly for people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.

title: In New Garden Exhibit, Its All About the Presidents
description: New Yorkers might be forgiven for feeling left out of the presidential campaign. With the state considered firmly in President Obamas column, the candidates have spent little time campaigning in the city, other than attending the occasional fund-raiser or making a speech at the United Nations.

title: Relying on Glam Style in a Crowd of Athletes
description: STANDING in his parents driveway in Great Barrington, Mass., my girlfriends cousin, 13, regarded the lustrous gray scarab that appeared before him one morning last summer. What do you think? I asked. With the dispassion of a Westminster Kennel Club judge, he walked from the creatures rear three-quarter aspect to its profile, then around the nose before returning to the three-quarter.

title: Forecasting Unemployment
description: The unemployment rate for September surprised economists by dropping to 7.8 percent  the lowest rate since early 2009  from 8.1 percent. But where will it go in the next month?

title: If Looks Could Thrill
description: While an improvement over the base model, the turbo version of the 2013 Hyundai Veloster still makes promises with its rowdy styling that its performance cant keep.

title: Group Finds More Gay and Lesbian Characters on Television
description: There are more gay and lesbian characters on network television this season than ever before, according to a study released Friday by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, or GLAAD, a group that advocates for diversity in the media.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 5
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Rescued Cake Parfait
description: Dont let a stuck cake defeat you. Turn it into a parfait! Melissa Clark shows how.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 5
description: Subjects include the opening of the Barclays Center, police layoffs in Camden, N.J., and a fatal shooting by a police detective in Queens.

title: Underestimating Health Care Costs in Retirement
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about an often-overlooked expense in retirement: the cost of health care. One study Paul mentions, by Nationwide Financial, found that people near retirement routinely overestimated the percent of health care costs covered by Medicare.

title: No Apologies Necessary When a Dish Goes Awry
description: MANY years ago, I saw a photo of braised Provenal duck in a food magazine. It was stunning, with bronzed pieces of duck nestled in sauce studded with olives and potatoes.

title: T Fall Design 2012 | Editors Letter
description: Whos to say what perfect is? One persons idea of perfection is anothers idea of too much  or not enough. For John Derian, whose decoupaged plates, lamps and paperweights evoke the past in a way thats anything but nostalgic, renovating a former artists studio in the East Village for his new home meant leaving its uneven floors, cloudy windows and imperfect moldings intact, in an effort to preserve the patina of the 19th-century space. For Lynn Yaegers story, T followed the project over six months, photographing the renovation from start to finish. While Derian made significant changes to the interior, the envelope itself looked as if it had hardly been touched. Some might recoil at the apparent decrepitude of the space, but in Derians eyes  and ours  he was preserving its tattered poetry, allowing the ghosts of history a place at his often crowded dinner table. In a similar vein, the multilayered arrangements in the artist Nick Caves Chicago loft, as described by Linda Yablonsky, create a portrait of the artist as a human being who is emotionally connected to those who, like himself, live to make things.

title: Living In | Cobble Hill, Brooklyn
description: Within brownstone Brooklyn, the low-rise streetscape of Cobble Hill is distinctive for its consistently intimate 19th-century feel.

title: Land of the Multi-No-Longer Family House
description: EVEN within the rarefied region of brownstone Brooklyn, where landmark protections abound and residents speak of vintage cornices in the same knowing manner they discuss artisanal cheeses, the low-rise streetscape of Cobble Hill is distinctive for its consistently intimate 19th-century feel.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 5
description: A view of the day in sports, in which American Olympic track athletes competed in the bobsled and a dog ran off with Paul Caseys golf ball at the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship in Scotland.

title: Gee, She Looks Familiar
description: LIGHT seems to chase Mamie Gummer wherever she goes. It all but strafed her at the Altuzarra show during New York Fashion Week last month, a barrage of flashbulbs bleaching her skin to a milky translucence. As she took her front-row seat, a dozen photographers bore down on her, turning her visit into an impromptu red-carpet moment.

title: A Family Affair
description: Mamie Gummer is just the latest young actress to step out from the shadow of a famous mother. In recent years, there have been a number of daughters who have joined the family business  some with limited success, others who have become famous in their own right.

title: The Dance Is Over at Brooklyn Museum
description: The Brooklyn Museum will end its free Saturday dance parties as of this weekend, the Web site DNAinfo.com reported on Friday.
