description: To the Editor:

title: Relief Pitcher Joins As After Infants Death
description: DETROIT  Few members of the Oakland As expected relief pitcher Pat Neshek to join them here for the American League division series. Earlier this week, the infant son of Neshek and his wife, Stephanee, died just 23 hours after he was born.

title: Getting the Number Wrong
description: Mitt Romney said on Friday that there were 23 million Americans struggling to find work. It looks as if he got that wrong, by engaging in a little double counting. The real number is around 21 million.

title: Valium Saved My Life
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Traffic Casualties
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big-Hearted Country Sound, Sure, but Complicated Still
description: The sensitive bro is a relatively new country paradigm: The outside is tough, mostly, and sometimes muscled, but the heart is big and often bursting. Its become a stand-in for masculinity in the post-outlaw age, in which real rebellion isnt an option, but a hint of it is welcome, particularly if it comes with a big, warm embrace and maybe a nibble on the earlobe.

title: Photographs of the First Snow of the Season on Twitter
description: An early-season snowstorm blanketed northwestern Minnesota and parts of North Dakota on Thursday, shutting schools, pulling down power lines and making trouble for farmers already struggling to salvage crops from the worst drought in 50 years.

title: Governors Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Lonely for the Last Human Left
description: Heroism is thrust upon the misfit protagonist of Eugne Ionescos absurdist comedy Rhinoceros, hanging on his slumped shoulders like an ill-fitting suit. As, one by one, his fellow townsfolk grow tusks, and their soft skin turns scaly, it is not steadfast courage or a firm belief in taking a principled stand that drives poor Brenger, portrayed by the wonderful Serge Maggiani in the French-language production (with supertitles) at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Saturday.

title: A Place to Dig In, With a Fork or a Spade
description: BASED in Terrain, a new upscale gardening supply and equipment center in Westport, Terrain Garden Caf opened in time for patrons to eat outside all summer long. The open-air, brick-lined patio, surrounded by plants for sale, paired beautifully with the fresh, natural aspects of the cafes locavore menu.

title: Pig Farmers Face Pressure on the Size of the Sty
description: ELDRIDGE, Iowa  Sow 44733 had broken the shoulder of one of her pen mates, rousted another who was huddled in the corner and was chewing on the ear of a third.

title: Leader of U.S. Soccer Discusses Womens Coaching Position, and a New League
description: The president ofthe United States Soccer Federation said Friday that he hoped to select a new coach for the womens national team in the next three to six weeks, and that the federation was working on multiple fronts to start a Division 1 womens league.

title: Next Stop: Dinner in a 1907 Train Depot
description: A BAR, a restaurant and a train station all in one, the Boxcar Bar and Grill in Short Hills has become a hot party spot in the five months since it opened. Already, it has been booked for a post-baptism luncheon, a bar mitzvah, Christmas parties and a Friday Sabbath dinner.

title: Concert Is a Roaring, if Not Quite Timely, Success
description: At the official starting time for the Jay-Z concert Thursday night, the Barclays Center in Brooklyn was more than half empty.

title: Rebels Say Wests Inaction Is Pushing Syrians to Extremism
description: SAMAS, Syria  Majed al-Muhammad, the commander of a Syrian antigovernment fighting group, slammed his hand on his desk. Doesnt America have satellites? he asked, almost shouting. Cant it see what is happening?

title: Wine With Charity in Mind
description: Harmony Vineyards, licensed in 2011 and opened in June in Head of the Harbor Village on the North Shore, seems to be a standard Long Island boutique winery  with one exception. The owner, David E. Acker, intends to give its profits to charity.

title: An Imperial Setting for Japanese Delicacies
description: NOT so long ago, Japanese restaurants were generally modest places defined by pale wood and shoji screens. In recent years, some newcomers have vaulted from the serene to the dramatic. Ginza, which opened in Massapequa in March, is firmly in that camp.

title: Longing for the Good Fight at the Norman Mailer Center Gala
description: Where have all the fighters gone? This was the melancholy question that seemed to hang over Thursday nights award ceremony and fundraiser, the fourth annual event held by the Norman Mailer Center. More specifically  since Muhammad Ali himself was in attendance  where have the fighting writers gone?

title: Missouri Rewrites Plot, Rehiring Editor in Chief of the University Press
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Administrators at the University of Missouri completed a reversal of their decision to close the universitys publishing house when they announced on Friday that the longtime editor in chief, Clair Willcox, would be rehired.

title: A Show With Humor, and a Grave Message
description: A giant bear makes his entrance, carrying three bright yellow Nike shoeboxes, and says something about the 47 percent. Teddy Roosevelt refers to texting. An infant appears in a full Ku Klux Klan outfit, including the pointy hat. Jesus Christ pops in, billed with his middle initial, H. A Fat Elvis impersonator in a star-spangled jumpsuit takes charge near the end.

title: The Times Pays Tribute to a Publisher Called Punch
description: His name was Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, but you wouldnt have known it from the speakers who paid tribute to him on Friday for his forceful, yet genial, guidance of The New York Times through more than three decades of turbulence and growth.

title: A Week of Jazz and Remembrance
description: THE TD James Moody Democracy of Jazz Festival, to take place Oct. 15 to 21 at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and other places in Newark, is so named for a couple of reasons, according to John Schreiber, the president and chief executive officer of the center.

title: Winners at the 0 to 5,000 Life Master Pairs
description: Donald Caplin of Waltham, Mass., and Zachary Grossack of Newton, Mass., won the 0 to 5,000 Life Master Pairs at the Summer North American Championships in Philadelphia in July. (Players were limited to a maximum of 5,000 master points.)

title: How Hugo Chvez Became Irrelevant
description: Caracas, Venezuela

title: Homeless Are Fighting Back Against Panhandling Bans
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Panhandlers, with their crumpled signs, coffee cups and pleas, are as customary a sight in many American towns and cities as Starbucks or McDonalds. But for one Utah homeless man, the right to ask people for money has become a personal legal crusade.

title: President of Museum to Quit Her Post
description: After 15 years of working to build a permanent home for the Museum for African Art in Manhattan, the museums president, Elsie McCabe Thompson, announced on Friday that she was stepping down to pursue other career opportunities.

title: Yours Truly: Love and Letters
description: It is no longer impossible to imagine Virginia Woolf on Facebook.

title: Officials Seek People Exposed to a Tainted Drug
description: As the case count continued to rise in a multistate outbreak of meningitis linked to a tainted drug, federal health officials emphasized on Friday that it was absolutely essential to find everyone who may have been exposed to the drug, which was used in spinal injections for back pain.

title: California Struggles With High Gas Prices
description: Drivers in Southern California awoke Friday to find that their gasoline prices had spiked by nearly 20 cents a gallon overnight as a result of fuel shortages caused by a series of refinery disruptions in recent weeks.

title: Can You Stand Some More Stan?
description: You overwhelmed me, dear reader, with your reaction(s) to the piece I did last time about Stan Laurel. Im particularly moved by the number of you who were touched, using phrases like I misted up, I shed a tear and even I wept. I didnt mean to upset anyone.

title: In Cyberattacks on Banks, Evidence of a New Weapon
description: How were amateur hackers able to take down some of Americas largest banks? And who were they?

title: Sam Steiger, Lawmaker and Lightning Rod, Dies at 83
description: Sam Steiger, a New Yorker who transformed himself into a Western rancher, served five terms in the House as a Republican from Arizona and barged brashly through a series of scandals and controversies, died on Sept. 26 in Prescott, Ariz. He was 83.

title: 5,000 Faces Appear in the Night
description: THE attraction called Rise of the Jack oLanterns at the Old Westbury Gardens this month has a lot to live up to.

title: Alabama: Teachers Accused of Altering Grades
description: The State Department of Education said Friday that it would investigate reports that high school teachers in Montgomery had altered students grades to help them pass classes. The move came after The Montgomery Advertiser reported Thursday that teachers at three high schools had changed grades to improve their schools performance under the federal No Child Left Behind Act. Teachers gave failing students high marks on fake assignments and raised semester grades by 50 points for students who completed a one-page extra-credit assignment, the newspaper reported. The Montgomery schools superintendent, Barbara Thompson, called for a state investigation.

title: Looking Down to See Natures Early-Autumn Change in Hues
description: This time of year, the leaves on local trees only hint at autumnal color. To admire early fall foliage, instead of gazing up, I have been looking down.

title: With Steve Jobs Tribute, a Home Page Reflects Apples Founder Again
description: On most days, Apple.com is like any other corporate home page  a billboard, a news hub for corporate goings-on and a launching pad for an online store where people can buy stuff. Every once in a while, though, it turns into something unlike any other big companys home page.

title: Pedro A. Sanjuan Dies at 82; Cleared U.S. Path for African Envoys
description: In the early 1960s, the State Department faced a prickly problem. Black diplomats from newly formed African nations were being denied service at restaurants along the highways between Washington and New York and barred from many of Washingtons best apartment buildings.

title: A Landmark Race With the Bull Moose
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.

title: With N.H.L. Arenas Silent, an Overseas League Welcomes Stars and Buzz
description: MOSCOW  It could easily have been a scene from Verizon Center in Washington when a crowd gathered last week in front of a short-staffed apparel stand to clamor for anything with Alex Ovechkins name stamped on it.

title: Maurice S. Friedman, Martin Bubers Biographer, Dies at 90
description: The ideas of the Austrian-born philosopher Martin Buber were highly influential in post-World War II America. They inspired interfaith alliances that helped seed the civil rights and antiwar movements. They influenced Paul Tillich and Reinhold Niebuhr, the favorite philosophers of some recent presidents. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. quoted Buber in 1963 in his Letter From Birmingham Jail.

title: More Than Art Books, the Books Are the Art
description: New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Easier Access to Ballot Is Pushed by Democrats
description: LOS ANGELES  At a time when Republicans have moved to enact tougher qualifications for voting in states around the country, Democrats have begun to push voter registration laws in the opposite direction in states they control, especially here.

title: No Appetite for Good-for-You School Lunches
description: Outside Pittsburgh, they are proclaiming a strike, taking to Twitter and Facebook to spread the word. In a village near Milwaukee, hundreds staged a boycott. In a small farming and ranching community in western Kansas, they have produced a parody video. And in Parsippany, N.J., the protest is six days old and counting.

title: Of Hooters, Zombies and Senators
description: Today, lets take a look at debates that do not involve Barack Obama and Mitt Romney. You can thank me later.

title: Disputed Ruling Falls Cardinals Way
description: ATLANTA  St. Louis vs. Atlanta on Friday carried a double dose of expectation.

title: Divorce and Deadlines
description: RAOUL FELDER likes to say that marriage is the first step to divorce, which might betray an agenda on his part since separations are his bread and butter. During his own 46-year marriage, however, the divorce lawyer says, he and his wife have never had an argument.

title: Oct. 5: Day After Debate, Strong Swing State Polls for Romney
description: On Friday, Mitt Romney had his best day in state-level polling since at least the party conventions, something that very probably reflects improvement in his standing following the presidential debate in Denver on Wednesday.

title: Loopholes Seen at Schools in Obama Get-Tough Policy
description: With an agenda that Arne Duncan, the secretary of education, has described as a quiet revolution, the Obama administration has pushed rigorous new standards for a majority of the nations public schools as well as requirements that states and districts evaluate not just schools but individual teachers, in part by assessing their ability to improve student scores on standardized tests.

title: Jobs Report: Cooked or Correct?
description: Unbelievable job numbers, tweeted Jack Welch, the iconic former boss of General Electric on Friday morning, moments after the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its September jobs figures. These Chicago guys will do anything, he continued. Cant debate so change numbers.

title: In New Jersey Senate Race, Sticking Close to the Script
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  At the opening of the debate between the candidates for United States Senate here on Thursday night, the moderator noted that their campaigns had slid into the familiar broad themes of Republican versus Democrat: he cares only about the wealthy; he is a tax-and-spender. The moderator pressed them for specifics: What is one thing that makes your opponent less qualified than you?

title: The Starving Artist at MoMAs Doors
description: IT is hard to make a trip to the Museum of Modern Art without noticing, just outside the entrance on West 53rd Street, the lean, fresh-faced young man with paint-caked clothes standing next to his paint-caked table.

title: In Myanmar, Identity Is Challenged
description: After nearly five decades of military rule in the country, the arrival of democracy last year has led to debates about national identity.

title: When Flooding Is Not a Taking
description: The takings clause of the Constitutions Fifth Amendment ensures that private property cannot be taken for public use without fair compensation. A classic example is the governments exercise of eminent domain power to build a highway; if the road cuts through private land, the government owes the owners payment equal to fair market value. That principle applies when the government builds a dam, and water and silt overflow land, permanently destroying or limiting its value. But for 88 years, the position of the Supreme Court has been that temporary invasion of land by flooding is not a taking because water recedes.

title: Local Stop: Prospect-Lefferts Gardens
description: The neighborhood is an architects handbook of building styles executed in limestone, brownstone and brick.

title: Fraud in the Scientific Literature
description: A surprising upsurge in the number of scientific papers that have had to be retracted because they were wrong or even fraudulent has journal editors and ethicists wringing their hands. The retracted papers are a small fraction of the vast flood of research published each year, but they offer a revealing glimpse of the pressures driving many scientists to improper conduct.

title: Forced to Choose in Soccer: Club or Community
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  If ever there were a picture-perfect day for high school sports, it was a sun-drenched Saturday afternoon in early September when the first intratown soccer showdown in a dozen years took place in this bustling suburb.

title: Falling Behind the Season
description: The dog wakes me at 5:15 and we go out. The only sound is dew falling from the maple branches. Directly overhead, the Moon and Jupiter are traveling together, as they will for another night or two. In the east, Venus coasts high above the horizon. Ceilidh steps high through the wet grass, hoping to keep her belly dry, but then plunges her face into the pasture thatch following a scent. It is never too early to follow a scent.

title: Catalan Leader Boldly Grasps a Separatist Lever
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Artur Mas, the leader of Catalonia, has a clear message for Madrid: He is serious about his threat to let the people of Spains most economically powerful region decide for themselves in a referendum whether they should remain a part of Spain.

title: Romney Claims of Bipartisanship as Governor Face Challenge
description: BOSTON  He came into office with a mandate to shake things up, an agenda laden with civics-book reforms and a raging fiscal crisis that threatened to torpedo both. He sparred with a hostile legislature and suffered a humiliating setback in the midterm elections. As four years drew to a close, his legacy was blotted by anemic job growth, sagging political popularity and  except for a landmark health care overhaul bill  a record of accomplishment that disappointed many.

title: Dont Mess With Big Bird
description: Mitt Romneys Big Bird swipe during Wednesdays debate raised some hackles: PBSs, many on social media and mine.

title: A Checkup for Natural Gas
description: Just as New York State seemed ready to allow drilling upstate to extract a rich supply of natural gas, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced a delay. Officials will now take another look at the potential health risks of hydraulic fracturing  a technique for extracting natural gas from deep shale formations, like the Marcellus Shale that lies beneath the statess southern tier. Such caution makes sense, especially when approval of full-scale drilling could mean tens of thousands of gas rigs dotting the landscape over the next 30 years.

title: Mets Seeking Banks Help With Heavy Debt
description: The Mets, whose financial woes have included steep losses, burdensome debt and an expensive showdown with the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff, are talking to banks to find a way to raise cash, according to two people with knowledge of their plans.

title: For Woman in Senate Race, Uphill Fight for Female Votes
description: HARTFORD  If Linda E. McMahon is elected to the United States Senate from Connecticut, her victory will be due in large part to women like Dorothy Martin-Neville.

title: Group Buying L.I. Estate for Tesla Memorial
description: A dream of 16 years came true for science enthusiasts on Friday when they struck a deal to buy a dilapidated estate on Long Island and transform it into a museum and educational memorial to Nikola Tesla, an eccentric genius who lit the world with alternating current but died penniless.

title: A.L.D.S.: Detroits Stars Against Oaklands Bargains
description: The 2011 Oakland Athletics went 74-88, the same record as this years Mets. They had two pitchers who worked 200 innings  Trevor Cahill and Gio Gonzalez  and traded both over the winter. Cahill went to Arizona, Gonzalez to Washington, and they are bargains for their new teams, earning less than $4 million each this season.

title: What April Has
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Im always amazed by constructors who find themeless construction easier than themed. I dont find stacking sparkling, cohesive entries on top of each other particularly easy, and I am much more interested in the wordplay and theme development. So I stay in my own constructing neighborhood, so to speak. Leave the heavy lifting to those who are good at it, thats my motto.

title: Corrections: October 6, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: New Clashes at Site in Jerusalem Holy to Both Muslims and Jews
description: JERUSALEM  Two Israeli police officers were slightly injured in a clash at a holy site in Jerusalem that erupted during a demonstration after Friday Prayer, and one Arab protester was arrested.

title: Accident Suspected in Agents Death on Mexican Border
description: WASHINGTON  Federal authorities said Friday that there were strong preliminary indications that a Border Patrol agent who was killed in a shooting on Tuesday in Arizona near the border with Mexico was accidentally shot by another agent.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Auto sales show renewed strength, workers protested a Walmart in California and the September unemployment report topped expectations.

title: Brownstones and Rastafarian Gear
description: Though Brooklynites identify themselves pretty closely with their neighborhoods, many areas are so big and varied that those designations cannot mean much. But say you live in the Prospect-Lefferts Gardens Historic District, just east of Prospect Park, and you are saying that you almost certainly live in a single-family house, on a tranquil, tree-shaded street, close to the zoo, the lake and the botanic garden. The neighborhood is an architects handbook of building styles executed in limestone, brownstone and brick. On an ordinary afternoon the streets are nearly empty and close to silent until they abut Flatbush Avenue, once called Vlacke Bos  Dutch for wooded plain  and today busy with Indian takeout restaurants, hair salons and ethnic boutiques. Its an eclectic array that matches the diversity of the areas residents.

title: Defiant Message Amid Iran Currency Crisis
description: Senior Iranian clerics intensified their anti-Western criticism on Friday, calling the near-collapse of the national currency this past week a consequence of an American-led conspiracy to wage an economic war on Iran, and predicting that the pressure would ease.

title: Living on His Own, Far From the Box
description: John Cornelius Foley, his new shoes laced, stood tall and patted his pockets. Cellphone, wallet, keys. All set. He pulled a ball cap over his gray hair, turned off his small, flat screen TV, cut off the apartment lights and locked the door behind him.

title: Napa Maker of Prized Kosher Wine Says His Faith Came Through the Vine
description: NAPA, Calif.  When Jeff Morgan rose before dawn one morning this week, two different calendars told him harvest time had arrived. It was the third day of October, the heart of grape-picking season in the wine country of Northern California, and it was the third day of Sukkot, the Jewish holiday that since antiquity has celebrated the gathering of crops.

title: Passenger Recounts Chaos of Fatal Bus Crash in Bronx
description: When Truc Thanh Tran boarded a World Wide Travel bus after a night at the Mohegan Sun casino in Connecticut, she wanted to sit in a front row but was sent to the back by a ticket-taker, she recalled on Friday.

title: With a Destination Set, So Are the Yankees
description: In past years when the Yankees won the American League East, they usually waited for an opponent to come to Yankee Stadium for the first two games of a playoff series.

title: Court Backs a Terminally Ill Woman, but Doubts About Her Wishes Arise
description: An appeals court panel on Friday ruled that a hospital could remove life support from a terminally ill Queens woman, but now there appears to be some doubt about what the patient, a 28-year-old bank manager with brain cancer, really wants.

title: Controversial Pro-Israel Ad Campaign to Expand to Buses
description: The group behind the subway station ads urging riders to support Israel and defeat jihad plans to run nearly identical ads on New York City buses, it said  and, this time, it appears that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will not object.

title: Vikings Surprisingly Atop N.F.C. North
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  The chest thumping stopped as soon as the Minnesota Vikings players arrived for meetings and practice Monday.

title: Leading Maryland and Virginia, With Stars on the Rise
description: Maryland and Virginia share a history rich in both rivalry and cooperation, and the same can be said for their governors.

title: Happiness Expert, Plying Her Craft
description: Gretchen Rubin is the author of seven books, including the best sellers The Happiness Project and Happier at Home, published last month. Ms. Rubin, 46, grew up in Kansas City, Mo., and lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan with her husband, Jamie, 44, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, and their daughters, Eliza and Eleanor, who are 13 and 7. Ms. Rubins study of domestic happiness has helped shape her weekends, and she tries to infuse them with leisure and a sense of rest.

title: Worries Over Defense Department Money for Hackerspaces
description: This fall, 16 high schools in California started experimental workshops, billed as a kind of shop class for the 21st century, that were financed by the federal government. And over the next three years, the $10 million program plans to expand to 1,000 high schools, modeled on the growing phenomenon of hackerspaces  community clubhouses where hackers gather to build, invent or take things apart in their spare time.

title: A Suite Called Home
description: NEW YORKS hotels are hives of urban velocity, where strangers live out epic adventures in a few days, then return home to spend the rest of their lives retelling them. Then there are the guests who never leave.

title: Stewart, Yankees Backup Catcher, Gets a Taste of Success
description: Chris Stewart chose the wrong moment to be early, when he streamed through the clubhouse doors Wednesday night, grabbed a Champagne bottle and realized he was the only one there.

title: Heart of Tigers Knows How to Relax, Smile and Win a Triple Crown
description: DETROIT  In the 1950s and 60s, before divisional play, the designated hitter and drug testing, the presence of a triple crown winner on your team meant a trip to the World Series.

title: Before a Test, a Poverty of Words
description: Not too long ago, I witnessed a child, about two months shy of 3, welcome the return of some furniture to his familys apartment with the enthusiastic declaration Ottoman is back! The child understood that the stout cylindrical object from which he liked to jump had a name and that its absence had been caused by a visit to someone called an upholsterer. The upholsterer, he realized, was responsible for converting the ottoman from one color or texture to another. Here was a child whose mother had prepared him, at the very least, for a future of reading World of Interiors.

title: Texas Not Hiding Its Concerns About Stopping Mountaineers Smith
description: AUSTIN, Tex.   When Texas Coach Mack Brown was asked this week about West Virginia quarterback Geno Smith, he spoke not of the way Smith has made opposing defenses seem as if they are not there, but of how he has made members of Browns own staff go missing.

title: Cuba: Blogger Detained as Trial Begins
description: The Cuban authorities detained the dissident blogger Yoani Snchez for 30 hours before releasing her late Friday. Ms. Sanchez was arrested Thursday with her husband near Bayamo while on her way to cover the trial of a Spanish politician charged in connection with the death of two dissidents in a car crash, according to news reports and human rights monitors.

title: Germany: Man Charged as Spy for Syria
description: A 48-year-old man with dual German-Lebanese citizenship has been charged with spying for the Syrian intelligence service from 2007 until his arrest in February, the federal prosecutors office said Friday. The suspect, who was identified only as Mahmoud El A., is accused of spying on Syrian opposition members living in Germany, according to prosecutors. After antigovernment protests began in Syria in early 2011, the suspect intensified his contacts with his intelligence agency handler in Berlin, reporting on gatherings of exiled opponents of the Syrian government and taking photographs of demonstrators, prosecutors said.

title: Judge Faults Police for Delays in Providing Records of Fatal Accident
description: A judge criticized the police on Friday for dragging their feet in releasing records and reports to the family of a cyclist who was fatally struck by a truck in Brooklyn last year, saying the department had needlessly delayed handing over documents.

title: Suicide Prevention Resources
description: Last year, New York City police officers responded to 519 reports of people threatening to jump from buildings and bridges, and the number is likely to be higher this year, Wendy Ruderman reports in this weeks Metropolitan section. In the United States, nearly 100 people take their own lives each day.

title: The Jumper Squad
description: ON a concrete ledge off the upper deck of the George Washington Bridge, more than 200 feet above the swift and leaden Hudson River that November night, the two detectives gingerly approached the despondent man as he contemplated jumping.

title: Wild Evening
description: The Cardinals came back from a 2-0 deficit to advance in a game delayed by a disputed call in the eighth.

title: Imagining a Sideline Without Coaches
description: To transform Boston University from a commuter school to an enviable private institution, its longtime president and chancellor, John R. Silber, who died last week, relied on innovation, his endless ideas both popular and despised.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Lottery Numbers
Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Umpires in the Outfield Can Produce Errors in Judgment in the Postseason
description: Creating a new round of the postseason that consisted of only one game was sure to create some drama, especially when it was advertised as Win or Go Home! With everything on the line for the Atlanta Braves on Friday night, a questionable call by an umpire was part of what sent them packing.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: College Football Matchups
description: What was supposed to be a paucity of interesting games last week ended with several thrillers. This Saturday is mouthwatering, with huge tests of strength that could help determine who plays where come January. There will probably be routs from one end of the country to the other. Lets break down the best games anyway, starting with two monster games from the Tyrannosaurus rex of conferences, the Southeastern.FINALLY, A CHALLENGE No. 5 Georgia has somehow managed to win 15 straight regular-season games without beating any team of notable strength. And it plays in the SEC. Something will give when the Bulldogs visit No. 6 South Carolina. With their leading receiver, Michael Bennett, injured, the Bulldogs will rely on the freshmen running backs Todd Gurley and Keith Marshall, who are nicknamed Gurshall. The two combined for 294 yards and 5 touchdowns against Tennessee. South Carolina has a pretty fair back of its own in Marcus Lattimore, who has run for eight touchdowns. Both defenses are laden with Sunday-ready players, putting the onus on which teams offensive linemen can avoid getting tossed around like bales of hay and open some holes for the runners behind them.

title: Returning to Playoffs in Style, Orioles Await Yankees
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Constant-demography Employment (Wonkish But Relevant)
description: These days everyone knows that the unemployment rate is a problematic measure, because it can fall not because more people are working but simply because fewer people are looking for work. (This isnt what happened in September, but it has been an issue in the recent past). An alternative is therefore to count employment rather than unemployment; one simple measure is the employment-population ratio, which suggests no improvement for years:

title: A Conversation With: Chief Economic Adviser Raghuram G. Rajan
description: Raghuram Rajan, whom I profiled in a recent story for The New York Times, took over as the chief economic adviser in Indias Finance Ministry last month. He has long been an adviser to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, and he is known in global economic policy circles for a paper he wrote on the growing risks in the financial system years before the collapse of Lehman Brothers, and for his work at the International Monetary Fund, where he was chief economist.

title: North Korean Soldier Said to Cross Demilitarized Zone to Defect
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A North Korean Army sergeant defected to South Korea on Saturday after killing his platoon and squadron leaders, a South Korean military spokesman said.

title: IHT Weekend Quick Read: Oct. 6-7
description: NEWS Artur Mas, Catalonias leader, says he is serious about letting Catalans decide whether to secede, and this posturing has thrust him to the forefront of Spanish politics. Raphael Minder reports from Barcelona.

title: Turkey Fires Back at Syria a Fourth Day in a Row
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkey fired artillery into Syria for a fourth consecutive day on Saturday after another Syrian shell landed on the Turkish side of the increasingly tense border.

title: The Weekend Word: On the Job
description: Todays Times

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Himachal Pradesh: The Election Commission announced Wednesday that polling for the state legislature will be held on Nov. 4, The Hindustan Times reported. Ballots are scheduled to be counted by Dec.20.

title: Popes Butler Sentenced to 18 Months in Theft Case
description: VATICAN CITY  A Vatican court on Saturday sentenced the popes former butler, Paolo Gabriele, to 18 months in prison for leaking confidential documents to a journalist in one of the most serious breaches of vaunted Vatican secrecy in modern history.

title: British Rights Campaigners Concerned About U.S. Terror Extraditions
description: LONDON  As Britains most notorious Islamist preacher and four other terror suspects were flown to the United States overnight, the overwhelming reaction among the public, the press and the British justice system was one of relief.

title: Michael Schumacher and Retirement, Round 2
description: SUZUKA, Japan  Shortly before 5 p.m. in the Formula One paddock in Suzuka on Thurdsay, during the media sessions in advance of the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday, a team press representative asked me where everyone was  who else was giving a media session at that moment that so few were there with his driver?

title: U.S. to Play Russia?
description: Buried deep in a wire service article Saturday is a report that is probably news to many fans of the United States mens national team  the Americans will travel to Russia for an international friendly in Krasnodar on Nov. 14.

title: A Master of Improv, Writing Twitters Script
description: WELCOME to the Dick Costolo Show.

title: Preventing Sports Concussions Among Children
description: This fall, about three million children younger than 14 are playing organized tackle football in the United States. Is that a good thing?

title: Obama and Democrats Raise $181 Million in September
description: 3:17 p.m. | Updated President Obama and the Democrats shattered the election cycles fund-raising record with a $181 million haul for September, the campaign announced on Saturday morning.

title: Icing Tactic Leaves Some Kickers Neither Shaken nor Stirred
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It is anticlimactic, drama-draining and a killer of rhythm. It is, from a statistical perspective, debatably effective. And it is, in the words of Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes, the most ridiculously talked-about and overanalyzed issue in the game.

title: It Is Getting Harder to Overlook Schaub
description: HOUSTON  Matt Schaub knew where the question was headed. He recoiled at the mention of the word elite and dismissed the notion that it might even remotely refer to him or the Houston Texans.

title: Another Big Day at Barclays Center in Brooklyn
description: A team dressed in black and white will take the court Sunday morning at Barclays Center, making a small bit of history with every dribble.

title: Man Killed by French Police During an Antiterrorism Raid
description: PARIS  French police officers fatally shot a man during an antiterrorism raid in the northeastern city of Strasbourg on Saturday, one of a series of raids across France stemming from the investigation into a grenade attack last month on a Jewish market near Paris, the police and judiciary officials said.

title: Romneys Goals on Environmental Regulation Would Face Difficult Path
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney vowed in a campaign appearance earlier this year to take a weed whacker to the thicket of federal regulations adopted by the Obama administration and promised to impose a rigid freeze and cost cap on all new government rules.

title: Political Islam and the Fate of Two Libyan Brothers
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  One brother joined the global jihad against the West under the nom de guerre Abu Yahya al-Libi. He rose to become Al Qaedas brightest star and second in command, until an American drone strike killed him in Pakistan four months ago.

title: Live Coverage: College Football Saturday
description: Good morning, sports and Internet fans, and welcome to Week 6. And what a week we have set up for us.

title: Wyoming, Energy and Libertarianism
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is a look at Wyoming, the Cowboy State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Erich Frankland, a political science professor at Casper College, and James D. King, a political science professor at the University of Wyoming.

title: A Noisy Acrostic
description: English is an outrageous tangle of those derivations and other multifarious linguistic influences, from Yiddish to Shoshone, which has grown up around a gnarly core of chewy, clangorous yawps derived from ancestors who painted themselves blue to frighten their enemies.  Roy Blount, Jr., Alphabet Juice

title: Some in G.O.P. Choose to Return to Akins Corner
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  For establishment Republicans, it is decision time in the Missouri Senate race.

title: Extradited Muslim Cleric and 4 Other Terrorism Suspects Appear in American Courts
description: After a protracted battle in the British and European courts, Abu Hamza al-Masri, an incendiary Muslim preacher with links to Al Qaeda, and four other terrorism suspects implicated in an array of terrorist plots were extradited to the United States on Saturday to face federal charges in Manhattan and New Haven.

title: Emory Confronts a Legacy of Bias Against Jews
description: Early in the summer of 1952, after his first year of dental school at Emory University in Atlanta, Perry Brickman received a letter from the dean. It informed him that he had flunked out.

title: Scientists Adopt Tiny Island as a Warming Bellwether
description: TATOOSH ISLAND, Wash.  From a stretch of rocky shoreline on this tiny island, one can, on any given morning, watch otters floating on their backs, elephant seals hauling out of the water and a bald eagle flying past murres huddled along a cliff face. The startled birds perform a synchronized dive into the sea, their ovoid black-and-white bodies resembling miniature penguins.

title: Fifty Years Ago, Last Outpost of Segregation in N.F.L. Fell
description: On a mild autumn Sunday in Washington a half-century ago, Bobby Mitchell dominated the St. Louis Cardinals. Mitchell, a 27-year-old flanker for the Redskins, caught 7 passes for 147 yards and 2 touchdowns in a 24-14 victory. Trying to contain Mitchell, The Washington Post sports columnist Shirley Povich wrote, was like trying to deal with a basketful of snakes.

title: Whos in Charge Inside Your Head?
description: ZOMBIE bees?

title: Europes Richer Regions Want Out
description: PARIS

title: The Pain of Reading
description: Santurce, P.R.

title: Impartial Justice at Risk
description: The success of right-wing forces two years ago in ousting three Iowa Supreme Court justices for participating in a unanimous ruling that allowed same-sex marriage has inspired similar efforts there and elsewhere in the country this fall.

title: Is America Man Enough to Vote?
description: HUNDREDS of variables affect voting patterns: income, race, gender, unemployment, the weather, polling locations, altruism, to name a few. And on Election Day these all come together to produce a voter. Too often they produce a nonvoter.

title: Riggleman, Who Left, Wants Back In
description: WASHINGTON  Gio Gonzalez led the Nationals  the team and the league  with 21 victories this season. The first-time closer Tyler Clippard saved 32 games, first baseman Adam LaRoche slammed 33 home runs and drove in 100 runs, and Stephen Strasburg won 15 games before being shelved for the year.

title: Why Women Hide Their Pregnancies
description: LAST week, Yahoos new chief executive, Marissa Mayer, gave birth to a baby boy. When she was hired in July, late in her second trimester, bloggers and newspaper columnists celebrated the breaking of another pane in the glass ceiling. Pregnant women, it seemed, could be hired for top jobs. Given the many breathless and celebratory bump watches in tabloids, it might seem that the stigma around working while pregnant has finally lifted. The birth of Ms. Mayers son came only a week after the host of the Emmys, Jimmy Kimmel, introduced the actress Claire Danes with the line, Our next presenter has a baby in her. Ms. Danes traversed the stage in a bright yellow dress that emphasized her fertile form.

title: A Big Laser Runs Into Trouble
description: After spending more than $5 billion to build and operate a giant laser installation the size of a football stadium, the Energy Department has not achieved its goal of igniting a fusion reaction that could produce energy to generate power or simulate what happens in a nuclear weapon.

title: Court Cases That Last Longer Than Some Lives
description: OVER the course of two days last month, I testified in federal court in Wilmington, N.C., at an evidentiary hearing called to consider claims by the convicted murderer Jeffrey MacDonald, who for the eighth time has appealed for a new trial.

title: Colleges Value Diversity, but Will the Court?
description: The most anticipated case of the new Supreme Court term, to be argued on Wednesday, was brought by Abigail Noel Fisher, a white student who was denied admission to the University of Texas at Austin in 2008.

title: Its Not Me, Its You
description: WEVE all been there: you feel especially smart and funny when talking to a particular person, only to feel hopelessly unintelligent and inarticulate in the presence of another.

title: The Cancer Lobby
description: WHO knew that carcinogens had their own lobby in Washington?

title: The Steel Butterfly Still Soars
description: LIKE a cockroach after a nuclear bomb, Imelda Marcoss charm has survived what should have been a deadly blow. Back in 1986, a popular revolt ended her 20-year reign as the Philippines first lady. She fled to Hawaii with her husband, Ferdinand, leaving behind a grisly record of human rights abuses, corruption and, of course, more than 1,000 pairs of shoes.

title: Life and Climate Change on a Rocky Island
description: Tatoosh Island, off the coast of Washington State, has seen a decline across species and could prove to be a bellwether for oceanic change globally.

title: Two Presidents, Smoking and Scheming
description: AFTER the debate, I was talking to Aaron Sorkin, who was a little down. Or, as he put it, nonverbal, shouting incoherently at a squirrel, angrier than when the Jets lost to the 49ers last Sunday without ever really being on the field.

title: Can I Phone a Friend?
description: LAST weeks debate was important not only because Mitt Romney won and thereby energized his moribund campaign. It was important because Romney won in a way that exposed and deepened President Obamas two greatest vulnerabilities in this election, while overcoming, at least for one night, Romneys greatest weakness.

title: Soriano Fills Empty Chair in Yankees Bullpen
description: The chairs were nearly side by side in front of neighboring dressing stalls that just happened to be devoid of tenants but contained the kind of ancillary materials typically scattered about a baseball clubhouse.

title: It Could Be His Party
description: IN countries with parliamentary systems, political parties rarely lack for formal leadership. When the British Tories or Canadian Liberals are out of power, they have an official prime minister-in-waiting standing by, and a shadow cabinet as well. Theres jockeying for influence behind the scenes, but theres always somebody out front who can claim to speak for the party, setting its agenda and making a case to the country as a whole.

title: Never Waver, Never Wobble
description: WHAT fools most of us are. What chumps. We worry about our flaws, sweat our mistakes, allow the truth to be our tether and let conscience trip us up. We tiptoe. We equivocate.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Using Race in Admissions
description: How should the Supreme Court rule on affirmative action?

title: Raj Chetty
description: Raj Chetty, 33, is an Indian-American economist who accepted a tenured professorship at Harvard University while still in his 20s. He was awarded a MacArthur genius grant last week for his work in the emerging field of behavioral public finance, i.e., using empirical data to measure how economic policies and public-sector investment affect individual behavior and social outcomes.

title: Voters in Florida Are Set to Weigh In on Two Contentious Ballot Questions
description: MIAMI  In a year in which most states have steered clear of contentious ballot initiatives, Florida voters are facing two proposed constitutional amendments  one on abortion, the other on the separation of church and state  that could have far-reaching repercussions.

title: Posey, the Heart of San Francisco, Beats Quietly
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Everything about Buster Posey stands out, except Buster Posey.

title: Collins Has Not Paid a Big Price for Losing
description: For another autumn and winter, stable amid the rubble of another collapsed Mets season will stand Terry Collins, the teams fiery manager, who has pulled off a noteworthy feat in presiding over two straight losing seasons while staying mostly free from blame or reproach.

title: Slow-Burning Challenge to Chile on Easter Island
description: HANGA ROA, Easter Island  Not long ago, as some elders of the Rapanui people wistfully recall, a sense of profound isolation pervaded this windswept speck of land in the Pacific. Horses were the dominant mode of transportation, flights to the outside world were few and far between, and the islands Polynesian language enjoyed dominance in most spheres of life.

title: Better News on Jobs
description: The September jobs report contains information with important consequences for government policy. But dont expect Republicans to seriously engage with any of it, for two reasons.

title: Chiles Challenge on Easter Island
description: The quest for political autonomy presents a unique test for a Latin American country: quelling a challenge to its rule in the middle of the South Pacific.

title: Detective Thought Man He Fatally Shot Had Gun, Lawyer Says
description: Detective Hassan Hamdy made the split-second decision to fire a single fatal shot at an unarmed motorist during an early morning traffic stop on a highway in Queens because he thought the driver was reaching for a gun, according to the detectives lawyer.

title: 30 Seconds With Jim Kaat
description: In a 25-year major league career pitching for five franchises, the left-hander Jim Kaat compiled 283 wins and a 3.45 earned run average. He was a three-time All-Star and won the World Series with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1982.

title: Coming Out as a Boy Scout Has a Price
description: National Coming Out Day, on Oct. 11 this year, is a day that provokes mixed feelings among those it prompts, or has prompted, to reveal a sexual identity that they have hidden. But in Helping a Child to Come Out, the New York Times John Schwartz writes about another group that, he says, regards the day with a mixture of longing, impatience and expectation: the parents of children who know that their son or daughter is gay, but hasnt yet worked up the courage to tell them.

title: Original Letters in Chinese From Bo Xilai to Li Danyu
description: Bo Xilai, a disgraced Communist Party leader, wrote a letter and poem to his first wife, Li Danyu, in 1975.

title: Bo Xilais Letter and Poem to His First Wife
description: The following are translations of a 11-page letter and a poem that Bo Xilai, a fallen Chinese official and son of a Communist leader, wrote to Li Danyu, a military doctor who is the daughter of a senior Communist Party official. The letter is dated July 14, 1975, and is written in the form of an eight-legged essay, used in imperial exams. The poem was given to her at another time.

title: Former Wife of Fallen Chinese Leader Tells of a Familys Paranoid Side
description: BEIJING  Just months before his fall from power, Bo Xilai asked the brother of his first wife to meet him at a government compound in the southwest metropolis of Chongqing.

title: Rangers Hamilton, Fragile and Remarkable, May Move On
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: A Graceful Swing That Bears Resemblance to Federers
description: Mick Kelleher, the Yankees first-base coach, a devoted tennis fan and competitive tennis player, noticed it during the last homestand and mentioned it to Alex Rodriguez in the dugout: Robinson Cano, one of the most fluid and graceful players in baseball, bears a resemblance to Roger Federer, one of the most fluid and graceful players in tennis.

title: How to Become a Bus Driver, Not a Bulldozer
description: This interview with  Ken Rees, president and chief executive of Think Finance, a developer of financial products, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Muni Bond Market, Mired in Its Past
description: THE $4 trillion market in municipal bonds, which finances American life where it gets lived, is stuck in the Dark Ages. It has been for decades.

title: A Luxury Locker Room for a Team That Has Been a Bit of a Fixer-Upper
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Jacksonville Jaguars have one victory, the lowest-ranked offense and one of the worst run defenses after the first month of the N.F.L. season.

title: Iran Denies Plan to End Nuclear Standoff
description: TEHRAN  Iranian officials on Saturday dismissed a New York Times report saying Iran had offered a nine-step plan for resolving a standoff with the United States and its allies over its disputed nuclear program, calling the report baseless.

title: Americans Join Pakistan Convoy to Protest Drone Strikes
description: CHASHMA, Pakistan  Hundreds of political activists, led by the opposition politician Imran Khan and accompanied by 32 American peace activists, departed Pakistans capital on Saturday in a convoy headed toward the countrys tribal regions to protest American drone strikes.

title: They Work Long Hours, but What About Results?
description: ITS 5 p.m. at the office. Working fast, youve finished your tasks for the day and want to go home. But none of your colleagues have left yet, so you stay another hour or two, surfing the Web and reading your e-mails again, so you dont come off as a slacker.

title: Sports Replay, Oct. 6
description: A look at the day in sports worldwide, from motorcycle racing in Egypt to cricket in Sri Lanka.

title: Beyond Our True Calling
description: To the Editor:

title: The Seeds That Federal Money Can Plant
description: LUIS VON AHN, a computer scientist at Carnegie Mellon University, sold one Internet start-up to Google in 2009, and is now on to another. With the new company, Duolingo, he hopes to tap the millions of people learning languages online to create a crowdsourced engine of translation. We want to translate the whole Web into every major language, Mr. von Ahn says.

title: How the G.O.P. Became the Anti-Urban Party
description: A LEADING Republican columnist, trying to re-stoke her candidates faltering campaign before the first presidential debate, felt so desperate that she advised him to turn to cities.

title: The Case for Calm Over Rising Health Costs
description: IN 1946, a British newspaper shocked its readers by running an article with this ominous-sounding headline: Nearly Half of U.K. Student Grades Are Below Average. Read that back to yourself slowly, and youll realize, of course, that the law of averages would have it no other way. But man, does it sound bad.

title: Housing Fever Can Work Both Ways
description: THE boom and bust in the housing market was a dual social epidemic. First, there was an epidemic of positive thinking that led to high expectations for long-term home price appreciation  and for the economy, too. Then, after 2005, an epidemic of negative thinking discouraged many people from buying a house or from spending in general, and kept many employers from hiring.

title: In Ryder Cup, Yay, Team!
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Information About Cancer? Suppress It!
description: My Sunday column looks at what I call the cancer lobby  a term that will have said lobby writing in indignation about now. But Im pretty indignant, too.

title: Rutgers Shuts Down Connecticut
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Rutgerss top-ranked rushing defense continued its dominant season, holding Connecticut to 53 yards on the ground in a 19-3 victory Saturday.

title: Democrats Bet on Shift in Hispanic Numbers to Win Arizona Race
description: TUCSON  The man who could be the first Latino to represent Arizona in the Senate, Richard H. Carmona, says he is not fooling himself. I want to be realistic on the expectations, he said last week at his office.

title: Market Clarity When Campaign Feathers Fly
description: IN the short run, the market is a voting machine, but in the long run it is a weighing machine, Benjamin Graham, the guru of value investing, once wrote about the stock market.

title: Good, by Design
description: Innovative change makers are trying to create a beautiful, just world.

title: Dignifying Design
description: IN 2006 a 26-year-old architecture student, Michael Murphy, approached the global health pioneer Paul Farmer after a lecture at Harvard. Mr. Murphy asked which architects Dr. Farmer had worked with to build the clinics, housing, schools and even the roads he had described in his talk. An aspiring social entrepreneur, Mr. Murphy was hoping to put his design degree to use by apprenticing with the humanitarian architects aiding Dr. Farmers work. But it turns out, those architects didnt exist.

title: Assistants, Yes, but They Can Do It All
description: THEIR titles vary: executive assistant, administrative assistant, the syllable-clipped admin, the classic secretary. Whatever you call them, these professionals continue to keep offices running as technology and budget cuts reshape their roles.

title: Writing With Miles Davis
description: If Miles Daviss midcentury trumpet solos can be described by a single phrase, it might be doing more with less. Despite his renown, Davis wasnt a flashy or highly technical player during the late 1950s and early 60s. He was melodic and economical, and his approach can teach prose writers a lot about the power of concision, suggestion and space.

title: A Careers Building Blocks
description: I LIVE on ancestral land that my family has owned in Alabama for almost 200 years. My wife and I have created a green space on part of it for school groups, church groups and organizations like the Boy Scouts to enjoy. Our family chapel is there, too.

title: With Baltimore, Buck Showalter Faces Past in Present
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Baltimore Orioles were wildly drenching themselves in celebration Friday, but Manager Buck Showalter was still dry. Suddenly, Jim Thome emerged, wrapped tightly in postseason plastic, and began to uncork a bottle of Champagne.

title: Knicks Battle Injuries Early
description: The Knicks, a team with several older veterans, announced their first significant injury of training camp Saturday. Marcus Camby, a 38-year-old power forward, will likely miss the first two preseason games with a strained left calf.

title: Mutual Fund Investors, Flying Again but Feeling Dizzy
description: THE ups and downs that have unnerved investors for at least two years produced another course correction for the stock market in the third quarter. A spring decline gave way to a summer rally that took popular indexes to their highest levels in at least five years.

title: Ways to Play a Recovery in Housing
description: WALL STREET prides itself on seeing things before they are broadly apparent. But, sometimes, even the shrewdest investors get ahead of themselves. The stock market, the old joke goes, has predicted nine of the last five recessions.

title: Nowadays, I Cant Even Invest in My Words
description: ITS not an easy time to be an investor  especially an inept investor. My buy-and-hold strategy feels like trying to tread water while holding a sack of hammers.

title: A.L.D.S. Preview: Drought Over, Orioles Face a Seasoned Foe
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Baltimore Orioles did not stage a wild celebration upon securing a spot in the postseason because they clinched a berth while traveling last Sunday night. But the bubbly flowed in the clubhouse here late Friday, and Adam Jones, the center fielder and team leader, surveyed the scene.

title: Emerging Markets Are More Than Just the BRICs
description: THE BRIC backlash has begun.

title: Fund Investors Are Nearing the Edge, Too
description: TAX increases and federal spending cuts scheduled for the end of 2012 could lop off nearly four percentage points of annual economic growth, according to government and private estimates. In an economy expanding at less than a 2 percent annual rate, this fiscal cliff, as the potential decline is called, is a concern on Wall Street, in Washington and beyond.

title: For Uncertain Times, Some Back-to-Basics Advice
description: AFTER a loss in which his Green Bay Packers played horrifically, Coach Vince Lombardi, according to legend, announced to the team that it would be returning to fundamentals.

title: N.L.D.S. Preview: A Fractured Timeline From Senators to Expos to Nationals
description: On Oct. 7, 1933, at Griffith Stadium, Dolf Luque of the New York Giants struck out Joe Kuhel of the Washington Senators for the final out of the World Series. This was the last postseason game in Washington.

title: Avoiding Yardsticks, Bond Funds Excel
description: BOND funds are on track for their best year since 2009, and the secret to many managers recent success has been simple: just dont mimic the indexes.

title: In Search of Funds That Dont Rock the Boat
description: IN the canon of investing commandments, risk and return are inextricably linked. Weve had it pounded into our heads that having a shot at higher returns requires accepting a more volatile portfolio. And any suggestion that its possible to ratchet down volatility without sacrificing performance would be an act of modern portfolio blasphemy, or a specious marketing ploy. Right?

title: What a Difference a Percentage Point Can Make
description: INVESTORS cant count on very much these days. The economy remains troubled, the stock market is volatile and the bond market seems fraught with risk.

title: Q & A
description: Neighbors Dog Barks for Hours

title: For Three Top Funds, the Paths to Success Dont Cross
description: OIL refineries, all-terrain vehicles and European banks would seem to share little, but they helped to provide good returns to managers of three of the better-performing mutual funds of the third quarter.

title: Space Invasion
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  A HIGH FIVE to Zoe Wheeler for being the first to have HIGH FIVE in a New York Times crossword puzzle. Considering how long weve all been slapping each other silly up high, wouldnt you think the phrase would have made it into a puzzle by now?

title: A Childs Remains Are Found in a Backyard on Long Island
description: A routine visit by child welfare authorities on Long Island led to a multicounty search for a boy who was mysteriously absent, an Amber Alert for one of the boys half-brothers and the discovery of a small body in a shallow grave in the backyard of the familys home, the police said Saturday.

title: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Syrian Rebel Aid
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  For months, Saudi Arabia and Qatar have been funneling money and small arms to Syrias rebels but have refused to provide heavier weapons, like shoulder-fired missiles, that could allow opposition fighters to bring down government aircraft, take out armored vehicles and turn the wars tide.

title: Scant Oversight of Drug Maker in Fatal Meningitis Outbreak
description: Eddie C. Lovelace, a Kentucky judge still on the bench into his late 70s, had a penchant for reciting Shakespeare from memory and telling funny stories in his big, booming voice. But a car accident last spring left him with severe neck pain, and in July and August he sought spinal injections with a steroid medicine for relief.

title: Cardinals, With Edge in Experience, Consider Themselves Underdogs
description: ST. LOUIS  Experience was the key word here Saturday, popping up in all contexts and conversations as the St. Louis Cardinals and Washington Nationals prepared for the start of their National League Division Series on Sunday afternoon.

title: British Soil Is Battlefield Over Peat, for Bogs Sake
description: DICKLEBURGH, England  For Britains legion of gardeners, peat has long been as essential to gardening as beer is to the corner pub. So trowels flew after the British government  heeding environmental concerns  announced plans to gradually eliminate peat from all gardening products, setting off an intense battle over how to prioritize two of this countrys defining passions: indulging the yard and protecting the planet.

title: Greens Versus the Green Thumb
description: The Timess Elisabeth Rosenthal documents the heated British debate between gardeners and environmentalists over the use of peat.

title: Oct. 6: Romney Maintains Poll Momentum
description: Mitt Romney continues to show improved numbers in polls published since the presidential debate in Denver on Wednesday and has now made clear gains in the FiveThirtyEight forecast. The forecast gives him roughly a 20 percent chance of winning the Electoral College, up from about 15 percent before the debate. Mr. Romneys gains in the polls have been sharp enough that he should continue to advance in the FiveThirtyEight forecast if he can maintain his numbers over the next couple of days.

title: A 2012 Scorecard
description: The regular season, 2,430 games in all, produced memorable moments  from a rare triple crown to an unprecedented three perfect games.

title: New Somalian President Picks a Businessman, a Political Newcomer, as Prime Minister
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The new Somalian president, Hassan Sheik Mohamud, on Saturday evening named as prime minister a political novice who is expected to lead the council of ministers for the next four years, officials said.

title: Good Start for a Promoter Who Is New to the Game
description: There were four winners in the inaugural tournament of the 2012-13 Mens Grand Prix, including the series organizer.

title: Bloomberg Pushes a Plan to Let Midtown Soar
description: London, Tokyo and other metropolises have created central business districts with forests of skyscrapers in recent years, seeking to meet the needs of globe-trotting corporate tenants.

title: The Kimbell Art Museum Casts Major Shadow
description: Eric M. Lee, the director of Fort Worths Kimbell Art Museum  regarded by some as the countrys finest small museum  had his first day on the job three and a half years ago, but his admiration of the museum dates back to 1987, when he was an art history major at Yale.

title: In Rematch, Memories of a Stolen Moment
description: When the Yankees face the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday, inevitably the conversation in living rooms across the country will turn to the last time these teams met in the playoffs, in 1996, when 12-year-old Jeffrey Maiers reach over the right-field wall in Yankee Stadium helped turn the American League Championship Series.

title: Close 2-Team Marathon Now Turns Into a Sprint
description: BALTIMORE  The Yankees and the Orioles played each other six times in September and split those games. For the rest of the month, they played other teams in a playoff race by proxy, but the results were just as close.

title: Romney, Buoyed by Debate, Shows Off His Softer Side
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Mitt Romney walked off the debate stage on Wednesday night to find that his staff had already lined the hall backstage, greeting him with applause.

title: Carroll F. Johnson, Schools Integrator, Dies at 99
description: Carroll F. Johnson, a Southern-born educator who was one of the first superintendents to voluntarily use busing to integrate an urban school district, doing so in White Plains in the 1960s, died on Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 99.

title: Florida Validates Standing in the SEC, Toppling L.S.U.
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  After incremental steps at improvement against lesser opponents, the Florida Gators took a leap forward Saturday, beating Louisiana State, 14-6, and perhaps signaling a shift of power in the Southeastern Conference.

title: Howard H. Scott, a Developer of the LP, Dies at 92
description: Howard H. Scott, who was part of the team at Columbia Records that introduced the long-playing vinyl record in 1948 before going on to produce albums with the New York Philharmonic, Glenn Gould, Isaac Stern and many other giants of classical music, died on Sept. 22 in Reading, Pa. He was 92.

title: Shlomo Venezia Dies at 88; Wrote of Auschwitz Horror
description: Shlomo Venezia was one of the first Jews to climb out of the freight car when it came to the end of the line at the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Poland on April 11, 1944, his mother crammed behind him. Two blows from a German guards baton struck him in the back of the neck.

title: Changing Her Mind, a Queens Woman Decides to Remain on Life Support
description: A terminally ill Queens woman who won a court battle against her parents to allow a hospital to disconnect a breathing tube has decided that she wants to live out the rest of her life, the womans lawyer said Saturday.

title: Browns at Giants: Matchup to Watch
description: Browns (0-4) at Giants (2-2), 1 p.m. Eastern Sunday, CBS

title: Sven Hassel, Novelist Who Depicted Nazi Soldiers Lives, Dies at 95
description: Sven Hassel, a Danish-born writer whose pulp novels depicting grunt life in the Wehrmacht during World War II  drawn, he said, from his own combat experiences  sold millions of copies worldwide died on Sept. 21 in Barcelona, Spain. He was 95.

title: Even After Rains, Facing Long-Term Water Needs
description: SAN ANGELO  With its pretty rivers and lakes, this city of 95,000 people is sometimes called the oasis of West Texas. But San Angelo recently came within a year of running out of water, as it faced a severe drought that produced brown lawns, dying bushes and fear.

title: As Swing and Miss, Again and Again
description: DETROIT  Justin Verlander is the most durable and dominant starter in baseball, a three-time leader in strikeouts and innings who faced more batters this season than any other pitcher in the majors. His opponent on Saturday, the Oakland Athletics, seemed set up to fail against him in Game 1 of this American League division series.

title: Student IDs That Track the Students
description: SAN ANTONIO  For Tira Starr, an eighth grader at Anson Jones Middle School, the plastic nametag hanging around her neck that she has decorated with a smiley face and a purple bat sticker offers a way to reflect her personal flair. For administrators, it is something else entirely: a device that lets them use radio frequency technology  with scanners tucked behind walls and ceilings  to track her whereabouts.

title: No Child Left Behind. Just a Demographic.
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: College Football Replay
description: The day featured an upset of L.S.U. by Florida and an end to Northwesterns undefeated record.

title: Corrections: October 7, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: In Florida, a Look at the Challenges of Mailed Ballots
description: Votes cast by mail are less likely to be counted, more likely to be compromised and more likely to be contested than those cast in a voting booth, statistics show.

title: Error and Fraud at Issue as Absentee Voting Rises
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  On the morning of the primary here in August, the local elections board met to decide which absentee ballots to count. It was not an easy job.

title: Voting by Mail
description: The rise of voting by mail in the United States has been driven by several Western states.

title: Lottery Numbers
Spurriers Team Delivers a Pummeling and a Party
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Never had the fans here partied quite like this. Marcus Lattimore bobbed and weaved. Connor Shaw pulled and fired. The stadium physically rocked. Never had more people come to watch a South Carolina football game, and all 85,199 of them would leave  once the sixth-ranked Gamecocks beat No. 5 Georgia, 35-7  knowing the Head Ball Coach could still have fun.

title: Cara Forte, Gilberto Diaz
description: Cara Elyse Forte and Gilberto Alexi Diaz were married Saturday at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Floral Park, Queens. The Most Rev. Raymond F. Chappetto, an auxiliary bishop of the Diocese of Brooklyn, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Harris, Shawn Baxter
description: Jennifer Diana Harris and Shawn Baxter are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Noah Fabricant at the Cheesman Park Pavilion in Denver.

title: Lindsey Boylan, LeRoy Kim
description: Lindsey Claire Boylan and LeRoy Kim were married Saturday evening in Scarborough, N.Y. John P. Ellis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

title: Emily Cashman, Christopher Mills
description: Emily Aloise Cashman and Dr. Christopher Jackson Mills were married Saturday at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Carleen R. Gerber, a senior minister at the church and a Congregationalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Megan Murphy and Joshua Vlasto
description: Megan A. Murphy and Joshua J. Vlasto are to be married Sunday at Our Lady Seat of Wisdom Chapel at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Charles P. Keeney, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Leslie Pope, Burden Walker
description: Leslie Victoria Pope and Burden Hastings Walker are to be married Sunday evening at the William Aiken House, an event space in Charleston, S.C. Judge Thea A. Sherry of the Missouri Circuit Court in Clayton received permission from the Charleston County Probate Court to officiate.

title: Alexandra Galgano, Daniel Zaccagnino

description: Marisa Meg Olsen and John William Grosvenor are to be married Sunday at Castle Hill Inn, a hotel in Newport, R.I. Judge Peter B. Regan of the municipal court in Middletown, R.I., is to officiate.

description: Courtney Agnes ADoris Streett, the daughter of Diane Clarke Streett and W. Dennis Streett, both of Wilmington, Del., was married Saturday to John Eben Reynolds, the son of Mary Burns Reynolds and Alister Williams Reynolds of Newport, R.I. Canon Lloyd S. Casson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Andrews School in Middletown, Del. Sterling V. Street, a cousin of the bride and a member of the Nanticoke Indian tribe (as is the bride), gave a Native American blessing.

The Rev. John S. Mitchell, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Hildene Estate, a house in Manchester, Vt., once owned by Robert Todd Lincoln.

description: Elyse Silver Viner and Joshua Robert Cromer were married Saturday at Center548, an event site in New York. Rabbi David M. Steinhardt officiated.

description: Dr. Olive Simone Silbert Eckstein and Dr. Guillermo Manuel Suarez were married Saturday at Barr Mansion, a wedding site in Austin, Tex. Rabbi David S. Gruber officiated, with the Rev. Milton K. Raybould, a minister of the White Robed Monks of St. Benedict, taking part.

description: Elizabeth Erin McDonald and Eric Brent Powers are to be married Sunday at Caf Brauer at the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago. Judge Amy Berman Jackson of United States District Court for the District of Columbia will officiate, with Chief Judge James E. Baker of the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces taking part.

title: Tracy Long, Andrew Goodwin
description: Tracy Allen Long and Andrew Ford Goodwin were married Saturday evening at Keswick Hall, a hotel in Keswick, Va. The Rev. Neal D. Halvorson-Taylor, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Joanna Kleinberg and Daniel Romanow
description: Joanna Leigh Kleinberg and Daniel Neil Romanow were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Herbert Brockman officiated.

title: Lizzie Dunlap, William Gahagan

title: Nicole Murray, Juan Snchez
description: Dr. Nicole Malinda Murray and Juan Luis Snchez Jr. are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Basking Ridge Country Club in Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. David Jefferson Sr., a Baptist minister, is to officiate.

title: Megan Flanagan and Dwight Tompkins
description: Megan Frances Flanagan, a daughter of Carol Rooney Flanagan and James M. Flanagan of Greenwich, Conn., was married on Nantucket Saturday to Dwight Jameson Tompkins, a son of Sabina S. Tompkins and Richard L. Tompkins of White Plains. The Rev. Robert P. Henry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Siasconset Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass.

title: Mary Collins, Karl Metz
description: Mary Katherine Collins and Karl Joseph Metz were married Saturday in Brooklyn. Arnold Wonsever, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Music Pagoda in Prospect Park.

title: Ying Wu, Ryan Stevenson
description: Dr. Ying Wu and Dr. Ryan Lloyd Stevenson are to be married Sunday at the Delta View Golf Club in Pittsburg, Calif. Taylor C. Smith, a friend of the groom who was appointed a temporary deputy marriage commissioner by Contra Costa County for the event, is to officiate.

title: Rachel Chen, Robert Klipper
description: Rachel Chen, the daughter of Lisa Jin Chen and Shihua Chen of Rockville, Md., was married Saturday to Robert Conrad Klipper, a son of Rosemarie Klipper and Mitchell Scott Klipper of Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi James Ponet, a Yale chaplain, officiated at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club in Old Westbury, N.Y.

description: Penelope Thomas and Robert Eugene Signom III were married Saturday. The Rev. Sarah Segal McCaslin, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Players Club in New York.

description: Lisa Maria Keels and Jeffrey Harris Lowenstein were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Philadelphia. Rabbi Claire Green led an interfaith ceremony with the Rev. Dennis J. Carbonaro, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.
