title: Reader Idea | Students Create Video Ads for Historical Presidential Elections
description: An ad created by high school juniors  Aimee Nagao, Jennifer Scoville, Katoa Ahau and Kanoe Sakamoto  supporting Harry S. Truman in the 1948 election against Thomas E. Dewey.

title: Chiefs Player Jeers Fans Who Cheer Cassels Injury
description: Chiefs tackle Eric Winston criticized the home fans who cheered as quarterback Matt Cassel lay on the ground with what was later found to be a concussion.

title: A Regulatory Odd Couple
description: The Odd Couple: The S.E.C. and High-Frequency Traders | Regulators are getting help policing the rapid-fire markets from an unlikely source  the rapid-fire traders. Tradeworx, 45-person high-speed trading firm based in New Jersey, has designed a program that will allow the Securities and Exchange Commission to see every bid and offer on each of the nations 13 public stock exchanges. The system, akin to an X-ray machine for the stock market, could enable regulators to detect whether trading firms are overwhelming the markets plumbing when they rapidly submit and cancel orders, Nathaniel Popper and Ben Protess write in The New York Times. While critics contend the program is akin to the fox guarding the hen house, the trading firm defends its partnership with regulators. Where else are they going to be able to get these capabilities? said Manoj Narang, the chief executive of Tradeworx.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on What We Know About Ina Drew
description: Susan Dominus, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about Ina Drew, who was one of the most powerful women on Wall Street before resigning from JPMorgan Chase in May. In recent years, Dominus has written for the magazine on such subjects asa mysterious illness in Le Roy, N.Y., conjoined twins, the actress Kristen Wiigand The Hunger Games author Suzanne Collins. Her most recent article was about Jenny Craig in France.

title: And Now for Something Completely Literate: A Memoir From John Cleese
description: Speaking of authors who are not dead yet: whenever that Great Critic in the sky delivers His final assessment of John Cleese, the 72-year-old Monty Python co-founder should earn a place in comedy paradise just on the basis of his performance in the Ministry of Silly Walks skit. (To say nothing of the Dead Parrot and Cheese Shop bits.) Until then, Mr. Cleese may sometimes perambulate strangely but he still types perfectly fine, and he has agreed to write a book about his life that the Crown Archetype imprint of Random House said on Monday it had acquired.

title: Daily Report: When Patents Become Weapons
description: Last year, for the first time, spending by Apple and Google on patent lawsuits and unusually big-dollar patent purchases exceeded spending on research and development of new products, according to public filings. Many technology executives, economists and policy makers say the use of software patents as destructive weapons has corrupted the marketplace for new ideas, Charles Duhigg and Steve Lohr report in the latest installment in The New York Timess iEconomy series.

title: Monday Reading: Strategies for Saving on Holiday Airfares
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Hark, the Danger! Or Not
description: Did you hear how sympathizers of a notorious terrorism suspect tried to storm the federal courthouse off Foley Square over the weekend? No? Surely, then, you heard about the armed camp that Lower Manhattan became, with a ring of blue uniforms so thick that you couldnt walk south of Canal Street without being stopped by a police officer.

title: The Get | Latest Revivals Vintage Lanvin Necklace
description: The newest member of the niche e-commerce clique is Latest Revival, an online boutique that went live last month and specializes in estate gems, vintage bijoux and fine jewelry, old and new. Founded by Dalia Oberlander the site stocks an eclectic mix of pieces, many of them one-of-a-kind and curated from resources around the world. Today, a capsule collection of Lanvin costume jewelry from the 1970s goes on sale. Handpicked from the House of Lavande archives, the eight Deco-modern pieces start at $498 for a pair of red and gold zigzag button earrings and go up to about $2,500 for a more sculptural large-scale pendant necklace. Ts favorite is this hexagonal charm necklace with a diamond center and striking black frame. Its an exceptional example of Lanvins statements from the 70s, Oberlander says. Id wear it with current Lanvin or Cline.

title: Is it Time to Retire Indias Quota System?
Fact-checking Financial Recessions
description: Thats the title of a new piece by Taylor (the good one) and Schularick; it basically confirms Ken Rogoffs dictum that were suffering from a garden-variety severe financial crisis. Heres the picture:

title: What Were Reading
description: Culture: Since youve already got those new autumn novels by Zadie Smith, Michael Chabon and Junot Diaz piled up next to the bed, why not place a wheel of Parmigiano-Reggiano on top of the heap, too? Theres a lot of stuff to read on the rind, and heres some guidance on how to decipher it all.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Cloning and Stem Cell Work Earns Nobel
description: Two scientists who were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday helped lay the foundation for regenerative medicine, the hotly pursued though still distant idea of rebuilding the body with tissues generated from its own cells. They are John B. Gurdon of the University of Cambridge in England and Shinya Yamanaka of Kyoto University in Japan.

title: On Our Radar: Californias Runaway Gasoline Prices
description: As gasoline prices head toward $5 a gallon in California, Gov. Jerry Brown tells state regulators to relax smog controls so oil refineries can increase supplies of cheaper fuel. Meanwhile, police officers are contending with scattered cases of fuel theft from filling stations. [Bloomberg News, The Los Angeles Times]

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Debate Prep on S.N.L. and The F.T.s True Colors
description: Whats so funny about marginal tax rates? That was the question facing the writers and performers of Saturday Night Live who had to turn last weeks presidential debate into comedy in just five days. The usually secretive Lorne Michaels let Bill Carter watch the whole process.

title: Violence and Pepper Spray During Nasheeds Arrest in Maldives, Party Claims
description: The former president of the Maldives, Mohamed Nasheed, was detained on Monday for failing to turn up for a court hearing in a case involving the unlawful arrest of a High Court judge when Mr. Nasheed was president.

title: CNN Creates Documentary Unit
description: LOS ANGELES  CNN, laboring to make itself more relevant, has decided that part of the answer involves movies  at least the nonfiction kind  and on Monday plans to announce the creation of CNN Films.

title: Missing List of Names Widens Greek Political Fissure
description: ATHENS  Can a memory stick bring down a political order? That is the question in Greece, where a tragicomic debate over what became of a list of nearly 2,000 Greeks with Swiss bank accounts is rapidly turning into a full-blown political crisis that is imperiling Greeces fragile coalition government at a crucial time.

title: BP to Sell Texas City Refinery to Marathon Petroleum
description: BP said on Monday that it would sell its refinery in Texas City, Tex., and other assets to Marathon Petroleum for as much as $2.5 billion, as BP neared the completion of an aggressive plan to pare back assets.

title: Lena Dunham Signs Book Deal for More Than $3.5 Million
description: Random House has acquired a book by Lena Dunham, the 26-year-old writer, actor and filmmaker, in one of the most heated auctions of the year.

title: Trailer: Fresh Off the Boat
description: Vice.com teams up with Eddie Huang of Baohaus to present a new Web series.

title: Vain Glorious | Walk of Shame
description: What: Walk Of Shame Dry Shampoo by Cody Hepworth for Maximus Clark Salon at Oasis Day Spa.

title: Eddie Huang Gets His Own Show
description: Eddie Huang came screeching onto the New York food scene in late 2009, when he opened the first Baohaus, a storefront serving bao  stuffed steamed buns, Taiwanese style  on the Lower East Side. It was the combination of his bao and blog posts that endowed him with instant fame.

title: Using Patents as Legal Weapons
description: Business Day Live: How technology giants use patents to stymie innovation. | An environmental battle over the commercial use of peat. | Travelers pay to bypass airport security.

title: Image of the Day: Oct. 8
Monday Motorsports: Matt Kenseth Avoids the Big One at Talladega
description: Talladega Superspeedway, with its trioval design, four lanes of traffic and a backstretch measuring nearly 4,000 feet, encourages some of the highest speeds and most tightly packed competition on the Nascar Sprint Cup circuit. The race on Sunday illustrated how those factors can contribute to a chain reaction crash known in stock-car racing simply as the big one.

title: Barbra Streisand Finally Comes Home
description: Barbra Streisand is set to give her first concert ever in her hometown of Brooklyn. A 1981 documentary about her upbringing in Flatbush has a new moment of relevance.

title: Jay-Z Releasing Barclays Concert Album
description: Jay-Z is releasing an eight-song, extended-play record of songs recorded during his recent string of live concerts at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. The rapper, whose real name is Shawn Carter, announced the new EP, Live in Brooklyn, on Twitter. The message directed fans to iTunes, where the record can be ordered in advance. No track list has been released by iTunes yet, but it appears the $9.99 download of the album will include eight videos as well.

title: E-Health Opportunities for Seniors
description: Are you among the 47 percent of older Americans who have not yet entered the digital age? If so, youre likely to be missing out on a lot of e-health opportunities available to help you live well despite chronic ailments and encroaching physical limitations.

title: Baseballs Twists Match Footballs Turns
description: With the start of the baseball playoffs on hyperdrive and the N.F.L. season in full attention-hogging mode, Sunday felt like a day spent in a sports fun house. It was sensory overload, full of twists and hairpin turns, and a lot of what you saw seemed just a bit off from what youre used to.

title: When the Tax Tail Wags Your Investment Dog
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Aid Groups Push for Clean Energy
description: BARCELONAWhen Samantha Smith started working for the World Wildlife Fund more than a decade ago, she was stationed in the Arctic, where her work focused on the species she was trying to protect in that habitat.

title: U.S. Panel Cites Risks in Chinese Equipment
description: WASHINGTON  In the latest development to highlight the sensitive terrain that the United States and China are navigating on economic issues, a House committee issued a blistering bipartisan report on Monday that accused two of Chinas largest telecommunications companies of being arms of the government that had stolen intellectual property from American companies and could potentially spy on Americans.

title: High Lead Found in City-Sourced Eggs
description: TO the long list of food conundrums, add this: research has found elevated levels of lead in eggs from chickens in New York City public neighborhood gardens.

title: Rothko Vandalized at Tate Modern
description: A Rothko mural at the Tate Modern in London was vandalized on Sunday afternoon when a visitor applied what museum officials described as a small area of black paint with a brush to the painting. A photograph posted by a visitor, Tim Wright, on Twitter also shows the name Vladimir scrawled on the painting along with the phrase a potential piece of yellowism.

title: How Pennies Add Up in a Securities Fraud Case
description: We are used to hearing big numbers thrown around in securities fraud cases, like the purported $64 billion in losses from the Ponzi scheme perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff or $7 billion by R. Allen Stanford. What sometimes gets overlooked is how conduct involving relatively small amounts can add up to millions of dollars if allowed to go on long enough.

title: Discontent Over Renaming of Kabul College Turns Into Violence
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The student, a social sciences major named Abdul Basir, was in the middle of giving an interview on Monday about why he did not want his university renamed.

title: Street Style: Caps
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Oct. 1.

title: Transcript: Mitt Romney Remarks at Virginia Military Institute
description: The following is the full text of Mitt Romneys speech on foreign policy as delivered on Monday at the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington, Va. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service)

title: The Non-Euclidean Geometry of Whales
Remembering a Film About Brooklynites Who Were All About Streisand
description: Come back to Brooklyn and give us a concert.

title: Snake Charmer
description: After 31 years of wrapping precious stones in gold, the jeweler veteran Paul Morelli has added handbags to his range. And it turns out that leather goods were always on his mind: Its not like I was going to start making candelabras, he explains. But he wasnt going to do just any old tote, either. I wanted to steer away from what everyone else was doing  the minimal bag, if you will. The 40-piece collection centers on an array of skins  fur, alligator, python, you name it  made (in Philadelphia) into hobo bags, satchels and minaudires. Every piece comes embellished with Morellis signature gold meditation bells, an exotic counterpoint to the lines classic shapes (as in the $2,895 leather envelope clutch seen here) and a way of creating what the designer calls a casual evening vibe. Go to paulmorelli.com.

title: Dont Apologize, Dont Explain (but You Can Confess Here)
description: I recently confessed one of my darkest kitchen secrets  that if I mess up a dish, Ill often just change the name and serve it anyway. Its a strategy Ive been using for years, ever since, taking a cue from bitter melons, I changed the name of my baba ghanouj to bitter eggplant salad. As in, that thread of bitterness running through the dish was supposed to be there. (Not.)

title: Strict New Procedures for Iran Currency Trading After Protest
description: TEHRAN  Iranian police officers moved to arrest unlicensed currency dealers and increase patrols in the center of the capital on Monday to prevent unofficial trading from disrupting new government-imposed rates of exchange for the national currency, the rial.

title: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
description: This weeks birthdays include one of my favorite writers, Elmore Leonard, hardly a boomer, but an author whose books of snappy dialogue, black humor and characters of questionable character influenced this generation of writers and are pure joy to read. There may not be anyone who can set a plot in motion with fewer words than Mr. Leonard. Take a look at this interview with him where he describes how he writes. Like a lot of gifted people, he makes what he does sound very simple.

title: What They Wore When the Impressionists Painted
description: PARISThe Belle poque has never seemed such an orgy of gorgeousness as it does in Impressionisme et la Mode at the Muse dOrsay, Suzy Menkes writes in her review of the exhibition.

title: My 6 Biggest Complaints About Business Travel
description: Although TerraCycle still has less than $20 million a year in annual revenue, it operates in 21 countries now. That means that my intense domestic travel  Minneapolis to Racine, Wisconsin, to Chicago  has morphed into intense global travel  Newark to Bogot, Colombia, to Tel Aviv.

title: Look of The Moment | Bella Heathcote
description: The Look: Jean Queen. A denim dress with matching blue nails and eyes gets the royal treatment with a Victorian neckline, hip-bustled skirt and embroidered bib front.The Girl: The actress Bella Heathcote, who stars in Not Fade Away, at the films screening at the Hamptons Film Festival in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: For Protectors of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, an Unlikely Ally
description: There are so many ways a city park like Flushing Meadows-Corona Park can die.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Believe Media, Los Angeles, opened a digital and interactive division, iBelieve, to be led by the director David van Eyssen, who worked with Luke Thornton, an owner of Believe Media along with Liz Silver, when the company was started in 2000.

title: Romney Says White House Botched Response to Benghazi Attack
description: 5:39 p.m. | Updated LEXINGTON, Va.  After weeks of refraining from dipping back into the sensitive topic of the attack that killed the American ambassador in Libya, Mitt Romney on Monday offered harsh criticism of the administration for being slow to label the assault terrorism and faulted its overall handling of the attack.

title: Weighing the Effect of an Exit of Centrists
description: WASHINGTON  While the occupant of the White House and the composition of the next Congress are still to be decided, one thing is clear: there will be many fewer moderate politicians here next year.

title: A Documentary-Only Film Theater for New York
description: The Downtown Community Television Center, a nonprofit organization devoted to documentary film education, will begin construction in March on a $3.2 million documentary-only movie theater, center officials said. The theater, in the centers Chinatown home, will show first-run nonfiction films throughout the year, providing a meeting place for established and emerging filmmakers and their audiences.

title: Detroit Police Chief Resigns Over Affair With Officer
description: A sex scandal in Detroit has forced out its chief of police, the second person in two years to resign from the position after being accused of inappropriate relations with a female officer.

title: Kretschmer Campaign Has More Than a Germ of an Idea
description: Another venerable grocery brand is seeking some time in the spotlight again.

title: Still Housing the Needy, In a Changed Manhattan
description: In a wide-open ballroom in Manhattan last week, a room with gilded columns and dark herringbone floors, men and women in dark suits sat at a reception for a retiring city official, listening to speeches as they munched on tidy portions of chicken and salad greens.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Romney at the Military Institute
description: Well have an editorial up soon on Mitt Romneys foreign policy speech at the Virginia Military Institute, but I wanted to quickly draw attention to his comments on Syria and Iran, and to a new survey of American public opinion on the Middle East.

title: Researchers Wring Hands as U.S. Clamps Down on Death Record Access
description: A shift last year by the Social Security Administration to limit access to its death records amid concerns about identity theft is beginning to hamper a range of research, including federal assessments of hospital safety and efforts by the financial industry to spot consumer fraud.

title: Motif Mash-Up
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: When Parents Too Invested in College Admissions Make Their Children Anxious
description: When several thousand guidance counselors and college admissions officers get together, they swap stories about students essays, scores, meltdowns.

title: Kiss Evokes Era When a Tigers Pitcher Only Talked to the Ball
description: It should not be surprising that the Detroit Tigers have a player who chose to kiss the ball before tossing it to first base in the ninth inning of a playoff game. After all, the team had a player in the 1970s who would have entire conversations with an inanimate object.

title: Digital Notes: Streaming Music Service Raises $130 Million
description: Deezer, a streaming music service that is a competitor to Spotify around the world, has raised $130 million in investment from Access Industries, the company that last year bought the Warner Music Group for $3.3 billion.

title: SolarCity Seeks Up to $201 Million in I.P.O.
description: The entrepreneur Elon Musk isnt a stranger to daunting business propositions, from electric cars to space travel. Now, a solar company that he chairs is attempting to take on another risky venture: going public.

title: More L.G.B.T. Characters on Television
description: TimesCast Media + Tech: Lesbian, gay, bi-sexual, and transgender characters become increasingly common on television. | The future of 3-D printing.

title: Honda Recalls 269,000 CR-Vs for Fire Hazard
description: In its latest recall to address a fire hazard traceable to the drivers door in some of its vehicles, Honda ordered a recall of almost 269,000 CR-V crossovers from the 2002-6 model years. The problem relates to a master switch that controls the vehicles power windows.

title: The War Goes to College
description: On Oct. 6, 1862, the faculty of South Carolina College, located in the state capital of Columbia, gathered for a meeting. They had nothing to discuss regarding the curriculum or student discipline. Instead, they met to acknowledge officially a simple fact: the college was closed. Over the summer, they recorded in their minutes, the Confederacy had converted the school into a military hospital. The students were all gone and no classes would meet again for several years. South Carolina College, like colleges across America and especially in the South, had been turned to serve the needs of the Civil War.

title: Mitt Romney's Speech on Foreign Policy
description: Mitt Romney delivered remarks focused on foreign policy at the Virginia Military Institute on Monday in Lexington, Va.

title: Tech Companies in Patent Wars
description: October 8, 2012 - Outdated patent system struggles to adapt for tech companies.

title: Walkabout  10/8: An Unending Check In and The Bright Side of Apple Maps
description: A Suite Called Home Two women have outlasted a change of ownership, renovations and even the arrival of key cards at the Hotel Wales in Manhattan. They have no plans to check out soon. (The New York Times)

title: A New Tooth, Made to Order in Under an Hour
description: I was chewing a piece of steak on a Saturday night last month when an old filling shattered. Suddenly, along with steak I had chunks of gray amalgam and shards of tooth in my mouth. I felt the hole with my tongue  it seemed as large as a crater.

title: New Label Alert | Maggy Frances
description: Its not super-innovative, its not at all avant-garde and its not about being trendy, says the 24-year-old designer Maggy Schultz about her line, Maggy Frances. Despite the fashion editors never-less-than-new-new mind-set, the notion of Schultzs versatile and thoughtful, but not all that creative, uniform dressing, might be the freshest news out there. The collection is made up of multiples of the same silhouette  skater dress, customizable skirt, hot pants, Italian-wool blazer, silk blouse and cashmere sweater  cut in a variety of prints, plaids and solid colors.

title: The Caucus Click: From the Military Institute to the Schoolyard
Science Times Podcast
description: From this weeks special section, The Digital Doctor: two generations of physicians, and their tools; electronic medical records, and reaching teens via text about their health.

title: Los Angeles Kosher: Beyond Corned Beef and a Knish
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Doctors Bag for the New Millennium
description: When I was a medical student in Madras, India, in the late 1970s, my uncle, a retired physician, still made occasional house calls. In his early years he delivered babies in dimly lighted huts, often resorting to high forceps on the head  something that is rarely done now. His compounder  the man who would compound his prescription of mistura carminativa and dispense it in corked glass bottles  carried my uncles medical bag. It was almost like a trunk  a mobile office. The compounder became so experienced from watching my uncle that he secretly began a practice of his own, delivering babies and even applying forceps.

title: Amid Newfound Glory, Echoes of Old Detroit
description: For more than a century, the city of Detroit has been driven by a pair of powerful but erratic engines: cars and sports. Detroiters are no strangers to the sorrows these engines can bring: layoffs, factory shutdowns, losing streaks, even winless seasons. Yet, many Detroiters are feeling giddy these days. The auto industry has come roaring back from the brink of ruin, and the Tigers are back in the playoffs for the second straight year  routine stuff in the Bronx, perhaps, but something that hasnt happened in the Motor City since the 1930s.

title: Foreign-Language Oscar Candidates Welcome a New Entrant: Kenya
description: LOS ANGELES  Kenya for the first time joined the countries submitting a candidate for the best foreign-language film Oscar, as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced its list of 71 official entries.

title: Qatar Airways Is Latest in Middle East to Join Alliance
description: The global airline alliances are moving into the Middle East.

title: In Search of Answers From Mr. Romney
description: Mitt Romney mounted a big foreign policy display on a flag-draped stage at the Virginia Military Institute on Monday, serving up a lot of tough-sounding sound bites and hawkish bumper stickers, some of them even bumping up somewhere close to the truth, to give the appearance that he would be stronger and more forceful on international affairs than President Obama.

title: Globetrotters Help Break In Barclays
description: Jay-Zs series of concerts may have been the official opener of Barclays Center in Brooklyn, but the first sporting event to take place in the new home of the Brooklyn Nets was considerably more kid-friendly.

title: Frustrating Hurdle at Customs
description: The governments trusted traveler program has proved itself more popular than officials expected, with 1.2 million people now eligible to speed up their entry to this country using a self-service kiosk rather than waiting to speak to a customs agent at the airport.

title: Britain Rethinks Its Opposition to a Two-Tier Europe
description: LONDON

title: Texting the Teenage Patient
description: The teenagers cellphone buzzes. Her doctor, Natasha Burgert, is texting her: Better morning with this medication?

title: Nurtured by Nature
description: Pomme Chans quirky illustrations have charmed the likes of Marc Jacobs, Diane von Furstenberg and Nike, who slapped her nature-inspired drawings on ads, a store and shoes, respectively. This year Chan, a Bangkok native and London resident, has branched out with a brand of her own called What If. Available at her online shop, Chans line includes dresses, cushions, handkerchiefs and scarves with her signature designs, which might be described as falling somewhere between an Herms pattern, a Dal drawing and an Ernst Haeckel print.

title: Screenwriter Found for Fifty Shades Film Adaptation
description: Having whipped the best-seller lists into submission, E L Jamess erotic novel Fifty Shades of Grey is now inspiring a bit of cultural whiplash with the announcement on Monday that a screenwriter has been hired to adapt the novel into a feature film.

title: Syria Rebukes Turkey as Artillery Fight Continues
description: Syria escalated tensions with Turkey on Monday, accusing its neighbor and former friend of imperialist delusions reminiscent of Ottoman dynastic rule, as Syrian Army gunners exchanged artillery blasts with their Turkish counterparts across the border for the sixth consecutive day.

title: With Madness in Its Rear View, a Triumphant Duesenberg Heads to Hershey
description: A further chapter in the sputtering, 80-year-old saga known as Madness at Muroc, a tale of dry-lake racing, high-stakes gambling, million-dollar cars and Hollywood hot-rodders, is about to be written.

title: More Turnover in the Juilliard String Quartet
description: The Juilliard String Quartet alumni association is about to grow. Samuel Rhodes, the groups violist since 1969, will step down from the group at the end of this season, the Juilliard School said on Monday. Roger Tapping, who was born in 1960, will take his place in September, becoming the 14th man (there have been no women) to claim membership in a club that has lasted continuously since 1946. Mr. Tapping, 52, a former member of the Takacs Quartet, teaches viola at the New England Conservatory and will leave to join Juilliards faculty. Mr. Rhodes, 71, will continue to direct the viola department at Juilliard, the school said. Mr. Rhodes is the second person in the viola position, having taken over for Raphael Hillyer. The last original member to leave the Juilliard Quartet was Robert Mann, the first violinist, who stepped down in 1997. The remaining current members are Joseph Lin and Ronald Copes, violinists, and Joel Krosnick, cellist.

title: Redefining Medicine With Apps and iPads
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dr. Alvin Rajkomar was doing rounds with his team at the University of California, San Francisco Medical Center when he came upon a puzzling case: a frail, elderly patient with a dangerously low sodium level.

title: Jobs  Jack Welch  and Cooking the Books
description: As the news from Fridays jobs report emerged, so did some strange interpretations.

title: Strides in Medicine, and Their Price
description: Medicine has advanced more in the last century than in all of previous history, and technologys fingerprints can be found on most of the gains  from new ways to teach medical students to care of patients in hospitals with the most sophisticated equipment to everyday practice in offices. Technology has even helped eradicate a disease, smallpox.

title: Obamacare and Middle Class Families
description: President Obama outlines his plan to help families maintain affordable healthcare during the debate.

title: Broadway and Dey Street, 12:45 P.M.
Mobile Devices 'On Call' in Hospitals
description: At hospitals around the country, mobile devices, including smartphones and tablet computers, are becoming critical to efficient and precise patient care.

title: Obama Campaign Hits Back on Romney Foreign Policy Speech
description: KEENE, Calif.  The Obama campaign hit back aggressively on Monday at Mitt Romneys charge that President Obama has not led on foreign policy, accusing him of an erratic, unsteady and irresponsible national security strategy that could endanger the United States and alienate allies.

title: Online, a Genome Project for the World of Art
description: Any music fan knows that there are myriad ways to find new songs online: a scroll through digital playlists and streaming radio services like Pandora, which serve as musical recommendation engines. Likewise, Netflix subscribers are regularly showered with suggestions for, say, romantic comedies and horror films, based on previously viewed movies.

title: Hours Before Suicide, Former City Official Betrayed Little in an E-Mail
description: It would be comforting to think that a man about to end his own life makes a certain noise, a howl, a scream, anything to telegraph an approaching moment that once it arrives, cannot be undone.

title: Mile by Mile: Where the Marathon Begins
description: When more than 45,000 runners line up to start the New York City Marathon on Nov. 4, the foot of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in Staten Island will be like a shaken soda bottle.

title: Friends Remember David Foster Wallace at New Yorker Festival
description: Last weekend was a busy time for bookworms who wanted to make the most of the annual New Yorker Festival, which featured appearances by Marilynne Robinson, Zadie Smith, George Saunders and many other literary luminaries.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A Supersonic Plunge, and Marissa Mayers Journey
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: With Telemedicine as Bridge, No Hospital Is an Island
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.  When Sarah Cohens acne drove her to visit a dermatologist in July, thats what she figured shed be doing  visiting a dermatologist. But at the hospital on Nantucket, where her family spends summers, Ms. Cohen, 19, was perplexed.

title: Case Study | Presto Chango, Limoncello!
description: At the close of a recent meal at Cathy Whimss standout Italian restaurant Nostrana in Portland, Ore., my table-mates and I found ourselves seeking a bibulous dessert of some type. Usually that would mean vin santo for me, but as I was dining with a distiller, I thought the house-made limoncello I spied on the menu might be of greater interest. Its one of those things you never think about, limoncello, until it pops up as a suddenly great idea: that dazzling bright yellow, half-frozen, lemony tang, like an adult slushie. Though it is also sweet, its penetrating citrine pop cuts like the Jaws of Life at the close of a hearty meal.

title: The Ups and Downs of Electronic Medical Records
description: The case for electronic medical records is compelling: They can make health care more efficient and less expensive, and improve the quality of care by making patients medical history easily accessible to all who treat them.

title: Kovalchuk Takes Scoring Touch to Russia
description: Ilya Kovalchuk, turning out to be as prolific in Russia as he was in the N.H.L., scored a hat trick Monday, sparking SKA St. Petersburg to a 4-2 victory over hosts CSKA Moscow in a K.H.L. match.

title: WFAN Finds Another Home, on the FM Dial
description: 6:46 p.m. | Updated For a quarter-century, WFAN been a staple of AM radio, the band where sports talk stations blossomed. From Pete Franklin to Mike and the Mad Dog to Boomer and Carton, WFAN was first heard at 1050 on the dial, then at 660, where WNBC once reigned.

title: Smashed Guitars and Other Damage
description: No one knows what its like to be the bad man, Pete Townshend wrote in a famous Who song, To be the sad man behind blue eyes/No one knows what its like/To be hated, to be fated to telling only lies.

title: Television Becomes More LGBT Friendly
description: There are more gay and lesbian characters on network television this season than ever before according to a study released Friday by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.

title: Fifth Avenue, 12:51 P.M.
Which HT to Treat: Hypertension or Hammertoe?
description: You can jump into a swimming pool, you can dive, or you can inch across the shallow end, making faces and shrieking. But no matter how you immerse yourself, youve still got to swim once youre in.

title: Bringing My White Boyfriend Home to Mom
description: Is interracial dating still such a big deal for people to grasp?

title: The Patent, Used as a Sword: An Outtake From the 1980s
description: In the long narrative tour of the patent system published on Monday, The Patent, Used as a Sword,  one story line is the strategy of Apple as it seeks to fend off competition in the smartphone market. Apples main rival, of course, is Google and the handset makers that use its Android software.

title: The Polling Conspiracy
description: Ive been waiting for the polling conspiracy theorists to notice the Pew Poll that came out today, with the headline Romneys Strong Debate Performance Erases Obamas Lead.

title: I.M.F. Lowers Its Forecast for Global Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund is cutting its global economic forecasts yet again, calling the risks of a slowdown alarmingly high, primarily because of policy uncertainty in the United States and Europe.

title: Buyout Funds Lift Carlyle in 3rd Quarter
description: Since going public, the Carlyle Group has emphasized the breadth of its investment activities. But in the third quarter, its traditional business of buying and selling companies generated the most growth among its many funds.

title: Recalibrating Therapy for Our Wired World
description: Speed, instant gratification, accessibility  these are a few of the appealing hallmarks of digital technology. Its no coincidence that we love our smart wireless devices: Humans are a notoriously impatient species, born with a preference for immediate rewards.

title: Pew Poll Shows Romney Advancing
description: Mitt Romneys strong performance at the debate last week has wiped out President Obamas lead in the latest national poll conducted by the Pew Research Center.

title: Austen-Con
description: The Jane Austen Society of North America held its annual convention last weekend at the Brooklyn Marriott.

title: Westerners With Roots in Syria Trickle In to Help Rebels
description: The night before leaving his parents home in Wayne, Tex., to join the rebels trying to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad in Syria, Obaida Hitto left a bouquet of white roses for his mother, with a sterling silver locket and a note: Youve made me what I am. But now I need to go and do what I need to do.

title: More Is the Mantra at This Festival
description: In its final week, the 50th edition of the New York Film Festival aims high and hits the mark again and again. This years main slate of 33 features offers a dynamic mixed bag of the sincere and the delirious, the predictable and the I-didnt-see-that-coming unexpected. There are 11 titles from the main slate playing for the first time at the festival between now and Sunday, when this latest edition comes to a starry end with four sold-out screenings of Robert Zemeckiss Flight and a Denzel Washington performance that will be talked about until the next Oscars.

title: Lots of Pride, a Little Prejudice
description: In 1979 about 100 people gathered at the Gramercy Park Hotel for the inaugural gathering of the Jane Austen Society of North America, dressed in a style The New Yorker summed up as dinner dresses, subdued-looking jewelry, comfortable-looking jackets.

title: Cuomo Backs Queens Senator Caught in a Tight Race
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat who has carefully avoided saying whether he wants his own party to retake the State Senate, on Monday endorsed a Democratic state senator from Queens who is locked in a tight re-election battle.

title: Altidore Left Off U.S. Roster for Qualifiers
description: United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann announced his roster Monday for the teams coming World Cup qualifiers at Antigua and against Guatemala, and it was as notable for the names on it as it was for the ones that were missing.

title: Why I Dont Fly With Anyone Elses Clothes
description: I GREW up flying. My wife thinks Im crazy because I enjoy it so much. I mean, where else do you get to watch TV or read a book uninterrupted, and have someone tell you when its time to eat? Its like being in perpetual preschool.

title: From the Land of Angry Birds, a Mobile Game Maker Lifts Off
description: For a country with a population about the size of Minnesota, Finland has produced some giant global hits in the mobile business, like the phone maker Nokia and Rovio, the company responsible for Angry Birds and Bad Piggies. A Finnish mobile games start-up called Supercell wants its crack at glory too.

title: Wal-Mart and AmEx in Prepaid Card Deal
description: Wal-Mart Stores is taking another leap into the banking world, announcing on Monday a prepaid card and debit account with American Express that will give low-income consumers access to features like smartphone deposits.

title: Prospect Park Lake, 3:35 P.M.
Highlights and Analysis From Game 2 of Yankees-Orioles
description: After a 2-2 tie lingered for much of Game 1 of the American League division series, the Yankees rallied late to beat the Orioles in Baltimore, sparked by a ninth-inning home run by Russell Martin and strong pitching from C.C. Sabathia.

title: On Display, a Spiegelman Mural
description: Installation took place, above, on Monday of Art Spiegelmans glass-paneled mural Today, Only Yesterday in the new High School of Art and Design building in Manhattan. Mr. Spiegelman, who created the Pulitzer Prize-winning Maus, is a graduate of the school.

title: Pictures of the Day: Venezuela and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Venezuela, Kashmir, Sudan and Germany.

title: Sending a Message by Tooting Their Horns
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass.  On a rainy Saturday night here more than 100 revelers jigged to The Smash-a-Bank Polka. They chanted Rise up! Get down! and stomped their feet. Three members of a brass band used a homemade concoction of duct tape and rubber cement to set the ends of their trumpets on fire, then kept playing. Everyone cheered and sang. Heres to the bands in the streets! they belted out, fists pumping in time with the drums. It was hard to tell where the politics ended and the party began at the Honk! festival of activist street bands, which ran for five days, starting on Thursday, in this Boston suburb.

title: Honk! Festival in Massachusetts
description: The festival of activist street bands ran for five days in Somerville, Mass.

title: Laboratories Seek New Ways to Take a Look Inside
description: STANFORD, Calif.  In a bioengineering laboratory at Stanford University, Christopher Contag, a microbiologist, is designing new approaches to virtual pathology. He has created a variety of instruments that can travel the esophagus, stomach and intestine, allowing pathologists to probe for cancers by peering in three dimensions below the surface of the skin.

title: Indian Fusion and Traditional Hula
description: With buttocks, torsos and legs bare and handsomely muscular, the 11 male performers of Ka Leo O Laka I Ka Hikina O Ka La, closing Fall for Dances fourth program on Thursday night, created a frisson made up of odd contradictions. There was a touch of Chippendales about their attire  garlands and jockstraps in a very fetching green  and yet their manner was earnest. Their dances (the choreography was by Kumu Hula Kaleo Trinidad) were largely a mixture of ritual and martial arts, vividly showing firm rhythms on the spot to face left, front and right.

title: Knicks Take Cautious Approach With Wallaces Return
description: Rasheed Wallace wore his No. 36 practice jersey backward Monday, as he did at practice last week, and again he was on the sideline.

title: New Albums by Mountain Goats, Kurt Elling and Trash Talk
description: THE MOUNTAIN GOATS

title: Making the Standup Routine Less Routine
description: People who for some reason think that standup comedy is moribund might find something to like in Mash Up, T. J. Millers new show on Comedy Central. But anyone who feels that standup is in the midst of an enjoyable renaissance  which it is  is likely to find the series more annoying than innovative.

title: Fossilizing With a Camera
description: In a corner of his airy studio looking down on the High Line in Chelsea, Hiroshi Sugimoto maintains a kind of private natural history museum, a choice paring from the immense collection of wunderkammer artifacts he has amassed since becoming one of the art worlds most successful photographers.

title: Amid Volatile Polling, Keep an Eye on Election Fundamentals
description: After a summer in which the polling in the presidential race was exceptionally stable  withPresident Obama generally holding a lead of about two percentage points in national surveys  the numbers since the party conventions have been a wild ride.

title: Apps Alert the Doctor When Trouble Looms
description: For many patients with chronic medical conditions like depression, pain or diabetes, the pattern is predictable: The more they suffer, the more they draw inward. Doctors may not see them until they are in crisis and show up in an emergency room.

title: Kelly Says Shooting of Unarmed Man Warrants a Grand Jury Investigation
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said that the moments leading up to last weeks fatal shooting of an unarmed motorist on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens remained unclear, and warrant grand jury scrutiny.

title: Age-Old Fixes for Indias Water
description: INDIAS monsoon rains are retreating this week, a delayed end to a yearly wet season that has become ever more unpredictable as a result of global warming. Of all the challenges that face India, few are more pressing than how it manages water. In vast cities like New Delhi, where showers and flush toilets have become necessities for a rapidly expanding middle class, groundwater has been depleted. New Delhi once had many ponds and an open floodplain to absorb the monsoon and replenish aquifers; now the sprawling city has more concrete and asphalt than it has ponds and fields to absorb water.

title: A Few Well-Chosen Words Pay the Fare for Some
description: THAT white-knuckled flier sitting across the aisle muttering anxiously may well have a case of fear of flying. But it may also be a case of fear of public speaking.

title: Daredevil Sets Sight on a 22-Mile Fall
description: ROSWELL, N.M.  Whatever the leap means for mankind, it should definitely be one giant step for a man.

title: Romney in the Rain
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.  The rain fell in sheets, turning the grass into a muddy bog, and prompting women to shuck their shoes to go barefoot. Mitt Romney gave an 11-minute abbreviated stump speech, joking at an outdoor rally, Im not going to go through all this in great detail because youve been here for a little while in this sunshine.

title: Pepsi and Coke to Post Calories of Drinks Sold in Vending Machines
description: Big beverage makers including Pepsico and Coca-Cola are retooling their vending machines to let consumers know the number of calories in the drinks available to buy.

title: Georgian Leader Emerges as an Enigma
description: TBILISI, Georgia  More than 20 years since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the West has become familiar with a wide variety of leaders to emerge in this space  Soviet apparatchiks, fierce nationalists, K.G.B.-trained strongmen  but Bidzina Ivanishvili, nominated Monday as Georgias next prime minister, does not resemble any of them, not even remotely.

title: Investors Billion-Dollar Fraud Fighter
description: A few days after securing the largest shareholder recovery arising from the financial crisis  $2.43 billion from Bank of America  the plaintiffs lawyer Max W. Berger was not taking a victory lap.

title: For Rookies, Its Ready, Set, Throw
description: The symbolism Sunday was almost impossible to miss. Moments before the duel of the best quarterbacks of their era began, and ultimately fizzled, the next generation kept the N.F.L. spellbound, a comforting reminder that even after Tom Brady and Peyton Manning step away from the scene in a few years, football will remain in the hands of those who may even top them.

title: You Pay the Toll. Where Should That Money Go?
Mr. Mayor, Please Save the Majesty of Midtown
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Women as Priests?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Big Bird? Is That Part of Starve the Beast?
description: To the Editor:
