description: To the Editor:

title: In California, Growing Diversity First Made Its Mark
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is a look at California, the Golden State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Larry Gerston, a political science professor at San Jose State University; Thad Kousser, an associate professor of political science at the University of California, San Diego; and Bruce Cain, a profesor of political science at Stanford University.

title: Europe Tells Greece to Speed Up Economic Reform
description: LUXEMBOURG  International officials told Greece on Monday night to accelerate the pace of economic reform in exchange for further financing from a stalled bailout package. Jean-Claude Juncker, the head of the Eurogroup of finance ministers, told a news conference that 89 so-called prior actions like overhauling labor and pension laws that were agreed to with Greece in March needed to be implemented, at the latest, by Oct. 18.

title: Three Strikes of Injustice
description: A documentary profiles Shane Taylor, one of more than 4,000 nonviolent offenders serving life in California prisons under a three-strikes law.

title: Three Strikes of Injustice
description: In 1994, California voters passed the harshest three-strikes law in the country. Soon after, stories began to emerge about people receiving life sentences for petty crimes such as stealing a pair of gloves or a slice of pizza. Such cases challenged the commonly held belief that the law applied only to violent criminals.

title: Radicalism Prompts Warnings in France
description: PARIS  Jewish and Muslim leaders here warned on Monday of rising anti-Semitism among young Muslims, two days after the police arrested 11 men and fatally shot one in raids in a handful of cities  aimed at young radical French Muslims.

title: Ruths Chris Serves Up Steak and Inspiration for Women
description: ITS been belabored in womens magazines and among women themselves that eating foods like bread can lead to social isolation, a dormant love life and belly fat that could sentence women to a wardrobe of muumuus. There have been knocks, too, on avocados, egg yolks and the ever-menacing blueberry muffin.

title: Jets Trying to Plug Some Holes in Their Run Defense
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Middle linebacker David Harris was well aware the Jets ranked 31st among the 32 N.F.L. teams in rushing defense through their first four games. It was not only embarrassing, but problematic.

title: At Long Last, Dignity?
description: Cape Neddick, Me.

title: A Big Test for Gay Marriage
description: For supporters of same-sex marriageand for opponents, toothis Election Day is a pivotal one, an opportunity for voters in Maine, Maryland and Washington to make history and do something that voters across America have never done before. My Tuesday column looks at one Maine residents feelings about that.

title: Cuban One Reason Williams Stayed With Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The balance of power in the N.B.A. and the future of basketball in Brooklyn may have been decided by a single meeting in July. Or, more specifically, by a single absence at that meeting.

title: Facebook Offers to Sweeten Deal to Settle Sponsored Stories Suit
description: Facebook says a form of advertising known as Sponsored Stories is its most promising money-maker. Sponsored Stories dont seem like advertisements exactly; they are simply notices on your page that your friend X likes Y. They cost virtually nothing to produce (X doesnt get paid), and because they take up very little real estate, they can be easily shown on a mobile device, which is precisely where Facebook is struggling to make money.But Sponsored Stories are also proving to be a legal headache for the company. Efforts to settle a class action lawsuit involving them have stumbled. Now, Facebook has offered to sweeten the deal, in effect offering to compensate millions of users whose names and pictures were used in a Sponsored Stories ad with $10 apiece.

title: Mexico Gang Leader Held in Massacre of Migrants
description: MEXICO CITY  In the grim reckoning of horrors in Mexicos drug war, the massacres of San Fernando are among the most haunting. The victims were dozens of migrants hauled from buses and trucks heading north and killed, their bodies left on an abandoned ranch and stuffed into mass graves.

title: Thousands Exposed to Tainted Steroid, C.D.C. Says
description: About 13,000 people may have been exposed to the tainted steroid that has been linked to a growing outbreak of fungal meningitis, a spokesman for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Monday. The outbreak has killed 8 people and sickened 97 others in 23 states. More cases are expected.

title: Ireland Plans Bold Measures to Lift Housing
description: DUBLIN  With its economy still reeling from the housing crash, Ireland is making a bold move to help tens of thousands of struggling homeowners.

title: Dangerous Intersection
description: I dont know much about camels, having ridden one only once (and that was enough). But from what Ive been told, you can usually add another piece of straw to a camels burden without ill effect.

title: Is There a Constitution in This Text?
description: Akhil Reed Amar, a professor of law at Yale, begins his new book, Americas Unwritten Constitution, by calling our attention to two places in Article 1, Section 3 of the Constitution. The first declares that the Vice President of the United States shall be the President of the Senate. The second reads, When the President of the United States is tried, the Chief Justice will preside.

title: Allied World Assurance Buys Stake in MatlinPatterson
description: Allied World Assurance, a publicly traded insurance company, has acquired a substantial minority interest in MatlinPatterson, the private equity and hedge fund firm, according to people briefed on the deal.

title: Orioles Comeback Story Is Rewritten
description: BALTIMORE  If the Orioles could have described an ideal setup for deciding Game 1 of their American League division series, based on how their season has gone, it might have looked awfully similar to Sunday night.

title: Answering Questions About Twitters C.E.O.
description: Over the weekend I profiled Dick Costolo, a former improv comedian who is now the chief executive of Twitter. We asked readers to submit questions about Mr. Costolo and Twitter via social media. Here are the questions and answers.

title: For 17 Years, No Development as Insiders Held Rights to Bronx Eyesore
description: In 1995, a Bronx Democratic Party power broker and judge-maker named Stanley Schlein gathered up two politically connected friends and embarked on a treasure hunt.

title: South Africa Has a Black Idol. The Surprise Is That Its a First.
description: JOHANNESBURG  When Khaya Mthethwa breathed out the last notes of Nicki Minajs Super Bass, a song he had heard for the first time that same day, the judges of Idols SA, the South African version of American Idol, were blown away.

title: Misleading Advice for Student Borrowers
description: Federal student loan default rates are rising ever higher, with the worst rates among those who attended for-profit colleges. For-profit schools account for about 13 percent of higher education enrollment but nearly half of all defaults. New data from the Department of Education show that 22.7 percent of students from for-profit schools who began repayment in 2009 defaulted within three years. Thats twice the three-year default rate of public colleges and three times the rate at private, nonprofit institutions.

title: Homeless Veterans: Whose Responsibility?
description: Veterans and their advocates in southern California, the epicenter of veterans homelessness, are angry that President Obama and the Veterans Affairs Department have not built a single bed for homeless disabled veterans on the 400 acres the government owns in West Los Angeles, property that was deeded to the federal government for that very purpose in 1888.

title: Two Decades After Apartheid, a Black Idol
description: After eight seasons, Idols SA, the South African version of American Idol, has crowned its first black pop idol  one who represents 80 percent of the countrys population. Here, a look at all the winners.

title: The Policy Verdict I
description: In Thursday nights debate, Vice President Joe Biden will almost certainly go after Representative Paul Ryans Medicare plan. And why shouldnt he? Its unpopular. But Id like to make a case for that plan. Its the best thing the Romney-Ryan campaign has going for it.

title: Georgia Law Requiring Proof of Legal Residency Creates Licensing Backlog
description: ATLANTA  For nurses, hair stylists, kickboxing instructors and even geologists, Georgias desire to clamp down on illegal immigration is having an unintended side effect.

title: Chvez Calls for Unity After Victory in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez followed his least convincing election victory  a still powerful 55 percent of the vote  with a phone call to his challenger on Monday and an appeal for national unity. But there appeared to be little prospect of concessions to the opposition, despite its relatively strong showing.

title: Race and College Admissions, Facing a New Test by Justices
description: WASHINGTON  Abigail Fisher is a slight young woman with strawberry blond hair, a smile that needs little prompting, a determined manner and a good academic record. She played soccer in high school, and she is an accomplished cellist.

title: Cardinals Hitters Crackle With Power
description: ST. LOUIS  The home teams home runs are marked with short bursts of fireworks, and they were exploding again late Monday afternoon  pop, pop, pop, pop  to mark the demolition unfolding at Busch Stadium. One day after slumping to a maddening defeat, the St. Louis Cardinals whacked their way to a 12-4 victory over the Washington Nationals, evening the best-of-five National League division series at one game apiece.

title: Welcoming Higher Taxes, but Not That High
description: PARIS  A little over a year ago, some of the most prominent and wealthy executives in France signed a petition seeking higher taxes on themselves. Yes, higher taxes.

title: Buying the Election?
description: Do you remember that moment in the first Austin Powers movie when Dr. Evil, back in action after being cryogenically frozen for 30 years, gets his hands on a nuclear warhead? If you want it back, he snarls to a group of world leaders who have gathered in a secret United Nations bunker, you will have to pay me  here he pauses for dramatic effect  one million dollars! The assembled leaders burst into laughter because it was such a pathetically small sum.

title: Kazakhstan: Leader of an Opposition Party Is Jailed
description: The leader of an opposition party, Vladimir Kozlov, was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison on Monday after he was convicted of trying to overthrow the government by inciting social discord among striking oil workers in Zhanaozen last December. At least 14 people were killed when the police fired on the workers. Mr. Kozlov denied the charges.

title: Suzuki Soaks in the Postseason After a Decade Away From It
description: BALTIMORE  The 2001 season was a whirlwind for Ichiro Suzuki. It was his first year in Major League Baseball as a 27-year-old rookie from Japan, and he lit up the American League, winning the rookie of the year and the Most Valuable Player awards as the Seattle Mariners won 116 games, by far the most in club history.

title: 4 Die in Crash at Notorious Turn on L.I. Road
description: All five were teenage friends from Queens, and four had been classmates at Richmond Hill High School. Some had started college and were planning for careers years away, and they were all out for a ride early Monday in a car that one of them  a 17-year-old with a learners permit  had recently started driving.

title: New Super PACs Alter Landscape for House Races
description: In the shadow of the supersize super PACs that have reshaped the battle for the White House and Senate, a new and potentially potent kind of super PAC is proliferating in the closing weeks of the campaign and taking aim at House races.

title: Special Parking Rules
description: Because of Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Naughty Goose and Moose Drool
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This is apparently a debut by John Guzzetta, and it cheered me up considerably. I consider myself to be having a particularly good day if I can give my post a title like Naughty Goose and Moose Drool. If Paul Krugman tried that hed get fired, but here at Wordplay were free to be as silly as we like, within reason. Of course, I dont have a Nobel Prize and he does, so I guess were even.

title: Corrections: October 9, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Team Used to Trotting Shows a Bit of Dashing
description: Baltimore

title: Access and Scrutiny for a Kennedy
description: The directions to her secluded home, sitting atop a hill abutting a 640-acre wildlife preserve, were not the kind spit out by Google maps or a GPS device.

title: U.S. Ties Legislators Ex-Associate to Mob
description: In 2006, when Michael G. Grimm retired from a career as an undercover agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a businessman named Bennett Orfaly helped smooth his return to civilian life.

title: Grand Plan for a Toxic Site Is Scorned and Celebrated
description: Look upon them as among the first palazzos on a not-so-grand canal, two proposed buildings that rival the scale of almost any residence in Venice and harbor a total of 700 rental apartments. They represent an emphatic confirmation of what local artists and other urban pioneers have increasingly feared  that real estate operators would officially anoint the once-scorned Gowanus Canal and its gritty jigsaw patch of Brooklyn as up and coming.

title: Lottery Numbers
Giants Defense Faces Pressure After Browns Saw Little of It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Amid a postgame locker room teeming with optimism and merriment, Justin Tuck offered a sobering reminder that not every unit flourished in the Giants 41-27 blowout of the Cleveland Browns on Sunday.

title: Reprogramming Adult Cells
description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to two scientists who showed that adult cells could be manipulated to a primitive state.

title: Sudan: Rebels Shell City in a Southern Border State
description: Rebels on Monday shelled Kadugli, in South Kordofan State, killing at least one person and wounding three, said a Sudanese Army spokesman. The rebels of the Sudanese Peoples Liberation Movement-North told Reuters that the shelling was in retaliation for attacks on their positions. Since last year, the rebels have clashed with Sudans government forces in South Kordofan, which borders South Sudan. The rebels previously fought alongside the forces of South Sudan before it gained independence from Sudan.

title: China Slams Cold War Mentality in U.S. Report
description: HONG KONG  China struck back Tuesday at a U.S. congressional report that says two leading Chinese telecommunication companies represent potential security threats to the United States.

title: Bay Area Teams Rose Together, and Now Could Be Ousted Together
description: CINCINNATI  As the San Francisco Giants pulled away from the Los Angeles Dodgers down the stretch in the National League West and the Oakland Athletics erased a 13-game deficit to overtake the Texas Rangers in the American League West, the Bay Area had visions of a Northern California World Series.

title: NBC Delays Premiere of Community
description: Fans of the NBC comedy Community were already worried about the networks commitment to the show because the shows creator, Dan Harmon, was removed at the end of last season, and the show was slated for the little-watched programming desert of Friday night.

title: No Immigration Charges Filed Against Activist in Traffic Stop
description: Federal immigration officials said on Monday that they had decided not to detain a prominent immigrant rights advocate after his arrest in Minnesota last week on a traffic violation because he did not present a risk to public safety.

title: Stacks of Counterfeit Bills Found in Teller Machines at 2 Midtown Banks
description: The forgers efforts were at most halfhearted. The bills were made from ordinary paper stock and were blank on one side. But stacks of them were found in A.T.M.s in Midtown on Monday and a few of them wound up in customers hands.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,117 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: With New Vigor, Romney Resets Ohio Campaign
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  If one place is emerging as a test of Mitt Romneys ability to capitalize on a new dynamic in the presidential race, it is Ohio, where he is intensifying his advertising, deploying more troops and spending four of the next five days.

title: Vote Lincoln in 2012
description: Mitt Romney may have upstaged President Obama in last weeks presidential debate, but it was Abraham Lincoln who stole the show at the last minute. An extended promotional trailer for Steven Spielbergs forthcoming Lincoln biopic aired on several major television networks  including ABC, CBS and CNN  immediately after the final fadeout in Denver. Its soundtrack of soaring strings and crashing percussion, and its images of Union soldiers dying in agony and jubilant African-Americans rejoicing in freedom, certainly made presidential politics appear more thrilling than it might have seemed during the candidates umpteenth round of bickering over budgetary policy.

title: Sbarro Plan for Growth Is Starting in Kitchen
description: The pizza wars may be just beginning.

title: Word of the Day | reconnaissance
description: reconnaissance \ri-k-n-zn(t)s, -sn(t)s\ noun

title: Jets Give Themselves a Chance, if Not a Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Despite a depleted roster, a maligned defense and a quarterback situation that seemed more and more unsustainable by the day, here the Jets were: late fourth quarter, trailing undefeated Houston by 6 points, the football in their possession. Precisely how they arrived at that moment was somewhat of a mystery, especially to a crowd that for a good portion of Monday night made MetLife Stadium sound as cold and unforgiving as Radio City Music Hall after an unpopular draft selection.

title: Romney Speaks Harshly but Treads Fine Line on Foreign Policy
description: LEXINGTON, Va.  Mitt Romney launched a broad attack on Monday against what he termed President Obamas failure to shape history in the Middle East, but he found himself walking a fine line between criticizing the president he is running against and avoiding any endorsement of the type of international interventions undertaken by the most recent president from his own party, George W. Bush, whom he rarely mentions.

title: Neck and Neck, Headed for Home
description: BALTIMORE  Matt Wieters lunged once, scampered a few feet on his hands and knees and lunged again in the opposite direction, trying in vain to tag the elusive Ichiro Suzuki, who rolled, dodged, pivoted and reached out to safely touch home and score the first run of the game.

title: Pharmaceutical Study Aids
description: Some doctors are prescribing stimulants used to treat A.D.H.D. to children who do not have the disorder to help them perform better in school.

title: Attention Disorder or Not, Pills to Help in School
description: CANTON, Ga.  When Dr. Michael Anderson hears about his low-income patients struggling in elementary school, he usually gives them a taste of some powerful medicine: Adderall.

title: Oct. 8: A Great Poll for Romney, in Perspective
description: Mitt Romney gained further ground in the FiveThirtyEight forecast on Monday, with his chances of winning the Electoral College increasing to 25.2 percent from 21.6 percent on Sunday.

title: Orioles Beat Yankees
description: Ichiro Suzuki scored in acrobatic fashion to put the Yankees ahead early, but they gave Andy Pettitte little help after that.

title: Beloved Bar of Old Detroit
description: The Lindell A.C. was a saloon where stars, from Mickey Mantle to Milton Berle, mingled with fans.

title: Cargo Spaceship Is On Course Despite Engine Trouble
description: A spaceship carrying cargo bound for the International Space Station is on course despite the disintegration of one of its rocket engines shortly after liftoff on Sunday night. About 79 seconds after the launching, one of the rockets nine engines was engulfed in a burst of smoke. Pieces of debris fell away, and the onboard computer shut down the bad engine. By design, the other eight engines burned longer to compensate, and the ship reached its correct orbit. In a statement on Monday, Space Exploration Technologies of Hawthorne, Calif., or SpaceX, the company that built and launched the spaceship, said that the engine had lost pressure and that a protective structure around it then ruptured. We know the engine did not explode because we continued to receive data from it, the company said. The cargo ship is scheduled to arrive at the space station on Wednesday.

title: Mervyn M. Dymally, Who Broke Racial Barriers in California, Dies at 86
description: Mervyn M. Dymally, who broke barriers as a black lawmaker in California and in Congress after moving to the United States from his native Trinidad at age 19, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: Jets Replay: Week 5
description: The Jets chance to win was blown by an interception by the Texans.

title: Yankees Breakthrough at Plate Lasts Only One Game
description: BALTIMORE  When the Yankees scored five runs in the ninth inning Sunday, it appeared as though they had snapped out of their collective funk in clutch situations in the postseason.

title: News Quiz | October 9, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Mexico Kills a Drug Kingpin, but the Body Gets Away
description: MEXICO CITY  It seemed such a triumphant moment in the drug war: the leader of the Zetas, one of the countrys biggest and most ruthless gangs, killed by the celebrated Mexican Marines in a fierce battle with guns and grenades.

title: Devoted to Facial Yoga (Dont Try This in Public)
description: After hot yoga, extreme yoga and yoga clubbing, what could be next? How about facial yoga, designed to keep the face youthful-looking?

title: Missed Chances Mount as Do Questions of Rodriguezs Place in Order
description: BALTIMORE  Early Monday night, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was asked if there was any scenario where he would move Alex Rodriguez out of the No. 3 spot in the batting order, a position Rodriguez is holding down like an anchor.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 9, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Slow-Burning Challenge to Chile on Easter Island.

title: Below 5 Percent Growth for India, I.M.F. Says
description: Gloomy projections about Indias economy hit a new low Tuesday when the International Monetary Fund downgraded its estimate for growth this year to just 4.9 percent, as the country struggles to cut subsidies and plump up investor confidence.

title: IHT Quick Read: Tuesday, Oct. 9
description: NEWS Despite Britains long ambivalence toward European integration and its refusal to adopt the euro, the country has usually demanded a seat at Europes top table. But as Britain struggles to emerge from recession and Prime Minister David Cameron faces domestic pressure to distance his country from Europes financial problems, Mr. Cameron is now willing to let Britain take a back seat in the European Union. Stephen Castle reports from London.

title: North Korea Says Its Missiles Can Reach U.S. Mainland
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea claimed Tuesday to have missiles that can reach the American mainland, and it said that the recent agreement between the United States and South Korea to extend the range of the Souths ballistic missiles was increasing the risk of war on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Vote Obamney!
description: Christina Beckwith was a public high-school Spanish teacher in Michigan when she was laid off because of government spending cuts. She says she wants to vote for whichever candidate will fix the economy, but she isnt sure who that is. I dont have any training to be able to figure all of that out, she told me.

title: Is There Life After Mitt?
description: Not long ago, David Winston, a leading pollster in the Republican Party, listed for me some of the empirical reasons that Mitt Romney should be winning the election. In the past 64 years, Winston said, only six presidents had run for re-election at a time when the unemployment rate was above 6 percent, and five of them lost. (The exception was Ronald Reagan, whose unemployment rate, while over 7 percent, had dropped almost three full points since his election.) Since 1948, when the government started keeping such statistics, the country experienced a total of 82 months with an unemployment rate of more than 8 percent, and 43 of those months came under President Obama  more than the previous 11 administrations combined. George H. W. Bushs economy grew at triple the rate of Obamas during his last quarter before the election, and he never stood a chance.

title: Looking Into the Eyes of Made in China
description: Your clothes, your childs toys, even the device you use to read these words may have been made in China. They are among the $100 billion of goods that the United States imports from China each year  an exchange that has become an important issue in the 2012 presidential campaign.

title: Should Schools Put Tracking Devices in Students I.D. Cards?
description: At Anson Jones Middle School in San Antonio, students wear name tags that use radio frequency technology. School personnel can pinpoint exactly where students are inside the school building. Why might this be helpful? Why do you think some people object to tracking the whereabout of students?

title: Re-election Lament
description: CARACAS  Hugo Chvezs resounding election victory in the Venezuelan presidential election on Sunday set me at war with myself.

title: Julius Baer to Cut 1,000 Jobs After Deal for Bank of America Unit
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank Julius Baer announced on Tuesday that it would eliminate about 1,000 jobs to reduce costs.

title: Official Warmth and Public Rage for Merkel in Athens
description: ATHENS  Venturing into the most hostile territory in Europe, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany visited Athens on Tuesday, telling Greeks that she understood their suffering but urging the country to stay the course on reforms and budget cuts.

title: Its Official: The N.F.C. Is the Dominant Conference
description: With the addition of the expansion Houston Texans in 2002, the N.F.L. realigned, with four divisions of four teams each per conference. Since that time, the American Football Conference has often been dominant, in part because of the durable success of teams like New England, Indianapolis and Pittsburgh.

title: Partisan Bias and Economic Forecasts
description: There is a well-known tendency in sports for referees to tilt their calls in favor of the home team. The same thing happens in other areas of life as well, such as economic forecasting. This weeks Economist magazine, for example, notes sharp differences in the current outlook between Republican and Democratic economists.

title: The Early Word: Second Wind
description: Todays Times

title: In the Wake of Our Forebears
description: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes.

title: Fearless Felix and the Giant Leap
description: WHO is Felix Baumgartner?

title: A Nobel for Teasing Out the Secret Life of Atoms
description: Two physicists who developed techniques to peer in on the most intimate relations between light and matter won the Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday. They are Serge Haroche, 68, of the Collge de France and the cole Normale Suprieure, in Paris, and David J. Wineland, also 68, of the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the University of Colorado.

title: Shopping for Vivid Colors
description: Jamie Drake, an interior designer, is known for his audacious use of color, and says that a single brightly colored piece of furniture or decorative accessory can enliven a sedate room.

title: Colors That Shout
description: FOR as long as Jamie Drake can remember, he has loved color.

title: A Web Site for Cheaters Says Groupon Cheated
description: This weeks dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to an article about how Groupon, the daily deal site, called off a deal with Ashley Madison, a dating service for people who are married but looking (Life is short. Have an affair). We spoke with Noel Biderman, who founded Ashley Madison in Toronto and is chief executive of its parent company, about the challenges of running a controversial business. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

title: The Running of the Bears
description: This is a story about men who race in bear suits.

title: High Court in Philippines Suspends Contentious Internet Law
description: MANILA  The Supreme Court of the Philippines suspended a new Internet law on Tuesday that critics had said could lead to imprisonment for sharing posts on social media.

title: Barclays to Buy British Retail Unit From ING
description: LONDON  Barclays agreed on Tuesday to buy the British savings and loan business of the Dutch firm ING Group.

title: In China Protests, Japanese Car Sales Suffer
description: HONG KONG  Japanese automakers suffered plunging sales in China last month and have cut manufacturing by up to half in China this month after violent anti-Japanese protests against Japanese-brand cars and even their owners.

title: Merkel Reaches Out to Greece With German Voters in Mind
description: LONDON  The Greek authorities welcomed Angela Merkel, the visiting German chancellor, on Tuesday by cordoning off central Athens, putting thousands of police officers on the streets, snipers on rooftops and water cannons on standby.

title: The 30-second Rule
description: Hmm. A late thought about the discussion on This Week. I suggested that it was the job of the news media to check on and report falsehoods from politicians. The response of the other panelists was that the media cant do that if the opposing candidates didnt make an issue of it  which as far as I can tell makes no sense at all.

title: A Tragic Vindication
description: Im sorry to say that Im on the road again, this time at the World Knowledge Forum in Seoul. Heres a preview of my presentation:

title: For Jets, Fourth-Quarter Glimpses of Ground-and-Pound Identity
description: There are no moral victories for any team when the loss column reads 3 this far from Halloween. Any silver lining can turn gray in a hurry.

title: The U.S. Presidential Race
description: Following the first presidential debate, a poll on Monday suggested that Mitt Romney had caught up to President Obamas lead nationally.

title: Sandusky Gets 30 to 60 Years for Sexual Abuse
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.  Jerry Sandusky stood in court Tuesday in his current uniform, the bright red jumpsuit of the Centre County jail. No longer was he in his Penn State coaching gear, nor in the suit and tie he wore at his trial in June. He was, in a sense, as powerless before his victims as they had once been before him. So he sat, forced to listen.

title: Seasonal Geometry
description: Dear Diary:

title: He Knew Where the Money Was, and He Usually Took It
description: There are two ways to read Sutton, by J. R. Moehringer: as a third-rate novel with a deep and crippling cornball streak, or as a loose and journalistic speculative biography of a famous bank robber. Either way, you lose. But you lose less if you decide to read it as semi-true biography. You can at least enjoy the ragtime shuffle of the authors better sentences.

title: Remedial Chaos Theory: Meet the New Show Runners of Community
description: LOS ANGELES  Depending on your perspective, David Guarascio and Moses Port may have the best job in television or the worst. In May these two longtime comedy-writing collaborators, who have previously worked on Mad About You, Just Shoot Me and Happy Endings, were named the new show runners of Community, NBCs passionately adored  if not widely watched  comedy about a study group of misfit students.

title: Matters of Fact
description: My colleague Patrick LaForge offered this timely reminder:

title: Opinion Report: For-Profit Schools
description: From the editorial page

title: Fill-In | Driving the Mohawk Trail in Massachusetts
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this article, Driving the Mohawk Trail in Massachusetts.

title: A Vacuum That Promises No More Tangles
description: The bagless cyclonic vacuum cleaners made by the design company Dyson, which maintain suction even as they fill with debris, shared an Achilles heel with even the most plebeian vacuums  the nuisance of tangling hair.

title: Stanley Black & Decker to Sell Hardware and Home Unit for $1.4 Billion
description: Stanley Black & Decker agreed on Tuesday to sell its hardware and home improvement unit to Spectrum Brands Holdings for $1.4 billion in cash, as the company worked to whittle down its product portfolio.

description: Q.

title: MegaFon of Russia Moves Ahead on I.P.O.
description: MOSCOW  One of Russias largest cellphone companies, MegaFon, announced plans to go public later this year on London Stock Exchange.

title: Obama Ad Features Someone Big, Yellow and Feathery
description: 1:49 a.m. | Updated If President Obama loses the election next month, his ad makers may have a second career on The Daily Show.

title: A Move Toward Romney in Polls, but Will It Last?
description: For weeks in August and September, while conservative pundits increasingly began writing off Mitt Romneys campaign as hapless and hopeless, top aides to the Republican presidential hopeful privately preached patience and resolve.

title: A Tax Too High
description: A Tax Too High | Wall Street doesnt exactly love the idea of higher taxes. But a proposal in France looks much scarier than anything being discussed in this country: a 75 percent marginal tax rate on all income over $1.3 million, with capital gains taxes as high as 60 percent.

title: Daily Report: Mobile Devices Change Doctors Rounds
description: The proliferation of gadgets, apps and Web-based information has given the medical profession a black bag of new tools, Katie Hafner reports in Tuesdays New York Times. Clinicians have new ways to diagnose symptoms and treat patients, to obtain and share information, to think about what it means to be both a doctor and a patient.

title: Tuesday Reading: Some Doctors Text Their Teenage Patients
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sonia, Modi and the Swami
description: Swami Vivekananda, a monk widely credited for raising global awareness of Hinduism and yoga more than a century ago, has become an unlikely touchstone in the run-up to the closely watched Gujarat elections.

title: A Quirk in Time Warner Cables New Modem Fee
description: When Tom Arana-Wolfe, a Manhattan resident, learned that Time Warner Cable would begin charging a $4 monthly rental fee to use its cable modem, he started researching modems he could buy to avoid paying the fee. But Mr. Arana-Wolfe soon realized something odd: He would have to keep using the cable companys modem even if he bought his own.

title: Chvez Wins, Kirchner Wins
description: BUENOS AIRES  After Hugo Chvezs easy re-election as Venezuelas president on Sunday, President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina took to Twitter for the first time in almost a week. She sent five messages in quick succession, congratulating Chvez and Venezuela. Your victory is also ours, she wrote:

title: Archive of Jewish Life in Central Europe Going Online
description: The Leo Baeck Institute, a New York research library and archive devoted to documenting the history of German-speaking Jewry, has completed the digitization of its entire archive, which will provide free online access to primary-source materials encompassing five centuries of Jewish life in Central Europe.

title: Pyramid Scheme
description: As if it werent enough for him to turn wrists into weapons, the jewelry designer Eddie Borgo  known for his spiked and studded cone bracelets  is expanding his hard-edged vision with his first handbag.

title: World Is Growing Older, and Its Not All Senior Discounts
description: One of the best things about growing older is that youre growing older. The alternative, as an old line has it, is rotten.

title: Tapping Into a More Moderate Islam  in China
description: BEIJING  Over the past decade, people around the world have grown accustomed to a violent face of Islam, the extremism that a leading Islamic law expert, Khaled Abou El Fadl, described as petrol bomber Islam in an interview for my column this week.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Dunham Book Deal and Girls Who Like Steak
description: Lena Dunham, the creator of Tiny Furniture and Girls, has signed a book deal worth at least $3.5 million with Random House, where executives are clearly hoping to have another Bossypants on their hands. The tentative title is Not That Kind of Girl.

title: What Were Reading
description: Travel + Leisure: Youll find them in Maine, the Hawaiian islands, the Florida Keys, New Orleans and New York City: Heres the magazines exhaustively briny list of the some of the best seafood restaurants in the United States.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Cheering for an Injury? Not Cool
description: Perhaps Monday was a pivotal point in sports culture, the day people got to contemplate whether the whole business of fandom might be going off the rails. Yes, it might have been a relatively small proportion of the Kansas City fans who cheered an injury to their own quarterback, Matt Cassel, on Sunday, but the sound was heard far and wide. And it seemed to split fans into factions, separating those who think the price of their tickets buys them the ability to say pretty much anything they want without reprisal and those who thought the hostility in our culture just took too big a leap.

title: Open vs. Closed: The Cloud Wars
description: For all the freedom promised by cloud computing, businesses may be really looking at less choice and more constraint than ever before. Whether that happens is the technology industrys next great battleground.

title: Schumer Shakes Up Deficit Talks With Call to Raise Taxes on the Rich
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, the Senates third-ranking Democrat, threw cold water on Tuesday on one emerging approach for striking a bipartisan deficit-reduction deal  an overhaul of the tax code that lowers top income tax rates but raises more revenue. Mr. Schumers position complicates efforts to seal a deal before January, when the fiscal cliff of tax increases and automatic spending cuts goes into effect.

title: From Shaggy Dog to Fish Stories
Geithner Meets Chidambaram in Delhi
description: Timothy F. Geithner, the United States Treasury secretary, returned to his childhood elementary school here in India on Tuesday before attending a day of meetings with Indian leaders and business executives.

title: Ateras Tasting Menu
description: Sit through a feast at Atera  all 28 courses of it.

title: Workday Raises I.P.O. Range to $24 to $26
description: Initial public offerings have largely sputtered in the last few weeks, but the dismal environment has done little to dent investors enthusiasm for Workday, a maker of human resources software.

title: Aftermath of a Housing Bust
description: Ireland plans a bold move to help struggling homeowners. | The I.M.F. cuts its global growth forecast. | How Wal-Mart found a banking partner in American Express.

title: Voter Portraits: John Grant
description: Rev. John H. Grant, a black Baptist pastor in Asheville, N.C., and a lifelong Democrat, is torn between voting for President Obama or Mitt Romney because of his conservative stance on social issues.

title: Business Day Live: Ireland Plans Bold Measures to Lift Housing
description: Ireland plans a bold move to help struggling homeowners. | The I.M.F. cuts its global growth forecast. | How Wal-Mart found a banking partner in American Express.

title: Pakistani Activist, 15, Is Shot by Taliban
description: Last Updated, 8:42 p.m. A spokesman for the Taliban in Pakistans Swat Valley took responsibility for the shooting on Tuesday of a 15-year-old activist who is an outspoken advocate of education for girls. The attack on Malala Yousafzai, who was shot in the head on her way home from school in Mingora, the regions main city, outraged many Pakistanis, but a Taliban spokesman told a newspaper that the group would target the girl again if she survived.

title: Face Time | Zoe Lister-Jones
description: I met the actress and filmmaker Zoe Lister-Jones at her mothers home in Brooklyn. We had a lovely time strolling around the neighborhood, chatting about her recent engagement to the filmmaker Daryl Wein (they did a movie together called Lola Versus) and the new season of her NBC show, Whitney, which will have its premiere later this month. Jones admitted to being a bit of a makeup hound, so naturally I wanted more details!

title: On Our Radar: Mock Candidates Go Head to Head on Energy
description: Surrogates for President Obama and Mitt Romney debate the future of federal energy policy. [E&E News]

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: Just how good are the Vikings? The Broncos? What do the Packers have to do to beat the Texans? Will Michael Vick keep the quarterback job in Philadelphia? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

title: NPR Appoints Executive from Morning Edition to Oversee All News Coverage
description: NPR on Tuesday promoted Madhulika Sikka, the executive producer of Morning Edition for the last six years, to a position overseeing all news coverage for the organization.

title: Image of the Day: Oct. 9
At the Louvre, Islamic Art Evokes Food and Wine
description: From a dark corner in the new galleries for Islamic art at the Louvre, in Paris, a deep male voice beckons. It is a recording of some of the most famous verses of poetry in Persian, from the Shahnameh, the Book of Kings, written in the 10th century by Abolghasem Ferdowsi, Irans greatest epic poet.

title: Wheelies: The Dealers Dilemma Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Old Pro, Still Outclassing the New Girl
description: By now Connie Britton must be a little tired of playing variations on the tough, beleaguered wife, as she did for five seasons on Friday Night Lights and one on American Horror Story, picking up three Emmy nominations along the way. But shes back at it, this time as a country music queen in ABCs new drama Nashville, and shes still outstanding: Nashville is the best of the fall pilots, if only because of her presence.

title: Try as He Might, Sanchez Cant Lift Jets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Keeping Kosher in Los Angeles
description: New York may have a larger Jewish population, but the kosher options in Southern California seem far more exciting.

title: After Losing Its Sponsor, Literary Prize for Women Will Live On
description: A consortium of private donors including Cherie Blair, the wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair, and the novelist Joanna Trollope have joined together to preserve financing for a prominent British literary prize awarded to women, The Guardian reported. The prize, known from its introduction in 1996 as the Orange Prize for Fiction, was created to celebrate excellence, originality and accessibility in womens writing from throughout the world, according to its Web site, and had been awarded to authors including Lionel Shriver (for We Need to Talk About Kevin), Zadie Smith (On Beauty), Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (Half of a Yellow Sun) and Marilynne Robinson (Home).

title: This Weeks Admissions Tip: Pay Close Attention to the Supreme Court
description: Students and parents who will be hurtling through the college admissions process this year, or in future years, would do well to pay close attention to the arguments in a case that will be heard by the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

title: Visualizing the Impact of C.D. Laddering
description: With interest rates on savings accounts still anemic, considering a so-called ladder of certificate of deposits might make sense. Ally Bank has started an online tool with interactive graphics that helps savers visualize the laddering process and its potential financial benefits.

title: Parsing Romneys Foreign Policy Speech
description: Theres hardly a paragraph in Mitt Romneys foreign policy speech at the Virginia Military Institute that doesnt need clarifying in one way or another.

title: Matters of the Latter Day: Ideas for Addressing Mormonism in the Classroom
description: Update | Oct. 10, 2012

title: Qaeda-Linked Group Claims Responsibility for Syrian Blasts
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A jihadist insurgent group that Western intelligence officials have linked to Al Qaeda claimed responsibility on Tuesday for a multiple bombing by suicide attackers who struck an intelligence compound on the outskirts of Damascus overnight. It was the second major assault that the group has claimed to have carried out against a government facility in a Syrian urban center in about a week.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Students Call to Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Looks to Rally Blacks in North Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Dexter Hady, a black landscaper here, is exactly the kind of Obama supporter who could have slipped through the cracks this year. He recently moved and, not being as excited about the coming election as he was about the 2008 campaign, neglected to update his voter registration.

title: NBC News Names New Rock Center Producer
description: 12:21 p.m. | Updated NBC News on Tuesday named a new producer of Rock Center with Brian Williams, its one-year-old newsmagazine, and promoted several other executives in a restructuring of sorts.

title: Same-Day Delivery Test at Wal-Mart
description: Wal-Mart Stores kicked Amazon out of its 4,000 stores last month when it discontinued Kindle tablets and e-readers. Now, the retailer is poised to use those stores against its online rival once again  this time aiming for the heart of Amazons retail model.

title: The State of the Race
description: In a presidential campaign as thick with polling data as this one, everyone needs a savvysensei to help them make sense of how things actually stand. Mine is usually the wonderfully-named Sean Trende of RealClearPolitics, who blends his numbers-crunching with a keen eye for the broader political dynamics that too much time in the cross-tabs can sometimes obscure.

title: More Often These Days, the Director Is a She
description: LONDONMy God, there are a lot of women directors working in the theater these days in London, a female theater director who happens not to be from London remarked to me the other day.

title: All Inclusive
description: The artist Rosemarie Trockel has long taken an everything-and-the-kitchen-sink approach to her work: giant knitted canvases, crude ceramics, repurposed housewares, mouth sculptures made from chewed gum, and quirky clothing all fit comfortably in her wide embrace. (The image below is from the 2005 series From a French Magazine.) If there is one thing she rejects, perhaps, its labels like art and artist and the conventional hierarchies that keep them in place. In Rosemarie Trockel: A Cosmos, on view at the New Museum from Oct. 24 through Jan. 13, 2013, Trockel shares the floor, and the walls, with work that may not be recognized as art  say, book engravings by the pioneering 18th-century botanist Maria Sibylla Merian or Judith Scotts yarn-choked sculptures  but whose maverick creators Trockel recognizes as kindred spirits.

title: South Korean Teams Fight for Attention at Home
description: South Korean soccer has a longer history of success than the recently popular South Korean music. But while the countrys pop music exploits have been well documented and received, soccer success has been greeted with what can only be described as public indifference.

title: Ohio Official Will Take Early Voting Decision to Supreme Court
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The Ohio secretary of state, Jon Husted, said Tuesday that he would appeal to the Supreme Court a decision by a federal appeals court last week that sided with President Obamas campaign, allowing expanded early voting in the final three days before the election.

title: When Modest Wine Storage Will Not Do
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y.

title: Pepper, but With Shape and Color
description: Peppercorns, the prized fruit of piper nigrum, a tropical vine, are used when they are still fresh and green in a number of French recipes. But until now, the only greens ones available in the United States have been canned, in brine or dried. Denis Heraud, a French filmmaker and painter, has entered the peppercorn business, importing fresh green ones that are grown on a farm in Costa Rica, with no chemicals used on the plants. The terroir is what makes these so wonderful, he said. Theyre the grand cru, the Lafite of pepper.

title: Breakfasts That Reflect New Guests
description: Visitors to the Plaza Athne on the Upper East Side will now find, listed alongside the eggs and croissants on the breakfast menu, an unusual option. Since August, the hotel has been serving a prix fixe Chinese breakfast that includes congee (a rice porridge with a dusting of scallions); an egg cooked in tea; shrimp and vegetable dumplings; and steamed buns filled with pork, bean paste and egg. Fresh juice and jasmine tea are poured. A chef in Chinatown prepares the buns and dumplings, which are delivered daily to the hotel and steamed to order.

title: In Leftovers of Winemaking, a Versatile Oil
description: Grapeseed oil, which tends to have a less assertive flavor and a lighter body than olive oil, is just catching on in the United States. Finger Lakes Extra Virgin Grape Seed Oil, cold-pressed from the winemaking leftovers of about 25 wineries in the region, is a new one with real personality. Fairly viscous, with a greenish color and an herbaceous flavor, it has more in common with fine olive oil than most grapeseed oils. Its excellent in salad dressing, as a finishing drizzle and for some sauting jobs, especially vegetable-based stir-fries. Its also good to brush on meat, poultry or seafood as it grills, and its tailor-made for mayonnaise.

title: In the Dark Cave, Fearsome Living Fossils
description: Every day, around 5,000 visitors trek up the 272 narrow steps to the Batu Caves to pay their respects to Lord Murugan, the god of war and victory. Located just north of Kuala Lumpur, the bustling Malaysian capital, the caves are a focal point for devout Hindus and a must-see for foreign visitors. Tucked into a corner off the well-worn tourist trail is the Dark Cave, a natural heritage site that is the habitat of a wildlife community dating back around 100 million years.

title: A Better Solution Is Needed for Failed Financial Giants
description: Harvey R. Miller is a partner of the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, where he created and developed the firms business finance and restructuring department that specializes in reorganizing distressed business entities. Maurice Horwitz is an associate in that department.

title: China Gets Back to Work
description: A slumping economy did not deter Chinese from their travels.

title: Does The Megawatt Hours Web Site Make Sense?
description: Alexandra Mayzler, Susan Parker, and Beth Shaw  three of the five owners in the She Owns It business group  are updating or overhauling their Web sites. Deirdre Lord recently created hers, and Jessica Johnson updated hers as part of her companys rebranding efforts this year. Recently, I talked to all of them about their approaches to Web design and development  and how satisfied theyve been with their results.

title: Voters for the Documentary Oscar Get More Time
description: LOS ANGELES  Members of the documentary branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, overwhelmed by a large number of submissions and the demands of a new voting system, will have extra time to figure out which 15 documentary feature films will be included on a short list of those eligible for Oscar nominations.

title: In a Fire Sale, Penske Media Buys Variety
description: LOS ANGELES  Variety, the 107-year-old giant of entertainment news, has been seized by blogger insurgents.

title: Billionaire Financier Leon Black Buys Art Publisher Phaidon
description: The billionaire financier Leon Black has recently made as many headlines for his art patronage as for his business deals. On Tuesday, he combined the two, announcing an acquisition of Phaidon Press, a leading publisher of fine art books.

title: Closer Finds Redemption in a 1-2-3 Ninth
description: Baltimore

title: Athletics Become Hot Ticket but Keep Lower Capacity and Cozy Vibe
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Beyond all expectations, the tarps are staying put. Despite a capacity crowd of 36,067 on the seasons final day, the tarps are staying put. In the face of outcry from fans seeking playoff tickets, including the Web site removethetarps.com, the tarps are staying put.

title: Superheroes, Stitched Together in Spandex
description: On the second floor of a brownstone in Ocean Hill, Brooklyn, Darlena Marie Blander lives a life that would be the dream of just about any 7-year-old.

title: Louis C. K. to Take Hiatus From FX Series Louie
description: When you  or your fictionalized TV counterpart  have in a single season traveled to China, dated Melissa Leo and Parker Posey and vied to replace David Letterman on his late-night talk show, what do you do for an encore?

title: The Lowdown | Max RIPO Rippon
description: A street artist who borrows from graffiti is nothing new, but one that elevates both mediums with his devoted, ever-developing craftsmanship is a rarity. For close to a decade, Max Rippon has been exploring the intersection of classic calligraphy, hand-painted signage and graffiti in his public artworks. In the spirit of Steve Powers (ESPO), Rippon (who goes by Ripo) has injected imagery into wordplay, and words into visual landscapes that he offers up as a gift to every city he visits in the form of large-scale murals. Rippon has traveled through the better part of South America, Europe and the United States, leaving a trail of public works. Several years ago, the native New Yorker moved to Barcelona and began working on paper, canvas, found materials and with sculpture. Over the summer he displayed some of his recent work at the White Walls Gallery in San Francisco.

title: A Coffee Seller Seeks to Cut Hunger Among Coffee Growers
description: Theres perhaps no habit that more firmly illustrates the global nature of the modern human enterprise than drinking coffee. For centuries, trade in beans came with scant concern at the consumer end for the conditions on the plantations or small farms where coffee is harvested. Thats changing, of course, with growing, and sometimes controversial, efforts to certify good labor or environmental standards in coffee regions.

title: French Assembly Approves European Budget Discipline Treaty
description: PARIS  The lower house of the French Parliament approved the ratification of a European budget discipline treaty by a large majority on Tuesday, with final adoption expected this week.

title: Democrats React as the Race Tightens
description: TimesCast Politics: A new tone from the Obama campaign. | Some perspective on the latest polls. | A focus on turning out black voters.

title: SpongeBob and Others Come to Hulu
description: Nickelodeon shows like SpongeBob SquarePants and iCarly are coming to Hulu, the streaming TV Web site, for the first time.

title: From McLaren and Neiman Marcus, a Potent Holiday Fantasy
description: For someone special on your holiday shopping list, Neiman Marcus has a gift suggestion. The recipient cannot be someone with whom youre merely smitten. Only crazy, unqualified love will do, the kind that ill-advised second mortgages are made of.

title: Jack Welch Breaks With Fortune Over Jobs Report Comments
description: 8:19 p.m. | Updated with Mr. Welchs response in The Wall Street Journal.

title: The Movement to Put Utility Payments on Credit Reports
description: It sounds like a good way to help consumers who lack full credit reports, or any credit report at all: Report their utility payments to credit bureaus, to help them develop credit files.

title: Walmart Partners With American Express
description: October 9, 2012 - Walmart partners with American Express to offer a prepaid debit account and card called "Bluebird".

title: An Island Vineyard, the Hard Way
description: AVALON, Calif.

title: TimesCast Politics: Democrats React as the Race Tightens
description: The Associated Press

title: Rangers Roundup: Nash Scores, Hagelin Debuts and McDonagh Heads to K.H.L.
description: 5:03 p.m. | Updated It was a fruitful Tuesday for Rick Nash and Carl Hagelin, two Rangers playing in Europe during the N.H.L. lockout.

title: Cuomo Picks Communications Chief With NBC Ties
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, making one of the first changes to his inner circle since he took office nearly two years ago, has hired a former chief spokeswoman for NBC Universal to serve as his communications director.

title: U.S. Alleges Plot to Kill a Prosecutor and a Judge
description: From his jail cell, where he was serving time for fraud, the man detailed his deadly plot. Kill the federal judge and prosecutor he believed were responsible for putting him behind bars, he told a man he believed to be a killer for hire. Cut off their heads and preserve them in formaldehyde as souvenirs. The payment: $40,000.

title: Taliban Gun Down Girl Who Spoke Up for Rights
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  At the age of 11, Malala Yousafzai took on the Taliban by giving voice to her dreams. As turbaned fighters swept through her town in northwestern Pakistan in 2009, the tiny schoolgirl spoke out about her passion for education  she wanted to become a doctor, she said  and became a symbol of defiance against Taliban subjugation.

title: Italy and Spain Add Support to a Tax on Financial Trades in Europe
description: LUXEMBOURG  Italy and Spain joined nine other European Union countries on Tuesday in backing a tax on financial trades, bringing the most significant attempt at such an initiative a step closer to success.

title: In New York, Another Setback for Rock Radio
description: Once again, rock radio has been dealt a blow in New York.

title: The Sandusky Rape Verdict
description: The case of Jerry Sandusky over the serial raping of young boys while a coach in Penn States football program ended Tuesday as it began: in denial and delusion. In my heart, I know I did not do these alleged disgusting acts, Mr. Sandusky said in a call from the jailhouse to the Pennsylvania State radio station Monday night. My wife has been my only sex partner, and that was after marriage.

title: The Get | Chanels Lion Constellation Brooch
description: Coco Chanels love affair with jewelry was hardly a secret. She sprinkled her clothes with all kinds of things that sparkled  metallic thread woven through her boucls, jewel-like buttons for her jackets  and many of the fine jewelry pieces that she designed have since become house hallmarks. One such piece is the comet necklace she created in 1932, which today, 80 years later, is the anchor for Chanels newest bijoux de diamantes collection. Among its 80 pieces is this one-of-a-kind brooch featuring a lion perched atop that famous falling star. (Coco was a Leo, its worth mentioning.) Set with 1,300 white diamonds totaling more than 14 carats, the pins additional 103 fancy-cut yellow diamonds and 43 fancy-cut orange diamonds make the lions coat and mane, respectively. Ready to roar about it, Chanel is hosting a lavish soiree tonight with Diane Kruger, January Jones and Alexa Chung all expected to attend. Star power, indeed.

title: Irish Housing Market Woes
description: October 9, 2012 - Irish government to pass law encouraging banks to write-down mortgage debt.

title: European Central Banks Leader Sees Progress in Tough Times for Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank on Tuesday joined a small but growing number of economists who argue that, even though the euro zone still faces huge economic problems, there are tentative signs that two years of painful adjustment are beginning to pay off.

title: Pills for the Struggling Student
description: Its long been known that medications designed to boost focus and impulse control in children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder offer the same benefits to people without the disorder. Now, Alan Schwarz reports for The Times in Attention Disorder or Not, Pills to Help in School, some doctors have decided to offer the drugs to students struggling in school for reasons unrelated to A.D.H.D.

title: A Bigger Paycheck on Wall Street
description: It still pays to be on Wall Street.

title: Breaking Down Breess Record-Setting Touchdown
description: Jonathan Bales will analyze a big play each week.

title: Romney Reveals That He Met Former Navy SEAL Killed in Libya
description: VAN METER, Iowa  One day after criticizing President Obama for his handling of the deadly assault on Americans in Benghazi, Libya, Mitt Romney revealed that he had met one of the former Navy SEALs killed at the diplomatic compound there.

title: Rolled by Hands Large and Small
description: LINDA EVANGELISTA once said that she and other superstar models dont wake up for less than $10,000 a day.

title: Mile 2: Where Its All Downhill
description: After a glorious run uphill in the opening mile of the New York City Marathon, Mile 2 is a downhill joy ride from the crest of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge into Brooklyn.

title: The Caucus Click: Feathered Protesters
Yunnan Kitchen
description: Inside the restaurant that showcases the cuisine of the Yunnan Province on the Lower East Side.

title: A Farmers Market, Deep in China
description: SOME dream of the redistribution of wealth. For eaters in search of fresh adventures, a more pressing agenda might be the redistribution of excellent ingredients.

title: The Private Equity Wizardry Behind Realogys Comeback
description: Realogy, the operator of Century 21 and other real estate businesses, is the Rocky Balboa of corporate America. Left for dead in the financial crisis, Realogy has not only survived but is now in a Rocky-like comeback, planning an initial public offering.

title: LWren Scott: A Different Kind of Comfort Food
description: LWren Scotts collections sometimes have enigmatic titles, none more so than her latest: Yorkshire Pudding. That sounded mighty tempting in rain-drenched Paris when she met with buyers and editors in her showroom. David Hockneys touring exhibition A Bigger Picture, based on landscape paintings he did near his home in East Yorkshire, England, inspired Ms. Scotts radiant palette, as well as leaf patterns. Colors have long been a Scott signature, and this season they are distinctively bold: deep aqua (for a dress with a heavy embroidered bodice), dark rose, fuchsia, turquoise (for a boyish leather jacket). Gold is sprinkled throughout the ultra-feminine collection (with a wink at Marlene Dietrich). Theres a solid gold-sequined coat, as well as a plaid halter-neck blouse with a matching gold cardigan. Ms. Scott, who lives part of the year in London, knows England well. In her fashion, she alludes to it with white summer tweeds, plaids, lace jabots, and somewhat tongue-in-cheek shoes done in two colors.

title: Regulator Prepares to Appeal Dodd-Frank Court Ruling
description: Regulators are preparing to appeal a recent court ruling that struck down new curbs on Wall Street trading.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: The Last Time It Was Fun to Be a Knicks Fan
description: Yes, we had Linsanity last season, and though it was undeniably fun, it was brief and illusory. The Knicks decision not to match the Rockets offer for Lin made it seem as if the whole thing had never happened at all. So for the last, true, expansive experience of fun as a Knicks fan, you have to go all the way back to 1999, when Marcus Camby and Latrell Sprewell led a spirited run through the Eastern Conference playoffs. I think Im falling in love, said Doc Rivers, now the Celtics coach, then an announcer, as he watched Camby pluck another offensive rebound from the air and thunderously slam it back home.

title: These People Make Me Sick
description: Lawrence Wilkerson, who should know an irresponsible neo-con when he sees, dished out heavy criticism of Mitt Romneys foreign policy team yesterday. He said, These people make me sick.

title: Lawsuit Charges Motherwell Painting Is Fake
description: A Manhattan art dealer who settled a suit last year involving a fake painting that had been attributed to Robert Motherwell is being sued for selling another work from the same collection as a Motherwell, the Courthouse News Service reported on Tuesday.

title: Muslim Cleric Pleads Not Guilty in Terror Case
description: The fiery Islamic preacher who was flown to the United States from Britain over the weekend after a lengthy extradition battle pleaded not guilty to terrorism charges on Tuesday in a Manhattan courtroom.

title: Led Zeppelin Concert Film Is Released; No Reunion Planned
description: 10:07 p.m. | Updated The three surviving members of Led Zeppelin made it clear on a visit to New York City on Tuesday to promote their concert film Celebration Day that they have no plans to reunite for another concert, much less for a tour or for a new album.

title: When Washington Cheered a Winner
description: In 1924 and 1925, pitcher Walter Johnson and the Washington Senators generated excitement in a city starved for a baseball championship.

title: Questions From Readers on Topics From Jane Austen to Kerry Kennedy
description: As I sometimes do in this blog, I am allowing readers to ask the questions today, and I am providing answers from Times staff members. In two of the three cases, Ill add my own point of view.

title: Big Train Is Still Rolling
description: WASHINGTON  A stranger recently telephoned Carolyn Thomas to ask how old she was when her father died. Twenty-three, she replied.

title: Warming Trend | Puffers for All Occasions
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Cheerful Self-Help Program, Delivered in Song
description: Andrea Marcoviccis annual Manhattan cabaret appearances are more than starry-eyed exercises in pop nostalgia steeped in show business lore. They are full-scale charm offensives that on a good night vanquish opposing armies of cynicism and despair and momentarily turn you into a true believer in the power of that evanescent quality known as glamour.

title: Caregiver, Plus M.D. or R.N.
description: Lets briefly consider this phrase: family caregiver.

title: Heiress, Annie Draw Well in Early Previews on Broadway
description: Two new Broadway revivals The Heiress, starring Oscar nominee Jessica Chastain (The Help) in her Broadway debut, and the famed musical Annie  were solid sellers at the box office last week during their first sets of preview performances, according to ticket sales data released on Tuesday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

title: Nadal Says Injury Comeback Slow but Encouraging
description: Rafael Nadal said that the first few months of rehabilitation for his ailing knees went slowly and discouragingly, capped by being unable to play at the United States Open, but that he has seen more progress recently. He said he hoped to begin practicing again soon.

title: Nibbled to Death
description: ONE of the most inviting openings to a restaurant meal Ive ever heard came when I had closed the menu at Bouley and a server asked, What shall we cook for you this evening? The question managed to suggest that my choices would bring the kitchen intense pleasure, and that the pleasure would be returned to me many times over.

title: Landmarks Commission Approves East Village Historic District
description: The city created a historic district Tuesday aimed at preserving the heart of the East Village.

title: Taking Its Heritage In for a Tuneup
description: ON one of the first days of the season in which a jacket was advisable, Belstaff appeared to be a wise choice. From the outside, everything looked bundled up. Jackets were heavy. Materials were thick. You could do much worse, it seemed, than head in from the cold and allow yourself to take on a layer.

title: Deleveraging Shocks and the Multiplier (Sort of Wonkish)
description: Jonathan Portes  who will be my teammate in a debate on fiscal policy in London next week  weighs in on the IMFs multiplier mea culpa. He confirms that policy makers in many places were working with the assumption of a multiplier on fiscal contraction much less than 1, whereas experience now suggests that its actually more than 1.

title: Critiquing Perfection with Chaos
description: Laura Letinsky, a fine art photographer and a professor at the University of Chicago, has won acclaim for her disorderly photos of food.

title: Returning From War to a Check-Up Full of Holes
description: Nonchalant introductions are exchanged. The formalities are almost insulting; theyre done with such little care and enthusiasm. My name is Im a You know why youre here, correct? And then without any warning she jumps to, Have you ever had thoughts of hurting others? Such an innocent question to most but as I sit here in this stark, drab room I cant help but look at her like shes the crazy one. Given that she works on base, she knows where Ive been for the last year. Gazing through her, intimidation sets in as I read her gilded diplomas affixed to the wall. Meanwhile, her impersonal demeanor allows me to maintain a facade. A simple no suffices, and she moves to the next question. I think to myself, How easy this is? A battery of questions follow: Have you ever thought of hurting yourself? Do you wish to talk to someone about your experiences overseas? Again, one word moves us to the next topic. No red flags. Ten minutes after the first question, I am given a clean bill of mental health.

title: Indias Embrace of Foreign Retailers
description: PATNA, India  A long-festering controversy about whether India should allow foreign retailers like Wal-Mart into the country has often been cast as a battle between millions of small shopkeepers and large corporate interests. But in much of the country, including in this eastern city, the issue often divides Indians as much by age as by their livelihoods.

title: Opposition as Aquarium Seeks Import of Whales
description: A proposal to import 18 beluga whales for popular interactive park attractions in the United States is drawing fierce opposition from animal rights advocates and others who object to their removal from the wild.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefits

title: IPhone 5 Shortage Spooks Apple Investors
description: Every night for the last week, Gene Munster, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, or one of his co-workers has tried to buy an iPhone 5, logging on to Apples Web site about an hour after the company begins letting people reserve one of the phones for next-day pickup in Apple retail stores. So far they havent been able to buy a single iPhone 5 that way.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 9
description: The day in sports, including a ground-level view of the division series.

title: Black Voter Turnout Was Crucial for Obama in North Carolina
description: Turnout in black precincts pushed Democrats over the top in North Carolina in 2008, reversing much of recent history.

title: David Chase on 'Not Fade Away'
description: David Chase, the writer and director of Not Fade Away, discusses his film.

title: Equity in the Tax Code
description: As his fellow Democrats in Congress consider negotiating away the enormous advantage they now have on tax rates, Senator Charles Schumer of New York said today he wouldnt go along. Speaking up for equity and rationality in the tax code, he said taxes for the rich have to go up, as scheduled, on Jan. 1, and cannot be tied to some kind of amorphous tax-reform package.

title: Castaways Gain New Leases on Lives of Promise
description: Two subsections of the television audience will be watching with particular interest when the CW network rolls out a couple of new series on Wednesday and Thursday: fans of Green Arrow comics and cultists who have spent the last two decades mourning the demise of the CBS show Beauty & the Beast.

title: My Small Video Star Fights for Her Life
description: I had the privilege of following Malala Yousafzai, on and off, for six months in 2009, documenting some of the most critical days of her life for a two-part documentary. We filmed her final school day before the Taliban closed down her school in Pakistans Swat Valley; the summer when war displaced and separated her family; the day she pleaded with President Obamas special representative to Afghanistan and Pakistan, Richard Holbrooke, to intervene; and the uncertain afternoon she returned to discover the fate of her home, school and her two pet chickens.

title: New Video Games
description: These edited and condensed reviews are from the writers and editors of the gaming Web site Kotaku.com. Full reviews are at kotaku.com/nytselects.

title: Stream of Fancy, Evading Time
description: Why isnt Douglas Dunn a more celebrated artist? Its an abiding and troublesome mystery.

title: In Anguish of a Storm, an Identity Forged
description: Every now and again during 10 Years, 1 Night, the New Orleans Jazz Orchestras grandiose, guest-laden anniversary concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday, the trumpeter Irvin Mayfield urged the crowd toward a show of rapture. He made it clear that this was for the benefit of another, unseen audience back home, tuned in to WWOZ-FM. The cheers that greeted every prompt were obliging but enthusiastic enough, and maybe a little proprietary: Mr. Mayfield, the orchestras founder and director, wasnt the only person in the hall who wanted the evening to sound, from afar, like a smashing success.

title: Churning Their Way Through a Familiar Labyrinth of Economics and Politics
description: How does the notion of turbulence manifest itself in a dance? For the San Francisco-based choreographer Keith Hennessy, its accomplished through structured disorder. If you create enough chaotic situations, a piece of dance-theater will collapse on itself.

title: For U.S., and Then There Were 22
description: One day after being named to Coach Jurgen Klinsmanns 24-man roster for two World Cup qualifying matches, Landon Donovan and Brek Shea were ruled out because of injuries, U.S. soccer said Tuesday.

title: Heroism and Hazing in a Firehouse
description: The blazes arent very convincing, and neither are the intrasquad dramas in Chicago Fire, Dick Wolfs latest attempt to branch out from his Law & Order base. The series, which has its premiere on Wednesday night on NBC, is really good at doing exactly what you expect, which makes it surprisingly tedious for a show where lives are on the line almost nonstop.

title: Riding Into Carnegie Hall on a Masterpiece by Bach
description: Piano competitions are often criticized for favoring empty virtuosity over originality and introspection. But Minsoo Sohn, the South Korean-born winner of the 2006 Honens International Piano Competition in Calgary, Alberta, and a faculty member at Michigan State University, has proved himself a distinctive artist with his recording of Bachs Goldberg Variations.

title: Music In Review
description: New York University Symphony Orchestra

title: 10 Travel Web Sites Worth Bookmarking
description: People managed to travel quite well before the Internet came along, although how they did it is now shrouded in mystery. There are so many Web sites to help you plan trips and book trips and fantasize about trips and (best of all) save money on trips that the difficulty is not finding a site that will help you but choosing from among the bounty.

title: Suspect in Fatal Stabbing of Soccer Coach Flees to Mexico, Police Say
description: Updated, 1:27 a.m. Wednesday |  The man suspected in the slashing murder of a British soccer coach on West 14th Street over the weekend has fled the country for Mexico, the police said Wednesday.

title: Giving Leftovers a New Place at the Table
description: People want perfection, even if its a falsehood, said Laura Letinsky, who is both a fine-art photographer and a professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Excerpt: The Old Man and the Old Moon
description: A scene from PigPen Theater's production.

title: Obama Makes Last-Minute Appeal for Early Voters in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  On the last day of golden week here  so named because it is the week in which you can register to vote and then vote at the same time and place  President Obama descended on the Ohio State University campus to urge his faithful to head to the polls. Now.

title: Netanyahu Calls for Early Elections in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday called for elections early next year instead of as scheduled in October 2013, saying that conversations with his coalition partners had proved it would be impossible to pass a responsible budget with deep cuts.

title: Class Dismissed: Malalas Story
description: A 2009 documentary by Adam B. Ellick profiled Malala Yousafzai, a Pakistani girl whose school was shut down by the Taliban. Ms. Yousafzai was shot by a gunman on Oct. 9, 2012.

title: Heeding the Siren Call of a Magical Song
description: What do you call this kind of theater? my guest asked, excitedly, after The Old Man and the Old Moon. Good question. Though the show bills itself as a play with music, youll need more words than those to sum it up. For brevitys sake, lets just call it a really fine time.

title: Q&A: Understanding the Fiscal Cliff
description: Updated Nov. 14, 2012

title: Video: David Chase on Not Fade Away
