description: Every week The Shot offers a photo of the people, places or things of our generation. Do you have memories related to this image? Share them with us in the comments.

title: Holding the Keys to the Kingdom
description: Bryan Peele is one of perhaps 1,000 estate managers throughout the United States who manage every detail of properties of high-worth individuals.

title: How Can a Stay-at-Home Mom Get Back to Work?
description: A fellow mother and law-school graduate sent me this quandary. I feel her intense frustration in her words, which I take not as a judgment of others, but of herself and her own particular choice. Does anyone have advice about how to restart a career in an economy that is particularly punishing for those who voluntarily pulled the plug, or how to cope with the feeling of having sabotaged yourself, as you search for a way to make it all work out?

title: Palestinian Artwork at Brandeis
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  Its been a tough few years for art at Brandeis University. Its Rose museum has been struggling to recover from a near-death experience since it tried to sell its distinguished collection in 2009 to fill a financial hole punched by the recession and the Bernard Madoff scandal.

title: Soda Industry Sues to Stop a Sales Ban on Big Drinks
description: New Yorks battle over big sodas is heading to the courtroom.

title: Mondays Arent as Blue as We Think
description: DESPITE the beating that Mondays have taken in pop songs  Fats Domino crooned Blue Monday, how I hate blue Monday  the day does not deserve its gloomy reputation.

title: Downtown Feel Turns Up in Midtown
description: AT one time a primarily industrial area that turned derelict at nightfall, the area north of 34th Street and west of Eighth Avenue, which is included in the citys Hudson Yards redevelopment plan, is already transforming into a comfortable residential neighborhood with a slightly downtown feel.

title: Five Games Into the Season, Tebows Actual Role Remains a Mystery
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Even now, it is all very puzzling, this Tim Tebow thing. He was billed as a short-yardage force, but more than half of his offensive plays have come on first-and-10. Sometimes the Jets deploy him in the red zone, but usually they do not. He lines up at quarterback, at receiver, at running back, at fullback, performing admirably, doing what he is asked, which is not all that much.

title: How Players Like Suzuki Widen the Basepaths
description: Before Raul Ibanezs late-inning homer heroics in Game 3 between New York and Baltimore, the seriess most exciting play took place on  or near  the basepaths in Game 2 when Ichiro Suzuki made like elusive New York Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz in evading catcher Matt Wieterss tag not once but twice for a score (salsa dance not included).

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $15.5 Million
description: A sky-high bachelor pad near the apex of Trump World Tower at 845 United Nations Plaza, the spot the ever-eligible Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter designated as his urban man-cave after Donald Trump personally made him a deal he couldnt refuse, has sold for $15.5 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Between Auto Show and Showroom, a Supercars Mettle Is Tested
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Desert Dynamo
description: With production scheduled to start in less than a year, Porsche brought two prototypes of its 918 Spyder plug-in hybrid supercar to Nevada to test its hot-weather mettle.

title: Pursuing 3-Ds Full Dimensions
description: IN the early 1950s Hollywood faced unexpected competition from a popular new medium  television  that was encouraging the audience to stay at home, parked before tiny screens, rather than venture out to the local movie palace.

title: Shape Shifter | Ken Price at LACMA
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Chris Wares Book in a Box at No. 1
description: Building Stories, by Chris Ware, is at No. 1 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. It feels very much like Christmas morning: you have this wonderful box to open filled with lots of goodies. In this case, Mr. Ware is telling his stories in 14 parts  four Sunday-strip-style broadsheets, one hardcover book, three magazines and more, all contained in a sturdy box. The parts may be in different shapes and sizes, but the stories  about the residents of a brownstone in Chicago  are all very human. The art is richly detailed and the pages are wonderfully designed, both of which are hallmarks of Mr. Wares work.

title: Wheelies: The Bear Market Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Friday Night Lights Creator Accuses Romney of Plagiarism
description: All week Mitt Romney has quoted one of his favorite TV series to punctuate the poignant stories of lives cut short that he has woven into his campaign speeches.

title: Living In | Murray Hill, Queens
description: The other Murray Hill neighborhood, the one next to downtown Flushing, has become home in the last decade to large numbers of new immigrants.

title: Reliving the Glamour of the Supremes
description: MEMBERS may have come and gone during the original two-decade reign of the Supremes, but the sequins and bugle beads always remained the same.

title: Week in Review: What Criminal Case? Inside JPMorgans Rising Profit
description: He may no longer be Americas least-hated banker, but Jamie Dimon still has the hearts of JPMorgans investors.

title: Another Place Named for Those Murrays
description: THE Murray Hill on the East Side of Manhattan isnt the only neighborhood of that name in the city; another one, in Queens, is just east of downtown Flushing. It took its name from members of the same Murray family, which at one time owned a vast plant nursery there, as well as houses on both sides of the East River.

title: Amphibious Car Is Still Waiting to Catch a Wave
description: IF all goes according to plan, the 2013 Quadski will be the first amphibious vehicle from the Gibbs companies to make it into the sales distribution chain. But it wont be the first introduced as ready-for-market.

title: Now Less Interesting, and All the Better for It
description: By JOHN PEARLEY HUFFMAN

title: After Romping in the Mud, You Can Take It for a Bath
description: OXFORD, Mich.

title: The Grace, and the Glee, of a Clown
description: NOT many comics can claim effusive praise from both Jerry Lewis and Franois Truffaut, much less a close partnership with a screenwriter of Luis Buuel movies and a role in a Robert Bresson film. Yet the French performer Pierre Etaix, one of cinemas finest physical comedians after the silent era, is little known even to fans of Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Turkey, India and New York.

title: An Allroad Without Ups and Downs
description: AUDI says the introduction of a new Allroad wagon for the American market, after an eight-year absence, signifies the return of the icon.

title: Teaching Respect to the Faithful
description: ALIA RAMER, a mother of three from Maplewood, N.J., first noticed the problem when her daughter was just reaching adolescence, the age when many Jewish children celebrate their bar and bat mitzvahs.

title: Q & A
description: Building Requires Pet Deposit

title: President Obama to Appear as Guest on The Daily Show on Oct. 18
description: 5:33 p.m. | Updated Perhaps looking for another outlet to reach his base constituency, President Obama has agreed to appear as a guest with Jon Stewart on Comedy Centrals The Daily Show on Oct. 18.

title: Talk at Ad Conference Turns to Risk, Failure and Mistakes
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Advertising ought to be more of a risky business, according to some of the more interesting and best-received speakers at a major marketing conference.

title: Javits Center, 2:38 P.M.
Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Ireland is close to approving a bold measure to help troubled homeowners, Wall Street compensation is near record levels and foreign chains are finding a foothold in India.

title: Giants and 49ers Ratchet Up Pregame Hyperbole
description: Apparently, saying that a player gets away with murder, even in a figurative sense, is not a way to endear yourself to San Francisco Coach Jim Harbaugh.

title: From Star Father on a Series to a Clueless One at Home
description: Consider the Eternal Truths of Television. About every six months, a news anchor or weather forecaster will accidentally say something vulgar into a live microphone. At any given moment, a shopping channel will be offering something for $19.99, with an extra one thrown in free, if you call right now. And somebody, somewhere, will always be willing to give Scott Baio another TV show.

title: Tailgating Recipe: Bacon Smores
description: A couple of weeks ago, some readers were upset with us because we presented a recipe for an alcoholic beverage. We appreciate their concerns. (For the record, the only complaint we heard about the actual recipe for Overtime Punch from those who tried it was, we didnt make enough!) Anyway, this week we decided to present something more wholesome.

title: At Home in a House of Horrors
description: The waitress at the Brazier Burger drive-in in Savannah got it right, sort of, when she decided that Edgar Oliver and his sister must be from Transylvania. Mr. Oliver was a little boy, and had rarely ventured far from his Georgia home, when that assessment was made. But if he talked anything like the way he does today, it was a logical assumption.

title: Giants Nicks Returns to Practice and Hopes to Play Against 49ers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Wide receiver Hakeem Nicks, who has missed three consecutive games with injuries to his knee and surgically-repaired right foot, returned to practice on Friday amid expectations that he will play for the Giants when they visit the 49ers on Sunday.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 12
description: A selection of images of the Frieze Art Fair in London, the Jane Austen Society of North Americas annual convention and actor John Hawkes.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 12
description: More Photographs

title: Obama to Appear on Daily Show Next Week
description: When all else fails, make fun of self.

title: Chic in Review | The Justin Bieber Files
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.Atwood, BrianThe shoe designer opens his first store. Where? Why uptown Manhattan, of course.

title: Another Reason You Might Not Want to Be President
description: Among the memorable tidbits of Michael Lewiss extended hang at the White House for Vanity Fair was President Obamas description of his ascetic lifestyle. Youll see I wear only gray or blue suits, the president told Lewis. Im trying to pare down decisions. I dont want to make decisions about what Im eating or wearing. Because I have too many other decisions to make.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Chelsea duplex co-op, a Stuyvesant Square co-op and a Sunset Park co-op.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom converted barn in Old Westbury, N.Y., and a  four-bedroom Cape Cod-style house in Chatham, N.J.

title: Last-Ditch Bid in Texas to Try to Stop Oil Pipeline
description: WINNSBORO, Tex.  Deep within the oak and pine forests that blanket this stretch of East Texas, the chug of machinery drones on late into the day, broken only by the sounds of a band of activists who have vowed to stop it.

title: Sharing Lessons From a Farm in Japan
description: THOUGH she had intended to spend only one year abroad, Nancy Singleton Hachisu has lived in a small village in rural Japan for more than 20.

title: Miso Makes Vegetables Sing
description: In this weeks City Kitchen column, I write about the new cookbook Japanese Farm Food, by Nancy Singleton Hachisu, which tells the story of life on a small organic farm. Though the book gives methods for everything from plucking a chicken to making tofu from scratch, the simple recipes for fresh farm-grown vegetables are especially inspiring.

title: As Take Curtain Call After Bowing Out
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It took far longer than anybody expected, but the team that was never supposed to be here finally no longer is. No exhortations from Grant Balfour or clutch hitting from Coco Crisp would save them this time. A 6-0 loss to a dominant Justin Verlander and the Detroit Tigers ended Oaklands dream season five games into the playoffs.

title: In Maine, a Kumbaya Moment for the Billboards of the Road
description: In an uncommon display of cross-corporate synergy, the L.L. Bean Bootmobile, Oscar Mayer Wienermobile, Peeps Peepster and Lindt Chocolate Gold Bunny convened on Friday in Freeport, Me., the corporate headquarters of L.L. Bean.

title: Graphene Could Usher in Flexible, Ultra-Slim Gadgets
description: Youve probably never heard of graphene, a carbon-based material, but it might be stuffed into your pocket or wrapped around your wrist in the not-too-distant future.

title: Descendants of Old Money Look Back at a Benefit It Wrought
description: Mary R. Morgan said she was seeing it for the first time: the building on the Lower East Side that $15,000 of her great-grandfathers money had gone into, back in 1899  a sum that would have the purchasing power of $420,000 in todays dollars, according to the Web site measuringworth.com.

title: Vice-Presidential Debate Draws More Than 50 Million Viewers
description: Thursdays televised debate between Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan attracted well over 50 million people  a significant chunk of the public, but a smaller total than the debate between the presidential candidates last week.

title: Star Spotting at the Beverly Hills Hotel
description: The hotel has long played host to Hollywood royals.

title: The Dowagers Makeover
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: The Week in New York Region Pictures for Oct. 12
description: Subjects include walrus inhabitants at the New York Aquarium, the Columbus Day Parade and a ceremony for new inscriptions on the citys Police Memorial Wall.

title: Week in Pictures for Oct. 12
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include walrus inhabitants at the New York Aquarium, the Columbus Day Parade and a ceremony for new inscriptions on the citys Police Memorial Wall.

title: Taliban Reiterate Vow to Kill Pakistani Girl
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  The police said Friday that they had made several arrests in connection with the Talibans shooting of Malala Yousafzai, a 14-year-old education activist who was critically injured, but militant commanders in northwestern Pakistan reiterated their intention to kill the schoolgirl or her father.

title: A Deal From the Long Island Fall Regional
description: Justine Cushing, Melih Ozdil and Joel Wooldridge of New York City, and Lew Finkel of Jupiter, Fla., were the most successful players at the Long Island Fall Regional in Smithtown, N.Y., last week, winning all five events that they entered.

title: World Cup Qualifying: U.S. 2, Antigua and Barbuda 1
description: The United States is on the road Friday night for a World Cup qualifier against Antigua & Barbuda at Sir Vivian Richards Stadium in Antigua. Kickoff is 7 p.m; the game is being televised by beIN Sport, so count yourself fortunate if youre settling down to watch.

title: Federal Deficit for 2012 Falls to $1.1 Trillion
description: WASHINGTON  The federal deficit fell to $1.1 trillion in the 2012 fiscal year, down from about $1.3 trillion a year earlier, the Obama administration said on Friday.

title: Southern Comfort, Cooked Low and Slow
description: I ATE hush puppies out of context at Merediths New Orleans Cuisine, a boxy little restaurant that shares a foyer with the Twilight Bar and Lounge in Manalapan.

title: In a Shoebox, an Owl and a Mystery
description: Update, Dec. 12 |  The owl, fully recovered, was released into the wild. Read the follow-up post.

title: A Bloggers Caregiving Chapter Closes
description: For several years, Ive been a fan of Chuck Rosss Life With Father blog. In 2008 Mr. Ross, a journalist and consultant who had recently moved to Cape Cod, took in his father, Charles Ross Sr., and has been chronicling his caregiving experiences almost ever since.

title: Flashing Lights and Thrashing Music in a Search for Order and Chaos
description: Political Mother, the first evening-length work by the Israeli-born choreographer Hofesh Shechter, arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday laden with praise and a warning. In Britain, where Mr. Shechters company is based and where he has become a dance world star, this 2010 dance received widespread acclaim for its theatricality and political commentary. The warning had to do with the volume of Mr. Shechter s score of drums and heavy-metal guitar: loud.

title: From the Island of Sicily, a Distinct Cuisine
description: SOME restaurants have great food, some have terrible food, and some have both. Sicilia Risturanti is one of the uneven places. The food here has as many peaks and valleys as the terrain of Sicily.

title: Friday Night Music: The Arrangement of the Rice
description: In honor of my current location. And what a joy streaming video is! Ive known this music for decades, but never got to see a stage production, so Im seeing this for the first time. Bonus points for the lesson on physiocratic economics in the middle:

title: Frieze Art Fair
description: The annual contemporary art fair in London has expanded its brand.

title: The Personality Problem
description: In the 19th century, sermons were a big deal. Theyd be reprinted in newspapers. In the 20th century, psychoanalysts were a big deal. There were a number of best-selling authors spinning theories about the psyche, which had a large impact on how people saw the world and themselves. This includes not only Freud and Jung, but also people like Erick Erikson, Erich Fromm, Carl Rogers, Viktor Frankl and Philip Rieff. Today were more into cognition and the brain. Over the years, attention has shifted from the soul to the personality to decision-making. Preoccupations have migrated from salvation to psychic security to success.

title: Paul Ryans Christmas Tale
description: Thursday nights debate was light on personal anecdotes, but Paul Ryan did have time for a rather revealing Christmas tale.

title: A Sibling for a Shiny Art Show in London
description: LONDON  Soon after the Frieze art fair opened its doors on Wednesday morning to those who are solemnly known as serious collectors, a man stood in the White Cube booth contemplating Damien Hirsts silver and black Destruction Dreamscape. After a few moments he turned to his smartly garbed companion. She looked at him expectantly.

title: Drafting Antitrust Case, F.T.C. Raises Pressure on Google
description: The Federal Trade Commission is raising the ante in its antitrust confrontation with Google with the commission staff preparing a recommendation that the government sue the search giant.

title: In Vietnam, a Lively Gathering Place
description: The Tran Huu Trang market is an adventurous alternative to Ho Chi Minh Citys more tourist-oriented markets.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,118 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Comfort Food Kept Sophisticatedly Simple
description: WHAT kind of dining experience would you expect to have in a restaurant serving corn chowder, pork and beans, and fried chicken with watermelon? Almost certainly not what you get at Millwrights, where Tyler Anderson offers a brashly elegant take on these and other homey American classics. A winner on the Food Network show Chopped, Mr. Anderson decamped this summer from Copper Beech Inn in Ivoryton to open his own restaurant in a historic West Street mill. His fans have been thronging the place ever since.

title: Reviewing the Acura RDX
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the Acura RDX, refreshed for 2013 to wrest away sales from segment stalwarts like the BMW X3, Audi Q5 and Infiniti EX35.

title: When Design Burst From Cloth
description: THE world of design has produced many celebrated couples: the Eameses, the Toledos ... the Tilletts?

title: Yankees Seeking Changes in YES Ownership
description: The Yankees are looking for the right investor to buy out their partners in the YES Network, including Goldman Sachs.

title: Local Ingredients and Local Ambience
description: A PERFECTLY ripe, juicy tomato is a wonderful thing. It was September, and I had somehow managed to go through the whole summer without experiencing that quintessential summer taste. Then I went to Bistro Rollin. The B.L.T. salad was exactly what Id been missing. The mixed greens were crispy, the bacon expertly rendered, the dressing a pleasingly sharp garlic aioli. But it was the tomatoes that won my heart. They were a perfect balance of sweet and acidic, the outer skin tight but yielding quickly to an intense concentration of flavor. I felt as if I could finally let the season go and welcome autumn.

title: Divorced Adults
description: New Jersey has the lowest percentage of adults who are now divorced.

title: Desperately Auditioning for a Chance to Shine
description: A Chorus Line is at once a period piece and a brilliantly timeless work of musical theater about talented people who are striving to achieve their dreams  or at least to make a living. One of them, Mitzi Hamilton  the inspiration for the shows saucy character Val, who advances her career through strategic plastic surgery  is directing the production currently at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

title: Want Your Union to Last? Marry in New Jersey
description: ALL that nasty gossip notwithstanding, Teresa Giudice, resolute as ever on the recent Real Housewives of New Jersey reunion, apparently has not dissolved her stormy marriage. Which squares with the latest Census Bureau figures on divorce in the Garden State.

title: Ann Romneys Style
description: Mrs. Romney has been spotted wearing Alfred Fiandaca designs at various events.

title: Preaching and Converting Get a Young Man Into Trouble. Sound Familiar?
description: It was only a matter of time before A. R. Gurney decided to answer the question What would Jesus do? And of course he would unveil his response at the Flea Theater.

title: Fighting for Women in the Dark Heaven of Gaza
description: GAZA CITY  ANDALIB ADWAN SHEHADA has lived all but two of her 47 years here in the Gaza Strip, yet the neighbors along the alley where she and her family built a three-story home in 1998 have taken to calling them the foreigners.

title: Space Shuttle Endeavour Rolls Through Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  The space shuttle Endeavour rolled out of Los Angeles International Airport around 2 a.m. Friday for what has been named Mission 26: the two-day crawl through urban streets to retirement at the California Science Center 12 miles away.

title: The Dresser Behind Ann Romney
description: LAST Wednesday, on Good Morning America, Ann Romney baked Welsh cakes and talked equine therapy in a red Alfred Fiandaca stretch taffeta shirtdress from his fall 2012 ready-to-wear collection  a number she also wore at the farewell victory rally for the Republican National Convention on Aug. 31 in Lakeland, Fla.

title: The Potato, as Art and Instrument
description: EAST ISLIP, N.Y.

title: Russia Protests Treatment of Russians Arrested in Texas
description: MOSCOW  Several Russians arrested last week in Texas and accused of illegally exporting microelectronics to Russian military and intelligence agencies have been subjected to psychological and moral pressure to make admissions of guilt, the Russian Foreign Ministry said Friday in a statement.

title: Flashy Moves and Loud Stomping as a Festival Comes to a Close
description: The final Fall for Dance program opened on Thursday evening with Shen Weis too familiar 2003 take on Rite of Spring. Yet to give indication of the direness that followed, Rite of Spring was the high point.

title: Intimate Moments in a Voluminous Hall
description: The title that Kent Tritle, the music director of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, has revived for its concerts, Great Music in a Great Space, has a nice ring to it, like that of Sacred Music in a Sacred Space, the series Mr. Tritle founded at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in 1989 and directed until his move to the cathedral last season. But it doesnt have quite the same symmetry.

title: A Messenger Who Does the Shooting
description: TWO days after President Obamas first debate against Mitt Romney, Stephanie Cutter, a deputy campaign manager for the Obama re-election effort, decided to tweak Mr. Romney for his attack on federal funding for PBS.

title: Report Could Open Armstrong to Legal Issues
description: Although federal prosecutors abruptly abandoned a criminal investigation related to doping accusations against Lance Armstrong earlier this year, the report released on Wednesday by antidoping officials is likely to create new legal issues for Armstrong.

title: Women on the Verge of an Explanation
description: The publicity flier for Penguin Reps production of The How and the Why includes one of those ascent-of-man images  a series of figures that begins with a slouching, long-armed ape and ends with a tall, erect hominid. In this instance, the human striding so confidently into the future is a pony-tailed woman wearing slacks and carrying a briefcase. So it was a good bet that Sarah Treems play would have something to say about evolution and something to say about feminism. But as it turns out, that is only the starting point for a smart, densely textured work about men and women, love and conflict, genes and destiny.

title: Opponents and Supporters of Egypts President Clash
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of Islamist supporters of Egypts new president clashed with his more secular opponents on Friday as rival demonstrations in the city center, Tahrir Square, devolved into a battle of fists, rocks and Molotov cocktails. At least 110 people were injured, according to state news agencies, and protesters set fire to two buses that had transported members of the presidents political party to the square.

title: A Sad Sequence of Collisions
description: AT the Democratic National Convention, Michelle Obama shared a pithy car story calculated to remind Americans of her husbands humble origins. Long before he was president, she recalled, he drove a car so rusted out that she could see the pavement going by in a hole in the passenger side door. Mitt Romney, whose father was president of American Motors Corporation, made a different point during a speech in Detroit last winter: I drive a Mustang and a Chevy pickup truck. Ann drives a couple of Cadillacs, actually.Stories about the Romneys cars  and the dog that rode atop one  have proved welcome fodder for late-night comedians.

title: Notes on a Vice-Presidential Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn States Response
description: To the Editor:

title: M.T.A. Weighs Who Will Pay When It Raises Transit Fares
description: In the broadest sense, the debate over fare increases on New York City subways and buses was over before it began.

title: Airport Security Ruse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Big Grin, an Angry Satchmo
description: WHO knew Louis Armstrong had such a mouth on him? And we dont mean embouchure.

title: Yankees Move Past Orioles to A.L.C.S.
description: It took well over a month of unrelenting high-tension baseball, and five more games into the playoffs, but the Yankees finally disposed of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Mayor, 91, Admits Stealing From Her Alabama Town
description: A small Alabama town is struggling to understand how its 91-year-old mayor could have stolen $201,000 in taxpayer funds over the last three years without being caught until this week.

title: On The Non-burden of Debt
description: Brad DeLong takes on Nick Rowe over this bizarrely confused issue; in a moment Ill try to offer a new way of explaining why the conventional presentation is all wrong.

title: A Toast, and a Last Hurrah
description: There is no chocolate pudding at this museum cafeteria. But there is blood pudding, beef cheek stroganoff and maple pie at M. Wells Dinette. The Montreal chef Hugue Dufour and his wife, Sarah Obraitis, earned foodie fame for their short-lived M. Wells Diner in Long Island City, Queens. Their new venture opened three weeks ago inside nearby MoMA P.S. 1, blending a schoolroom motif (desks and chalkboards) with diner accents (chrome and stools). Early this month, they doused controversy by striking a planned dish of horse meat tartare from the menu, but they still offer plenty of adventure to the loyalists, neighborhood workers and unsuspecting museumgoers who stream inside for lunch.

title: To Go Distance, Tigers Lean on Starters
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the middle of the Detroit Tigers clubhouse celebration on Thursday night, reliever Octavio Dotel managed to keep a fat cigar lit and dry  no small feat with nonalcoholic sparkling wine flying everywhere, some of it sprayed and poured by the 38-year-old Dotel himself.

title: Veeps Go Yeep! Nation Nods.
description: O.K. Forget everything thats happened so far. Now its all about the next debate.

title: On Edge as Syrias War Knocks Ever Harder on the Door to Turkey
description: HACIPASA, Turkey  The men stood at the roads edge and watched the war that is inching ever closer to home. Amid the rumble of explosions, workers picked cotton and red peppers in this nook of Turkeys fertile southwest.

title: A War With No Name, but at Least One Battlefield Casualty
description: A week later, the question still hovers over the Lower East Side. It is barked in anger from a crying aunt, or spoken with a young mans quick look over his shoulder, or conveyed, without words, in the cold stare of a police officer behind the wheel of an idling marked car.

title: Despite Ad Barrage, Two Incumbents Vying for One Seat Still Feel Unheard
description: MEDINA, Ohio  Somewhere in the barrage of negative political advertising that is saturating the airwaves of greater Cleveland, Representative James B. Renacci acknowledges in a new commercial  that neither he nor his Democratic opponent, Representative Betty Sutton, hates puppies or grandmothers.

title: Leaf and Death
description: A short animated film by Jeff Scher celebrates the fading (yet somehow glowing) leaves of autumn.

title: Leaf and Death
description: After a few cold nights the colors come on like glowing embers. Then they burst into flame. They crackle in flickering reds, yellows and electric greens. They are beautiful and surreal against the infinite blues of a chilly October afternoon sky. Entire landscapes are transformed into a state of agitated Technicolor. Its natures color-coded warning of the approaching longer nights and colder days sneaking up the calendar.

title: One Among Many
description: Most major leaguers begin their baseball lives head and shoulders above other players. They may have dominated Little League; at school, they might have stood tall even as freshmen among seniors; later, maybe they were a very high draft pick. Even so, theres always a moment when they realize there is, and always will be, someone better.

title: San Francisco Is a Throwback by Throwing Less Often
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a let-it-fly age when N.F.L. teams tend to rely on strong-armed quarterbacks and playmakers who can change the complexion of a game with one touch, the 49ers offense begins with a 3-yards-and-a-cloud-of-dust philosophy and takes that to another level.

title: The Operas Wardrobe Diva
description: WITH 15 minutes before curtain at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, Suzi Gomez-Pizzo, 51, was still waiting outside the dressing room of the renowned Russian soprano Anna Netrebko.

title: Data on Iran Dims Outlook for Economy
description: Daily oil production in Iran, the most important component of its economy, fell in September to the weakest level in nearly a quarter-century, according to monthly data released on Friday by the International Energy Agency. The agency forecast declines in Irans ability to produce oil for years to come if Western sanctions were not lifted.

title: Convening an Algonquin Table at Kochs Place
description: Slouching in a club chair with his left leg draped over the arm, Edward I. Koch shared an anecdote. Not surprisingly, it was about him. But Mr. Koch is always an engaging storyteller. And what made this one special was that the half-dozen friends and former colleagues assembled in his Greenwich Village living room had never heard it before.

title: Wanted: A Berth for a Lonely Old Ship
description: Efforts by the South Street Seaport Museum to return one of its tall ships to Hamburg, Germany, where it was originally launched, have fallen through.

title: Time to Change Expectations for Aging Slugger
description: I keep telling you guys, Alex Rodriguez told reporters after batting practice Friday, this is not a story about one person.

title: Can a Race Among Doped Cyclists Be Fair? One Former Armstrong Teammate Says No.
description: Last Updated | Saturday, 1:38 p.m. Since Lance Armstrong waived his right to appeal the United States Anti-Doping Agencys finding that his victories in the Tour de France were aided by systematic doping  confirmed in the sworn testimony of 11 former teammates made public this week  some of his fans have suggested that, since it now appears that most of the professional peloton was doping at the same time, Armstrong should still be considered the winner of those races.

title: Focus Was on Tripoli in Requests for Security in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  In the weeks leading up to the attack last month on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans, diplomats on the ground sounded increasingly urgent alarms. In a stream of diplomatic cables, embassy security officers warned their superiors at the State Department of a worsening threat from Islamic extremists, and requested that the teams of military personnel and State Department security guards who were already on duty be kept in service.

title: Letting Movers Bid to Haul Your Stuff
description: Sharone Ben-Harosh, a longtime veteran of the moving industry, has no illusions about his ability to make people actually enjoy the experience of packing their lives into boxes and relocating.

title: Funeral Trumpets in Chinatown
description: The funerals of Chinese dignitaries often used brass bands, so when Chinatown expanded into Little Italy, Italian bands, like the Red Mike Festival Band, remained staples in the area.

title: Rabbi Linked to Campaign Inquiry Is Questioned in Israeli Bribe Case
description: A prominent rabbi who is a figure in the federal inquiry into the campaign of Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island has been put under house arrest in Israel in a bribery and money-laundering investigation there, the Israeli police said on Friday.

title: Armstrong Aide Talks of Doping and Price Paid
description: The job title is soigneur, an elegant sounding name for the person on a professional cycling team who is assigned some unglamorous work: massaging the muscles of the cyclists, laundering their clothes, booking their hotel rooms and preparing their food. Discretion and loyalty are also part of the job.

title: Why Netanyahu Backed Down
description: FOR three years Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his defense minister, Ehud Barak, seemed to be united in urging an early military attack on Irans nuclear facilities. But last week that alliance collapsed, with Mr. Netanyahu accusing Mr. Barak of having conspired with the Obama administration, in talks behind his back.

title: Ex-Workers at Firm Tied to Pharmacy Had Safety Fears
description: BOSTON One pharmacist said she quit because she was worried that unqualified people were helping prepare dangerous narcotics for use by hospitals. A quality control technician said he tried to stop the production line when he noticed that some labels were missing, but was overruled by management. A salesman said he and his colleagues were brought into the sterile lab to help out with packaging and labeling during rush orders, something they were not trained for.

title: Lottery Numbers
Scrutiny for Home Appraisers as the Market Struggles
description: When Justin Olson put his Southwestern-style ranch house outside Phoenix on the market, he got what he was expecting: an immediate batch of offers, virtually all above his asking price, which was set intentionally low, at $197,500, to attract interest. He chose an offer of $210,000.

title: Chicago Schools Chief Steps Down After 17 Months That Ended With Teacher Strike
description: CHICAGO  Just three weeks after a teacher strike here that kept 350,000 children from their classrooms, the head of the citys public schools system has chosen to step down, Mayor Rahm Emanuel said at a news conference on Friday.

title: U.S. Rethinks a Drug War After Deaths in Honduras
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras  The Honduran Air Force pilot did not know what to do. It was the dead of night, and he was chasing a small, suspected drug plane at a dangerously low altitude, just a few hundred feet above the Caribbean. He fired warning shots, but instead of landing, the plane flew lower and closer to the sea.

title: Who Will Mourn George Whitmore?
description: I RECEIVED news this week of the death of George Whitmore Jr., an occurrence noted, apparently, by no one in the public arena.

title: Ending as Winners in All Ways but One
description: The door to the Baltimore Orioles clubhouse was closed for more than 15 minutes at the conclusion of Fridays game, which is a little longer than is customary. When the door opened, Manager Buck Showalter emerged to say he had lost track of the time.

title: Italian Brass for Chinatown Goodbyes
description: On a stretch of Mulberry Street last month, squeezed between Columbus Park and the Wah Lai Funeral Home, a snare drum rolled, and dignified brass horns answered.

title: Voter Registration Rolls in 2 States Are Called Vulnerable to Hackers
description: Computer security experts have identified vulnerabilities in the voter registration databases in two states, raising concerns about the ability of hackers and others to disenfranchise voters.

title: The Moderate Mitt Myth
description: The way a presidential candidate campaigns for office matters to the country. A campaign should demonstrate seriousness of purpose and a set of core beliefs, and it should signal to voters whether a candidate shows trustworthiness and judgment. Those things dont seem to matter to Mitt Romney.

title: Secret Israel-Syria Peace Talks Involved Golan Heights Exit
description: JERUSALEM  For several months in 2010, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel engaged in secret, American-brokered discussions with Syria for a possible peace treaty based on a full Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights.

title: Runners at Van Cortlandt Park
description: Van Cortlandt Park has been a wellspring of athletic purity and a touchstone of grace and empowerment for thousands of runners.

title: Another Fare Increase?
description: More than 8.5 million riders in the New York City area may soon start paying a lot more to get to work every day. Next week, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to propose fare and toll increases to raise another $450 million a year. If approved, this increase, in 2013, would be the fourth in five years.

title: Come to the Surface
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  You know whats nice? There are still surprises for me in crossword puzzles, even after making scores of them and solving many more.

title: Corrections: October 13, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: South Carolinas Voting Rights Act
description: A three-judge federal panel told South Carolina this week that the state could not enforce its new voter photo ID law until after the November elections. There is not enough time to educate voters about the laws complexities, the court said, noting further that rushing the rules into effect could have racially discriminatory outcomes because South Carolina voters who lack the required photo ID are disproportionately African-American.

title: A Nobel for the Continent
description: Perhaps we should congratulate the European Union for winning the Nobel Peace Prize and let it go at that. It is not, after all, unusual for the Norwegian committee to select an organization rather than an individual, and the E.U. surely satisfies Alfred Nobels criteria of forging fraternity between nations, reducing standing armies, and holding and promoting peace congresses.

title: Turning Point for Suits Over Chinese Drywall
description: Three years ago, Colleen Stephens moved her family from a 5,000-square-foot, newly renovated home overlooking the bay in Virginia Beach into a house half the size and much farther inland.

title: The Other Carnegies
description: Q. Someone told me that Dale Carnegie, the expert on salesmanship and public speaking, was named after Carnegie Hall. True?

title: Late Goal Eases Pressure on U.S. in World Cup Qualifying
description: NORTH SOUND, Antigua and Barbuda  Often thought of as a safe bet to qualify every four years for the World Cup, the United States national team nearly found itself facing early elimination Friday night before it was rescued by a late second-half goal from Eddie Johnson and beat Antigua and Barbuda, 2-1.

title: Bill Cunningham | Bubbly
description: The guests at Rick Owenss Paris show were mostly in black, but the designer tried to wash black out of the scene for spring by showing champagne colors.

title: Claims on Abortion and Afghanistan Get a Closer Look
description: The vice-presidential debate on Thursday provoked heated discussion into the next day. Here are a look at two disputed claims.

title: Britain: 7 Royal Marines Arrested Over 2011 Death in Afghanistan
description: The authorities in London said Friday that seven members of the Royal Marines had been arrested on suspicion of murder after an engagement with an insurgent in Afghanistan last year, apparently the first time that members of British services have been held on such charges in more than a decade of war there. The Defense Ministry said no civilians were involved in the episode, which, the BBC reported, concerned a commando brigade stationed in the troubled Helmand Province.

title: Espada Speaks Softly as He Pleads Guilty to a Single Tax Charge
description: For years, Pedro Espada Jr., the former Democratic state senator, railed viciously against anyone who dared to question him. He took a fighters relish in attacking both the political foes who failed to stem his rise and the prosecutors who accused him of stealing from the nonprofit health care center he founded and ran in the Bronx.

title: France: Appeal in Gang-Rape Case
description: A public prosecutor on Friday appealed the rulings of a French court on Wednesday in a gruesome gang-rape trial, calling many of the 10 acquittals in the case and the sentences for the four convictions inappropriate. The case involves two women from a poor suburb outside Paris who said they were repeatedly raped, often by as many as two dozen men at once, between 1999 and 2001. Of the 14 defendants, 4 were convicted of gang rape; 2 of them received one-year prison sentences, one received a six-month prison term and one a suspended sentence. Several government ministers had voiced concern with the rulings, and womens groups had reacted angrily.

title: At Home in the Apollo Theater
description: Billy Mitchell, the resident historian and official tour guide for the Apollo Theater in Harlem, started working at the famous music hall in 1965, when he was 15. As he tells the story, his mother sent him from their home in the Bronx to borrow money from his Aunt Essie, who lived across the street from the theater. His aunt wasnt home, so he hung around the stage door and wound up fetching coffee for that evenings acts  a simple errand that over time led to a larger career.

title: China: Suit for Anti-Japan Attack
description: The lawyer for Li Jianli, who was badly beaten in Xian for driving a Japanese-made car during anti-Japan protests in China last month, said by telephone Friday that Mr. Li had decided to sue the local police on grounds of serious negligence. In the complaint, Mr. Li accused the police of failing to respond quickly and effectively to the violence during the protests. He is seeking 500,000 renminbi, or about $80,000, to cover his medical expenses and property damage costs. A suspect in the attack is awaiting trial.

title: With Big East as Backdrop, Connecticut Coach Faces His Protg
description: CHESHIRE, Conn.  Just off Route 10, past the sleepy trickle of antique shops and greenhouses, rests a flat expanse of cabbage patches, tomato rows and cornfields  the staple crops since 1956 at Pasqualoni Farm. On many early fall weekend mornings, Paul Pasqualoni would drive his familys produce truck to markets in New Haven.

title: Nearly 4,600 Get Deportation Reprieves
description: Two months after the Obama administration started giving reprieves from deportation and work permits to young immigrants here illegally, 179,794 applications have been received and 4,591 have been approved, according to new figures from the Department of Homeland Security. The number of approvals increased significantly since officials reported on Sept. 14 that 29 immigrants had been the first ones granted the two-year deportation deferrals. But Peter Boogaard, a department spokesman, said immigrants should now expect that the average time to process an application would be four to six months. As many as 1.2 million immigrants could be eligible.

title: Orioles Miss Their Chances, Including Close Call in Sixth
description: In a division series mostly notable for the large number of star sluggers who were rendered incapable of hitting, the Baltimore Orioles could not have asked for more from Nate McLouth. But in two key at-bats of Game 5, he came up short against C. C. Sabathia.

title: Mystery in Offer by Terrorist to Cooperate
description: Federal officials had to be intrigued a few years ago when they learned that the terrorist Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, who is serving a life sentence at the Supermax prison in Colorado for orchestrating the 1993 World Trade Center bombing and other crimes, wanted to cooperate with the authorities.

title: Security Council Seeks to Aid Mali
description: The Security Council unanimously passed a resolution on Friday authorizing the use of military force to assist Malis government in reclaiming the northern half of the country. Radical Islamists have turned the territory into an enclave for Qaeda militants and for the imposition of harsh Shariah law, which has been used to terrorize the population with amputations, stonings, whippings and other abuses, particularly against women. The Council resolution, sponsored by France, says the Islamists and their collaborators in northern Mali may be held accountable for war crimes. It gives Secretary General Ban Ki-moon 45 days to devise a plan to help the Malian authorities and endorses the deployment of troops from the Economic Community of West African States as part of the plan.

title: New Parks Chief Is a Voice for Expansion
description: Maybe it was the experience of growing up in a family with 12 children in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, that propelled Veronica M. White outdoors and fostered a passion for parkland. Shore Road Park, with its sweeping views of New York Bay and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, became Ms. Whites extended backyard.

title: I Say Missouri, You Say ...
description: Some candidates running for statewide offices in Missouri use two pronunciations of the state.

title: Missouree? Missouruh? To Be Politic, Say Both
description: In Missouri, a perennial swing state with a deeply divided electorate, it has long been one of the politically delicate calculations a candidate can make.

title: Oct. 12: Romney Debate Gains Show Staying Power
description: Mitt Romney continues to surge in the FiveThirtyEight forecast, and Friday may have featured his best set of polls all year.

title: Yankees-Orioles Replay: Game 5
description: C. C. Sabathia went the distance as the Yankees beat the Orioles.

title: Despite Prize, European Union Loses Much of Its Appeal as Unity Eludes Continent
description: FRANKFURT  In awarding the Nobel Peace Prize to the European Union on Friday, the Norwegian Nobel Committee endorsed the organizations creation story  that it has kept chronic enemies from repeating the horrors of two world wars, and remains essential for that reason.

title: Dear Teacher, Johnny Is Skipping the Test
description: LATER this month, children at 169 New York City elementary and middle schools will, for the second time in a calendar year, take a 40-minute field test in math and English language arts to determine which questions will go on future state standardized exams.

title: Syrias War Edges Closer to Turkey
description: Turkish residents are witnessing one of the gravest concerns about the Syrian conflict: that it would spill over the border and become a regional conflagration.

title: After Benghazi Attack, Private Security Hovers as an Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Lost amid the election-year wrangling over the militants attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi, Libya, is a complex back story involving growing regional resentment against heavily armed American private security contractors, increased demands on State Department resources and mounting frustration among diplomats over ever-tighter protections that they say make it more difficult to do their jobs.

title: Teixeiras Stolen Base Gets the Yankees Moving
description: Early in this American League division series, Mark Teixeira noticed that Orioles first baseman Mark Reynolds would not hold him on the bag when he reached first. He considered stealing but never felt spry enough to try. The left calf strain that had cost him nearly all of September kept holding him back.

title: Lockout Has Rangers Kreider Playing in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD  Chris Kreider stayed on the ice long after practice Friday morning, firing shots, playfully bumping his Connecticut Whale teammates.

title: Ryan Joins Criticism of Administration on Libya Attack
description: LANCASTER, Ohio  Representative Paul D. Ryan joined Mitt Romney in criticizing President Obama on Friday over the attack in Benghazi, Libya, adding another turn of the screw to an indictment of the administrations evolving explanation of events.

title: Roosevelt Avenue, a Corridor of Vice
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided to get rid of a colony of pigeons that roosted under the elevated subway that runs down the middle of Roosevelt Avenue in Queens several years ago, it installed anti-pigeon spikes and sound machines to drive the birds off. The birds decamped, but only to the trees next to the tracks, where they continued to befoul the street below, according to local residents. When the parks department pruned the trees, the birds headed back to the tracks to another spot. Now, the transit agency continues to power-wash the caked-on debris away.

title: Keselowski Shows Hes the One to Beat in Chase and on Twitter
description: CONCORD, N.C.  The 2012 Daytona 500 will always be remembered for fire, rain and the first midrace Twitter message by a Nascar driver.

title: Barrett Jones Plays the Violin
description: Barrett Jones, now a center for Alabama, playing the violin in the fifth grade at age 10.

title: Skilled at Seeing Surprises, Most of the Time
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  No one would give Barrett Jones a straight answer, and this visibly bothered him.

title: Saturdays College Football Matchups
description: Saturday is the halfway point of the regular season for most of the nation. Sixteen Football Bowl Subdivision teams remain unbeaten, including one that has not been 5-0 since 2002.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Not the Best Cook
description: Part 7: The chefs and Food Network hosts talk about their show Food Network Star.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the chefs and Food Network hosts Bobby Flay and Giada De Laurentiis.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Bobbys Burgers
description: Part 3: The chef and Food Network host Bobby Flay talks about his fast casual Bobbys Burger Palace chain and explains why he hasnt brought it to New York City.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Death Row Meals
description: Part 11: The chefs and Food Network hosts reveal what theyd pick as their last meal.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: I Dont Microwave
description: Part 12: The chef and Food Network host Giada De Laurentiis explains the best way to reheat pasta, and talks about finding balance with work and family.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: DDL Foodshow
description: Part 5: The chef and Food Network host Giada De Laurentiis reminisces about moving to the United States as a child; and talks about her grandfather, the Italian film producer Dino De Laurentiis.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Giadas Story
description: Part 2: The chef and Food Network host Giada De Laurentiis talks about her background and how she ended up as a television chef.

title: TimesTalks | Celebrity Chefs: Preview
description: The chefs and Food Network hosts Bobby Flay and Giada De Laurentiis talk about their friendship, reflect on the business of cooking for television and recall their paths to food celebrity.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Cheesy Cupcakes
description: Part 10: The chefs and Food Network hosts discuss training restaurant staff and cooking for kids.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Shaming My Family
description: Part 4: The chefs and Food Network hosts talk about the cultural space Giada De Laurentiis filled when she came to the network.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Christopher Walken
description: Part 13: The chefs and Food Network hosts explore what it would take for a vegetarian show to succeed on the Food Network.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: Buds and Jams
description: Part 6: The chef and Food Network host Bobby Flay recounts his own culinary journey from growing up Irish-American in the 1960s to becoming the celebrity face of Southwestern cooking.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: TV Show Ideas
description: Part 9: The chefs and Food Network hosts talk about why they think food shows are a more dynamic format than most people assume.

title: Flay & De Laurentiis: You Cant Teach It
description: Part 8: The chefs and Food Network hosts argue over what the most important element is in a successful food television host.

title: Gift, and a Tragedy, Born of a Car Culture
description: It is a common refrain of some parents in New York City that the considerable burdens of raising children here  financial, logistical, emotional  are outweighed by the considerable benefits of living in a place where driving is neither necessary nor consecrated. The 17-year-old living on the Upper West Side suffers no status wounds without a car; in a sense, a dismissal of driving is its own mark of neurotic urbanity. Many of us can easily summon the names of friends  natives  who at 38 have still never bothered to get a license and, thus, depend on sisters, husbands, neighbors, in-laws to take them to Costco or Montauk.

title: Postgame Reaction from U.S.-Antigua
description: Brian Sciaretta covered Friday nights World Cup qualifier between the United States and Antigua and Barbuda for The Times, but newsprint being a finite resource he had some things left over. Among them were some quotes from the Americans on their underwhelming, albeit exhilarating, 2-1 victory.

title: Roy Bates, Bigger-Than-Life Founder of a Micronation, Dies at 91
description: Roy Bates, who commandeered a former British military outpost in the North Sea nearly 50 years ago and declared it a sovereign nation, died on Tuesday in Essex, England. He was 91.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: An Unusual Fund-Raising Pitch in Massachusetts
description: 5:25 p.m. | Updated  BOSTON  The fund-raising competition between Senator Scott P. Brown and Elizabeth Warren, his Democratic challenger, may have finally jumped the shark.

title: Cardinals Patented Escape Act Caps Magical First Round of Playoffs
description: WASHINGTON  The first round of baseballs postseason unfolded spectacularly into a full week of high and prolonged drama.

title: Giants Stay and Wait for Which Way to Fly
description: CINCINNATI  The San Francisco Giants enjoyed this city so much that they decided to stay an extra night. When the last of the Champagne had been sprayed after their 6-4 win Thursday  their third consecutive victory here, which capped a memorable comeback from a two-games-to-none deficit  the team did not immediately fly back to the West Coast.

title: Modi Ends Yatra on a Triumphant Note
description: Gujarats chief minister, Narendra Modi, ended his one-month statewide political march on Thursday in Pavagadh by trumpeting his states successes under his governance and pledging to the crowds that Gujarat would not fall into the hands of the corrupt, a clear dig at the Congress Party.

title: IHT Quick Read: Saturday, Oct. 13
description: NEWS  In awarding the Nobel Peace Prize to the European Union on Friday, the Norwegian Nobel Committee endorsed the organizations creation story  that it has kept chronic enemies from repeating the horrors of two world wars. But some critics wonder whether the E.U. needs a newer marketing pitch for citizens who mostly have no memory of war, and who may be more likely to associate the bloc with inept management of the debt crisis. Jack Ewing reports.

title: Cedar Lake Ballet Makes a Brief, Well-Chosen Stop at Sadlers Wells
description: LONDON  When Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was founded in New York in 2003 by the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie, it was generally regarded in the dance world as a rich womans folly. Ms. Laurie hired dancers and a director, and later bought the photographer Annie Leibowitzs former studios and transformed them into a state-of-the-art black box theater, rehearsal and office space. But for a few years no one heard much about the company, and the naysayers muttered that Ms. Laurie would soon lose interest.

title: I.M.F. Urges Leaders to Act Decisively on Debt
description: TOKYO  World finance officials called on the United States and Europe to quickly resolve their debt problems, saying on Saturday that more decisive action was needed to restore confidence in the faltering global economy.

title: The Weekend Word: Up for Debate
description: In Todays Times:How the Obama administration handled the attack on an American consulate in Libya has become a top issue in the presidential campaign, Peter Baker and Trip Gabriel write. Debate flared up after the vice-presidential debate in which Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. seemed to contradict official statements by the White House and the State Department about the event.

title: French Scallop War Roils English Channel
description: LONDON  The Nobel committee was obviously too busy handing out its Peace Prize to the European Union this week to notice that war has broken out between two of the Continents major powers.

title: Turkey Faults U.N. Inaction Over Syria
description: ISTANBUL  In a sign of escalating frustration in Turkey after days of cross-border shelling with Syria, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan lashed out at the United Nations inaction in Syria with some of his strongest comments yet, saying world powers are repeating the mistakes they made in Bosnia in the 1990s.

title: Springsteen Hits the Road for Obama
description: 3:40 p.m. | Updated  SOS to BRUUUUUUUUUUCE.

title: Romneys Go-To Economist
description: I HOPE youre sitting down for this, said Ali Velshi, the CNN anchor, staring into the camera, his voice booming with incredulity about a campaign promise issued by Mitt Romney: that, if elected, Mr. Romney would create 12 million jobs in four years.

title: G.O.P. Senate Hopes Fade, Even as Romneys Rise, Polls Show
description: Mitt Romneyhas had a pronounced change of fortunes since the first presidential debate inDenver. After trailingPresident Obamaby 4 or 5 points in the polls on Oct. 1  a position that very few candidates have come back from  he now holds ties or small leads in many national polls and has cut the advantage Mr. Obama had in swing states to a razor-thin margin.

title: 16 Killed in Suicide Attack in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber exploded his vehicle at an arms bazaar in northwestern Pakistan on Saturday, killing 16 people and wounding 15, a senior government official said.

title: The New York City Marathon Is Thriving. So Whats the Problem?
description: Mary Wittenberg, the chief executive of New York Road Runners, figured it might be a rough day when she headed to Harlem in late August for the Percy Sutton 5K, a race held on a hazy, humid morning on the cusp of the fall marathon season.

title: China Exports Rise, Hinting at a Glimmer of a Revival
description: HONG KONG  Chinas exports to the United States and Southeast Asia rose last month while the countrys money supply expanded faster than expected, Chinese government agencies said on Saturday, in the first signs that the Chinese economy might be starting to bottom out.

title: Highlights and Analysis: College Football Saturday
El Paso Schools Confront Scandal of Students Who Disappeared at Test Time
description: EL PASO  It sounded at first like a familiar story: school administrators, seeking to meet state and federal standards, fraudulently raised students scores on crucial exams.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Ill be completely honest. I have a serious block when it comes to Rosalie Moscovitchs cryptic crossword puzzles. I guess I just dont think the way Ms. Moscovitch does. Wheelhouses, and all that.

title: Colleges Take a Leap Into Voter Registration
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Every four years, volunteers swarm university campuses, clipboards in hand, to register newly eligible voters for what is generally the only presidential election of their undergraduate careers. This year they found large numbers were already registered.

title: Young Pro Tries to Stay On the PGA Fast Track
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  Golfs fall series is like American Idol, a proving ground for those hoping to fast-track their touring careers in the United States. A good showing can lead to the golfing equivalent of a recording contract: membership on the 2013 PGA Tour.

title: As Massachusetts Governor, Romney Was Often Away
description: BOSTON  When the ceiling collapsed in the Big Dig tunnel here, Gov. Mitt Romney was at his vacation home in New Hampshire. When the Bush administration warned that the nation was at high risk of a terror attack in December 2003, he was at his Utah retreat. And for much of the time the legislature was negotiating changes to his landmark health care bill, he was on the road.

title: Donnas Diner
description: Its 7 a.m. in Elyria, Ohio, and the day on Ely Square starts with the first pulse of the neon sign in the window of Donnas Diner.

title: A.L.C.S.: In Third Meeting in Seven Octobers, Expect Strikeouts and Rain
description: Around 8:30 on Friday night, as the celebration died down in the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, an attendant slapped a white sheet of paper on the message board: Saturday Report  4:30. The Yankees would have only 20 hours to rest before starting the American League Championship Series.

title: Marijuana Referendum Divides Both Sides
description: SEATTLE  Most efforts to legalize marijuana possession have generally run aground in the face of unified opposition. Mothers Against Drunk Driving led the charge in helping to defeat a ballot measure in California in 2010. Law enforcement groups, not too surprisingly, have also been largely opposed in the past.

title: Russia Says 20 Caucasus Groups Shut Down
description: MOSCOW  The Federal Security Service, Russias main domestic intelligence agency, announced on Saturday that it had shut down 20 nongovernmental organizations in southern Russia after discovering links to foreign spy agencies. But aid groups in the region said no such organizations had been closed, raising suspicions that the announcement was in fact a threat.

title: In Spains Housing Bust, Sell-Off Brings Bargains
description: CANET DE BERENGUER, Spain  For years, the Mar de Canet apartment complex in this beach town south of Barcelona stood empty, another casualty of a real estate crash that left this country littered with ghost towns and half-finished developments no one would buy.

title: 148 Middle Avenue
description: Old newspaper advertisments tell the story of 148 Middle Avenue, Elyria, Ohio.

title: Upheaval Grips South Africa as Hopes for Its Workers Fade
description: TEMBISA, South Africa  When Morris Sello arrived in Johannesburg from his home province of Limpopo in 1994, his horizons seemed limitless. Apartheid, the oppressive hand that smothered opportunity for black people for decades, was gone. He dreamed of a slice of the life white South Africans had enjoyed for years: a good job, a house, a car, good schools for his children.

title: This Land
description: The dateline is Elyria, Ohio, a city of 55,000 about 30 miles southwest of Cleveland. You know this town, even if you have never been here.

title: N.L.C.S.: Past Two World Series Champions Duel for a Chance to Return
description: The League Championship Series has been part of baseball since 1969, but never before has it featured a matchup like this: the last two World Series champions going head-to-head for the pennant. That is how it stands in the National League.

title: Israeli Ex-Soldier Recalls Captivity Under Militants
description: JERUSALEM  Almost a year after he was released from five years of captivity in Gaza, Gilad Shalit, the former Israeli soldier, has revealed more details of how he coped with the ordeal and his fears of being forgotten.

title: At the Corner of Hope and Worry
description: ELYRIA, OHIO  Another day begins with a sound softer than a finger-snap, in an Ohio place called Elyria. In the central square of this small city, the gushing water fountain applauds the early-morning chorus of sparrows. A car clears its throat. A door slams. And then: click.

title: Churchs Muscle Helped Propel Presidents Rivals to Victory in Georgia
description: TBILISI, Georgia  As sharply contested parliamentary voting approached in Georgia last week, the countrys Orthodox patriarch implemented his own peculiar pre-election ritual: He arranged for an airplane carrying icons and holy relics to circle over Georgian airspace while priests prayed over the countrys future, in an updated version of an ancient practice employed ahead of enemy invasions and other calamities.

title: After Avalanche, Record Climb Is Bittersweet
description: After 15  hours of climbing, the ski-mountaineer Benedikt Bhm reached the summit of Nepals 26,759-foot Mount Manaslu, the worlds eighth-highest peak. Atop the mountain on Sept. 30, he did not celebrate. No ice axes held above his head in triumph, or summit pictures with his buddies. Instead, he solemnly dug a hole in the snow, and buried a scarf blessed by a Tibetan lama and a carabiner.

title: As a Net, Johnson Is Relearning to Share
description: The man called Iso-Joe did not ask for the nickname, or the ball-dominating style that spawned it, or the burdens of a one-man show. The label suggests self-indulgence, and the modest, soft-speaking fellow from Little Rock, Ark., hardly fits the caricature.

title: Mile 6: Where the Music Plays and the Dead Rest
description: In the sixth mile of the ING New York City Marathon, competitors will fly by at least half a dozen live bands and one spectacular cemetery.

title: Donna's Diner
description: The first in a five-part series.

title: Inspired by Revis, and Assuming His Role
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Most cornerbacks in the N.F.L. are not as tall as Antonio Cromartie. Or as fast. Or as strong. Or as long. Or as athletic. And this, in so many words, was Darrelle Reviss point during a recent talk with Cromartie, a conversation they shared before Revis sustained his season-ending knee injury.

title: Matt Ryan Displays New Trust in Receivers and Himself
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  There is a declaration of a quarterbacks skill that is typically uttered around Drew Brees, Tom Brady, Aaron Rodgers, Peyton Manning and Eli Manning. It is being heard now around the Atlanta Falcons Matt Ryan, who seems on the verge of jumping onto the same shelf as those Super Bowl-winning quarterbacks.

title: A League Outlaw With an Endearing Scowl
description: For me, Alex Karras will always be a pink giant with a towel wrapped around his waist. He will always have a scowl on his face, a cigar in one paw and a cold beer in the other.

title: Flash of Reds Phillips Loses Spotlight Again
description: CINCINNATI  This is for sure: Brandon Phillips has swagger. This is also for sure: fans around the country will not see it on display for the remainder of October because his Cincinnati Reds were ambushed by the San Francisco Giants last week after taking a two-games-to-none lead in a first-round best-of-five playoff series.

title: Umenyiora Looks Beyond Next Sack, Wondering What It All Means
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  One day last week, the Giants defensive linemen were discussing money in their meeting room at the teams training center. Several players had watched a television documentary about seemingly flush athletes going broke after their careers ended, and a casual conversation quickly turned more passionate.

title: Sex Life Was Out of Step, Strauss-Kahn Says, but Not Illegal
description: PARIS  More than a year after resigning in disgrace as the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking redemption with a new consulting company, the lecture circuit and a uniquely French legal defense to settle a criminal inquiry that exposed his hidden life as a libertine.

title: A Grand Experiment to Rein In Climate Change
description: LEGGETT, Calif.  Braced against a steep slope, Robert Hrubes cinched his measuring tape around the trunk of one tree after another, barking out diameters like an auctioneer announcing bids. Twelve point two! Fourteen point one!

title: Detroits Voice of Hockey Leaves a Sad Silence
description: DETROIT  In the summer, the radio airwaves here once belonged to Ernie Harwell. In the winter, they were under the command of Budd Lynch.

title: Ryan Criticizes Obama Administrations China Policy
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  Representative Paul D. Ryan, seizing on new ammunition Saturday with which to attack President Obama on his stance toward China, criticized his administration delaying a report on currency manipulation that was due to be released next week.

title: My Phone Numbers Other Woman
description: Long before my iPhone 4 introduced me to Siri, it brought Sharlene into my life. Sharlene is an elusive woman who has unwittingly redefined my idea of relationships. It was March 2011 when I bought the phone, and even before Id given out my new number, I started getting calls. All were for Sharlene.

title: An Irish Catholic Wake-Up
description: WASHINGTON

title: Sunday Dialogue: Transforming Our Schools
description: Readers react to a students ideas for a learning revolution.

title: U.S. Suspects Iran Was Behind a Wave of Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence officials are increasingly convinced that Iran was the origin of a serious wave of network attacks that crippled computers across the Saudi oil industry and breached financial institutions in the United States, episodes that contributed to a warning last week from Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta that the United States was at risk of a cyber-Pearl Harbor.

title: Questions From a Bailout Eyewitness
description: IT has become almost unpatriotic to question the many and munificent bank rescues of 2008 and beyond. If you have the temerity to do so, youre likely to hear that the bailouts were the only thing standing between us and financial obliteration. You will also be told that, four years on, many of the bailouts have made money.

title: Mobilizing the Home Front
description: They were not ordered into companies and regiments, but they constituted a great army of their own. Within the first full year of the Civil War, the women of northeastern Ohio, what was once called the Connecticut Western Reserve, had mustered themselves into hundreds of soldiers aid societies, electing officers and reconnoitering every village, town and city in the region for food, money and hospital supplies.

title: Afghan Boys Eke Living Amid Peril at Gorge
description: MAHI PAR PASS, Afghanistan  Beneath the soaring faces of rock, on a treacherous road flanked by gaping drops, lines of trucks crawled up from the Pakistani border, groaning under impossible loads of house-size metal containers and boxes tottering under tarps.

title: Keeping Score: Aging Yankees Are Low on Rest
description: If the Yankees appeared to be in a rush to finish off the Baltimore Orioles in Game 5 of the teams American League division series, uncharacteristically finishing a game in less than three hours, it may have been in hopes of getting some rest before facing the Detroit Tigers the next day.

title: Rethinking Affirmative Action
description: Washington

title: On a Busy Road, a Company Needs Guardrails
description: This interview with  Christopher J. Nassetta, president and chief executive of Hilton Worldwide, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Bachmann Family Values
description: Minneapolis

title: Race, Holistic Admissions and U.C.L.A.
description: After the state of California banned racial preferences in 1996, the University of California, Los Angeles, began taking several steps to encourage more black and Latino students to apply. The goal was ensuring that U.C.L.A.s student body remained racially diverse even without affirmative action.

title: Running in Place, Before the Treadmill Ever Arrived
description: AND now a tale that seems preapproved by the gods of metaphor. Its about a man who takes an exhausting journey that ultimately leaves him in exactly the same place where he started  as he tries to buy a treadmill.

title: Which Millionaire Are You Voting For?
description: ELECTIONS are supposed to give us choices. We can reward incumbents or we can throw the bums out. We can choose Republicans or Democrats. We can choose conservative policies or progressive ones.

title: Matchup: Colts (2-2) at Jets (2-3)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Times Like This Are Different
description: Jonathan Portes and Simon Wren-Lewis have further thoughts on the new IMF report, with its concession that the adverse effect of austerity has been much worse than expected; both make points I should have stressed.

title: Matchup: Giants (3-2) at 49ers (4-1)
description: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Going Far, Without Regrets
description: I WAS born and raised in Singapore. When I was 12, I told my mother, Im going to work in the Big Apple one day. She said she wasnt surprised, because as a young child I had held my chopsticks far away from my food. In the Chinese culture that means youre going to live far from home.

title: A Treacherous Highway
description: Even in a nation beset by insurgency and suicide bombings, you would be hard-pressed to find anything as reliably terrifying as the national highway through the Kabul Gorge.

title: Rutgers Continues Surge Against a Departing Rival
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Syracuse, whose football tradition helped shape the Big East Conference since the leagues football beginnings in 1991, lost its final game against Rutgers as a conference member on Saturday, 23-15.

title: That Blurry Line Between Makers and Takers
description: MITT ROMNEY has apologized for his depiction of 47 percent of America as wealth takers rather than wealth makers. But his blunder touched inadvertently on some discomforting truths about the importance of politics in income distribution in the United States.

title: The Self-Destruction of the 1 Percent
description: IN the early 14th century, Venice was one of the richest cities in Europe. At the heart of its economy was the colleganza, a basic form of joint-stock company created to finance a single trade expedition. The brilliance of the colleganza was that it opened the economy to new entrants, allowing risk-taking entrepreneurs to share in the financial upside with the established businessmen who financed their merchant voyages.

title: Deaf, Determined and Sold on Mozzarella
description: MY parents have owned restaurants in Hong Kong and San Francisco throughout my life. So it was reasonable that I dreamed of running my own someday. I wasnt going to let the fact that I was born deaf deter me from realizing that dream.

title: The Pumpkin Cartel of Corning, N.Y.
description: GROWING up in the 80s, my brother and I sold pumpkins door to door every October. Whenever 4-foot children selling Halloween squash ring your doorbell, youre hamstrung into purchasing one, or risk being labeled the local curmudgeon. But it bears mentioning that we were the only children in Corning, N.Y., our small town upstate, with our very own pumpkin supplier and that we had a virtual monopoly on the market.

title: Do Not Track? Advertisers Say Dont Tread on Us
description: THE campaign to defang the Do Not Track movement began late last month.

title: My Dream Food Label
description: WHAT would an ideal food label look like? By ideal, I mean from the perspective of consumers, not marketers.

title: The Proposed Nutrition Label: A Quick Read, Out Front
description: How a new graphic on the front of food packaging would work.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 14
