description: With a little more than three weeks until Election Day, the Sunday shows are swarming with campaign surrogates, weighing in on the vice-presidential debate, the next presidential debate and strategy for the final stretch.

title: Dueling Prisms for Valuing Stocks
description: AFTER the tech crash a decade ago, investors started giving closer attention to the prices they pay for stocks.

title: Afghanistan's Pepsi Bottle Boys
description: A group of boys have taken up traffic duty on Mahi Par pass, a dangerous, highly trafficked road outside of Kabul, using only old soda bottles and determination to make money.

title: Doing the Two-Step, Beyond the A.T.M.
description: BANK A.T.M.s embody decades-old technology. A four-digit PIN? What a seemingly crude security system. Where are the uppercase and lowercase letters and the random punctuation that we are continually told are crucial to hacker-resistant passwords?

title: Cracking the Quantum Safe
description: Rochester

title: Those Long Hours Arent Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: When Doctors Play Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving Afghanistan
description: The battle in Afghanistan has become longest, bloodiest, most expensive war in American history. Editorials over the past 11 years have followed the events.

title: Time to Pack Up
description: After more than a decade of having American blood spilled in Afghanistan, with nearly six years lost to President George W. Bushs disastrous indifference, it is time for United States forces to leave Afghanistan on a schedule dictated only by the security of the troops. It should not take more than a year. The United States will not achieve even President Obamas narrowing goals, and prolonging the war will only do more harm.

title: Two More Saints From a State of Grace
description: When Pope Benedict XVI canonizes seven Catholic saints in Rome next Sunday, two Americans will be among them, bringing the total of American saints to an even dozen. That may seem surprisingly few after 500 years of Christianity in the New World, but the United States is still a relative newcomer in the Catholic Church, and these things take time.

title: The Mystery of Benghazi
description: TWENTY-FOUR hours after the American compound in Benghazi was attacked and our ambassador murdered, the tragedy seemed more likely to help President Obamas re-election campaign than to damage it.

title: Questions on Drones, Unanswered Still
description: UNDERSTANDING American drone strikes is like a deadly version of the old telephone game: I whisper to you and you whisper to someone else, and eventually all meaning is lost.

title: Media Start-Ups
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  A relatively simple theme for a Sunday, but it works.

title: Game 1 Highlights and Analysis: Tigers 6, Yankees 4, 12 Innings
description: Game 1 of the American League Championship Series had many of the elements of recent postseason series for the Yankees, but this one took a frightening twist in the 12th inning when Derek Jeter, the teams shortstop, captain and heart and soul went down with a fractured ankle.

title: Palestinians Go to the Polls
description: Maysoun Qawasmi leads the first all-woman list of candidates for elective office in the Palestinian territories.

title: Ulrich Franzen, Designer of Brutalist Buildings, Dies at 91
description: Ulrich Franzen, a German-born architect whose fortresslike buildings seemed to buttress the interior landscape of New York City during the shaky 1970s, and who gave it some buoyance, too, with skywalks, died on Oct. 6 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 91. His death was confirmed by his wife, Josephine.

title: Until Justice Is Served
description: Wilmington, N.C.

title: Gary Collins, Host of Miss America Pageant, Dies at 74
description: Gary Collins, a prolific actor who became a successful host of daytime talk shows and  for almost a decade  master of ceremonies for the Miss America pageant, died on Saturday in Biloxi, Miss. He was 74.

title: A Rulings Mixed Verdict
description: When the Supreme Court banned life sentences without parole for those under age 18 convicted of murder, it offered hope to some and pain to others.

title: Juvenile Killers and Life Terms: a Case in Point
description: LA BELLE, Pa.  To this day, Maurice Bailey goes to sleep trying to understand what happened on Nov. 6, 1993, when as a 15-year-old high school student he killed his 15-year-old girlfriend, Kristina Grill, a classmate who was pregnant with his child.

title: Billy Currington
description: Billy Currington is a country singer and songwriter working on his fifth album. His four previous albums produced 11 hits, 6 of which reached No. 1 on Billboards charts, including People Are Crazy and Good Directions.

title: U.S.-Antigua Player Ratings
description: The United States advanced to the final qualifying game of Group A in the Concacaf World Cup Qualifying after defeating Antigua and Barbuda, 2-1, in an unimpressive win and in less-than-ideal playing conditions.

title: William C. Friday, University of North Carolina Leader, Dies at 92
description: William C. Friday, a politically deft lawyer who, with scant scholarly qualifications, steered the University of North Carolina through three decades of tumultuous growth and helped scale back federal desegregation demands, died on Friday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 92.

title: Man and Woman Fatally Shot at Bronx Motel
description: A gunman approached a man and a woman outside a Bronx motel early Saturday, then fatally shot both of them before fleeing, the police and witnesses said.

title: Stoudemire Held Out of Celtics Game
description: HARTFORD  Amare Stoudemire will not play in Saturday nights preseason game against the Boston Celtics. The Knicks, in a precautionary move, did not have Stoudemire travel with the team for the game. Stoudemire, who has a left knee bruise, did not play in the Knicks preseason opener, a victory over the Washington Wizards. Kurt Thomas will start in his place at power forward.

title: Campaigns Mine Personal Lives to Get Out Vote
description: Strategists affiliated with the Obama and Romney campaigns say they have access to information about the personal lives of voters at a scale never before imagined. And they are using that data to try to influence voting habits  in effect, to train voters to go to the polls through subtle cues, rewards and threats in a manner akin to the marketing efforts of credit card companies and big-box retailers.

title: Oct. 13: Arizona and the Spanish-Speaking Vote
description: President Obama halted an 8-day winning streak for Mitt Romney in the FiveThirtyEight forecast on Saturday, with his chances of winning the Electoral College ticking up to 62.9 percent from 61.1 percent on Friday.

title: Rodriguez Returns to Lineup, but in the Sixth Spot; Kuroda Will Start Game 2
description: Joe Girardi hit the reset button Saturday and put Alex Rodriguez back in the lineup for Game 1 of the American League Championship Series against the Detroit Tigers.

title: Silence on Abuse Reports Plunges BBC Into Scandal
description: LONDON  As host of the television programs Jimll Fix It and Top of the Pops, Jimmy Savile was one of the British Broadcasting Corporations best-known figures in a four-decade career spanning the 1960s to the mid-1990s. But now he is the subject of numerous posthumous investigations into whether he sexually abused perhaps dozens of underage girls, some of them on BBC property.

title: Israeli Airstrike Kills 2 Militants in Gaza
description: GAZA  Israel on Saturday killed a senior Palestinian militant and his assistant in an airstrike in the northern Gaza Strip, a spokesman for the Gaza medical services said.

title: A Room to Impress Romney
description: LEBANON, Ohio  Mitt Romney could not stop marveling at the John Quincy Adams room.

title: G.O.P. Ticket Focuses on Crucial Ohio Votes
description: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio  The Republican ticket has all but taken up residence in vital Ohio: Mitt Romney spent four days in the state this week and Representative Paul D. Ryan two, with plans to return Monday.

title: A Stamp on a Set of Division Series to Write Home About
description: The St. Louis Cardinals won the World Series last October, and in quick succession lost their decorated manager, their superstar first baseman and the greatest pitching coach of the last generation. They reached the postseason, anyway  as the last National League team to clinch  but entered the playoffs without two more stars from their championship lineup.

title: The Game Gets a Moment in Pop Cultures Spotlight
description: Is chess cool? Judging by a new movie, Vogue magazine, a book and a pop stars comments, it is.

title: Irish Keep Cardinal Out of End Zone Just Long Enough to Stay Unbeaten
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  The blue-gray October sky had turned to night after a long, wet and tiresome afternoon. The rain had come and gone. The offense had, too. But the defense remained, proud and strong, when Stepfan Taylor ran, four last times, straight into its teeth.

title: Straight-Ticket Voting Takes a Trusting Soul
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: When Faith Meets Football in East Texas
description: KOUNTZE  There is a new angle to the usual hometown high school football pride on display in the store windows and marquees of this East Texas town.

title: Linking History and Fortunes of a City and a Team
description: The rapid-fire, ultra-glitzy, superstar-driven nature of professional football as it is played on any given Sunday does not always lend itself to serious literary contemplation. For every nonfiction classic like George Plimptons Paper Lion or Michael MacCambridges Americas Game, the shelves are cluttered with dozens of adoring biographies, glossy chapbooks and quickie novelty items like 100 Things Steelers Fans Should Know & Do Before They Die.

title: Two House Candidates Who Agree on a Lot, but Not When It Comes to Party
description: State Representative Sarah Davis, Republican of Houston, and her Democratic opponent, Ann Johnson, have a lot in common: they are both lawyers and young cancer survivors campaigning on a platform of defending womens health and supporting the regions medical centers.

title: Foreigners and the Burden of Debt
description: A number of comments on my non-burden of the debt post were along the lines of But what if the debt is owed to foreigners? OK, this takes a bit more thinking.

title: Eduard Volodarsky, Screenwriter Banned by Soviets, Dies at 71
description: MOSCOW  Eduard Y. Volodarsky, a Russian screenwriter whose films are recognized classics today in Russia but whose efforts to present a picture of war on his own terms led the Soviet authorities to shelve many of his works for years, died here on Tuesday. He was 71.

title: College Football Replay: Oct. 13
description: The days games included Oklahomas clobbering of Texas and Iowas double-overtime win over Michigan State.

title: Corrections: October 14, 2012
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Libya Struggles to Curb Militias, the Only Police
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  A month after the killing of the American ambassador ignited a public outcry for civilian control of Libyas fractious militias, that hope has been all but lost in a tangle of grudges, rivalries and egos.

title: Lottery Numbers
Tigers Delmon Young Moving Past His New York Arrest
description: Delmon Young strode to the plate for his first at-bat of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium on Saturday night to a conspicuously silent audience.

description: Hannah Elka Meyers and Joseph Abrams are to be married Sunday evening at Park East Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Hayyim J. Angel is to perform the ceremony, with Joshua I. Beraha, a rabbinical student and the grooms brother-in-law, participating.

description: Suzanne Beth Kling and Barry Langman are to be married Sunday at Congregation Mishkan Tefila in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Adam Feldman is to perform the ceremony.

title: Leslie Dougherty, Matthew Parker
description: Leslie Julia Dougherty, the daughter of Cynthia C. Dougherty and Charles W. Dougherty of Washington, was married Saturday to Matthew Hayes Parker, a son of Dr. Virginia S. Parker and David L. Parker of East Greenwich, R.I. The Rev. Percival DSilva, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Aldrich Mansion in Warwick, R.I.

title: Nets Sharp, and Winners, in Preseason Opener
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The first chants of Brook-lyn came far from the Nets new home, far down the coastline, in a building resembling an airplane hangar, in the middle of a casino district, in the state they just recently abandoned.

title: L.S.U. and Its Defense Roar Back to Silence Doubters
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  On the night Louisiana State saved its football season, if only temporarily, a white board hung in the corner of one meeting room. It spelled out the most basic principles in the game plan, standard stuff, all hallmarks of the Tigers in years past.

title: Knicks Edge Celtics Despite Struggles With 3-Pointers and Defense
description: HARTFORD  At certain moments, the game had the feel of a regular-season meeting, with hard drives to the basket, coaches screaming at the referees and the whistle being blown every few seconds. The Knicks and the Boston Celtics pushed each other for 53 minutes in an exhibition game Saturday.

title: Pakistani Girl Shot by Taliban Was Named for a Battlefield Heroine
description: HONG KONG  News reports from Pakistan on Sunday said that Malala Yousafzai has about a 50-50 chance of survival, maybe a little better, according to her doctors. She remains stable but unconscious in an army hospital in Rawalpindi.

title: Valverdes Struggles Continue With a Collapse
description: After the first game of the last playoff round, when Joaquin Benoit and Jose Valverde closed out a victory, Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland was asked about their performance. Leyland, considered a strong advocate for his players, seemed to take the question as a dare.

title: For Yankees, Thrilling Rally Ends Badly
description: After another magical ninth-inning home run by Raul Ibanez sent Yankee Stadium into near delirium Saturday night, it seemed there was nothing that could dampen the euphoria that the 40-year-old designated hitter had unleashed once again.

title: Red Bull Strong Again; Attendance Lags in Korea
description: YEONGAM, South Korea  The Red Bull team has dominated the last two seasons of Formula One racing. But just when it looked as if the teams control of the series had ended this season, Red Bull seemed to be returning to its winning ways.

title: Malala Yousafzai Shot by Taliban
description: Malala Yousafzai was shot in the head by the Taliban for speaking out in favor of girls education.

title: Swisher Laments Lost Chances in the Field
description: Amid the protracted commotion at Yankee Stadium late Saturday night, two of the Detroit Tigers hits were particularly rued inside the home clubhouse for how avoidable they seemed.

title: A Jarring Reality: The Yankees Without Jeter
description: The natural rhythms of the baseball season remind us that summer never lasts. In places like New York, the postseason arrives with the cold snap of autumn, the first sign that winter is coming. This is when the Yankees make their mark.

title: Returning Favors With Neighborly Advice
description: The other day I came home from work and there was a fruit basket waiting for me as a thank you from a mom and dad for helping their daughter with her college essay.

title: Against Accelerating the Gifted Child
description: A quarter of a million people have watched the premiere episode of the new YouTube show Prodigies, about 9-year-old Tanishq Abraham, the youngest student at American River College in Sacramento. The show makes much of Tanishqs brilliance and academic precocity, but toward the end of the episode, his mother reveals her concerns about Tanishqs educational experience.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: The state assembly on Wednesday witnessed a protest by legislators from some opposition parties, who demanded that seats be set aside for members of scheduled castes, scheduled tribes, other backwards classes and women in next months block development council elections, Kashmir Live reported.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: An estimated 46,000 people die in India every year because of snake bites. Or, put in another way, there is one death caused by a snake bite for every two people who die of AIDS in India. Tehelka magazine has these shocking figures in a story titled Snake Bites and Poisoned Stats. The writer, Jay Mazoomdaar, says that scores of these snake bite deaths arent present in government reports partly because few of the victims reach hospitals.

title: Mauritania Says Soldier Shot Leader by Accident
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The president of Mauritania, Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz, was shot and wounded while returning home from a country weekend on Saturday evening in what his spokesman said Sunday was an accidental shooting by a nervous soldier.

title: Ruling Party Shows Strength Amid Low Turnout in Russian Vote
description: MOSCOW  Russians voted in nearly 5,000 regional and local elections on Sunday, as opposition candidates tried to take advantage of electoral laws loosened last year in response to demands for open political competition.

title: A Robot Plumbs the Depths of the Gowanus Canal
description: No one knows what lurks inthe toxic depths of the Gowanus Canal, but with the advent of a fleet of remotely controlled rovers that will roam its dank waters for the next few years, the canals secrets may finally be stripped bare.

title: 24 Miles, 4 Minutes and 834 M.P.H., All in One Jump
description: ROSWELL, N.M.  A man fell to Earth from more than 24 miles high Sunday, becoming the first human to break the sound barrier under his own power  with some help from gravity.

title: The Envelope, Please: Bryan Stromer
description: Bryan Stromer, a student at the New York City Lab School for Collaborative Studies, needs a break from the omnipresent shoving crowds of his hometown.

title: Disruptions: Seeking Privacy in a Networked Age
description: A pulled pork taco hovered about four inches from my mouth when my phone impolitely interrupted me. Hey, I see youre having people over. O.K. if I stop by? read a text message from someone whom I had not invited to my dinner party.

title: Sherie Rene Scott at 54 Below
description: Sherie Rene Scott, with Todd Almond on piano, performs the Talking Heads song Life During Wartime as part of her new show at 54 Below.

title: Game 2 Highlights and Analysis: Tigers 3, Yankees 0
description: Justin Sablich, with the help of his Times colleagues, provided live updates and analysis of Game 2 between the Tigers and Yankees at Yankee Stadium. Continue reading for highlights and analysis.

title: Ben Afflecks Argo, With Strong Reviews, Opens in Second Place
description: Movies that appeal primarily to older adults rarely rocket out of the box office starting gate  graying patrons dont much care for crowds or you-must-go-right-this-minute marketing pressure  and Ben Afflecks Argo was no exception. A suspenseful drama about the unusual rescue of six Americans during the 1979 Iran hostage crisis, Argo managed only second place for the weekend, taking in about $20.1 million at North American movie theaters. But Argo, which cost Warner Brothers and GK Films about $44 million to make, is likely to stick around for the long haul given its rave reviews and rare A-plus grade from moviegoers in Cinemascore exit polls.

title: Arlen Specter, Pennsylvania Senator, Is Dead at 82
description: WASHINGTON  Arlen Specter, the irascible senator from Pennsylvania who was at the center of many of the Senates most divisive legal battles  from the Supreme Court nominations of Robert H. Bork and Clarence Thomas to the impeachment of President Bill Clinton  only to lose his seat in 2010 after quitting the Republican Party to become a Democrat, died Sunday morning at his home in Philadelphia. He was 82.

title: Which Millionaire Are You Voting For?
description: In the Sunday Review, Nicholas Carnes explores how even in our great democracy, we rarely have the option to put someone in office who isnt part of the elite. Read article

title: Jumping From the Stratosphere
description: Felix Baumgartner, the professional daredevil, made the highest jump in history, 24 miles above the New Mexico desert.

title: Brightness Mirrors Solemnity
description: The word unbearable may seem an odd description to apply to a stunning performance of Beethovens String Quartet in A minor (Op. 132), but when the Danish String Quartet played the work on Thursday in the Victor Borge Hall at Scandinavia House, there was an almost unbearable intensity to its searing interpretation of the slow movement.

title:
Most Crucial Time
for Candidates May
Be After the Debate
description: The most important time for the presidential candidates this week may be after Tuesday nights debate.

title: Unable to Use His Arm, A Giant Uses His Words
description: SAN FRANCISCO  How does a closer who cannot pitch help his team win? The question is a perfect strike for an existentialist like the San Francisco Giants Brian Wilson, who is on the disabled list after having reconstructive surgery on his right elbow, his season shut down after two appearances in April.

title: Q & A About Wittenberg and the Marathon
description: In less than three weeks, nearly 50,000 runners will participate in the New York City Marathon, the marquee event of New York Road Runners. Under the leadership of Mary Wittenberg, the marathon and the Road Runners organization more broadly have experienced soaring growth by almost every measure. The club has an increasingly global presence, and Wittenberg is one of the most influential women in sports.

title: Austerity Protests Are Rude Awakening in Portugal
description: LISBON  Portugal has long been regarded a role model in the grinding euro zone crisis. In return for an international bailout, its government cut services and raised taxes while its citizens patiently endured with little of the popular outcry seen elsewhere in southern Europe.

title: China in Hollywood, Hailed and Investigated
description: LOS ANGELES  The powerful gatekeeper of Chinas rapidly growing film world, the China Film Group chairman Han Sanping, will be here on Oct. 30 to receive an award as the China Entertainment Visionary of the Year. He will be honored at the third annual U.S.-China Film Summit, sponsored by the Asia Society of Southern California.

title: An Extra Ingredient in North Dakota Politics: Oil
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, an examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is North Dakota, the Peace Garden State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Mark S. Jendrysik and Dana Harsell, both professors of political science at the University of North Dakota.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include retail sales for September and business inventories for August (Monday); the Consumer Price Index for September and industrial production for September (Tuesday); housing starts for September (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed index for October leading economic indicators for September (Thursday); and existing home sales for September (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Without Jeter, Yanks Look to Nix and Nunez
description: While Derek Jeter was at the hospital having more tests done on his fractured left ankle, Jayson Nix and Eduardo Nunez were the first Yankees out on the field early Sunday afternoon, taking ground balls as they prepared to replace one of the most celebrated players in major league history.

title: A Risky Lifeline for the Elderly Is Costing Some Their Homes
description: The very loans that are supposed to help seniors stay in their homes are in many cases pushing them out.

title: Two Sides Trade Criticism in Rancor Over Libya Attack
description: WASHINGTON  Caught in the uneasy nexus between politics and foreign policy, the debate over the violence in Benghazi, Libya, that claimed four American lives turned angry on Sunday as Republicans said it reflected a dangerous failure by the Obama administration to protect Americans across the region. Democrats, meanwhile, accused the Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, of cravenly trying to exploit the episode in a political witch hunt.

title: Architects of Sound, Creating Structures From the Ground Up
description: One of the real challenges for a composer today is finding a way to structure a piece so that it comes across with a compelling dramatic arc. Things were a little easier back in the days when sonata form, rondo and other such genres were common, though in reality those classical forms provided little more than general layouts.

title: Flavors of Algeria and China, and Emily Dickinson
description: In 1908 and 1909, after one of the most difficult periods of his life, Gustav Mahler wrote a dark, challenging masterpiece, Das Lied von der Erde (The Song of the Earth). It is a song cycle for two voices, but given its scoring for full orchestra and its length of more than an hour, on the title page Mahler called it a symphony.

title: Celebrating a Southern California Light Before Its Sunset
description: A wistful fairy tale without a happy ending: that is the story of the Los Angeles singer-songwriters clustered in Laurel Canyon in the late 1960s and early 70s, as sung and told by Lauren Fox in her enthralling new show, Canyon Folkies, on Friday at the Metropolitan Room. The program is a companion piece to Love, Lust, Fear & Freedom: The Songs of Joni Mitchell and Leonard Cohen, her brilliant exploration of the music and the personal relationship of two songwriting legends, which I saw at the same club in February.

title: Tension Is Uncorked Before a Parting
description: We audience members are always getting attached to companies and individual performers  its one of the deeply human pleasures (and pains: life spans in dance can be so brief) to be gotten from following a live art form.

title: A Reverse Mortgage Solicitation
description: Regulators worry that some of the same high-pressure tactics deployed during the subprime lending crisis are showing up again in reverse mortgage solicitations.

title: Reconsidering Obama the Pragmatist
description: The December 29, 2008, issue of The Nation magazine proclaimed in all caps on the cover: Barack Obama, Pragmatist. Inside, the story, written by Christopher Hayes, considered the idea that Obama was more interested in what works than in either conservative or liberal ideology. Others have continued to reflect on that idea: Fareed Zakaria, Glenn Greenwald, Peter Berkowitz and Andrew Sullivan have all done so of late, as have the academic philosophers who contributed to a recent symposium on Obama and pragmatism.

title: Girls Who Broke the Laugh Ceiling
description: The oral history is a dicey format, especially when it comes to comedy. Performers famed for their hilarious writing or delivery may not sound the least bit funny when talking about the creation myths behind their own careers.

title: Jets Regain Footing, Trampling the Colts
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a departure from the norm, the Jets special-teams unit  not their offense, not their defense  was announced before Sundays game against Indianapolis. Punter Robert Malone sprinted out of the tunnel. The long snapper Tanner Purdum welcomed the fans cheers. Fire spewed as Nick Folk, the kicker, slapped hands with his teammates.

title: Taking No Prisoners in Boozy, Brutal Head Games
description: George and Martha: sad, sad, sad.

title: Quiz: Dont Google This
description: See whether you can answer a series of popular mobile Google queries  without reaching for your phone.

title: Google Wants to Join the Party, Not Crash It
description: Lisa Cericola, 31, a food editor and blogger, recently held a party at her home in Brooklyn, with grilled steak and chimichurri on the table and the Red Hot Chili Peppers on the iPod.

title: Cavendish Invitational Tournament in Monaco
description: The Cavendish Invitational tournament, which begins in Monaco on Monday, features two competitions. There is a two-day team tournament on Monday and Tuesday, followed by the main event, the three-day pairs.

title: Christian Group Finds Gay Agenda in an Anti-Bullying Day
description: On Mix It Up at Lunch Day, schoolchildren around the country are encouraged to hang out with someone they normally might not speak to.

title: Glories of Capitalism, With Gas at $40 a Gallon
description: If you have never read Ayn Rands legendary 1957 novel, Atlas Shrugged, (guilty!) or seen the 2011 dystopian fantasy Atlas Shrugged: Part I (not guilty, alas), you may have trouble parsing whos doing what and why in that movies narratively addled sequel. Atlas Shrugged: Part II, which opened on Friday and was not shown in advance to critics for The New York Times, takes off where Part I left off. Like the first, it opens in 2016 with the world gripped in an economic crisis (and rife with amusingly torpid Occupy-style protests) that has led to an astonishing development that sounds like an environmentalists dream: because gas costs more than $40 a gallon, Americans now rely on railroads as their major means of transportation.

title: On Stage, a Comics Still at Home
description: At the Beacon Theater almost two weeks ago Jerry Seinfeld didnt walk to the microphone. He ran. After his meticulously paced trot, he froze in an action pose, then riffed on the challenge of simply going out to do something.

title: Eerie Harmonics and Timbres Evoking a Swarm of Bees
description: Witold Lutoslawski, the avant-garde Polish composer, told a member of the LaSalle Quartet, which gave the premiere of his String Quartet in 1965, that each particular player is supposed not to know what the others are doing, or at least to perform his part as if he were to hear nothing except that which he is playing himself. In other words, the performers should ignore the chamber music mantra of closely listening to and collaborating with colleagues and instead think as a soloist.

title: Jazz Guitarist Assumes Many Guises
description: Near the end of Pat Methenys capacious performance with his new quartet and his old machines on Friday night at Town Hall, he played his new song Breakdealer, and the best music of the night happened. Its a medium-fast song with a hard rhythm and heavy accents; its a little dire, messaging right away that somethings going to go down, and it did.

title: TV Debates That Sell More Than Just Drama
description: In 1960, John F. Kennedy was trailing Richard Nixon as they stepped into the crucible of the first nationally televised debate. While Kennedy soared, Nixon stumbled and never recovered.

title: Worshiper in a Temple
description: There is something about a Martini,A tingle remarkably pleasant;A yellow, a mellow Martini;I wish I had one at present.There is something about a Martini,Ere the dining and dancing begin,And to tell you the truth,It is not the vermouthI think that perhaps its the gin.  A Drink With Something in It, OGDEN Nash

title: Driven by Desire Back to Meat
description: Sherie Rene Scott, a star of the 2010 Broadway production of Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown but probably best known for the autobiographical Everyday Rapture, is opening a one-woman show on Tuesday night at 54 Below. Called Piece of Meat and developed in collaboration with Todd Almond as musical director, its a mash-up of (mostly) contemporary pop songs by Joni Mitchell, Talking Heads and Paul McCartney, among others, along with tightly woven monologues inspired, partly, by Ms. Scotts recent conversion to omnivore, after spending her entire adult life as a vegetarian. She says, quite simply, that the show  which runs through Oct. 27  is about desire.

title: Arlen Specter, 1930-2012
description: The senator from Pennsylvania led the Judiciary Committee through one of its most tumultuous periods, even while battling Hodgkins disease in 2005.

title: Mayhem, Crowds and Musicians Drive Conference
description: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights from the 2012 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which took place from Wednesday through Saturday in Orlando, Fla.

title: Mondays Matchup: Broncos (2-3) at Chargers (3-2)
description: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

title: Doubt on Cancer Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Children Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents on Software: A Nobel Laureates View
description: To the Editor:

title: Deciding When to End Life Support
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cancer Care, Cost Matters
description: AT Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, we recently made a decision that should have been a no-brainer: we are not going to give a phenomenally expensive new cancer drug to our patients.

title: Republican Candidates Embrace Cuomos Appeal
description: As they seek to maintain a power base in Albany, New Yorks Republicans have found an unlikely standard-bearer: the states Democratic governor, Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: The Radical Is Romney, Not Ryan
description: MITT ROMNEY, moderate. That earnestly sought post-debate public image contrasts starkly with Mr. Romneys actual positions on many issues, especially the future trajectory of government spending.

title: Giants Coach Struck by Ball Is Out for First 2 Games
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a San Francisco Giants coaching staff brimming with former Yankees, one ex-Yankee will replace another on the first-base line for Games 1 and 2 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Memphis Film Is Planned
description: A film adaptation of the Tony Award-winning musical Memphis is in the works. Belle Pictures and the Mark Gordon Company are to announce on Monday that Mark Gordon and Molly Smith will produce the movie with Alcon Entertainment, a Warner Brothers-based production company. Joe DiPietro, who wrote the book and co-wrote the lyrics with David Bryan, will write the screenplay for that tale of two star-crossed lovers living in segregated Memphis in the 1950s.

title: Want to Ruin Teaching? Give Ratings
description: AS the founder of a charter school network in Harlem, Ive seen firsthand the nuances inherent in teacher evaluation. A few years ago, for instance, we decided not to renew the contract of one of our teachers despite the fact that his students performed exceptionally well on the state exam.

title: Unique Morning Show on NPR Thrives as Others Slip
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Fifteen minutes before Morning Edition is beamed to radios across the country, Renee Montagne is ready to record her one-minute introduction. To cue her, the director points his index finger. Good morning. It was the presidents turn to court Latino voters...

title: Sprint Said to Be in Final Stages of Selling Most of Itself to SoftBank of Japan
description: 11:13 p.m. | Updated

title: All-Female Ticket Aims to Be Heard, if Not Seen
description: HEBRON, West Bank  The faces of five men in business suits and one woman in a white head scarf beam under the slogan Modern Hebron on campaign banners along the streets of this famously conservative city ahead of local elections scheduled for Saturday. Other banners saying Hebron Independents feature 12 less formal photos, including three women, with looks more stern than smiling.

title: Giants Defense Turns Rematch Into Mismatch
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With a little less than 10 minutes remaining in the fourth quarter, 49ers quarterback Alex Smith took the snap, dropped back to pass and immediately saw Giants linebacker Mathias Kiwanuka rushing toward him as if Kiwanuka were running straight down Nob Hill.

title: Loomis Camera
description: Ive been in Elyria in the camera business for 62 years. When I bought this little store up here, I got it for next to nothing, and I decided to move up here because I liked the little town.

title: A Seat for the Taking, but First Seeking Traction
description: Voters in Staten Island know plenty about Representative Michael G. Grimm, the embattled first-term Republican facing a barrage of questions about his fund-raising practices and business deals.

title: Mayor Holly Brinda
description: Mayor Holly Brinda, a fourth-generation Elyrian, wants to restore the glory and the economy, and reviving the downtown would be a big step toward a revival.

title: Anna Hallman
description: Well, Im basically doing what I can each day, trying to keep the house.

title: The Elyrian Landscape
description: A guide through the downtown square in Elyria, Ohio

title: Reviewing Week 6 in the N.F.L.
description: DAYS BEST

title: Drive Seeks to Curb Revelry on Lower East Side by Limiting Liquor Licenses
description: The crowds arrived on the Lower East Side on Friday night by car service, subway and taxi. Some people came bundled against the autumn chill. Others shivered, in thin dresses or T-shirts, prepared for the heat inside packed nightclubs with names like Viktor and Spoils, Hotel Chantelle and Libation.

title: North Koreans See Few Gains Below Top Tier
description: DANDONG, China  On her weekly shopping trips to downtown Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea, a 52-year-old pig farmer who gave her name as Mrs. Kim tries to ignore the dusting of prosperity that has begun to transform the city in recent years: the newly built apartment blocks, the increasing number of Mercedes-Benzes that zip along once-empty boulevards, the smartly dressed young women who conspicuously gab on their newly acquired cellphones. She has never been to the Rungna Peoples Pleasure Ground, a new amusement park where children of the elite howled with delight this summer as they shot down a waterslide.

title: Mining Contract Details Disclosed in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Enmeshed in a bruising political battle over new mining rules seen as vital to Afghanistans economic future, the countrys mining minister on Sunday disclosed about 200 previous mining contracts for the first time, portraying the move as an attempt to bring transparency to a process vulnerable to corruption.

title: Tebow Plays His Part on Fake Punt
New Mayor, Big To-Do List
description: ELYRIA, OHIO  Near the cherished gazebo of Ely Square Park, just outside Donnas Diner, the mayor of Elyria waits with patient grace to perform a wedding already running late. She wears a blue blazer, white pants, a red-white-and-blue scarf and an American flag lapel pin that dazzles when caught by the midday June sun. It is Flag Day.

title: High-Speed Trading No Longer Hurtling Forward
description: The hottest new thing on Wall Street is cooling down.

title: Yanks Offense, Still Asleep, Fails to Support Kuroda
description: The Yankees lost the first two games at home, barely scoring four runs in 21 innings, their captain and hits leader, Derek Jeter, is moving on crutches, and they next face Justin Verlander, perhaps the best pitcher in baseball, in a critical Game 3 in Detroit.

title: Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodian Leader Through Shifting Allegiances, Dies at 89
description: Norodom Sihanouk, the charismatic Cambodian leader whose remarkable skills of political adaptation personified for the world the tiny, troubled kingdom where he was a towering figure through six decades, died early Monday in Beijing. He was 89.

title: Eagles Loss Adds to Run of Struggles and Doubts
description: PHILADELPHIA  Not much has come easily for the Philadelphia Eagles this season. Not holding on to the ball, not scoring points and certainly not winning.

title: A Prisoners Incompetence, a Judges Discretion
description: At the Supreme Court last week, the  justices considered the rights of an Ohio death row inmate, Sean Carter, who challenged his conviction in federal court, but who is mentally incompetent and cannot assist in his own legal defense. Mr. Carter had pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity to rape and murder, but was found competent to stand trial. He sought to overturn the conviction, alleging ineffective assistance of counsel.

title: Sick Leave in New York
description: The arrival of flu season is a reminder that New York City has no law requiring employers to provide paid sick leave and that the City Council should pass one. Connecticut requires paid sick leave from most companies with more than 50 employees. Seattle, San Francisco and Washington all require employers to provide sick leave, and workers in New York deserve the same benefit.

title: The Speculators Win a Round
description: The foes of Dodd-Frank financial reform scored a victory recently when a federal court overturned a new rule to limit speculative trading in derivatives.

title: Death by Ideology
description: Mitt Romney doesnt see dead people. But thats only because he doesnt want to see them; if he did, hed have to acknowledge the ugly reality of what will happen if he and Paul Ryan get their way on health care.

title: Predators on Pedestals
description: America has Jerry Sandusky. Britain has Jimmy Savile.

title: Even on the 49ers Turf, the Air Still Belongs to Manning and the Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One difference, and maybe the deciding difference, in the rivalry between the Giants and the 49ers became evident in the second quarter of the Giants 26-3 victory on Sunday.

title: As Tension Escalates, Turkey Issues a Ban on All Syrian Aircraft
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys foreign minister announced on Sunday a ban on all Syrian aircraft entering his countrys airspace, days after the authorities discovered what they said were Russian military munitions on board a passenger plane bound for Damascus.

title: No Shame
description: There are many unanswered questions about the vicious assault in Benghazi last month that killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens. And Congress has a responsibility to raise them. But Republican lawmakers leading the charge on Capitol Hill seem more interested in attacking President Obama than in formulating an effective response.

title: Retracted Science Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebel Arms Flow Is Said to Benefit Jihadists in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  Most of the arms shipped at the behest of Saudi Arabia and Qatar to supply Syrian rebel groups fighting the government of Bashar al-Assad are going to hard-line Islamic jihadists, and not the more secular opposition groups that the West wants to bolster, according to American officials and Middle Eastern diplomats.

title: Middle Linebacker Fits Mold as Irish Idol
description: The sons playing catch in the shadow of the Golden Dome want to hit like Manti Teo.

title: A Familiar Lesson in Having Little to Work With
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Even Making Amends Comes With Drawbacks
description: A judge facing a potential death sentence  imposed by illness, as opposed to the legal system  is arraigned before the court of his progeny in Dont Go Gentle, a tidy drama by Stephen Belber that opened on Sunday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in an MCC Theater production. In the central role of a retired conservative judge in Buffalo, the veteran actor Michael Cristofer gives the play an absorbing center, delivering a prickly, moving performance as a man whose attempt to make amends for a lifetime of spiritual flaws only draws him deeper into conflict with his troubled children.

title: What If Candidates Ran Without the Horse Race?
Obamas Prep Session Goal: Dont Repeat Mistakes of Last Debate
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  To prepare for the second round of the presidential debates, President Obama retreated here this weekend  to the environs of this historic village where actors in 18th century garb wander about spouting off in colonial diction.

title: Gray Pinstripes: With Jeter Out, Times Toll Rises
description: It is the one foe every athlete faces, but no athlete can beat. Each knows that the end will come, that age is undefeated in the annals of sports. The trick is to make summer last as long as possible, to put off reality for another day.

title: Getting It Right on the Field and in the Booth Isnt Always the Same
description: You could sense George Steinbrenner smiling from Yankee heaven when the teams radio voice, John Sterling, invoked the late owner Saturday night, as in, If George Steinbrenner were alive, those tapes would be in the commissioners office tomorrow.

title: Cano Sets Record for Futility in Playoffs
description: Robinson Cano, the Yankees star second baseman, maintained Sunday night that he still felt good at the plate. The teams hitting coach, Kevin Long, maintained that Cano still looked good at the plate. But for another night, the evidence, both visual and numerical, suggested otherwise.

title: Knicks Copeland Stands Out After Entrance Is Put Off
description: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson kept rotating players in and out during the first half of Saturdays preseason game against the Boston Celtics  everyone except for Chris Copeland. While Woodson used 11 players in the first half, Copeland watched from the bench, eager to get his chance.

title: Swisher Feels Fans About-Face
description: No Yankee plays to the crowd more than Nick Swisher. But if Swisher, who is facing free agency, has played his final home game as a Yankee, he went out bitterly.

title: A Shift to the Left in Lithuania Jeopardizes the Ruling Party
description: MOSCOW  Preliminary returns from parliamentary elections in Lithuania on Sunday showed voters on track to oust the conservative government of Prime Minister Andrius Kubilius  an apparent reflection of public anger over tax increases and other austerity measures imposed in response to the European financial crisis.

title: Peralta, the Other Shortstop, Shows Off Hands and Hitting
description: The pregame focus Sunday afternoon was understandably zeroed in on the Yankees vacancy at shortstop. For the first time in the postseason since 1995, Derek Jeter would not be there.

title: Woman Must Relinquish Kafka Papers, Judge Says
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli judge has ruled that a huge trove of documents written by Franz Kafka and his friend Max Brod that have been hidden from view for decades must be turned over to Israels national library, which plans to publish them online.

title: Lottery Numbers
First B.C.S. Rankings Provide Buzz but Little Else
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  The Bowl Championship Series released its first rankings of the season Sunday, and on the surface, the list highlighted what most expected: Alabama in the top slot, the decisive favorite, the defending champion on course to repeat, followed by everybody else.

title: A Cardinals Parents Cheer Equally for His Little Sister
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was just another manic Sunday for the Descalso family, which started the day at Burton Park in San Carlos rooting for one childs team to make it to the championship and ended the day at AT&T Park cheering on another childs team in its championship series.

title: Channel Surfing: The Walking Deads Latest Victim
description: This season, the critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger are checking out favorite shows and seeing how they hold up. Previous entries in this series include posts on New Girl, NCIS, Scandal, The Good Wife, 30 Rock, Dexter and Supernatural.

title: Attendance Down for Yankees
description: Derek Jeter was not the only person missing at Yankee Stadium on Sunday. Several thousand fans were, too.

title: Giants Replay  Week 6
description: The Giants defense saved its best for the 49ers in a 26-3 win.

title: In Bedroom Community, Birth of a Tech Center
description: A canopy of solar cells, a nearly classroom-free academic center, cafes open to the public and even a hotel. The new campus of the Cornell University graduate school for technology is expected to transform Roosevelt Island from a sleepy bedroom community into a high-technology hothouse, and indeed, the plans to be formally unveiled for the campus on Monday bear little resemblance to anything that is there now.

title: Jets Replay  Week 6
description: The Jets had four sacks in a 35-9 victory against Indianapolis, which also included a big pass play by Tim Tebow.

title: Spoiler Alert! G.O.P. Fighting Libertarians Spot on the Ballot
description: When he was running for the Republican presidential nomination last year, Gary Johnson, the former two-term Republican governor of New Mexico, drew ridicule from mainstream party members as he advocated legalized marijuana and a 43 percent cut in military spending.

title: In Chase for Wins, a Runner Cheats
description: With one end of the rubber band between his teeth, Christian Hesch cinched the tourniquet tight around his biceps. The thick veins in his forearm quickly surfaced, and he carefully grabbed the syringe.

title: Revival for Giants Pass Rush
A.C.L.U. Sues Morgan Stanley Over Mortgage Loans
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is accusing Morgan Stanley of fueling the production of risky, expensive loans that targeted African-American borrowers.

title: Can You Do Too Much to Prevent a Stroke?
description: Stroke is the fourth leading cause of death among Americans, and a much larger contributor to chronic disability and health care costs than this ranking suggests. Theres no question that preventing strokes is important. But a big question is how best to do so and in whom.

title: HPV Vaccine Doesnt Alter Sexual Behavior, Study Finds
description: Coni Butler, an accountant in Austin, Tex., and a devout Catholic, encourages her three children to remain celibate before marriage. But that did not stop her from getting them vaccinated against human papillomavirus, or HPV, a sexually transmitted disease that raises the risk of some cancers.

title: Microsoft Makes New Push Into Music
description: SEATTLE  Music fans have often viewed Microsoft as something like a bad cover band, one that pumped out uninviting facsimiles of Apples iPod and iTunes with its Zune music players and service.

title: Word of the Day | aerie
description: aerie \er-e, ir-, a-(-)re\ noun

title: George Whitmore Jr., Who Falsely Confessed to 3 Murders in 1964, Dies at 68
description: George Whitmore Jr., an eighth-grade dropout whose confession in 1964 to three New York murders he did not commit had a decisive role in the Supreme Courts Miranda ruling protecting criminal suspects and in the partial repeal of capital punishment in New York State, died on Oct. 8 in a nursing home in Wildwood, N.J. He was 68.

title: Endeavours Final Mission
description: The retired space shuttle Endeavour was towed through Los Angeles city streets en route to its new home at the California Science Center.

title: Video of Baumgartners Supersonic Free Fall
description: Last Updated, 11:59 a.m. As my colleague John Tierney reports, Felix Baumgartner, a former Austrian paratrooper, made the highest and fastest jump in history on Sunday, after ascending by a helium balloon to an altitude of 128,100 feet.

title: N.F.L. Rewind  Week 6
description: Images from action around the N.F.L. on Sunday.

title: Waiting in Lines, Some That Stretch and Wind, and Too Many That Disappoint
description: Like most people, I hate lines.And like most everyone, I cannot escape them. Some are disguised as waiting rooms. Some stretch on interminably  at post offices, airports and the purgatory known as the Department of Motor Vehicles. Some promise entertainment at the end of them  or better yet, food  but most disappoint.

title: The Bloodied Legacy of Cambodias Chameleon King
description: HONG KONG  He was a libertine and a francophile, a filmmaker and a painter, a serial husband and father and philanderer, a cherubic but ruthless god-king who liked to putter about in the garden. He played the sax in his own jazz band. He loved to eat. He once served Champagne to a visiting U.S. secretary of state. At 10 a.m.

title: Beauty Queen | Pat McGrath
description: When shes not creating trend-setting looks for fashion shows and photo shoots, the makeup artist Pat McGrath helps concoct creams and colors for Dolce & Gabbanas makeup line. None of it even feels like work, she says. Im lucky enough to collaborate with the very best in the business, so I never get the chance to be bored.

title: After Power Surge, Cardinals Win Battle of Bullpens in N.L.C.S. Opener
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a postseason so loaded with dramatic comebacks that attempts to rank them seemingly need updating by the hour, the St. Louis Cardinals and the San Francisco Giants opened the National League Championship Series on Sunday with the least eventful game in at least two days.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 2: Yankees vs. Tigers
description: Yankees lost a contentious game to Detroit on Sunday.

title: Klinsmanns Shrinking Roster
description: U.S. Soccer announced on its mens national team blog Sunday that midfielder Jermaine Jones had returned to Germany over the weekend. The move was not unexpected: when Jones received a yellow card in Fridays 2-1 win against Antigua and Barbuda, it meant that he would be suspended for Tuesdays final qualifier, against Guatemala at Livestrong Sporting Park in Kansas City (7 p.m. Eastern, ESPN2).

title: Oct. 7-Oct. 13: An Energized Romney Campaign

title: News Quiz | October 15, 2012

title: No More Industrial Revolutions?
description: The American economy is running on empty. Thats the hypothesis put forward by Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University. Lets assume for a moment that hes right. The politicalconsequences would be enormous.

title: A Very Big Issue at Manilas Zoo
description: MANILA  The chief veterinarian of the Manila Zoo looked uncomfortable as the graying, tattered elephant snaked her trunk through the rusty bars of her enclosure.

title: Lacking Teachers and Textbooks, Indias Schools Turn to Khan Academy to Survive
description: CHENNAI  In a country where teachers are in short supply and decent textbooks are hard to find, Indian schools are pinning their hopes on a free online tutorial service based in the United States.

title: IHT Quick Read: Monday, Oct. 15
description: NEWS The Portuguese have suddenly joined the swelling ranks of Europes discontented, following Greece and Spain, after the government tried to take another step toward austerity last month. Raphael Minder reports from Lisbon.

title: Congressional Races Getting Positively Negative
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has another nationwide contest in 2012, the battle for Congress, and its getting down and dirty.

title: Global Outpouring to Help Pakistani Schoolgirl
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  When the time came to choose medical treatment for Malala Yousafzai, the 14-year-old Pakistani schoolgirl who defied the Taliban and then was gunned down by them, her family and doctors faced a world of possibilities after a global outpouring of advice and offers of assistance.

description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Meg Whitmans Toughest Campaign: Retooling H.P..

description: WHAT is Art.sy?WHAT is the Art Genome Project?WHAT work do you like best, after browsing the site?

title: Mining Contract Details Disclosed in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Enmeshed in a bruising political battle over new mining rules seen as vital to Afghanistans economic future, the countrys mining minister on Sunday disclosed about 200 previous mining contracts for the first time, portraying the move as an attempt to bring transparency to a process vulnerable to corruption.

title: Through a Lens, Baryshnikov Falls in Love With Dance Again
description: To be a great dancer, flawless technique is not enough. For Mikhail Baryshnikov  the dancer, not the photographer  you have to go further than athleticism and use the technique to embody the music.

title: The Breakup Bed
description: I stopped seeing someone recently and decided, as one does in these situations, that it was time to change my life, or at least my bed. This bed and the set it is a part of have been an embarrassment to me ever since I told my mother I would take them. Big and overwrought, they are the sort of thing that might work in the European mountain house of a histrionic soprano, but in a New York City apartment they are too much. I was pretty certain that if a guy got a look at my bedroom he would reassess my character and be gone, although a good male friend, with whom I discuss this, told me that is not the case.

title: How, and by Whom, Should Children Be Taught Appropriate Behavior?
description: Adults often say that young people should have known better than to act in a way they characterize as disrespectful, immature or rude, especially at formal events.

title: Britains Rate Stuff
description: So, later today Im participating in a debate at Parliament (sponsored by speakers of both Houses) on austerity versus expansion; not, as far as I know, open to the general public. Jonathan Portes is my teammate; Stephen King and Deborah Falcus Bridget Rosewall on the other side.

description: A physician writes:

title: Can Jets Match Up With Patriots?

title: A, B, and Me
description: A quick generic note: Im constantly facing critiques along the lines of Now you say A, but back in 1996, or 2003, or something, you said B. Youre not consistent! Since Ive written so much over the years, theres plenty of opportunity for this sort of trawling, and I dont have time to answer each case.

title: Contraceptive Economics
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.

title: Looking for a College Home Away From a Hectic Hometown
description: The subways in New York City, with their stainless steel shells, look rather bland from the outside. Which is fine. The beauty of a New York City subway car is on the inside, not the outside.

description: Forthis weeks food issue, Mark Bittman, the magazines lead food writer and a Times opinion columnist,wrote thecover story about Californias Central Valley after asking readers of his blog to suggest places he should visit.

title: Oct. 14: Breaking the State-National Poll Stalemate
description: For the last week or so, we have been hoping to decode a confusing polling landscape. President Obama still appeared to hold a narrow Electoral College lead on the basis of state-by-state surveys, while national polls were suggestive of a tie or perhaps the slightest edge for Mitt Romney.

title: Anxiety Art: This Mortal Coil
description: The series is featuring occasional works of art. This is one.

title: Time, Speed and Distance
description: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes.

title: Romney Donors Gather in New York for Fund-Raising Retreat
description: While Mitt Romney is hunkering down with his brain trust, preparing for his second debate against President Obama, Mr. Romneys donors will be living it up at a three-day fall retreat beginning Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria in Midtown Manhattan.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Agreement Signed on Scottish Independence Vote
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron and Alex Salmond, the Scottish first minister, ended months of preliminary sparring on Monday, formally agreeing to the terms for a referendum on independence for Scotland that could dismantle the sometimes uneasy and often uneven partnership between their lands since the Act of Union in 1707.

title: German Retailer Douglas in $1.9 Billion Buyout Deal
description: LONDON  The buyout firm Advent International offered on Monday to buy the German retailer Douglas Holding for around $1.9 billion.

title: Men Who Fall From Space
description: MOSCOW Watching Felix Baumgartners parachute jump from the stratosphere on Sunday was, for some here, a source of inspiration and, for others, a much-needed distraction from the dispiriting spectacle of rigged local elections. I also felt an odd personal connection to the Austrian athletes feat, the sort of connection that comes from family lore: my great-uncle, my grandmothers older brother, was the first man to parachute from the stratosphere.

title: Workdays I.P.O.: The Incumbents Are Not Prepared
description: On Friday, Workday held one of the most anticipated enterprise tech initial public offerings of the year, closing at $48.69 a share, up 74 percent. The company pocketed about $675 million. Even more than money, its co-founder says, Workday bought itself credibility for a coming battle with competitors like Oracle and SAP.
