title: 2 From U.S. Win Nobel in Economics
description: Two Americans, Alvin E. Roth and Lloyd S. Shapley, were awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science on Monday for their work on market design and matching theory, which relate to how people and companies find and select one another in everything from marriage to school choice to jobs to organ donations.

title: On Our Radar: Robots Plying the Gowanus
description: A fleet of robots will move through the polluted waters of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, measuring pH levels, oxygen, temperature, air quality and salinity and transmitting the results to a Web site. The hope is that residents will use the site to track the progress of the canals Superfund cleanup. [The New York Times]

title: When Air India Was Efficient, Profitable and Growing Fast
description: Having convinced the government, in 1932, that he should run an air mail service for it, 28-year-old J. R. D. Tata did not need much longer to demonstrate that he was doing a stand-up job. Tata Air Mails scrupulous adherence to schedules was legendary. Only a year into its operations, the Directorate of Civil Aviation wrote in a report:

title: In the High-Tech Patent Wars, an Inventors Lament
description: A long, narrative article we ran last week on the challenges facing the patent system, The Patent, Used as a Sword, prompted a lot of comments, and we posted more than 275 of them.

title: Breakfast Meeting: The Power of TV Debates
description: With the second presidential debate approaching on Tuesday night, the focus will be on whether President Obama can recover from his lackluster performance in the first debate, which infused new energy into the campaign of Mitt Romney. David Carr notes, in his Media Equation column, how striking it was that a ritual as old as Lincoln-Douglas was able to have such an effect  especially since we consume information constantly, and often in small bits.

title: Fill-In | Daredevil Jumps, and Lands on His Feet
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first five paragraphs of the article Daredevil Jumps, and Lands on His Feet.

title: Signs of Possible Recovery Buoy Chinese Exporters
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Buyers from around the world thronged the cavernous halls of the Canton Fair at its opening day on Monday as a new and somewhat more optimistic mood seemed to take hold among Chinese exporters.

title: Norway Increases Carbon Tax on Domestic Production
description: Norway will nearly double the carbon dioxide tax rate for its offshore oil and gas production in 2013, the countrys environment ministry announced last week.

title: Opinion Report: Politicizing Benghazi
description: From the editorial page

title: Middleman in Financing of Rebecca Is Arrested on Federal Fraud Charges
description: A Long Island stockbroker defrauded the producers of the Broadway musical Rebecca with an elaborate scheme that included a fictitious loan and phantom investors who were conjured up as part of a sham plan to rescue the financially ailing show, federal authorities charged in a criminal complaint Monday.

title: Sprint Clinches Deal With SoftBank
description: SPRINT CLINCHES DEAL WITH SOFTBANK | Sprint Nextel is selling 70 percent of itself to SoftBank for $20.1 billion. The deal, which was announced on Monday, is Sprints boldest attempt to improve its fortunes as it faces new pressure from rivals, DealBook reports.

title: Stones to Play in Newark, Not Brooklyn or Manhattan
description: The Rolling Stones announced on Monday that for their 50th-anniversary tour they would play four shows in two cities that know how to rock.One is London. The other is Newark, where they last performed in 1965.

title: Citigroup Earnings Plummeted in Third Quarter on Write-Down
description: 5:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Would You Rescue a Moth?
description: Dear Diary:

title: Monday Reading: My Phone Numbers Other Woman
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Haute Stuff
description: When I got my first big job in fashion in the 1980s, couture was called a laboratory of ideas. Really? The dusty French houses, with their aging designers and gilded mansions, were producing more potent concoctions than the cerebral Rei Kawakubo or the emerging Azzedine Alaa?

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Faces Tough Market in Branch Sale
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland is expected to settle for a lower price as it looks to sell a number of its bank branches in Britain after Santander of Spain pulled out of a deal to buy them for 1.7 billion ($2.7 billion).

title: The Play of Laughter and Forgetting
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  What would happen if Muhammad Ali Jinnah, Pakistans founding father, returned here only to find a place wracked by militancy, corruption, intolerance and repeated power outages? This is the premise of Pawnay 14 August, a play by Anwar Maqsood, a writer and presenter of satirical shows on Pakistans state television channel since the 1970s.

title: What Were Reading
description: Zester Daily: Who even knew there was such a thing as an okra festival? Love the stuff.  Julia Moskin

title: At Elite Schools, a Single Test Comes Under Review
description: Dozens of no-longer-young alumni gathered at the Bronx High School of Science just before the weekend, with not a single Nobelist to be found in the bunch.

title: E-Book Releases Are Coming for Diary of a Wimpy Kid Novels
description: The personal journals of a young Greg Heffley, the not entirely wimpy protagonist of Jeff Kinneys best-selling Diary of a Wimpy Kid book series, are getting an electronic upgrade. The Amulet Books imprint of Abrams said on Monday that it would release the first six volumes of the illustrated Wimpy Kid novels in e-book  or is that wimp-e-book?  format on Oct. 30, leading to the simultaneous hardcover and electronic publication of a new seventh book, Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Third Wheel, on Nov. 13.

title: Times to Add Portuguese-Language Edition
description: The New York Times Company, continuing its drive to expand its international presence, is adding a Portuguese-language edition next year.

title: Why Do Humans Have Two Eyes? A Cheat Sheet for Getting Into Oxford
description: HONG KONG  The application period for Oxford, the 800-year-old British university, ended Monday, which is why it felt free to release sample questions asked in the infamously difficult interviews held at its various colleges.

title: A Corporate Boss With a Taste for Risk Makes His Latest Big Bet
description: By buying majority control of Sprint Nextel for $20.1 billion, SoftBank is making an enormous bet that it can turn around a flailing company beset by larger rivals.

title: Military Endorsements Hold Greater Benefits for Democrats, Study Finds
description: As the presidential campaign focuses increasingly on President Obamas performance as commander in chief, a study released Monday finds that he benefits from endorsements of retired military officers more than Mitt Romney does, particularly with coveted independent voters.

title: CNH Rejects Merger Deal From Fiat Industrial
description: LONDON  The agricultural and construction equipment company CNH on Monday rejected a proposed merger with its Italian majority shareholder, Fiat Industrial.

title: For Baby Boomers, the Perils of a Reverse Mortgage
description: It sounds like a good deal for boomers. A reverse mortgage that allows homeowners 62 and older to borrow money against the value of their homes and not pay it back until they move out or die. Perhaps the money could be used to pay off other debts, or take that vacation that was never possible while people were working fulltime.

title: As Prices Soar to Buy a Luxury Address, the Tax Bills Dont
description: The shimmering limestone tower at 15 Central Park West, where apartments routinely trade for upward of $20 million, has become symbolic of the most luxurious upper reaches of New Yorks real estate market. Its architect, Robert A. M. Stern, is the dean of the Yale School of Architecture. The views stretch out over the expanse of Central Park. And earlier this year, a single penthouse sold for $88 million.

title: Which Transit-Fare Increase Seems Fairest?
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled on Monday four proposals for a scheduled fare increase next March, introducing the possibility of raising the base fare on subways and buses to $2.50 from $2.25 or increasing the cost of a 30-day MetroCard by as much as $21.

title: A Risky Financial Lifeline
description: Business Day Live: Reverse mortgages are costing some older Americans their homes. | Sprint to sell a controlling stake to SoftBank of Japan. | A reversal in fortunes for high-speed trading firms.

title: Daily Report: Joining the Party, Not Crashing It
description: Youre at a dinner party, and conversation stalls over an urgent question  like how tall is the Statue of Liberty? What do you do? You pull out your phone and Google the answer, of course.

title: Basil L. Plumley, Veteran of Three Wars, Dies at 92
description: Night had fallen as American and North Vietnamese soldiers exchanged sheets of gunfire during Operation Landing Zone X-Ray in the Ia Drang Valley in November 1965. Illumination flares attached to parachutes floated from American aircraft.

title: Europe Urged to Revamp Education
description: BERLIN  Some European countries are cutting back on education spending to help their budgets at a time when it seems like Europe needs skilled and educated workers more than ever, a subject I write about in my Letter from Europe this week.

title: Merchant Plaintiffs Line Up Against Credit Card Settlement
description: In July, The Times reported on the controversy surrounding a proposed settlement between merchants, on one side, and Visa, MasterCard and many of their issuing banks on the other. Now a majority of the named merchant plaintiffs in the suit have announced opposition to the settlement.

title: The Data-Mining Industry Kicks Off a Public Relations Campaign
description: The Direct Marketing Association, a trade group in Manhattan, introduced a $1 million public relations campaign on Monday morning with a lofty title: the Data-Driven Marketing Institute.

title: Bookshelf
description: The Swiss novelist Robert Walser (1878-1956) wrote in a scrawl so infinitesimal, it was once believed to be a secret code. Microscripts (New Directions / Christine Burgin, $25), a gorgeous paperback illustrated by Maira Kalman, collects some of his original drafts, including a short story that he squeezed onto a business card. For her rich ensemble novel Eight Girls Taking Pictures (Scribner, $25), Whitney Otto mined the real lives of 20th-century photographers like Imogen Cunningham and Ruth Orkin, creating linked fictional portraits full of glamour and grit. And Viktor & Rolfs weirdly charming storybook, Fairy Tales (Hardie Grant Books, $20), began as letters that the Dutch designers exchanged with each other while traveling.

title: With New Sanctions, European Union Tightens Screws on Iran Over Nuclear Work
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union toughened sanctions against Iran over its disputed nuclear program on Monday, banning trade in industries like finance, metals and natural gas, and making other business transactions far more cumbersome.

title: Lusty Libertines in France
description: When the disgraced former banker Dominique Strauss-Kahn indulged in orgies, was he simply a free-spirited libertine following in a notorious tradition dating back centuries and pervasive in French culture?

title: Giants Show Yankees What a Dynasty Looks Like
description: If there really is such a thing as a New York minute  best description: the length of time between a light turning green and a cabby honking at you  one of them happened over the weekend. It provided a snapshot of two New York sporting institutions heading in entirely different directions. In one tiny sliver of time, the Yankees got old. They also fell behind the Tigers, two games to none, with Justin Verlander set to pitch next on full rest, but to be sure, their crisis is not about just this series and season. They no longer look like a former or potential dynasty, but a big budget calamity that managed to put together one triumphant playoff run in 2009 and has been leaking oil ever since.

title: Monday Motorsports: Red Bull Scores One-Two Finish in Korea
description: On the Formula One race circuit, its beginning to look a lot like 2011.

title: Cycling Becomes a Cleaner Sport, Not a Safer One
description: A childs sporting dream is precious. My dream to become a professional cyclist fueled a childhood of thrilling excursions, a healthy adolescence and lifelong friendships. Many of my peers in the professional peloton shared the dream. But, as I realized my goals, I found reality was far from what I had imagined.

title: Image of the Day: Oct. 15
Were Three!
description: Some may commemorate the occasion with parties and presents, but we prefer to celebrate our birthday each year with a (festive?) look at our analytics.

title: In Haryana, Hundreds Protest States Response to Rape
description: In Haryana, where a number of high-profile rape cases have attracted national attention in recent weeks, 800 protesters took to the streets on Monday to demand better policing and a safer environment for women.

title: Some Spaniards Blame the Germans
description: MADRID  While many blame the Spanish prime minister for the delay in requesting aid from Europe, some point to Germany.

title: Spain Waits, and Europe Frets
description: MADRID  It has become Spains version of Godot: waiting for Rajoy.

title: Questions and Answers on How The Times Handles Online Comments From Readers
description: It may seem a bit circular, but its true: One of the topics that receives the most questions and comments to the public editor is online commenting itself. So what youll find below are answers to some of the most frequently asked questions on The Timess policies and practices on this subject. The answers were provided by Sasha Koren and Bassey Etim, who manage social media and online commenting for The Times. The questions were assembled by my assistant Joseph Burgess, who often fields these reader queries as he combs through the public editor e-mail each day. Many thanks to all of them.

title: Inside Christoph Niemanns Potato Workshop
description: In this past Sundays Food & Drink Issue, Christoph Niemann, our contributing artist, relays the German legend of how potatoes became a staple of the local diet. He tells the tale using stamps that he carved out of potatoes. While he was at work, he sent along this snapshot from his studio. Its the anti-Photoshop, he said. The potato shop.

title: Stir-Fries for Crisp Autumn Days
description: I love stir-frying with the seasons. Right now Im phasing out summers tomatoes and corn, green beans and zucchini and picking up Chinese broccoli, mushrooms, cabbage and carrots at the farmers market. Im still finding an array of peppers and beautiful Asian eggplants to brighten my wok. Stir-fries can be adapted to any number of ingredients that may be lingering in your refrigerator, or in your freezer, like the frozen peas that liven up a fish and mushroom stir-fry that is one of this weeks recipes.

title: Vi Hart: Fun with Hexaflexagons
Getting That Extra Mile Out of Plastic
description: HONG KONG  Six decades ago, plastic erupted onto the world stage. By now, life without it is almost unthinkable.

title: HPV Vaccine Doesnt Increase Risky Behavior
description: In one study of parental attitudes toward the vaccine against human papillomavirus, or HPV, a sexually transmitted disease that raises the risk of some cancers, researchers found that concern that the vaccination would promote promiscuity was the single biggest factor in a parents decision not to vaccinate.

title: Justices to Review Voter Law in Arizona
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether Arizona may require proof of citizenship in order to register to vote in federal elections. The federal appeals court in San Francisco blocked the state law in April, saying it conflicted with a federal one.

title: On the Deficit
description: The latest Washington Post/ABC News national poll and New York Times/CBS News/Quinnipiac swing state poll both give President Obama the edge on health care, helping the middle class, Medicare and handling international crises. And they both show either a tight race or a slight advantage for the president on taxes and energy issues.

title: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
description: A lot of boomer musicians with birthdays this week  Wynton Marsalis, Tom Petty, Richard Carpenter  and one who is not a boomer, but had an enormous impact on our generations music.

title: Business Day Live: A Risky Financial Lifeline
description: Why reverse mortgages are costing some older Americans their homes. | Sprint to sell a controlling stake to SoftBank of Japan. | A swift reversal in fortunes for high-speed trading firms.

title: AeroVironment E.V. Charger Goes Portable
description: AeroVironment, whose hard-wired 240-volt EVSE-RS charger is the official preferred home charger for the Nissan Leaf and other electric vehicles, is expanding its product line with a portable version. The retail price of the EVSE-RS Plug-In is $1,099, or $100 more than the static charger.

title: American Politics and Chinese Data
description: In the midst of increasingly heated election rhetoric about China, Beijing has released some important economic data as its currency hits record highs.

title: Face Time | Norman Reedus
description: In the AMC thriller The Walking Dead, which is broadcast on Sunday nights at 9 p.m., the actor Norman Reedus plays Daryl Dixon, who skillfully dispatches legions of zombies with a nifty crossbow. If zombie slaying isnt youre thing, hes set to appear on the big screen soon in Sunlight Jr., with Naomi Watts and Matt Dillon. Read on to find out what he finds most attractive in a woman and how he stays so lean and mean. Plus, the hair and makeup artists for Walking Dead weigh in on a few product picks and share their thoughts on Reedus.

title: Putins Party Dominates Russian Regional Elections
description: MOSCOW  Candidates from the pro-Kremlin party United Russia won nearly all of the municipal and regional elections held across the country, according to results released on Monday, though analysts said the partys success owed much to low voter turnout.

title: Street Style: Graphic Prints
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Oct. 8.

title: SoftBanks Deal for Sprint Is One for the Books
description: Japanese companies have made a string of deals in the United States this year, but the pact announced on Monday is one for the record books.

title: Myths, More than Traditional Medicine, Driving Rhino Slaughter
description: 5:02 p.m. | Updated below |Rhinoceros populations from Asia through Africa are plummeting in the face of burgeoning illicit trade in their horns, much of it driven by myths promoted by criminal smuggling syndicates and targeting the new wealthy in China and Vietnam. The Green blog and Dot Earth have explored these issues, but its worth a slightly deeper dive, here provided in a Your Dot contribution from Matthew Wilkinson, the founder and editor of the informative Safaritalk blog.

title: Try to Focus on Your Personal Economy
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: 73,000 Political Ads Test Even a City of Excess
description: LAS VEGAS  No one comes here expecting anything in moderation. But to turn on the television these days is to shatter even Vegas-size notions of excess.

title: Declining U.S. High-Frequency Trading
description: Once the hottest thing to hit Wall Street in years, high-speed or high-frequency trading  known as H.F.T.  is now struggling to make gains in todays stock maket.

title: Fed Official Says Monetary Steps Were Too Timid
description: The Federal Reserves recent expansion of its economic stimulus campaign was announced as a course correction. It wasnt that economic circumstances had changed, officials said. They simply had concluded that they needed to do more. The implication, of course, was that the Fed had failed to do enough.

title: Obama Campaign Feels Good About State of Race
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  The Obama campaign insisted Monday it remained sanguine about the state of the presidential race, a day before President Obama was to meet Mitt Romney in Hempstead, N.Y., for a second high-stakes debate.

title: Mayoral Hopeful Switches to G.O.P.
description: The field of likely Democratic candidates for New York City mayor narrowed by one on Monday when Tom Allon, a newspaper publisher waging a long-shot bid, announced that he would switch to the Republican Party to increase his odds of making it to the 2013 general election ballot.

title: Gerhard Richter Painting Sets Record Auction Price for a Living Artist
description: After the critical success of a recent retrospective at the Tate Modern in London and the Pompidou Center in Paris this year, the prices of paintings by Gerhard Richter have been soaring. They climbed higher still at Sothebys in London on Friday, when Abstraktes Bild (809-4), one of the German artists abstract canvases from 1994, sold to a mystery telephone bidder for $34.2 million. (It had been estimated to bring $14.1 million to $18.8 million.)

title: Caught on Camera | The Architecture & Design Film Festival
description: It seems like only yesterday that the Architecture & Design Film Festival made its debut, but this year marks its fourth season. At the Tribeca Cinemas in New York from Oct. 18 to Oct. 21, this years festival includes more than 25 films from 11 countries, as well as discussions with filmmakers, architects and designers. Opening night brings the world premiere of Design Is One: Lella & Massimo Vignelli, Roberto Guerra and Kathy Brews look at the renowned husband-and-wife designers. Also showing that evening (at the Allen Room at Time Warner Center) is Richard Hankins 16 Acres, which tells the story of the plans for rebuilding the World Trade Center site. Among the other diverse offerings are Mission Statements: The Architecture of Dutch Diplomacy, Jord den Hollanders examination of a program that commissioned embassy buildings around the world from prominent Dutch architects; a short film about a group of young architects who build a lighthouse on a remote Scottish island; documentaries on both Long Island and West Coast Modernist houses; a look at Diller Scofidio + Renfros work on Lincoln Center and the High Line; a chamber opera based on the life and work of Louis Kahn; and Paraiso, Nadav Kurtzs short about three immigrant window cleaners who spend their days rappelling down some of Chicagos tallest buildings.

title: Lots of Ways to Run a Race
description: These elite runners, taped at the 2012 Olympic trials, show a wide variety of footstrikes.

title: In Maine, Independent Streak Complicates Political Landscape
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is Maine, the Pine Tree State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Amy Fried, a political science professor at the University of Maine; and Ethan Strimling, who served as a Democrat in the Maine Senate for six years and now works as a political analyst for The Bangor Daily News.

title: Holden Caulfield to Roam Manhattan in New Novel
description: The young-adult author Mary OConnells first novel for grown-ups will feature perhaps the most famous young adult in literary history: Holden Caulfield.

title: Rothschild Resigns from Board of Mining Company
description: LONDON  The British financier Nathaniel Rothschild resigned on Monday from the board of Bumi, the mining company that he helped to create.

title: Disney Sets Dates and New Details for Marvel Superhero Movies
description: Having made a huge dent at the box office with its summer superhero adventure The Avengers, which has sold more than $1.5 billion in tickets globally, Walt Disney on Monday announced an updated release calendar that was heavy on Marvel Comics characters and packed with enough colorful costumes to put David Bowies wardrobe to shame.

title: Devices Go Nose to Nose With Bomb-Sniffer Dogs
description: SAINT-LOUIS, France  Denis Spitzer wants to beat dogs at their own game.

title: In New Orleans, a Coach With a Steady Hand
description: In the first installment of its Real Training Camp series, NBA TV traveled to New Orleans, where the Hornets aim to forge a fresh identity in the still choppy wake of Chris Pauls departure.

title: California Food Dreaming
description: I am a California-phile; I have been visiting for 40-plus years, and I lived in L.A. for a couple of years too. The state is endlessly fascinating.

title: On College Essay, Write About Something That Made You Feel Deeply
description: The essay rules may be changing on the Common Application, but that doesnt change some basic rules about creative writing.

title: Parsing of Data Led to Mixed Messages on Organic Foods Value
description: A team of scientists laboriously reviewed decades of research comparing organic fruits and vegetables with those grown the usual way. They found that, as many had suspected, the organic produce, farmed without synthetic fertilizers or pesticides, was more nutritious, with more vitamin C, on average, and many more of the plant-defense molecules that in people help shield against cancer and heart disease.

title: Wall Streets Fund-Raising Push for Romney
description: The Wall Street supporters of Republican candidate Mitt Romney are making a last fund-raising push as the election heads into its final three weeks.

title: New Feature: Whats Going On in This Picture?
description: For our new Whats Going On in This Picture feature, well collaborate weekly with Visual Thinking Strategies (V.T.S.). In this video, Philip Yenawine, one of the founders of the organization, conducts a live V.T.S. discussion about a work of art.

title: Really? Tinted Contact Lenses Can Improve Athletic Performance
description: THE FACTS

title: Allergies on the Move
description: Q. People say that about five years after moving to Austin, Tex., you start to get your Austin allergies. Is that possible?

title: Redesigns Create Deals on New-Car Leftovers
description: Fall is usually a good time to buy a car because its the end of the model year, but even better deals are available if youre willing to buy a model that is about to be discontinued or redesigned, Edmunds.com advises.

title: Defendants in Sept. 11 Case Cooperate as Proceedings Resume at Guantnamo
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The Sept. 11 war-crimes case before a military commission at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, resumed relatively smoothly on Monday as five men accused of being co-conspirators in the attacks were calm and cooperative in the first session of a weeklong pretrial hearing.

title: Prenatal Mercury Exposure and A.D.H.D.
description: A new study suggests that prenatal exposure to mercury is associated with symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, but the greater a mothers consumption of fish  a source of mercury  the less likely her child is to suffer these symptoms.

title: Options in Treating Incontinence
description: The most common treatment for urinary incontinence is a daily dose of an anticholinergic medicine that alters the action of certain nerves. Botox injections are also used, often in cases where the medicine does not work.

title: Lycopene Linked to Reduced Stroke Risk
description: Could eating tomatoes help prevent strokes?

title: Showcasing the Power of Music, Even in War
description: Logitech, the Swiss company that makes computer mice, remote controls and other personal peripherals as well as videoconferencing products, is introducing onMonday a digital campaign in the United States and Europe for its new line of music-related products.

title: For Rise of Blocked Punts, Go Back to Off-Season
description: There are many confounding details about this N.F.L. season, ones that make you wonder why anyone would be willing to put money on an outcome. The team that looked like the best in the league Sunday  the Giants  is 0-2 in its division. The entire A.F.C. East is the very definition of mediocrity: 3-3, although on the bright side, its the first time since the divisions were realigned in 2002 that all teams in a division are tied for first place this late in the season. The N.F.C. West, which just two years ago sported a sub-. 500 division champion, is filled with teams at or above .500, even though only one of them won Sunday.

title: Growing Concerns About Reverse Mortgages
description: In The Times today, a cautionary tale about an increasingly popular income alternative for older people: reverse mortgages.

title: Heat-Seeking Missiles in Syria: The SA-7 in Action with Rebels
description: Throughout this year, as fighting intensified in Syria and antigovernment fighters grew in numbers and in strength, it had seemed inevitable that they would acquire heat-seeking shoulder-fired missiles and turn them against the Syrian military aircraft.

title: Steroid Shot Near Spine Gives Illness an Opening
description: One of the many troubling aspects of the national meningitis outbreak caused by a tainted steroid drug is that so many people are at risk: 14,000 are thought to have been exposed, mostly through injections near the spine for back or neck problems. The drug was contaminated with a fungus that causes a severe form of meningitis that can result in stroke.

title: Answers to Readers Questions About Wittenberg and the Marathon
description: 10:21 a.m. | Updated The New York City Marathon, the marquee event of New York Road Runners, will be held this year on Nov. 4. The organization is led by Mary Wittenberg, one of the most influential women in sports.

title: Debates and the Power of Live Event TV
description: TimesCast Media + Tech: The debates influence on the broadcasters. | Cory Doctorow, digital activist and novelist. | Social media meets spoken word poetry.

title: Ambushed on the Road to Manhood
description: With The Round House, her 14th novel, Louise Erdrich takes us back to the North Dakota Ojibwe reservation that she has conjured and mapped in so many earlier books, and made as indelibly real as Faulkners Yoknapatawpha County or Joyces Dublin. This time she focuses on one nuclear family  the 13-year-old Joe Coutts; his mother, Geraldine; and his father, Judge Antone Coutts  that is shattered and remade after a terrible event.

title: Myths of Running: Forefoot, Barefoot and Otherwise
description: Its a topic of endless debate among runners. Is there a best way to run, so that you use the least energy and go the fastest? And does it help to run barefoot or in minimalist shoes?

title: Bulls and Bears Fight It Out, in Courts
description: 5:17 p.m. | Updated with Silvercorp office declining to comment, and closing stock price.

title: Obamas to Vote Early, Hoping Others Do the Same
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  President Obama and his wife, Michelle, announced on Monday that they would both vote early, and Mrs. Obama was photographed holding an absentee ballot for Illinois that she later dropped in the mail. Mr. Obama followed up her announcement by saying that he would vote early, in person, on Oct. 25, the next time he planned to be in Chicago.

title: Romney Raises $170 Million to Finance Final Push
description: Mitt Romney and the Republican Party have begun a late push to raise tens of millions of dollars in the closing weeks of the election, cash that will finance a last-minute barrage of advertising that Mr. Romneys aides believe is critical to beating President Obama.

title: Look of The Moment | Marion Cotillard
description: The Look: French Noir. An L.B.D. and matching nails get some Gallic flair from asymmetrical two-tone heels and a poppy trimmed clutch.

title: Stoudemire Returns to Knicks Practice
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amare Stoudemire returned to practice Monday and said he would play in the Knicks next preseason game, against the Toronto Raptors on Friday in Montreal.

title: Tax Proposal in Mongolia Threatens Rio Tinto Project
description: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia  Rio Tintos biggest new mining project is under threat after the government of Mongolia said it was considering whether to renegotiate an investment agreement involving the $6 billion Oyu Tolgoi copper mine.

title: A Spotlight on Compounded Medicines
description: When Julie Auslanders son was sick and struggling to take his pills, she turned to a pharmacist, who made medicated patches for him to use instead. A few years later, when Ms. Auslanders mother, who had dementia, needed anti-anxiety drugs but couldnt swallow, Ms. Auslander turned again to a pharmacist, who prepared a special tablet that dissolved under the tongue.

title: Clearwire Investors Bet on Inevitability of a Deal With Sprint
description: Sprint Nextel may have found its financial savior in SoftBank of Japan, thanks to a $21.3 billion deal that will provide ballast to the struggling cellphone service provider.

title: A Crucial Child-Rearing Lesson From an Understanding Cow
description: His mother saw that he was not lonesome, and because she was an understanding mother, even though she was a cow, she let him just sit there and be happy.  The Story of Ferdinand, by Munro Leaf.

title: The Chemistry Behind Great Food Pairings
description: Red wine and steak, soda and burgers, pickles and pastrami sandwiches  these are combinations that just work. Now researchers provide a scientific explanation for why these unions are appealing to the tongue. Astringents like red wine and pickles balance out the grease of steaks and pastrami.

title: High-speed Trading Feeling the Pinch
description: High-speed trading firms struggle to maintain gains.

title: A 700,000-Year Trip From Mars to Morocco
description: A meteorite that landed in the Moroccan desert last summer was ejected from the surface of Mars 700,000 years ago, a new study reports. The meteorite is composed of an abundance of black glass, with noble gases trapped inside.

title: The Doctor Can See You Now. Really, Right Now.
description: Often the worst part of a visit to the doctor isnt the awkward hospital gown, needle sticks or embarrassing physical exams  its the drawn-out wait, camped out in the reception room in the company of sick patients and old magazines.

title: Mile 7: Where a Battle Was Fought in 1776
description: With all the cheering and the music, with runners dressed in tuxedos, tutus and Superman outfits, marathoners may be excused if they are not focusing on the American Revolution and the American pastime.

title: F.D.A. Warns of Further Risk From Tainted Drugs
description: Health officials are warning that more people may be at risk from contaminated drugs made by a Massachusetts company linked to a growing meningitis outbreak.

title: Prime Minister Emphasizes His Belief That Greece Will Stay in European Union
description: ATHENS  Even as talks with international creditors stalled, the Greek prime minister expressed optimism on Monday that an agreement would be reached that would end once and for all speculation that the country will leave the euro zone.

title: A Tango Partners Light Touch, and Other Late Night Intimacies
description: Dardo Galletto Studios are on the 11th floor of an ordinary office building near Times Square. Metal folding chairs hug the perimeter of the room; a mirror covers one wall, and windows look out onto other office buildings. Exposed along the low ceiling are sprinkler pipes, strung with white Christmas lights  the places one touch of elegance and romance.

title: TimesCast Media + Tech: Twitter and the Debates
description: The debates influence on the broadcasters. Cory Doctorow, digital activist and novelist. Social media meets spoken word poetry.

title: Then as Now, Businessmen Bent on Power
description: The titans of the early industrial age get a professional-wrestling sort of treatment in the slickly made docu-series The Men Who Built America, which begins on Tuesday night on the History channel.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: This week: an outbreak of fungal meningitis, a controversy over giving free samples of formula to new mothers, and detecting explosives with technology that mimics a bomb-sniffing dog.

title: H.I.V./AIDS: Methadone Treatment for Addicts Is Linked to Lower H.I.V. Risk
description: Offering methadone treatment to drug addicts substantially reduces the risk that they will get H.I.V. or give it to anyone else, a new study has found.

title: The Caucus Click: A Future Voter Considers Ryan
A Chemist Comes Very Close to a Midas Touch
description: In a lab in Princeton Universitys ultra-sleek chemistry building, researchers toil in a modern-day hunt for an elusive power: alchemy.

title: Hershey and Caffeine and Carburetors: A Tale of Two Car Shows
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.  As he directed traffic on Sunday for Caffeine and Carburetors, the informal automotive gathering in this suburb about 40 miles north of Midtown, Doug Zumbach, the events founder, described the origins of his coffee klatch.

title: Miamis Ultra Music Festival Expands to Two Weekends
description: When a big music festival becomes successful, it clones itself. Just ask Coachella, which this year expanded to two weekends from one (and later to a Caribbean cruise). Or Lollapalooza or Electric Daisy Carnival, a dance event that started in Los Angeles and is now held in Las Vegas, Puerto Rico, New Jersey and Florida.

title: Walkabout  10/15: Putting Through the Statues and Getting Lost of Your Own Accord
description: Mini Golf, Big Ideas At Big Stone Mini Golf in Minnesota, 13 holes feel more like a tour through a sculpture garden. (The New York Times)

title: Single Arachnid Fathers Attract More Mates
description: Single fatherhood isnt easy, but for one type of arachnid, it comes with a few benefits. Among them is that females find single fathers more attractive than gallivanting bachelors.

title: The Tastes of Myanmar
description: For fans of Southeast Asian cuisines like Thai and Vietnamese, discovering Burmese food is the adult equivalent of finding a new playground, right in your neighborhood.

title: But How Do You Really Feel? Someday the Computer May Know
description: In a Cairo school basement, two dozen women analyze facial expressions on laptops, training the computers to recognize anger, sadness and frustration.

title: In Myanmar, True Comfort in the Food
description: EACH time the Canadian photographer and writer Naomi Duguid traveled to Myanmar from 2008 to 2011, researching the countrys food traditions, she knew she had to cram in as much eating and learning as possible.

title: Walking Dead Sets Ratings Record on AMC
description: The Walking Dead, AMCs hugely popular drama, became the biggest hit of the fall television season on Sunday night, with the premiere of its third season posting ratings that surpassed every other nonsports program on television in most viewing categories.

title: Q and A: Tracking a Worrisome Dead Zone
description: For more than a quarter of a century, the marine ecologist Nancy Rabalais, the executive director of the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium, has worked to understand and to spread awareness of the so-called dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: When Life in a Hospital Feels Like High School
description: Did someone call for a young female doctor? Apparently so, because Mindy Kaling (The Mindy Project) and Jordana Spiro (The Mob Doctor) have already shown up this fall, joining Rachel Bilson (Hart of Dixie), whos still hanging around from last season. Now its a quartet with the arrival of Mamie Gummer in Emily Owens, M.D., making its debut on Tuesday night on CW.

title: Olga Smirnova on Her Toes
description: You would notice her on any street, in any room in the world. Even here, in downtown Moscow, where half the women look like supermodels and the other half are merely very pretty; even here, in the gilded lobby of the offices of the Bolshoi Ballet, where dancers drift weightlessly across the inlaid marble floors. When Olga Smirnova appears, you know that shes quite unlike anyone else. It isnt just that shes beautiful, though she is; with her long thin limbs, wide and raking cheekbones, and huge almond eyes, she looks like a runaway from Roswell, N.M., a lovely extraterrestrial who landed among us. But more than that, she carries the mysterious self-possession of someone whos simply better at what she does than anyone else, a sense that shes wrapped in her own dimension.

title: McCaskill Spends Heavily to Ward Off Akin Threat
description: Senator Claire McCaskill, the Missouri Democrat fighting to keep her seat, spent nearly $7 million over a three-month period through the end of September and her campaign had more than $2.1 million in the bank for her race against Representative Todd Akin, according to quarterly disclosure reports her campaign released on Monday.

title: Warren Among Top Senate Fund-Raisers of All Time
description: BOSTON  With a haul of $12.1 million in the last quarter, Elizabeth Warren has become one of the five most successful Senate fund-raisers of all time, surpassing the amount Hillary Rodham Clinton raised in her first Senate bid in 2000.

title: Book by Disgruntled Ex-Salesman Offers His Analysis of the Culture at Goldman
description: During Greg Smiths first week at Goldman Sachs, he was issued an identification badge and an e-mail address and each morning he had to scramble to make sure he got an 18-inch folding stool.

title: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Yoko Ono
description: Beginning at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time, watch a live stream of TimesTalks with Yoko Ono. She will discuss her work and her latest book, An Invisible Flower, with Michael Kimmelman, the New York Times architecture critic and global columnist.

title: Adele Leads Record Label to $67 Million Profit
description: Over the last 20 months, as Adeles album 21 spent week after week in the Top 10  a total of 79 weeks in the United States, with 24 of them at No. 1  envious record executives have, between salivations, wondered what kind of profit all those sales would bring.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Xbox Music, and H.P. Going Astray
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: Eataly Coming to Chicago
description: Eataly, the bustling high-end food hall that Mario Batali, Joseph Bastianich, his mother, Lidia, and their partners opened in Manhattan more than two years ago, has reached an agreement to open its second United States store in Chicago, Mr. Bastianich said.

title: They Plan to Dominate the World, but First They Want to Have Sex and Find Jobs
description: There were reasons to be curious about Underemployed, MTVs latest fictional series. It was created by Craig Wright, whose previous show, Dirty Sexy Money, was a hoot. And it was billed as a story about the anomie of the just-post-college generation, in the same general category as Lena Dunhams Girls on HBO and the underrated I Just Want My Pants Back on MTV.

title: A Spectacle, Narrative and Acrobatic
description: If you forget to turn off your cellphone during Urban, dont worry  no one will hear it if it rings. With a heavy hip-hop beat thumping throughout nearly the whole show, you wont even notice if its set to vibrate.

title: Rescued Owl Is Getting Cage Rest
description: The grounded saw-whet owl we wrote about on Friday after it was dropped off at the parks departments headquarters in a shoe box is recovering quietly at a wildlife rehabilitation center on Long Island.

title: Obama Phone
description: Last month the Drudge Report hyped a video of an African-American woman at an Ohio rally claiming the president had given her a free phone. Everybody in Cleveland, low minorities, got Obama phonesKeep Obama in president, you know! He gave us a phone, hes gonna do more. Dozens of news sites took it upon themselves to explain that the Obama campaign was not in fact operating an electronics-for-votes ring in swing states, but that there is in fact a government program that provides low-income people with free or cheap phones. It started under George W. Bush, not his successor.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.15
description: A view of the day in sports, from surfing to Game 2 of the Giants and Cardinals.

title: Why the Debate Over Big Bird Is a Sign of Progress
description: This past Sunday in the magazine, Adam Davidsonarguedthat, for all the surface discord that characterizes the Obama and Romney campaigns, the candidates hold surprisingly harmonious views on the economy. They back similar policies on free trade, Social Security and welfare. Perhaps their biggest disagreement centers on slightlydifferent tax rates for corporations and investors. For someone who lived in the first 150 years or so of this country,Davidson wrote, it might be hard to see whats so different about the economic policies ofBarackObama andMitt Romney.

title: No Indian Point + No Fracking = More Coal Burning?
description: The science writer John Horgan (whos also a friend and Hudson Valley neighbor) has written a piece for Scientific American laying out the tradeoffs that face New York State, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, if campaigners succeed in shutting the Indian Point nuclear plant and preventing gas drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

title: The Envelope, Please: Will Walker
description: Will Walker, a student at University School in Hunting Valley, Ohio, doesnt feel like lightning struck at any of the colleges he visited. But hes chosen apply binding early decision anyway.

title: Romney Is Attacked by His Fathers Longtime Aide
description: A longtime aide to George W. Romney issued a harshly worded critique of Mitt Romney, accusing him of shifting political positions in erratic and startling ways and failing to live up to the distinguished record of his father, the former governor of Michigan.

title: Giants Outfielder Exceeds Fill-In Status and Leaves Cabreras Shadow
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Because baseball is a meritocracy, not a democracy, personal affinity means little when it comes to matters of roster construction. For the better part of the summer, this fact presented Gregor Blanco, the San Francisco Giants left fielder, with a conundrum. Desirous of nothing more than the chance to prove his mettle, he found his path to playing time blocked by his best friend on the team.

title: Six Hopefuls Worth Watching at the CMJ Music Marathon
description: This week thousands of musicians swarm into New York City for the annual CMJ Music Marathon, looking to advance their careers. During six days of high-decibel chaos, starting on Tuesday, 1,300 acts from dozens of countries will vie for attention from a legion of journalists, music executives, booking agents, promoters and ordinary fans, all traipsing through Manhattan and Brooklyn nightspots with laminated badges and a hunger to hear something fresh.

title: Olmert Plans Comeback to Challenge Netanyahu
description: TEL AVIV  Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister who has spent the last several years battling corruption charges, is plotting a comeback that analysts say offers the best hope of uniting Israels fragmented political center, but also shows the oppositions desperation in trying to block the seemingly inevitable re-election of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Goldman Names Ogunlesi to Board
description: Goldman Sachs announced an addition to its board late Monday, appointing Adebayo O. Ogunlesi as an independent director of the bank.

title: Salesforce Hires to Go Open Source
description: It must grate that, while Oracle and Salesforce.com compete in business software applications, Oracle can (and does) taunt Salesforce with the fact that its applications also rely on Oracle databases for their core functions. That matters, particularly now that Oracle is making direct forays into cloud computing.

title: Wagners Songs Lifted by a Dark-Hued, Angelic Voice
description: Though the Russian-born conductor Semyon Bychkov was on the podium for the Met Orchestras excellent concert on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, James Levine was an unseen presence.

title: No Ibrahim Prize for African Leadership This Year
description: DAKAR, Senegal  For the third time in four years, a multimillion-dollar good-governance prize for African leaders has failed to find a winner, testimony to the continuing difficulties bedeviling democracy and human rights on the continent.

title: Hey, Thats My Professor Cursing on the Stage
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  David P. Schmidt stood center stage at the Quick Center for the Arts at Fairfield University here and glowered through his glasses at the audience before leaping into a corrosive, expletive-laden monologue from Glengarry Glen Ross. His character, Blake, is a hotshot manager, sent by the home office to inspire a handful of real estate salesmen with a contest: First prize, an Eldorado. Second prize, a set of steak knives. Third prize, youre fired.

title: Where Hungry Rats Will Do the Dirty Work
description: The uncanny valley is the phrase Masahiro Mori, a Japanese roboticist, used to describe the revulsion people feel when a robot or an image of a person is almost, but not quite, human. Its the feeling we get when we begin to focus on a representations inhuman aspects  its vacant eyes, its eerie rictus  instead of projecting our humanity onto it. R2D2 is adorable because he looks nothing like a person. But animatronic wax figures? Totally creepy.

title: App Smart Extra: A Look at Some Popular iPhone Apps
description: Last Thursdays App Smart column was all about some of the more interesting apps out there that make the most of the new iPhone 5s greater power and larger screen than its predecessors.

title: Hospitals Ditch Formula Samples to Promote Breast-Feeding
description: For years, virtually every new mother has been sent home from the hospital with a gift bag full of free product samples, including infant formula.

title: The Nobel Winners: A Reading List
description: On Monday the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to Alvin E. Roth and Lloyd S. Shapley for their work on market design. Heres some further reading on the recipients, the prize and the field of matching and market design.

title: Lively and Vivid, Music to Dance and Swoon To
description: This years early-music season is beginning with something that might be called chaconne fever.

title: Off Year on Wall St. Drove Down Manhattan Wages, Data Show
description: Despite all of the Bloomberg administrations efforts to diversify New York Citys economy, the latest data on wages show that Wall Street still has an outsize effect on income.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Delaware, The Philippines and Gaza Strip

title: U.S. to Help Create an Elite Libyan Force to Combat Islamic Extremists
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon and State Department are speeding up efforts to help the Libyan government create a commando force to combat Islamic extremists like the ones who killed the American ambassador in Libya last month and to help counter the countrys fractious militias, according to internal government documents.

title: Susie Bubble Thinks Pink
description: Susie Lau, a k a Susie Bubble of the fashion blog Style Bubble, took to the pavement in San Francisco for the Nike Womens Marathon on Saturday in the name of the battle against breast cancer. Nike invited Ms. Lau to run the half-marathon (13.1 miles) to benefit the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. (Last year her mother received a diagnosis of breast cancer and has been receiving treatment since.) When Ms. Lau told her mother of her plans to run a half-marathon, Ms. Lau said: First she laughed, then finally was touched by the idea. This is pretty normal behavior from Chinese parents. Susie accepted Nikes invitation and has raised money with a Just Giving page, an online donation Web site.

title: Over the Decades, How States Have Shifted
description: A look at how the states stacked up in the 2012 election and how they have shifted over past elections.

title: Releases by Jason Aldean, Sky Ferreira and Godspeed You! Black Emperor
description: JASON ALDEAN

title: The Mets Pinch Hitter Cant Always Step Up
description: The anticipated return of the recuperating James Levine affects many people inside the Metropolitan Opera. But the most interested, you might think, is his frequent substitute, the Italian conductor Fabio Luisi.

title: How to Flag Bad Science (1 Letter)
N.H.L. Negotiations Resume, Along With Battle for Public Opinion
description: 10:51 a.m. | Updated Talks between the N.H.L. and the players association are scheduled to resume Tuesday morning in Toronto, but Donald Fehr, the executive director of the union, said he did not expect substantive discussions on the core economic issues dividing the two sides in the 30-day lockout.

title: Now Democrats Suggest Polling Is Flawed
description: When polls last month showed President Obama pulling ahead, Republicans set up a noisy chorus that the results were flawed. Democrats dismissed the claims.

title: Generals 1962 Memo Addresses Nuclear Combat on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON  In a previously undisclosed memo to President John F. Kennedy in the closing days of the Cuban missile crisis, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of staff said his forces were prepared to use nuclear weapons in an American invasion of the island if the Cubans used nuclear arms to resist.

title: Memo Outlines Format and Rules for Candidate Debates
description: No props. No show of hands questions by the moderator. And by all means, no direct questions from one candidate to another.

title: New York Fed Turns Over New Libor Documents
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York released to Congressional investigators on Monday a battery of documents that detailed its response to interest rate manipulation at some of the worlds biggest banks.

title: M.T.A.s Choices of Fare Structures Draw Mixed Reactions
description: The multiple-choice question placed on the table by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Monday does not have a none-of-the-above option, unfortunately.

title: Over the Decades, How States Have Shifted
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,123 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Preparing for Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: The Afghan Army reached its full authorized strength in June, but it is struggling to keep its size, with the attrition rate in 2012 estimated at 32 to 35 percent.

title: Kyle Bennett, Bicycle Motocross Champion, Dies at 33
description: Kyle Bennett, a three-time world champion bicycle motocross racer who represented the United States in the inaugural appearance of BMX racing in the Olympics in Beijing in 2008, died in a one-car accident Sunday near his home in Conroe, Tex. He was 33.

title: Cardinals Find a Suitable Fill-In With the Rookie Kozma
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Politely and succinctly. Thats how Pete Kozma, the rookie shortstop for the St. Louis Cardinals, answered questions after Game 1 of the Cardinals 6-4 victory against the San Francisco Giants in the National League Championship Series on Sunday night. He stood in front of his locker with his hands clasped behind his back, his voice barely rising above the music pumping through the clubhouse.

title: Nowadays, Wall Street Saviors May Wish They Werent
description: Would I have done Bear Stearns again knowing what I know today?Jamie Dimon asked almost rhetorically last week at the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington.

title: Paul Ryan, Catholic Dissident
description: DURING last weeks vice-presidential debate  the first time two Catholics have shared such a stage  a question about abortion was inevitable. To some viewers, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s stance  that he personally opposes abortion but does not believe in imposing those beliefs on others  came across as a wishy-washy mlange of moral intuitions. In contrast, Representative Paul D. Ryan, who laid out his tickets policy to oppose abortion with the exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother, appeared to represent the principled, Catholic anti-abortion position.

title: Doctors Bath for Corpses Reinvigorates Cold Cases
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  Alejandro Hernndez Crdenas took a scorched-looking, decomposed head and five stiff, bloated hands and gently submerged them in his secret solution. After they soak for three days, he said, any scars, lesions or birthmarks the victim might have had will reappear.

title: Vice-Presidential Models
description: To the Editor:

title: With Win or Draw Against Guatemala, U.S. Would Advance
description: The United States will enter the final day of this World Cup qualifying semifinal group stage with just the slightest hint of doubt over their prospects for advancement.

title: Fed Governors Plan to Limit Bank Size Fuels Debate
description: Since the financial crisis, academics, politicians and even former bank chieftains have called for the nations banking behemoths to be broken up or shrunk  calls that appear to have fallen largely on deaf ears among Washingtons policy makers.

title: Mr. Romney Needs a Working Calculator
description: To the annoyance of the Romney campaign, members of Washingtons reality-based community have a habit of popping up to point out the many deceptions in the campaigns blue-sky promises of low taxes and instant growth. The latest is the Joint Committee on Taxation, an obscure but well-respected Congressional panel  currently evenly divided between the parties  that helps lawmakers calculate the effect of their tax plans.

title: Adolescents in Grown-Up Jails
description: The practice of confining young people to adult jails and prisons is both counterproductive and inhumane. Adolescents who are locked up with adults are more likely to be raped, battered or driven to suicide than young people who are handled through the juvenile justice system. After the trauma of doing hard, adult time, young people often return home as damaged individuals who are more likely to commit violent crimes and end up back inside.

title: Rules for Craftsmen
description: Voters have been astonishingly clear. In 2000, they elected George W. Bush after he promised to change the tone in Washington. In 2008, they elected Barack Obama after he promised to move the country beyond stale partisan debates. In this years first presidential debate, surveys show that viewers loved Mitt Romneys talk of professionalism and bipartisanship.

title: Pop Goes the President
description: To the clamor for administration records concerning embassy security, Id like to add my own request. I hereby subpoena President Obamas iPod.

title: Bronx Obama
description: In this short documentary we meet Louis Ortiz, an unemployed man from the Bronx whose life is turned upside down when he discovers his uncanny resemblance to President Obama.

title: 2 Officers Being Investigated After Video Shows Them Beating Man
description: The Police Department and the Brooklyn district attorneys office have begun separate investigations into allegations of police brutality after reviewing video (see also below) that shows two officers repeatedly striking a young man inside a Jewish community center in Brooklyn, officials said on Monday.

description: A prominent lawyer who has been involved in some of New York Citys most controversial criminal cases said he would run for Brooklyn district attorney, a move that would expand the field running against Charles J. Hynes, a longtime incumbent whose hold on the office has weakened amid mounting criticism.

title: Airlines Are Likely to Match Southwests Fare Increase
description: THE fourth quarter, when leisure travel sags until the holidays, is one of the busiest times of the year for business travel. Here are some trends for the rest of the year.

title: Bronx Obama
description: What if one day you looked in the mirror and saw the most powerful man in the world staring back at you? In this Op-Doc video, we meet Louis Ortiz, an unemployed Puerto Rican man from the Bronx, whose life turned upside down when he discovered his uncanny resemblance to President Obama.

title: If Roe v. Wade Goes
description: It is no secret that Mitt Romney and his running-mate, Representative Paul Ryan, are opponents of abortion rights. When Mr. Ryan was asked at last weeks debate whether voters who support abortion rights should be worried if the Romney-Ryan ticket were elected, he essentially said yes.

title: Manhattan Borough President Seeks Bonds to Expand Early Education
description: Piggybacking on a recent Bloomberg administration initiative, Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, plans to propose on Tuesday that New York City experiment with an innovative method to help pay for early education.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A member of the Afghan intelligence service detonated a suicide vest Saturday, killing two Americans and four Afghan intelligence agency colleagues, Afghan and international officials said Monday.

title: After a Childhood Pouring Refills, Reaching Beyond the Past
description: ELYRIA, OHIO  Bridgette the waitress glides through morning at Donnas Diner with an easy, familiar air, as though she were born somewhere between the cash register and the coffee maker. She is a constant, like pancakes on the menu.

title: A Twitching Nose at Security, Not Sniffing for Danger
description: MY job as owner and executive chef of my culinary company, Blu Aubergine, has me traveling all the time. Id better like to fly. Its the only way my business will work. Sure, flying is a lot less fun than it used to be, but all the annoyances are just part of the adventure of getting to where youre going. I do a lot of events in the United States, but I also have to travel all over Europe, and have also been to South America, Asia and the Middle East, and I split my time between Rome and New York. Every place I go, I can find some culinary inspiration.

title: Speedy Amos
description: A profile of Speedy Amos.

title: Elyria Then, Elyria Now
description: Bridgette Harvan has been pouring coffee at her grandmother's place, Donna's Diner, since childhood. But now, approaching her 21st birthday, Bridgette is forging a new path away from the grill.

title: Bed, Bathrobe and Beyond
description: The monogrammed bathrobes, the bedding and pillows? Hotels are now going far beyond that in offering products to remind guests of their stay or draw them back for another visit.

title: Giants Pleased With All-Around Play Against 49ers
description: Coach Tom Coughlin hammered his Giants players throughout the preseason with the slogan Build the Bridge, urging them to continue to display the qualities that allowed them to sweep their final six games last season and emerge as Super Bowl champions.

title: Giuliani Criticizes Obama on Handling of Benghazi Attack
description: On the evening that Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said she took responsibility for the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, had harsh words for President Obamas handling of the situation in the Middle East, calling it a policy of provocative weakness.

title: Seeking Aid, School Districts Change Teacher Evaluations
description: LONGMONT, Colo.  In an exercise evoking a corporate motivation seminar, a group of public school teachers and principals clustered around posters scrawled with the titles of Beatles songs. Their assignment: choose the one that captured their feelings about a new performance evaluation system being piloted in their district.

title: The BlackBerry Stigma
description: BlackBerry devices, once the phone of movers and shakers, have become a punchline.

title: The BlackBerry as Black Sheep

title: Fenway-Style Makeover Would Befit a Soccer Landmark
description: In English soccer, there is no place where history and tradition are valued, respected and cherished more highly than at Anfield, the home of Liverpool F.C.

title: U.N. Envoy Seeks Pause in Syria for Holiday
description: The new Syria peace envoy from the United Nations and Arab League enlisted Irans help on Monday in an effort to negotiate a cease-fire in observance of a three-day holiday dear to all Muslims, hoping that such a religious reprieve could become the basis for a dialogue.

title: A Short Defense of Literary Excess
description: The novelists I find myself attracted to are those who cannot resist the extra adjective, the additional image, the scale-tipping clause. It feels necessary to assert and celebrate this, for we are living in puritanical times. The contemporary preference seems to be for the economical, the efficient, for simple precision (though there is of course such a thing as complex precision). Books, it appears, should be neat and streamlined. Language shouldnt be allowed to obscure a good story. There is a craving for easily relatable and sympathetic characters. Among critics and reviewers, the plain style is more likely to be praised than the elaborate or sprawling. Embellished prose is treated with suspicion, if not dismissed outright as overwritten, pretentious or self-indulgent. Drab prose is everywhere.

title: Debate Fever on Campus Helps Lift Hofstras Image
description: David Zuniga, 21, is just the kind of student Hofstra University is looking for. A senior from West Palm Beach, Fla., with a mania for politics, Mr. Zuniga was deciding where to apply to college when he watched the presidential debate between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama at Hofstra in 2008.

title: 2nd Presidential Debate Is Less Formal, but Little Is Left to Chance
description: The format for the second presidential debate is designed to be a little less stiff  a free-flowing question-and-answer session between the candidates and a studio audience.

title: Lewis Is Out for Season, Leaving Hole in Middle
description: The Baltimore Ravens are 5-1 and might be the best team in the A.F.C. despite the absence of their best defensive player. But on Monday, they suffered a crushing blow to their psyche and persona when the team announced that another key defender, the star linebacker and leader Ray Lewis, would miss the rest of the season with a torn right triceps muscle, an injury that could imperil his career.

title: New Rule Leads to Old School Politics in South Carolina, Critics Say
description: ATLANTA  What began as a gap between the digital revolution and the way South Carolinas candidates had long filed for office has blown up into a legal battle that many say reflects a state whose politics have been raucous since the day it fired the shots that started the Civil War.

title: A Yankees Rally? Precedents Are Few but Memorable
description: The Yankees head into Comerica Park on Tuesday night for Game 3 of the American League Championship Series having to confront the Detroit Tigers ace, Justin Verlander, and plenty of unwelcome precedent in the record books.

title: S. Ward Casscells, Pentagon Medical Chief, Dies at 60
description: Dr. S. Ward Casscells, a nationally prominent cardiologist who astonished himself and those who knew him by joining the Army Reserve at 54 and volunteering to go to Iraq before being appointed the Pentagons top medical officer, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 60.

title: Amy Poehler and Tina Fey to Host Golden Globe Awards
description: After the recent announcement that the Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane will host the Academy Awards in February  an appeal, perhaps, to the Y-chromosomes out there in TV land  the organizers of the Golden Globe Awards are offering their own form of counterprogramming: on Monday night, they announced that Amy Poehler and Tina Fey, the former Saturday Night Live co-stars and now mainstays of NBCs Thursday night comedy lineup, will host the Golden Globes in January.

title: Where Mayor Sees Clear Fiscal Skies, Clouds Gather
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has reached what he apparently conceives of as the victory lap in his near-endless mayoralty.

Jackson Jr., who has stayed out of public view for much of the past four months while undergoing treatment for bipolar disorder, is being investigated by federal authorities for the possible misuse of campaign money, a federal official confirmed on Monday.

title: Proposals to Redraw School Lines Raise Alarm
description: Few issues have the potential to make parents and real estate brokers sweat like the system called zoning, which determines where children attend school and can inflate property values on certain blocks. So proposals in Washington Heights and Park Slope to shuffle or eliminate zone lines altogether next year are causing no small amount of perspiration.

Among those expected to take part are Tom Brokaw, Bill Clinton, the West Point Band and the singer Audra McDonald.

title: Debt Impasse Shadows Race for Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Mitt Romney will again debate their visions for the next four years on Tuesday night, and if the campaign so far is any guide, they will not acknowledge that the winners agenda could depend on the fiscal showdown between Election Day and Inauguration Day.

title: Do Good C.E.O.s Make Good Presidents?
description: With only a few weeks remaining until the election, its still not clear how Mitt Romney would manage our jobs crisis. There arent many lessons from his term as the governor of Massachusetts  the economy was comparatively healthy back then, and the unemployment rate was fairly low. His current economic platform lays out broad principles (Principle No. 1: Dont be Barack Obama) but is light on specifics. All thats certain is that Romney has promised to use decades of business savvy to create jobs, which raises the question: how do you apply business strategy to a jobs crisis? No business views hiring as an objective. When a crisis hits, the response of many executives is to let workers go.

title: In a Time of Hidden Crisis, President Visits Main Street
Sharing Life and Liquor on a Changing Bushwick Street
description: In 1996 Brenda Ann Kenneally moved into a Brooklyn neighborhood that had many abandoned buildings, empty lots strewn with garbage and what was essentially an open-air crack market. She was just looking for an affordable place to live, but her new home proved to be fertile ground for making her socially concerned photography.

title: Paul Ryan Cant Lose
description: On a Monday night in late September, Paul Ryan sat on the edge of a couch in his suite at the Cincinnatian Hotel, his left fist clenched so tightly around the neck of his bottle of Miller Lite that I could see the veins bulging in his hands. It was the end of a long day that began at Ryans home in Janesville, Wis., where hed spent the weekend preparing for the vice-presidential debate. Early Monday morning, he flew to the first of two fund-raisers, on top of which he did three local TV interviews and a brief chat on Fox Business Network and also a town-hall meeting, plus a half-hour phone call with Mitt Romney, after which he finally settled in on the couch to watch his Green Bay Packers play the Seattle Seahawks on Monday Night Football. A few minutes after kickoff, Ryans traveling press secretary, Michael Steel, led me into the suite where Ryan was watching the game with his older brother Tobin, his campaign adviser Dan Senor, the Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus and Senator Rob Portman of Ohio.

It was part of the project Towards a Common Archive, sponsored by Zochrot (Hebrew for remembering), an Israeli organization that hopes to bring awareness and recognition of the Nakba to Jewish Israelis so that they can take responsibility for this tragedy.
