Out of the national team for more than a year because of a knee injury sustained during the fourth Indian Premier League season in 2011, he celebrated his return to test cricket in August with a brilliant innings of 159 in Hyderabad, followed by an important innings of 48 at a crucial juncture, when India was chasing a victory target of 261 runs, in Bangalore.

title: IHT Quick Read: Thursday, Oct. 18
description: NEWS The Greek government had hoped to sew up a $17.7 billion austerity budget package before a summit meeting of European officials begins Thursday in Brussels. There, leaders were prepared to consider granting Athens more time to fix its finances and cement assurances that Greece could and should stay in the euro currency union. But what was supposed to be a fast-track European effort to support Greece seems to have slowed. Liz Alderman reports from Athens.

title: AOLs Got Mail, Again, With Alto
description: AOLs got mail, again. On Thursday, the company is beginning its rollout of Alto, a new e-mail program that it hopes will re-establish the company as the e-mailing juggernaut it was in the 1990s.

title: On Floridas Jewish Question
description: BOCA RATON, Florida  I got my first first-hand lesson on the technicalities of Florida voting among a small group of fellow Jews in a classroom here on Tuesday. It was an improvised seminar of sorts: a few friends sitting together to make sure they were on the same page and ready. Whats on the ballot, and how does one make sure to vote for the people and the causes one believes in?

title: A Quiet Beauty Along the Yangtze
description: HONG KONG  Nadav Kander, a photographer based in London, spent three years taking photographs along the Yangtze River in China for a series called Yangtze  The Long River.

title: CMJ: Embracing Garage Psychedelias Excesses
description: Back in 1981, when the CMJ Music Marathon started, 1960s garage psychedelia was already an antique genre being enthusiastically revived by fuzz-tone-loving aficionados. I cant think of a CMJ (or for that matter South By Southwest) where I havent thoroughly enjoyed some band plunging into the hopped-up stomps, overamped blues riffs, drones and freakouts so fondly remembered by bands that have been, in more recent years, too young to have possibly witnessed the original excesses.

title: Haiers Increased Offer Wins Fisher & Paykel
description: HONG KONG  The Haier Group of China, one of the worlds biggest manufacturers of household appliances, succeeded on Thursday in its bid to acquire Fisher & Paykel Appliances with an improved offer of 927 million New Zealand dollars ($762 million).

title: Coming to Terms With the Legacy of War
description: Spin the globe, point your finger and stop it cold. Odds are youve landed on a country that has, at one time or another, seen armed conflict or all-out war. Think Afghanistan, Iraq, the United States, Sudan, Israel, Colombia and Sri Lanka, to name a recent few. As each new conflict unfolds, audiences around the world feed on a steady diet of images depicting violence and suffering. They flash daily on our televisions and computer screens, and scroll across our tablets and smartphones. In the best of circumstances, cease-fires are eventually declared and peace agreements signed. The tanks roll out, soldiers depart and media attention shifts to a new story. Often, only a handful of international journalists and photographers stay behind  and join national ones  to cover what remains.

title: Running Citigroup Without Subsidies
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: The Scariest Little Corner of the World
description: On the southern outskirts of the city Zaranj, where the last derelict shanties meet an endless, vacant country  beige desert and beige sky, whipped together into a single coalescing haze by the accurately named Wind of 120 Days  there is a place called Ganj: a kind of way station for Afghan migrants trying to reach Iran. Every day except Friday, a little before 2 in the afternoon, hundreds of them gather. Squatting along a metal fence, Hazaras, Tajiks, Pashtuns, Uzbeks and Baluchis from all corners of the country watch the local drivers move through a fleet of dilapidated pickups  raising hoods, inspecting dipsticks. A few hope to continue on to Turkey, Greece and ultimately Western Europe. Most harbor humbler dreams: of living illegally in Iran, of becoming bricklayers, construction laborers, factory workers or farmhands. When one of the drivers announces he is ready to go, as many as 20 migrants pile into the back. The leaf springs flex; the bumper nearly kisses the ground. Arms and legs spill over the sides. Finally, apprehension gives way to expectation, and a few men laugh and wave goodbye.

His new book, Mind and Cosmos, extends this skepticism to much of contemporary scientific inquiry, including evolutionary biology, and calls for a new scientific revolution based on teleological principles. Its a proposal that has, unsurprisingly, been quite controversial.

title: Career Re-entry for the At-Home Parent
description: Last week, Jennifer Romaniuk wrote the Motherlode with a passionate parental quandary. I voluntarily walked away from a promising career, she e-mailed. I had no idea how long it would take to claw my way back. The decision to stay home seemed like the right one when she made it. Spending more time with her children would be fun; ending the race between work and child care for her two kids would make life feel less daunting for her and for her fast-tracked husband.

title: Nokia Loss Widens as Its Smartphone Sales Plummet
description: BERLIN  Nokia said on Thursday that its third-quarter loss widened to 969 million euros ($1.27 billion), citing sharply declining sales of its smartphones as customers await the introduction of a generation of handsets running a newer version of the Windows operating system.

title: At a Dinner, Political Banter and Some Familiar Suspicions
description: Across a stretch of 36 hours in New York, circumstances are bringing together, for the first time in this campaign and amid apprehension about the November election, two political leaders who long eyed each other suspiciously and who disagreed so strongly, both publicly and privately:

title: Hawker Beechcraft Says Deal Talks Ended
description: Hawker Beechcraft, the business jet maker, said on Thursday that takeover talks with the Superior Aviation Beijing Company had collapsed and that it would instead seek to emerge from bankruptcy as a stand-alone company.

title: Verizons Income Increases 15.5% as Sales Climb
description: At Verizon Communications, the plan is working. In May, it told investors it hoped to bring in more money from wireless customers with its new shared data plans, which encourage people to pay for more data. Those new plans, and strong smartphone sales, are paying off.

title: He Knew It When He Saw (and Heard) It
description: ON the morning of the Adult Video News Awards  the Oscars of the pornography industry  I woke up in my Las Vegas hotel room to the sound of a sex scene being shot next door. I knew it was a sex scene, as opposed to plain old sex, because 1) the womans screams were deafening and otherworldly and 2) I was in Las Vegas on the morning of the Adult Video News Awards.

title: What Were Reading
description: Instructables: Once you think about making a real-looking cob out of candy corn, how can you not do it? Here are instructions; yes, cookie dough is involved.  Julia Moskin

title: In a Five-Part Series, The Times Movingly Explores Another America
description: In a volatile election season, with candidates going for blood and the volume turned up full blast, Dan Barrys five-part series makes its appearance in The Times like a visitor from a distant planet.

title: Queens Residents Lead the City in Optimism, Poll Finds
description: Is Queens looking at the world through rose-colored glasses? A new survey found that almost a quarter of Queens residents were very optimistic about the future of life in New York City, up from 14 percent last year.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Support Has Grown Among Latinos, Survey Finds
description: More than half of the nations Latinos are in favor of same-sex marriage, according to a survey released on Thursday, dispelling a long-standing notion that their religious beliefs offered a safe path to Republicans looking to stake a claim in the community through shared social values.

title: Mitt Romneys Math Problem
description: In Tuesday nights debate, Mr. Romney again refused to say which deductions he would limit to pay for his tax plan (including his pledge to cut tax rates by 20 percent and eliminate the AMT) which would cost some $5 trillion over ten years. Instead, he said one way to curb deductions would be to cap the total amount that taxpayers can claim against their deductible expenses. Ill pick a number, he said, $25,000 of deductions and credits, and you can decide which ones to use.

title: Nobel Laureates Endorse Obama
description: Among Nobel laureates, President Obama appears to have won by a landslide.

title: Barclays Sets Aside $1.1 Billion More for Insurance Claims
description: LONDON  The British bank Barclays said on Thursday that it had set aside an additional 700 million ($1.1 billion) related to the inappropriate sales of insurance to British customers.

title: Rhode Island: The Most Elastic State
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is Rhode Island, the Ocean State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Scott MacKay, a political analyst for Rhode Island Public Radio; and Maureen Moakley, a professor of political science at the University of Rhode Island.

title: Germany Left to Ponder the Victory That Got Away
description: Wednesdays online edition of Der Spiegel ran the headline, 60 Minutes Heaven, 30 Minutes Hell, to sum up the Germany soccer teams shocking 4-4 draw with visiting Sweden on Tuesday night. What seemed like a routine win for Die Mannschaft quickly turned on its head late in the second half. Before CoachJoachim Lws team could retreat under the guidance of the final whistle, Sweden had rallied from four goals back to claim a point.

title: On Our Radar: Tigers and Tourism
description: Indias Supreme Court lifts a ban on tourism in tiger reserves after the government announces new rules intended to allow tourism to co-exist with conservation. No new hotels or other tourist facilities can be created in the tiger areas, and only 20 percent of tiger habitats will be open to visitors. [Associated Press]

title: More Asian Immigrants Are Finding Ballots in Their Native Tongue
description: LAS VEGAS  Joshua Pajarillo stood outside Seafood City, greeting fellow Filipinos in Tagalog  one of his native countrys main languages  and trying to get them to stop and fill out Clark Countys new voter registration form.

title: David Mitchell: By the Book
description: The author of Cloud Atlas would like to drink dodgy Crimean wine with Chekhov and play a few rounds of Anglo-Russian Scrabble.

title: CMJ: A Rocket Out of This Place
description: Bottom line first: Deap Vally was too good for the room. Playing Wednesday night at the Fader Fort, a pop-up space organized by the music and style magazine in a Williamsburg building that also houses Rubber Tracks, a Converse-sponsored recording studio, the band was confident and direct and efficient. Youd be surprised what short supply those things are in during CMJ.

title: Daily Report: Yelp Fights Fake Reviews With Shaming
description: Businesses caught soliciting favorable reviews are increasingly running the risk of getting slapped with a badge of shame, particularly on Yelp, David Streitfeld reports in Thursdays New York Times.

title: Bookshelf | Diego Uchitel: Polaroids
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Benjamin Millepieds Los Angeles Dance Project
description: The group aims to create new dances, revive seminal works and generally kick up dust by collaborating in unusual ways with various arts organizations in the city.

title: Giant Steps for Dance in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES

title: CMJ: Hundred Waters Suspends Time
description: Hundred Waters, a band from Gainesville, Fla., started its CMJ set on Wednesday night at the Mercury Lounge with more than two minutes of a sustained drone holding improvisations within itself: a watercolor wash of possibilities, a suspension of time, an embrace of textural experiment and open-ended expectations.

title: Airstrikes in Syria Levels Building
description: Government airstrikes on rebel areas in northern Syria killed at least 43 people and leveled buildings, forcing residents to search mounds of rubble for bodies trapped underneath, anti-regime activists said Thursday.

title: Newsweek to End Print Publication
description: Business Day Live: How lapses in quality at drug makers are slowing production. | Newsweek to end its print publication. | Rajat K. Gupta fights for leniency after insider-trading conviction.

title: Proposed Credit Card Rules Aid Spouses and Partners
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is proposing to make it easier for stay-at-home wives and husbands  as well as unmarried partners  to get credit cards.

title: Obama and Romney Share Stage Again Tonight, but This Time for Laughs
description: There hasnt been much smiling by President Obama and Mitt Romney since their tension-filled debate earlier this week.

title: For Hybrid Drivers, a Gas Pump Allergy?
description: Although electric vehicles have not taken off as some had hoped, there are now enough of them on the road that some behavioral differences between drivers of all-electric models and plug-in hybrids have become evident, in addition to those between E.V. users and owners of conventional models.

title: Leading Off: The Great A-Rod Debate
description: You have to hand it to the Yankees. Their current free-fall is so riveting that they have managed to keep a chokehold on the news on a day when their American League Championship Series game against Detroit was rained out. Or sort of rained out. It was more like a golly, the radar says its supposed to rain rained out. It definitely fell into the category of mysteries of the baseball universe, right up there with why everything that goes wrong with the Yankees ends up circling back to Alex Rodriguez.

title: Seized by Rebels, Town Is Crushed by Syrian Forces
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The town of Maarat al-Noaman in northern Syria was just last week the scene of a major victory for the insurgents, who drove government forces from checkpoints at a crucial crossroads on a major highway, apprehended scores of soldiers, celebrated atop captured armored vehicles and declared the town liberated.

title: Business Day Live: Newsweek to Cease Print Publication at End of Year
description: How lapses in quality at drug makers are slowing production. | Newsweek to end its print publication. | Rajat K. Gupta fights for leniency after insider-trading conviction.

description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

description: Highlights of some notable acts from the second day in New York.

title: For Northwestern Football, Sleep Is Not Optional
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Northwesterns football players will rise early Saturday, beginning preparations for their matchup with Nebraska, a game that earned national exposure with a kickoff set for 3:30 p.m. Eastern on ABC.

title: CMJ: Photos From Day 2
description: Photographers for The Times share highlights from the second day of the music marathon. See more photos.

title: Image of the Day: Oct. 18
Poetry Pairing | Prayers End
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Prayers End by Brooklyn Copeland with Experts See Signs of El Nio, but a Weak One, an article about how warmer ocean waters may affect the weather over the next several months.

title: Missing Boy, 5, Is Found Blocks From His Home
description: Aeden Wiggins, 5, of Rosedale, Queens, has a history of sleepwalking, his mother told the police.

title: Orient-Express Hotels Gets Buyout Offer
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated Shares of Orient-Express Hotels surged in trading on Thursday after the hotel arm of the Tata conglomerate of India made an offer for the rest of the company that it does not already own.

title: Why Am I Sleeping Like a Baby (Boomer)?
description: There are any number of reasons you might be up at 2 in the morning instead of snuggled asleep in bed. Maybe you are finishing some work  an article, say, that you owe the editor of that new Booming blog. Maybe you are one of those people who decided to have a baby at an age when parents would once have been making their last tuition payments. Or maybe the condo you bought over that all-night bowling alley was so cheap for a reason.

title: Roundabout Revival of Picnic Finds Its Stars
description: Maggie Grace, you are going to be taken  this time by a roguish but sensitive young man who carries away your heart at a memorable Labor Day gathering, in a new Broadway production of Picnic.

title: What I Love | Susanne Bartsch
description: Susanne Bartschs home is an apartment at the Chelsea Hotel, long noted for being shabby-cool and overrun with artists, writers and rockers.

title: A Lounge of Her Own
description: IN the 70s and 80s, thousands of would-be artists and as-yet-unknowns swept into New York City with fantasies of making it big.

title: Blackstone Swings to Profit of $622 Million in 3rd Quarter
description: If the Blackstone Groups third-quarter results can serve as a reasonable proxy for the private equity industry, then its brethren will have a lot of good news to share with investors.

title: After Bankruptcy of A123 Systems, Fisker Keeps Calm and Carries On
description: At the Luxury Review, an annual showcase in Chelsea for makers of big-ticket apparel, jewelry, liquor, single-origin chocolate bars and motorized conveyances, bankruptcy may be considered gauche cocktail conversation. But parked at the center of the Metropolitan Pavilion space on West 18th Street on Wednesday evening was the Fisker Karma, the $100,000 plug-in hybrid sedan, packing lithium-ion batteries supplied by the newly bankrupt A123 Systems.

title: India Puts Wal-Mart Deal With Retailer Under Scrutiny
description: MUMBAI  Indian regulators have begun an informal inquiry into allegations that Wal-Mart Stores violated rules restricting foreign investment in the countrys fast-growing retailing industry.

title: A Dogs Grace
description: I was standing on a ladder in the closet, cleaning out the shelves, when I noticed Gracie, our standard poodle puppy, throwing up in the corner.

title: Unanswered Questions at the Kunsthal
description: ROTTERDAM  Its back to the business of fine art for the Kunsthal, which reopened Wednesday with new paintings replacing the seven that were stolen during the early morning Tuesday.

title: Lord & Taylor Parent Moves Toward an I.P.O.
description: OTTAWA  The Hudsons Bay Company, which was founded in 1670, making it Canadas oldest corporation, has filed a preliminary prospectus in preparation for a return to the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Roy Lichtenstein: A Retrospective
description: The first major survey of the artists work since his death, at 73, in 1997, is at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Its My Sad Duty to Tweet This News
description: A few hours after my ex-husband died, our son (in his early 20s) tweeted the news and posted it on his Facebook page. I was appalled. And my exs widow was (and remains) furious with him about it. The only person who doesnt see anything wrong with his behavior is my son. Is there a generation gap at work here, or did he make a serious gaffe?

title: As Kolkata Celebrates Durga Puja, a Rift Between Idol Makers
description: KOLKATAOn a hot and humid July afternoon in Kumartuli, Kolkatas historic potters district, Shankar Kumar Paul was playing absentmindedly with a ball of clay, turning it first into a swan and then into an elephant.

title: Delta Expands Service to Europe
description: After suspending flights to several European hubs over the last few years, Delta Air Lines, in conjunction with its joint venture partners, Air France and KLM, has announced that it will begin increasing flights to Paris and Amsterdam.

title: Styled to a T | Grimes
description: The TrendScarf Tactics. With respect to the ladies who lunch, Givenchy, Chlo and Cline have given the classic foulard an urban twist with graphic prints.

title: Pakistani Police Detain Family of Suspect in Attack on Girl
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani security forces have detained relatives of a man accused of attacking Malala Yousafzai, the schoolgirl who became an icon of resistance against Taliban oppression and who is now being treated at a British hospital, neighbors of the mans family said Thursday.

title: A Power Vacuum in Bhutan
description: Aaron Putnam, a postdoctoral research scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, is a leader of an expedition to Bhutan to examine links among climate, glaciers and water resources in the Himalaya.

title: Attack of the Mystery Monkey
description: Well, it happened: the Mystery Monkey bit somebody.

title: Sneak Peeks Into New Book on Goldman Sachs
description: The book by Greg Smith, a former employee of Goldman Sachs, isnt scheduled to be released until Monday. But some details are already coming to light.

title: Cuomo to Travel the U.S. on Obamas Behalf
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo may be coming to a swing state near you.

title: A New Model: Cycle Hire, for Hire
description: Municipal bike sharing has rolled into dozens of American cities, from Washington to Oklahoma City to San Francisco. Now a Massachusetts start-up called Zagster aims to take the idea of bicycles on demand and deliver it to university and corporate campuses, apartment complexes, hotels and resorts.

title: Shares Fall Sharply as Google Earnings Are Released Early
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google released a disappointing earnings report on Thursday that sent its stock price plummeting and reflected the challenges the company faces as it tries to make money in a mobile world.

title: Cool. Commercial. Unmistakable.
description: WASHINGTON  Like a champion gymnast perfecting a winning routine, Roy Lichtenstein developed a deft, tight, virtually foolproof art style, one that was based on agility rather than brawn and, though narrow in range, was capable of surprising variations and extensions.

title: Staten Island Haunted by High Hum
description: Updated, 3:01 p.m. | Residents of South Beach, Staten Island, are being driven mad. When the wind is right along Father Capodanno Boulevard, high celestial harmonies swell in the air, crescendo and drift in and out of phase, like an battalion of crickets armed with sopranino recorders. It may sound like a cool environmental art installation, but if you live near it, it is not much fun.

title: CMJ Snapshot: From Online to On Line at Savages Show
description: Taking note of distinctive scenes at this years CMJ Music Marathon.

title: A Rogue Climate Experiment Outrages Scientists
description: A California businessman chartered a fishing boat in July, loaded it with 100 tons of iron dust and cruised through Pacific waters off western Canada, spewing his cargo into the sea in an ecological experiment that has outraged scientists and government officials.

title: Jogglers World
description: A look at Jack Hirschowitz, 67, who combined juggling and jogging in the early 1990s, thinking it was his own oddity. It was not.

title: 3 Beanbags and 26.2 Miles
description: When the Fort Wadsworth cannon sounds on Nov. 4, propelling more than 47,000 marathon runners across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge for the New York City Marathon, Jack Hirschowitzs first strides will be charged by the steady pulse of three white spheres, looping like electrons orbiting around an invisible core.

title: Obama Hits Back With New Abortion Ad
description: A day after Mitt Romney released a television commercial that sought to soften his position on abortion rights and contraception, President Obama came out Thursday with a response that all but accuses him of lying.

title: Campaigns Focus on Women Intensifies
description: TimesCast Politics: Aftermath of the binders full of women comment. | New data on young voters and Hispanics. | The final fund-raising sprint. | Bruce Springsteen returns to the campaign trail.

title: Highlights and Analysis From Game 4 of the A.L.C.S.
Guest Post | A Teenager on How Writing Helps Makes Sense of His Loss
description: Occasionally we collaborate with an organization called Youth Communication to feature true stories by young people that help add a new voice or angle to a topic were covering on this blog.

title: Without Love, Questions in Minnesota
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves announced Tuesday that the All-Star power forward Kevin Love would be sidelined for up to two months with a broken hand. The injury to Love, their franchise player, could derail the Timberwolves hopes of reaching the playoffs for the first time since 2003-4.

title: Tagg Romney Calibrates Swing at Obama Remark
description: The second presidential debate on Tuesday was a clash of finger-pointing, interruptions and bitter disagreements. Mitt Romneys eldest son had an especially visceral reaction. Tagg Romney said his instinct was to jump out of your seat and rush down to the debate stage and take a swing at President Obama.

title: Week 7 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Luck of the Ravens
description: Baltimore and Houston, the top two A.F.C teams by win-loss record, meet this Sunday. No other conference rival is above .500. But while Houston has been dominant so far this season, Baltimore has been exceptionally lucky.

title: U.S. Marriage Act Is Unfair to Gays, Court Panel Says
description: A federal appeals court on Thursday ruled that gay Americans are a class of people who deserve the same kinds of constitutional protections as many other victims of discrimination.

title: The War Democrats Big Night
description: When the Army of Northern Virginia invaded Maryland in September 1862, it did so in part to influence the upcoming Northern elections  an effort to conquer a peace. The presence of a Southern army on Union soil, Confederate General Robert E. Lee wrote President Jefferson Davis, would enable the people of the United States to determine at their coming elections whether they will support those who favor a prolongation of the war, or those who wish to bring it to a termination. Even if the Confederacy lost its war for independence on the battlefield, the reasoning went, it could still hope to undermine the Northern publics will to fight.

title: The Wisconsin Ad War
description: WAUSAU, Wisc.  For a few weeks, it seemed that Democrats in Wisconsin might have broken the states long stalemate and pulled ahead. But a poll out on Wednesday showed that voters were back in a familiar place: dead even.

title: Quirks of the Game: The Trouble With the Tie
description: One of Fox News online stories about Tuesdays presidential debate began with the line, In the baseball playoffs, the tie goes to the runner. Its a phrase with plenty of legs this political season, used in at least a half-dozen analyses of the vice presidential debate and by Time magazine in February referring to Mitt Romney in the Michigan primary. (Cliches tend to get recycled. In 2008, a New York Observer headline stated, In a Stifling Town Hall Debate, the Tie Goes to theFront-Runner.)

title: TimesCast Politics: A More Intent Focus on Women
description: Getty Images

title: Boy Scout Files Give Glimpse Into 20 Years of Sex Abuse
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Details of decades of sexual abuse in the Boy Scouts of America, and what child welfare experts say was a corrosive culture of secrecy that compounded the damage, were cast into full public view for the first time on Thursday with the release of thousands of pages of documents describing abuse accusations across the country.

title: Blue Collar
description: Inside Williamsburgs new burger shack, built in the In-N-Out Californian style.

title: Lake Trout
description: Inside Williamsburgs hole-in-the-wall Baltimore-style seafood restaurant.

title: Chemo on the Rocks
description: You have the power to choose your own toxicity, one speaker told the audience at a course for ovarian cancer survivors in Indianapolis recently. A professor of obstetrics and gynecology, she was urging patients to weigh side effects from various chemotherapy agents and participate in the decision on which treatments would least harm their quality of life.

title: Theater Talkback: Screams, Silent and Otherwise
description: I do not scream at the theater. At the movies, sure, whenever any shark or zombie catches me off guard. But I go the the-a-tuh to be enlightened, not frightened. I laugh, I cry, I might even gasp. Scream? Almost never.

title: Bronx Parks Animals Are Targeted With Darts
description: Updated Oct. 22, 11:34 a.m. |  Someone with a dart gun is stalking the wildlife of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx.

title: Tailgating Recipe: Balsamic Chicken
description: Picture the scene: Giants Stadium parking lot, circa 1992. Some libations are flowing, the grill is warming, serious tailgating preparations are under way. One of several cooks is searching through the cooler when it is determined that someone  name withheld to protect from more razzing  has forgotten the barbecue sauce.

title: Fast Food With a Local Twist in Williamsburg
description: THE artisanal revolution is apparently over in this corner of Brooklyn, a brief stretch of Havemeyer Street in Williamsburg where two fast-food joints, Blue Collar and Lake Trout, opened within a few doors of each other this past summer.

title: From India, Hoping to Find a U.S. College That Feels Right
description: Ive been spending the past few weeks narrowing down the list of colleges to which I will apply.

title: 36 Hours in Modena, Italy
description: WHAT did the tenor Luciano Pavarotti and the automobile company founder Enzo Ferrari have in common? For one thing, a hometown: the lovely city of Modena, 90 miles north of Florence, in the northern Italian region of Emilia-Romagna. But it was neither arias nor revving engines rumbling through Modenas cobblestone streets this spring, when a series of severe earthquakes struck the region. Fortunately, recovery has been steady, and today Modena is making noise with a new museum, a coterie of small boutiques, and a world-famous osteria, now with an affordable offshoot. In addition, visitors will find that the citys auspicious location  smack between Parma (of cheese and prosciutto fame) and Bologna (with its eponymous rag), each about a 45-minute drive away  foretells its many fine gustatory pleasures.

title: Food, Ferrari and Pavarotti
description: Sure, Modena, Italy, has some famous native sons. But theres far more to this citys story.

title: Understanding Romneynomics
description: Ive been delving a bit into what the Romney campaign and its economist fellow-travelers have been saying, and I think I have figured out the true economic doctrine Romney and his inner circle have in mind. It is, needless to say, not what the campaign has claimed.

title: Obamas Stump Speech Boils Down to One Word
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  With 19 days left before Americans go to the polls in a closely fought presidential campaign, President Obama is distilling his stump speech into the essential pitch of any political race: Vote.

title: Getty Institute Buys Knoedler Gallery Archive
description: Before the Knoedler Gallery closed its doors last year, and before it and its former president Ann Freedman were mired in lawsuits and accusations of selling fakes, the gallery on East 70th Street in Manhattan was considered among the most distinguished in the world.

title: Ancient Roman Artifact Is Seized by Italian Officials
description: ROME  Military police officers in the northern Italian city of Piacenza announced Thursday that they had recovered the head of a more than 2,000-year-old Roman statue that was very likely plundered from Italian soil.

title: When Wall Street Firms Change Risk Models
description: Morgan Stanley reported upbeat third-quarter earnings on Thursday. But its numbers provide a lesson in why its sometimes necessary to journey down rabbit holes to understand complex Wall Street firms.

title: Radios Star, Never Killed, May Lead the Way to New Frontiers
description: ITS easy to think about radio as a tragically consolidated, soon-to-be-doomed medium  to note how, in recent years, the airwaves have become overrun by barky, overcaffeinated D.J.s playing tiny, preprogrammed playlists. But radio, thankfully, is a broad and expansive thing, and this weekend its future (and past) iterations will be on display and up for debate at the Radiovision Festival, two days of talks, panels and performances about the future of noncommercial radio, online audio and digital online media.

title: Mapping the Path to Your Credit Report
description: Wonder how your credit report is created? Sometimes its best not to know how the sausage is made, but in this case some extra knowledge may be enlightening.

title: More Advice on Home Data Storage
description: In my Times column Thursday, I wrote about the Drobo, a consumer version of the RAID storage units that are popular in corporate IT departments.

title: Another Strike Against DOMA
description: A second federal appeals court ruled against the Defense of Marriage Act today, rejecting as unconstitutional the law that denies federal benefits to married same-sex couples.

title: During Renovations, a Team of Older Swimmers Is Left Without a Home
description: At 10 a.m. on Wednesday about a dozen older women gathered by the pool at the Hansborough Recreation Center in Harlem, dressed in sleek black racing suits and rubbery red swim caps.

title: From Readers, Devilishly Good Halloween Outings
description: An article by Stephanie Rosenbloom provides a list of destinations for people who long for that old haunted feeling this Halloween. So we asked you on Twitter to tell us about your own favorite Halloween journeys. A sampling of replies:[View the story Readers Recall Best Halloween Trips on Storify]

title: An Amendment Machine at Work
description: Wayne Wheelers Amazing Amendment Machine is a 20-foot-long, eight-foot-tall carnival-inspired contraption that traces how the temperance movement culminated in the 18th Amendment.

title: S.E.C. Settles Insider Trading Case Against Hong Kong Firm
description: Federal securities regulators settled an insider trading case on Thursday against an investment firm controlled by a prominent Hong Kong businessman.

title: Planter of the Seeds Of Mind-Expanding Conceptualism
description: Anyone who wants art to be more radical, anti-market and otherwise against the establishment should hasten to the Brooklyn Museum to see Materializing Six Years: Lucy R. Lippard and the Emergence of Conceptual Art. Traditionalists who bemoan the triumph of mind over matter brought to us by Bruce Nauman, Sol LeWitt, Adrian Piper and scores of others in the mid-to-late 1960s will also profit, for they will here become better acquainted with their enemy. Todays booming market for attractive objects notwithstanding, most of the ideas, values and fantasies that animated the conceptual turn half a century ago are still in play in the more intellectually fashionable circles of the art world.

title: G.M. Shows New Crossed-Flags Logo for Next Corvette
description: Though the official introduction of the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette, known in series as the C7, must wait until January for the Detroit auto show, at least one element of the sports car is a known quantity.

title: Springsteen Helps Obama Lure Blue-Collar Votes in Ohio
description: PARMA, Ohio  First, lets get to the point: He played six songs, starting with No Surrender, then weaving to The Promised Land, then a new one called Forward that he joked he came up with after President Obama telephoned him asking for a song to go with the campaigns Forward slogan.

title: With Tight Research Budgets, Is There Room for the Eternal Promise of Fusion?
description: Moving beyond the countrys, and the worlds, existing energy menu, which is still by far dominated by abundant and relatively cheap fossil fuels, is hard, whatever your preferred path.

title: On the Rocks: Benjamin Anastas Talks About Too Good to Be True
description: By 2001, Benjamin Anastas was in his early 30s and the author of two well-reviewed novels, An Underachievers Diary and The Faithful Narrative of a Pastors Disappearance. His new memoir, Too Good to Be True, details everything that went wrong after that, from deep financial troubles to the rupture of his marriage while his wife was pregnant with their son. In his review, Dwight Garner described the book as so plaintive and raw that most writers (and many readers) will finish it with heart palpitations. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Anastas discussed the taboo of money, his confidence as a writer, what hes tried to learn from Thomas Merton and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: App Snapshot: Some Democrats Seek Distance From Obama
description: Counterintuitive partisan relations are the theme of the day in some of the most competitive Senate races. In the Election 2012 app, were keeping up with all the developments in the presidential race, but were also checking in on the other contests:

title: CMJ: The Latest Playlists
description: Jon Pareles and Jon Caramanica, pop music critics for The Times, are sharing evolving Spotify playlists featuring tracks from some of the notable acts theyve seen at this weeks CMJ Music Marathon in New York.

title: Rare Video of Pakistani Talibans Radio Mullah, Blamed for Attack on Schoolgirl
description: As my colleague Declan Walsh reports, Pakistani security forces have detained relatives of a Taliban militant accused of shooting Malala Yousafzai, the 15-year-old schoolgirl who became an icon of resistance against Islamist fundamentalism in her native Swat Valley region.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.18
description: A view of the day in sports, which included a steeplechase race in Wincanton, England; cycling in Belgium; and surfing in Portugal.

title: Knights of Columbus Donate Millions to Anti-Gay Marriage Effort, Report Says
description: The Knights of Columbus are best known as a Roman Catholic fraternal and service organization that sells insurance policies to finance its charitable activities. The group provides coats for underprivileged children, prosthetics for Haitian earthquake victims and scholarships to Catholic colleges for the children of its members.

title: Still the Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Fancy Phrasing
description: To the Editor:

title: Most Trusted Adviser
description: To the Editor:

title: Left Evangelicals
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulls Offense Struggles Without Rose
description: For the Chicago Bulls - whose offense has struggled as the team has compiled a 2-2 record in the preseason - the return of Derrick Rose from torn anterior cruciate ligament cannot come soon enough. In their four games, the Bulls are averaging a mere 87.5 points, nearly 9 points fewer than last season. Theyre shooting only 38 percent from the field, including a woeful 21 percent from 3-point range. While some of this can be attributed to standard preseason sloppiness, its becoming clear - particularly in a much-improved Eastern Conference - that the prolonged recovery of Rose, the teams All-Star point guard, could spell trouble for Chicagos overall success, even more so than did his more sporadic absences a season ago.

title: NBC Pulls the Plug on Animal Practice
description: NBC announced Thursday that it was cancelling the new sitcom Animal Practice and replacing it on Wednesdays with the second-year sitcom Whitney.

title: Small Team With Enormous Heart
description: On paper, there was no way we should have won the Swedish Cup final, 2-1 after extra time on Oct. 11. But as we received our bouquets of flowers and took photos with the championship trophy, Marta, Vernica Boquete, Caroline Seger, and an entire host of star players on Tyreso sat empty-handed on the other side of the field.

title: Inside the Box
description: The most despairing image in Chris Wares magnificent new graphic novel, Building Stories  and there are plenty of candidates  depicts a dumpy middle-aged couple, naked in their bedroom. Shes just dropped her clothes to the floor; hes lying on the bed, oblivious to her, his face and chest illuminated by the iPad propped on his belly.

title: Microsofts Profit Falls as Sales of Personal Computers Shrink
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft is on the verge of releasing Windows 8, its biggest software product in years  and the companys lackluster financial results on Thursday underscored how badly the company needs it to succeed.

title: Syrian Forces Improvised Arms: Desperate Measures, or Deliberate Aid?
description: As the war in Syria escalated this year, fighters opposed to President Bashar al-Assad reached for arms from many sources, including weapons manufactured by their own hands: Molotov cocktails, roadside bombs and locally made mortars and rockets. These are the familiar tools of modern insurgencies  weapons of choice or necessity for fighters who begin conflicts with limited means.

title: Mystical Tai Chi Against a Giant Machine
description: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

title: Envelope, Please: Leobardo Espinoza Jr.
description: Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a student at Topeka High School in Kansas, no longer wants to be an anesthesiologist. The hospital is just too sad for me, he writes.

title: Obamas Election-Night Rally Will Be Indoors
description: After already losing one bet against the weather, President Obama is taking his election-night rally indoors.

title: Vintage Neon Signs and the Neon Museum in Las Vegas
description: Vintage neon signs no longer vanish without anyones noticing. Preservationists and curators have started monitoring and protecting them across the country, and scholars are documenting gas-infused glass tubes about to be scrapped.

title: Have You Thought About Soliciting a Yelp Review?
description: Lots of small-business owners have experienced frustrations dealing with sites that post consumer reviews. In case you have ever been tempted to deal with those frustrations by soliciting positive reviews, an article published Thursday in The New York Times contains a warning: Yelp is running a sting operation to try to catch businesses that dont play by their rules. The story explains:

title: Raging Hormones and Soul-Searching Conversations
description: Opens on Friday nationwide.

title: Newsweek to Adopt a Digital-Only Format
description: Business Day Live: Christine Haughney reports on Newsweeks announcement that it will cease print publication at the end of the year.

title: A Gorgeous Loner With a Long List of Enemies
description: Sam Hunter, the central character in the new Cinemax action drama Hunted, has quite a few enemies, but her most formidable one, Carrie Mathison, doesnt even turn up in the series.

title: American Presidents
description: A look at photographs in an exhibition at Federal Hall National Memorial.

title: The Envelope Please: Sush Krishnamoorthy
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student at Sardar Patel Vidyalaya, in New Delhi, writes that college Web sites do not help because all of them claim to have the best of everything.

title: Off-Camera Terrors on Hitchcocks Sets
description: Blondes make the best victims is a famous Alfred Hitchcock saying that introduces The Girl, an HBO movie on Saturday about that directors destructive obsession with one of the more enigmatic Hitchcock blondes.

title: A Computer Lesson Still Unlearned
description: It was just a quarter-century ago that Wall Street was shaken to its core by the Oct. 19, 1987, stock market crash.

title: Presenting Another Big Haul From Gun Seizures
description: There will be guns.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Greece, Syria, Gaza Strip and the Philippines.

title: Start Nears on Plan to Combat Online Infringement
description: Last year, five major Internet service providers and the big entertainment trade organizations announced a joint plan to fight illegal downloading through what might be called a strategy of annoyance. Instead of suing people suspected of copyright infringement, as the record labels have in the past, they would prod and poke people into good behavior through a six strikes system that escalate from friendly notices in their e-mail to, ultimately, throttled Internet access.

title: Same-Sex Marriage: What Both Halves Think
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Funny, but Plotting Havoc Isnt Easy
description: If all the would-be evildoers crawling the globe were as amusing and incompetent as the dizzy threesome from Modern Terrorism, a new play by Jon Kern that opened on Thursday at the Second Stage Theater, the world would be a pacific place indeed.

title: Springsteen Campaigns for Obama
description: Bruce Springsteen played six songs and gave a brief speech in support of President Obama.

title: Viewing Anti-Semitism From a Global Angle
description: Gloria Z. Greenfields documentary Unmasked Judeophobia is only 81 minutes long, but it feels like a marathon. A barrage of images (many lacking context) and a parade of commentators (dozens of scholars, political leaders, journalists and analysts) deliver a dire message: the escalation of threats against Jews worldwide is cause for alarm.

title: The Caucus Click: Springsteen Stumps for Obama
description: Related Article

title: Formula One Grand Prix in New Jersey Is Postponed Until 2014
description: Fans of Formula One who expected to witness open-wheel racing on the streets of Weehawken and West New York, N.J., will have to wait another year.

title: In Insider Trading Case, Drawing In David Ganek
description: Anthony Chiasson was unknown outside of Wall Street before his arrest in January on insider trading charges.

title: At 100, Pierrot Retains Its Power
description: Schoenbergs Pierrot Lunaire turned 100 on Tuesday, and the Proteus Ensemble and the mezzo-soprano Hai-Ting Chinn celebrated the occasion in a concert presented by the Five Boroughs Music Festival at the intimate Performing Garage in SoHo on Tuesday evening.

title: HELEN MIRANDA WILSON: New Paintings
description: Lori Bookstein

title: Wheelies: The Flight-Deck Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Bawling, Brawling and Boy-Crazy
description: Thats What She Said, an unpleasant comedy about friendship, aims to be a female twist on the bromance. Crude and knockabout, it nonetheless has  like many a bromance  a sloppy, sentimental heart.

title: Daniel Joseph Martinez: I Want to Go to Detroit: Cheerleaders Cheer
description: Simon Preston Gallery

title: International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show
description: Park Avenue Armory

title: James Welling : Overflow

description: White Box

title: The Steps of Michael Jacksons Bad
description: Celebrating the 25th anniversary of Michael Jacksons Bad album and subsequent world tour, Bad 25 reintroduces us to an artist viewed too often through the prism of tabloid speculation.

title: Gone Dry
description: Images from the exhibition American Spirits: The Rise and Fall of Prohibition at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia.

title: A Look at Prohibition, Hardly Dry
description: PHILADELPHIA  It has been a long time since anybody said: You know, the 18th Amendment was a pretty good idea. Too bad it was overturned by the 21st. And perhaps only the most prescriptively devout among us is likely to advocate banning the sale of alcohol again in the United States.

title: Sketches That Speak Their Lines Silently
description: This autumn New York is awash in master drawings. Last week the Morgan Library & Museum unveiled Drer to de Kooning: 100 Master Drawings From Munich, a show of loans from the Staatliche Graphische Sammlung. Not to be outdone, the Frick Collection has pulled in its own rare loans from Europe: Mantegna to Matisse: Master Drawings From the Courtauld Gallery, featuring 58 drawings from that London museum and institute of art history.

title: Theater Listings for Oct. 19-25
description: Theater

title: Writers, Musicians and More at Walls and Bridges
description: It has been a fortunate fall for Francophiles like the Miser. Before Crossing the Line, the monthlong arts festival organized by the French Institute Alliance Franaise, had even pulled up stakes, the city welcomed another Gallic gala, Walls and Bridges.

title: Comedy Listings for Oct. 19-25
description: Comedy

title: Standing Still, Saying Plenty
description: How high has anticipation been running for the Museum of Modern Arts fall atrium dance series, Some sweet day? Here is one indicator from Wednesday, the opening afternoon: viewers began staking out space for the nonticketed performance 40 minutes before it started, or a little more than twice the length of the actual program. The open space quickly filled up with restless bodies, with more crowds of people massing along the balconies from the surrounding floors.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 19-25
description: Movies

title: Womens Suffering Is a Messy Business in a Cello Opera
description: At the end of Robert Woodruff and Maya Beisers multimedia show Elsewhere, which had its premiere on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics new, intimate Fishman Space, the stage looked like the aftermath of a cataclysm. Framed by a row of disheveled hospital beds, the front half of the stage was covered with black gravel, strewed with once-white sheets that were now sodden with a gray, viscous substance. Among them lay the empty hull of a soft cello case fashioned out of the same gleaming plastic as a police body bag.

title: Pop Music Listings for Oct. 19-25
description: Pop

title: A Volatile Stew, Bubbling in the Anguish of Assimilation
description: Sunhwa Chung moved to the United States from South Korea in 1994, and in her newest dance, performed by her Ko-Ryo Dance Theater at Dance New Amsterdam on Wednesday evening, she explores ideas about cultural assimilation. How does one hold onto ones roots? What happens if you pull them out completely?

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 19-25
description: Jazz

title: The American Songbook, From Cole to, Yes, Cyndi
description: Woody Guthries This Land Is Your Land, Joni Mitchells Woodstock, Cyndi Laupers Girls Just Want to Have Fun: those songs, heard during the opening concert of the 23rd New York Cabaret Convention on Wednesday at the Rose Theater, Jazz at Lincoln Center, gave this annual convocation a reviving shot of adrenaline. In previous years they would never have been performed at an event dictated by the spirits of Cole Porter and Nol Coward and steeped in urbane 1950s nostalgia.

description: Classical

description: Art

title: Vain Glorious | Get a Whiff of This Girl
description: Who: The performance artist Martynka Wawrzyniak.

title: Therapy at Its Most Touching
description: At the risk of sounding hyperbolic, I would like to nominate John Hawkes and Helen Hunt in The Sessions as the movie couple of the year. Their extraordinary connection while re-enacting the true story of a disabled, virginal 38-year-old writer and his sexual surrogate infuses the movie, written and directed by Ben Lewin, with a piercing depth of humanity and no small amount of humor.

title: Weighing the Factors in the Gupta Sentencing
description: The memos submitted by the government and defense lawyers for the former Goldman Sachs director Rajat K. Gupta present sharply contrasting positions regarding how the court should punish the highest corporate executive caught in the crackdown on insider trading.

title: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 19-25
description: THALIA KIDS BOOK CLUB: LEMONY SNICKET

title: Mourning an N.Y.U. Fixture Who Kept Fast-Paced Students and Drivers Alert
description: For years, students at New York University grew accustomed to seeing John Votta at his usual spot, where Washington Place meets Washington Square East in Greenwich Village.

title: 20 Autumn Wines for $20
description: Eric Asimov selects 20 great fall wines, all at the magical price point of $20, presented here in no particular order.

title: Leaves Go Red, but You Neednt
description: DRINK seasonally. Its a fundamental precept, and it makes as much sense intuitively as dressing seasonally or carrying an umbrella on a cloudy day.

title: Trading Wig and Floppy Dress for a Badge
description: The Wikipedia entry for James Pattersons fictional character Alex Cross includes this nugget of understatement: Alex has had bad luck with women. Thats for sure, as anyone knows whos seen the films Kiss the Girls and Along Came a Spider, with Morgan Freeman as Cross, the brainy police psychologist whos either chasing down killers of women or women who kill. Women are something of an endangered sex in Alex Cross: one, half-dressed in black lingerie, dies after all her fingers are methodically snipped off. Another is similarly tortured to death; a third is shot straight through the chest. Wheres Madea when you need her?

title: Spare Times for Oct. 19-25
description: Around Town

title: End Is Nigh for Certain Tax Exemptions
description: JUST as beleaguered borrowers are beginning to feel some relief from a $25 billion deal requiring the nations biggest banks to forgive more mortgage debt, another financial threat looms.

title: Filmmakers Who Are Ultra-Orthodox and Ultracommitted
description: TEL AVIV

title: Aging Pipeline Poses Threat to Great Lakes, Report Says
description: A report released on Thursday by the National Wildlife Federation questions the safety of a network of oil pipelines operated by Enbridge that run through the Great Lakes region.

title: Obama Addresses Libya Attack in Daily Show Interview
description: President Obama on Thursday acknowledged screw-ups in the governments handling of the deadly attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, and vowed an investigation that would fix them.

title: Gallup vs. the World
description: Our regularly scheduled forecast update for Wednesday slipped through the cracks. The FiveThirtyEight forecast was not much changed based on Wednesdays polls, however, with Barack Obamas chances of winning the Electoral College increasing incrementally to 65.7 percent from 64.8 percent.

title: Faces of the Crash
description: On Oct. 19, 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 23 percent of its value.

title: A Rare Injury, Except for Footballs Big Men
description: As soon as Bertrand Berry saw the replay of Ray Lewiss final tackle last Sunday  made with Lewiss left arm, as his right hung at his side  he knew exactly what was wrong.

title: This Weeks Movies | October 19, 2012
description: The New York Times critics on Alex Cross, The Sessions and Brooklyn Castle.

title: In San Francisco, High-Rises by the Bay
description: San Francisco

title: The Daily Show With Nate Silver
description: For the first time in a long time  and most likely the last time until the election  FiveThirtyEight failed to publish an update Wednesday. But we had a good excuse: FiveThirtyEights own Nate Silver was the featured guest on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart to talk about his new book, The Signal and the Noise. (Apologies to President Obama, who is going on the show Thursday night and has to follow Nate.)

title: The Game Is All-Consuming, at Least Until the Outside World Intrudes
description: The child chess champions in the irresistible documentary Brooklyn Castle dont take long, as one of these sweetpeas likes to say, to crush you. Year after year, these big brains and little bodies at Intermediate School 318 in Williamsburg win chess tournaments, and their winning streak continues on screen. They are a remarkable, funny, inspiring, at times devastating group. Through the eyes of the director Katie Dellamaggiore, you come to know these children, their teachers and parents as you witness their pulse-quickening matches and tears splashed on the family dining-room table. Theres smiling uplift here, but the road is seldom easy and sometimes brutal.

title: Romney Super PAC Makes $12 Million Ad Buy
description: The super PAC supporting Mitt Romney is making its most aggressive and expensive push yet in the advertising wars with a $12 million ad buy in nine states.

title: For Dell, Consolidation Is Innovation
description: Dell announced Thursday a combination server, data storage and networking device, Active System 800. Dell hopes the glossy black rack, fast and flashy, will fare well against similar products from Cisco, Hewlett-Packard, Oracle and I.B.M. While the market sorts out which company wins, take a minute to admire what this trend says about tech.

title: Keyboard Activists in the Online Universe
description: The activist newsreel outfits that sprang up with the protests of the 1960s sent back glimpses of crowds, police lines, campuses and streets abuzz. The documentary We Are Legion: The Story of the Hacktivists depicts a movement that began instead in that virtual place where so many of us spend our time: online.

title: The Fred Goat Building and a Vanderbilt Neighbor
description: Q In the 1950s we children said, Good night, Fred Goat, as we passed the turreted red-brick building on the corner of Dean Street and Third Avenue in Brooklyn. It had a painting of a goats head in a circle on the top, with the name Fred Goat. Do you have any information on the building? ...

title: On One Coin, a Swastika and a Star of David
description: Borne on the generational ripples of a painful history, Arnon Goldfingers The Flat is a true-life detective story that uncovers much more than the tangled roots of its makers family tree.

title: Hollywood Still Awaits Coroners Report on Tony Scotts Death
description: LOS ANGELES Theres still no sign of the Los Angeles County coroners report that might shed some light on the story behind the film director Tony Scotts suicidal plunge from the Vincent Thomas Bridge here on Aug. 19.

title: Obama Ahead in Polls of Wisconsin and Iowa
description: President Obama has significant leads over Mitt Romney in Iowa and Wisconsin, two critical battleground states that could serve as a firewall for the president against a late surge by his rival in other places, according to new NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist polls released Thursday evening.

title: Women Watch Women Who Want to Be Sexual
description: Substituting graphic imagery for solid research, the documentary Sexy Baby hopes to reach our minds by grabbing our eyeballs. But this scattershot investigation of the effects of Internet pornography on female behavior only ruffles the surface of a complex issue, one that demands a much larger sample than three white, educated women.

title: From India, Hoping to Find a U.S. College That Feels Right
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, from New Delhi, is part of a Choice class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her second post is below.  Tanya Abrams

title: Filling a Familys Tall Order
description: FOR four years, since shortly before their marriage, Kristina Frantz and Pierre Alexandre lived in a spacious three-bedroom duplex in a two-family house in Carroll Gardens.

title: Going Solo From a Family of Friends
description: Countless television and film dramas of young adulthood have primed us to wait for the other shoe to drop. But in the fly-on-the-wall talkfest La Vie au Ranch, as the 20-year-old Pamela parties, feuds with her absent boyfriend and hangs out with friends in a messy Paris apartment nicknamed le Ranch, it becomes clear that the director, Sophie Letourneur, will stand back to observe the flow of life while deeper changes occur below the surface.

title: Afghan Officials Spar Over 2014 Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Nearly two years before Afghanistans presidential election, a brewing dispute between President Hamid Karzai and Afghan lawmakers over the handling of voter fraud complaints is raising questions about whether a credible election can be held  and, by extension, future international support for the countrys financially ailing government.

title: Recalling a New Pitch and a Strange Death
description: As the hitter gripped his bat and the pitcher began his windup, the catchers voice rang out across the blades of Kelly green grass on Thursday morning under a baseball-perfect sky in Brooklyn.

title: Women Know: The Downward Dog Is Good for You
description: To those of us unschooled in its ancient lineage and myriad applications, yoga has always seemed like something we should really get around to doing. Yogawoman, directed by the sisters Kate Clere McIntyre and Saraswati Clere, presents a range of testimonials about this healthful practice, amid a mood of contentment and uplift (with a dash of downward dog). The films firm, warm embrace is a better fit for the already converted, particularly the many women who have adopted yoga.

title: Can Paper Compete in a Digital World?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Safety of Marine Mammals
description: To the Editor:

title: Easing Travel to Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighborhood Joint: Upi Jaya
description: The restaurant Upi Jaya in Elmhurst, Queens, is a kitchen to a scattered Indonesian community.

title: A Kitchen for Indonesians Far From Home
description: ON a recent Thursday afternoon, two men in suits, wearing badges from the Indonesian Consulate, pushed open the door of Upi Jaya, a restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens. The diplomats walked straight into the kitchen and ordered food for the president of Indonesia, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, and his delegation, who were in town for the United Nations General Assembly. The order filled an entire notebook page and included more than 50 portions of rendang daging, Indonesian-style brisket.

title: Repaying Student Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nuclear Research Facility
description: To the Editor:

title: Courtship, Wedding, Existential Whimsy
description: The delightfully playful, playfully imaginative Grand Amour was directed by Pierre Etaix, a filmmaker, illustrator, musician and clown whose major work and poetic melancholia has long been denied to filmgoers. Presented at the Cannes Film Festival in 1969, it popped up on the American repertory circuit but never received a theatrical run here. Legal woes kept it and his other key movies out of view for 20 years, but Mr. Etaix  who worked with Jacques Tati and drew the exquisite images of him on the posters for Mon Oncle  is back with a retrospective that opens on Friday at Film Forum in New York. These films will travel to other cities and be brought out on DVD by Criterion.

title: On Trail of Objectivity in an Unnatural Home
description: In Bestiaire, a cool, sometimes cruel, formally elegant nonfiction look at a Quebec safari park, theres a scene in which some people stop on an outdoor bridge next to a chimpanzee exhibition. The Canadian filmmaker Denis Ct holds the image for what feels like minutes, allowing you to watch a chimp just standing in this unnatural home away from home while park visitors barely give the animal a glance. For a few beats, the chimp gazes in the direction of the camera  toward it, Mr. Ct, you. Its a look that feels like Jaccuse!

title: Among the Snipers of Aleppo
description: Antakya, Turkey

title: Texas Judge, Siding With Cheerleaders, Allows Bible Verses on Banners at School Games
description: KOUNTZE, Tex.  A judge on Thursday gave a group of cheerleaders here a temporary victory in their fight to display Bible verses on banners at public school football games, allowing them to continue to use the signs for the rest of the season.

title: Break Up a Family? Why Not, Ive Got Nothing Better to Do
description: The sultry wild child who dominates Ry Russo-Youngs acutely acted Nobody Walks is a type of femme fatale more likely to be seen in French cinema than in American movies. When Martine (Olivia Thirlby), a 23-year-old experimental artist from New York with a Jean Seberg pixie haircut, locks eyes with a man she fancies, he is a goner.

title: Aging Isnt for Sissies in France, Either, Especially for Men
description: Its strange. We plan for everything. We insure our cars, our homes. We even insure our lives. But we dont give a thought to our final years.

title: Why the Wildfires Still Rage
description: Washington

title: My Handyman, With a French Accent
description: My Worst Nightmare half-jokingly endorses the macho fantasy that the only thing a chilly woman really needs to warm her up is a good you-know-what. Its ice queen, Agathe (Isabelle Huppert), a Parisian art gallery owner whose subzero refrigeration freezes everything in her proximity, makes Meryl Streeps Miranda Priestly from The Devil Wears Prada seem like an overheated oven.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: New Face for Senate Higher Education Panel
description: Since it was created in 2009, the Senate Higher Education Committee has been led by State Senator Judith Zaffirini, Democrat of Laredo. But this month, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst replaced the chairwoman with Senator Kel Seliger, Republican of Amarillo, because of his ability to work well with all members.

title: Filling the Budget Hole Lawmakers Dug in 2011
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Mexican Tomato Growers Offer New Trade Deal
description: Hoping to stave off a brewing trade war, Mexican tomato growers said on Thursday that they would agree to significant increases in the minimum price at which their products can enter the United States and to establish a system to bolster compliance and enforcement.

title: Untimely Slump Shared by Pair of Catchers
description: ST. LOUIS  If it is any consolation to Yankees fans, October cold streaks are not a New York-specific phenomenon. The two best hitting catchers in the National League during the regular season entered Game 4 of the N.L. Championship Series here on Thursday relatively quiet at the plate this postseason.

title: Caught Up in Voting, Ads Ask Consumers to Cast a Ballot
description: Each fall in even-numbered years, Madison Avenue loves to capitalize on the interest in Election Day by bedecking ads in red, white and blue and comparing the process of buying products to the political process.

title: 5 Seats on Security Council Filled
description: The United Nations General Assembly elected Argentina, Australia, Luxembourg, Rwanda and South Korea on Thursday to two-year terms as nonpermanent members of the 15-seat Security Council, the most powerful body of the 193-member organization. The new members replace Colombia, Germany, India, Portugal and South Africa when their terms expire Dec. 31. The other five nonpermanent members  Azerbaijan, Guatemala, Morocco, Pakistan and Togo  remain until the end of 2013. The five permanent members, which have veto power, are Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States.

title: Killings Derail Effort at Grass-Roots Governance in India
description: NOWPORA JAGIR, India  On the day he was killed, Mohammad Shafiq Teli was working on a new sewage drain, precisely the sort of unglamorous, if essential, project that village governance is supposed to provide. Except that, for more than three decades, there had been no local governments here in the villages of Kashmir, Indias tinderbox.

title: South Korea: Professor Acquitted in Obscenity Case
description: A law professor indicted on charges that he posted a series of photographs showing a mans genitals on his Internet blog was acquitted on Thursday. The professor, Park Kyung-sin of Korea University, was charged in February with violating the countrys online obscenity law. At the time, he was a commissioner of the Korea Communications Standards Commission, a government agency with an authority to delete Internet content it considered harmful. When the commission found the photos on a blog last year and discussed whether to remove them, Mr. Park, who was appointed by opposition lawmakers, suggested that they be allowed to stay on the blog, but perhaps with a warning rating. When the other commissioners, most of whom were appointed by President Lee Myung-bak and his governing party, overruled him and deleted the photos without giving their owner a chance to defend himself, Mr. Park posted the photos on his own blog, Censors Diary, and invited a debate of the commissions decision. In the first court ruling in July, he was fined $2,700 for violating the obscenity law. But an appeals court on Thursday reversed the ruling, acquitting Mr. Park. The court said Mr. Parks posting could not be ruled indecent because the photos should be viewed in the context of his attempt to criticize the governments regulations on online content.

title: N.H.L. Dismisses Counteroffers From Union
description: Prospects for a prompt end to the N.H.L. lockout all but vanished Thursday after Commissioner Gary Bettman dismissed a new players union proposal as a step backward.

title: Sunlight on Lobbying in Albany
description: Given all the scandals that have embarrassed Albany in recent years, the Legislatures approval of a new ethics law last year was mostly good news. There will be no more secrets, Gov. Andrew Cuomo crowed as lawmakers were agreeing on the final bill. The governor boasted that New Yorkers, at last, would finally know whether lawmakers were working for the voters or the lobbyists.

title: An HPV Vaccine Myth Debunked
description: One of the most preposterous arguments raised by religious and social conservatives against administering a vaccine to girls to protect them from human papillomavirus, or HPV, has been that it might encourage them to become promiscuous. That notion has now been thoroughly repudiated by a study published on Monday in Pediatrics, a journal of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

title: Another Defeat for the Defense of Marriage Act
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on Thursday became the second federal appellate court in the nation to rule that the Defense of Marriage Act violates equal protection by barring same-sex couples legally married under state law from receiving the federal benefits available to heterosexual couples.

title: Misplays in the Field Cost the Yankees
The Other Missing Man
description: The great mystery of the first presidential debate was what happened to the Barack Obama a slim majority of the country was poised to rehire for another four years. That man  forward-looking, crisp-thinking, quick on his feet  was never on the stage in Denver two weeks ago.

title: On These Soccer Fields, a Brief Respite from the Killing Fields
description: MEXICO CITY  When Ana Aguirre stepped onto the soccer field in the main plaza here, wearing her green Mexican uniform, and scored goals against teams from Brazil and the United States, her life back in Ciudad Jurez seemed to have been vacuumed from the scene.

title: History of Filipino Labor Leader Resides in Shadows
description: Larry Itliong was a Filipino labor leader whose pivotal role in the farm labor movement has gone largely unrecognized.

title: Forgotten Hero of Labor Fight; His Sons Lonely Quest
description: DELANO, Calif.  It is the obscurity of his fathers grave, not far from the once-tumultuous grape fields where farmworker history was made, that most troubles Johnny Itliong, a chef from Los Angeles.

title: A Respite From Violence
description: At the Homeless World Cup, young people were able to turn to soccer to escape the drug violence plaguing Mexico.

title: Cornell President to Lead Horse Racing Board
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo appointed David Skorton, president of Cornell University, as chairman of the New York Racing Association Reorganization Board on Thursday, completing his takeover of horse racing in the hope of ending decades of scandal and mismanagement in an industry important to the state.

title: The Issue That Goes Ignored
description: It took an ordinary citizen, Nina Gonzalez, to stand up at the presidential debate on Tuesday to raise what has been a phantom issue on the campaign trail: the lack of effective gun controls and any meaningful political discussion about this crisis. Every year, more than 30,000 people are shot and killed in this country.

title: Seizure of Ship From Argentina Forces Shake-Up
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentinas military intelligence director resigned Thursday, the latest casualty in a dispute between Argentina and an American hedge fund over ownership of an Argentine Navy training vessel that is impounded at a port in West Africa.

title: Stanford R. Ovshinsky Dies at 89, a Self-Taught Maverick in Electronics
description: Stanford R. Ovshinsky, an iconoclastic, largely self-taught and commercially successful scientist who invented the nickel-metal hydride battery and contributed to the development of a host of devices, including solar energy panels, flat-panel displays and rewritable compact discs, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 89.

title: Tigers Sweep Ends Yankees Punchless Postseason
description: DETROIT  Four-game sweep. Its been a while since the Yankees were on the embarrassing lower end of that particular postseason seesaw.

title: A Financier in Chief
description: Mitt Romney stakes his claim to being a better job creator than President Obama largely on his success andexperience in the private sector. After the first two presidential debates, voters say that they trust him more than the president on the economy and jobs, but it isnt because Romney has talked much about what Bain Capital actually does.

title: Suspect in Libya Attack, in Plain Sight, Scoffs at U.S.
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Witnesses and the authorities have called Ahmed Abu Khattala one of the ringleaders of the Sept. 11 attack on the American diplomatic mission here. But just days after President Obama reasserted his vow to bring those responsible to justice, Mr. Abu Khattala spent two leisurely hours on Thursday evening at a crowded luxury hotel, sipping a strawberry frappe on a patio and scoffing at the threats coming from the American and Libyan governments.

title: Clearwire Is Sought by Sprint for Spectrum
description: Sprint Nextel has moved to protect one of its most valuable assets  access to a big chunk of spectrum  just as it is preparing to become a more aggressive force in wireless, with the backing of SoftBank of Japan.

description: DETROIT  When it mattered most, $200 million could barely buy a hit.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Second Suspect in Bomb Plot Against Bank

She is corrupt, Mr. Shelton alleged; he is an ideologue, Ms. Davis asserted before a rapt audience.

title: At Drivers Trial, Bus Rider Recounts Losing Arms

I got my first ride in a Prius from a conservative foreign policy hawk who said that these new technologies were going to help us end our dependence on Middle Eastern despots. Youd go to Silicon Valley and all the venture capitalists, it seemed, were rushing into clean tech.

title: Campaigns See Latino Voters as Deciders in 3 Key States

In Colorado, supporters of Mitt Romney are recruiting Latino owners of small businesses to reach out to other business owners whom they view as particularly receptive to the Republican economic message.

title: Purple Territory
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Now, this is a Friday puzzle. Crunchy, twisty, chewy  use whatever adjectives you like to describe it (within standards, of course) but this is a spanking clean, innovative grid with tough clues that need to be wrestled to the ground. This is what we wait for so patiently each week.

title: Stoudemire to Test His New Inside Moves
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The speed of the game will be faster than the speed of practice. The resistance from an actual defender should be stronger than that of a teammate. And after an off-season of working in the paint, Amare Stoudemire will have the opportunity to test his footwork.

title: Bloomberg Honored Letter, but Not Spirit, of Campaign Finance Law, Board Finds
description: On the eve of the 2009 mayoral election, Michael R. Bloomberg wrote two checks, totaling $1.2 million, to the states Independence Party. Even though the citys campaign finance board had declared that personal contributions to political committees would soon have to be disclosed, the Bloomberg campaign opted not to report those payments, which only became public months later, when the campaign was over.

title: Star Commentator Is Out as Christian College President After Scandal
description: While attending a conference last month, the president of the Kings College was spotted in the company of a woman other than his wife. At a typical institution of higher learning, a sighting like that might not have turned into a major controversy.

title: Democrats Use Health Law to Assail Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  A little-noticed provision of the new health care law is causing big headaches for some members of Congress in this years elections. And it is likely to cause even bigger headaches for lawmakers next year.

title: For a Game, Spurrier Will Oppose His Gators
description: Will Muschamps youth was wrapped in orange and blue. He would routinely make the short trek from his home to Floridas Ben Hill Griffin Stadium, dreaming of playing football for his hometown Gators. Even after walking on at Georgia and playing his college football there, he always kept a keen eye on his first love.

title: Drilling Payments Cause a Dispute in Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA  Four Pennsylvania townships are challenging a state regulators decision to withhold their share of proceeds from a statewide levy on drilling by the booming natural gas industry there.
