description: FRONT PAGE

title: Race Tightens in Divided District
description: SAN ANTONIO  Texas Republicans are used to playing offense  and winning  but this November in the sprawling 23rd Congressional District, they have a fight on their hands.

title: Sierra Club Fight Over Radioactive Waste Heats Up
description: ANDREWS  Rose Gardner inflated balloons for her grandsons birthday party recently at her floral shop in Eunice, N.M., and talked about nuclear waste.

title: Governors Chief Aide Misunderstands Plans for 2014, Helpfully
description: Dont try to hang an oops on Ken Armbrister.

title: An Austin Childrens Writer Revisits the Willows
description: When the Austin writer Jacqueline Kellys first novel, The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate, was published in 2009, it drew the sort of response every first-time author hopes for: positive reviews from Publishers Weekly and The New Yorker and an honorable mention from the Newbery Medal Selection Committee.

title: Ethel Person, Who Studied Sexual Fantasies, Dies at 77
description: Ethel Person, a Columbia University psychiatrist who did pioneering research on sexuality, visiting sex shops and drag dance clubs to help herself understand what motivates transsexuals and transvestites, and conducting broad-based clinical studies on the role of sexual fantasy in peoples lives, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77.

title: Lottery Numbers
With Tie, Red Bulls Clinch Spot in Playoffs
description: HARRISON, N.J.  It probably should not have been this hard. It should not have taken 31 games of the Major League Soccer season for the Red Bulls, the club with the leagues second-highest payroll, to clinch a postseason berth.

title: Oct. 14-Oct. 20: Rallying Voters
description: Every week during the 2012 presidential campaign, The Times will be posting a new slide show recapping the events of the past seven days.

title: Jennifer Kaufmann, Jesse Haladay
description: Jennifer Lauren Kaufmann and Jesse Alexander Haladay were married Saturday evening at the Fairmont Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Baht Yameem Weiss officiated.

title: Katherine Gregory, Matthew Graham
description: Katherine Anne Gregory and Matthew Robert Graham were married Saturday at SS. Agatha and James Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. James McGuinn, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Laurie Cedilnik, Glenn Shaheen
description: Laurie Ann Cedilnik and Glenn Christopher Shaheen were married Saturday at Villa Russo, an event space in Richmond Hill, Queens. Sean Brian Bishop, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Arielle Traub, Ethan Prosnit
description: Arielle Elissa Traub, a daughter of Ellen S. Lane of Westport, Conn., and Harry J. Traub of Weston, Conn., is to be married Sunday afternoon to Ethan Robert Bloch Prosnit, a son of Wendy B. Bloch and Rabbi James M. Prosnit of Fairfield, Conn. The grooms father is to officiate, with Rabbi Jonathan Prosnit, a brother of the groom, assisting at Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn.

title: Kristen Windmuller and Joseph Luna
description: Kristen Daisy Windmuller and Joseph Michael Luna are to be married Sunday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Annie Lawrence, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Main Street Pebble Beach in Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: Jessica Pack, Steven Olson
description: Jessica Bailey Pack and Steven Michael Olson were married Saturday at the Inn at Palmetto Bluff in Bluffton, S.C. The Rev. Alva R. Pack, a Southern Baptist minister and the brides brother, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Jacobs, Ilan Danan
description: Jennifer Anne Jacobs and Dr. Ilan Jacob Danan are to be married Sunday evening at the Rockleigh, an event space in Rockleigh, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Weiner is to officiate.

title: Anna Barranca, Kevin Burke
description: Anna Frances Barranca and Kevin Matthew Burke are to be married Sunday at the Church of St. Mary in Newburgh, N.Y. The Rev. William A. Scafidi, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Marisa Mendel, Joshua Abraham
description: Dr. Marisa Rory Mendel, the daughter of Ilene S. Mendel and Dr. Herbert E. Mendel of Fayetteville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening in Syracuse to Joshua Michael Abraham, a son of Harriet Sostman Abraham and Dr. Jerrold L. Abraham, also of Fayetteville. Rabbi Charles S. Sherman performed the ceremony at Temple Adath Yeshurun.

title: Elizabeth McGarr, Matt McCue
description: Elizabeth Nan McGarr and Matt McCue were married Saturday evening in Dallas. Judge Barbara M. G. Lynn of the Federal District Court for the Northern District of Texas, whose chambers are in Dallas, officiated at the Brook Hollow Golf Club.

title: Jessica DeLoach, Warwick Sabin
description: Jessica Xan DeLoach and Warwick Baron Reid Sabin were married Saturday evening at Moss Mountain Farm in Roland, Ark. Annabelle Imber Tuck, a retired state Supreme Court justice in Arkansas, officiated.

title: Morgan Weiner, Christopher Bellapianta
description: Morgan Blake Weiner and Christopher Michael Bellapianta were married Saturday evening at the Pearl River Hilton Hotel in Pearl River, N.Y. Rabbi Josh Cantor officiated, with the Rev. Paul Mayer, a former Roman Catholic priest who is now affiliated with the Federation of Christian Ministries, taking part.

title: Claire Hambrick, Christopher Simoglou
description: Claire Rzetelny Hambrick and Christopher Andrew Simoglou are to be married Sunday. The Rev. Panagiotis Lekkas is to perform the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, N.J., with the Rev. Christopher Foustoukos taking part in the ceremony.

title: Freya Bellin, Gregory Levow
description: Freya Ariel Bellin and Gregory Ian Levow were married Saturday at the New York City Fire Museum. Naomi L. Sage, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Erikka Walsh and Damir Makic
description: Erikka Walsh and Damir Makic are to be married Sunday evening at the Breakers Hotel in Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Andrew Fox, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

title: Nicholas Haddad, Thomas Ogletree
description: Nicholas William Haddad and Thomas Rimbey Ogletree were married Saturday by Mr. Ogletrees father, the Rev. Dr. Thomas W. Ogletree, a United Methodist minister. The ceremony took place at the Yale Club of New York.

title: Erin Ade, Rodrigo Real
description: Erin Michael Ade and Rodrigo Real were married Saturday at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Robert J. Bubel, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jill Wohrle, Brian Andrews
description: Jill Erin Wohrle and Brian Joseph Andrews were married Saturday in Washington. The Rev. W. Bruce McPherson performed the ceremony at St. Johns Episcopal Church in Georgetown, where he is the interim rector. The Rev. Mark F. Horak, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Leah Horowitz, Matthew Stuart
description: Leah Horowitz and Matthew Douglas Stuart are to be married Sunday evening at the Rouge Tomate, a restaurant in Manhattan. Acting State Supreme Justice Philip S. Straniere, the supervising judge for the New York City Civil Court on Staten Island, is to officiate.

title: Helaine Tabacoff and Adam Waldman
description: Helaine Sara Tabacoff and Dr. Adam Foster Waldman were married Saturday evening at the Ardsley Country Club in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Helene Ferris officiated with Rabbi Sandy Sasso assisting.

title: Sarah Bolt, David Crowell
description: Sarah Bolt and David John Crowell were married Saturday afternoon at St. John Nepomuk Church in St. Louis. The Rev. Ronald C. Chochol, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Benita Alexander-Noel, Edson Jeune
description: Benita Jane Alexander-Noel and Edson Ricardo Jeune were married Thursday on the Star of America, a 130-foot motor yacht, in the Hudson River. Frdric Havez, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Patricia Charman, William Wall
description: Patricia Hathorn Charman and William David Wall were married Saturday at the home of Byron Hathorn, the brides brother, in Ely, Vt. Kathleen Tomlinson, a United States magistrate judge for the Eastern District of New York in Central Islip, N.Y., officiated.

title: Yasmin Tabi, Jesse Levitt
description: Yasmin Tabi and Jesse Simon Levitt were married Saturday evening at the Deity Lounge, an event space in Brooklyn. Kenneth Mussman, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Sheli Reynolds, Zachary Faigen
description: Sheli Ann Reynolds and Zachary Marc Faigen were married Saturday evening at La Quinta Resort and Club in La Quinta, Calif. Rabbi Eric B. Wisnia officiated.

title: David Rogers and Daniel Ferrell
description: David Neil Rogers and Daniel Emmitt Ferrell were married Saturday at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass., on the Harvard University campus. Joseph N. Liberty, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate, performed the ceremony.

title: Margaret Choy and Joseph Merola
description: Dr. Margaret Choy and Dr. Joseph F. Merola were married Saturday at the Glen Manor House, an event space in Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Walter Kim, a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: Kathleen Shattuck, George Markov
description: Kathleen Elizabeth Shattuck, the daughter of Jennifer W. Budge of Carmel, Calif., and Mayo A. Shattuck III of Baltimore, was married Saturday to George Stillanov Markov, a son of Dr. Diana D. Markov and Stilian G. Markov of Sofia, Bulgaria. The Rev. Michael Marini, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Santa Catalina Rosary Chapel in Monterey, Calif.

title: Jane Biondi, Dax Munna
description: Jane Oughton Biondi and Dax Munna were married Saturday at the home of the brides parents in Edgartown, Mass. E. Leo Milonas, the retired chief administrative judge of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Emily Betson, Frank Balsamello
description: Emily Nora Betson and Frank James Balsamello were married Saturday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The Rev. Garry Koch, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: Abena Sanders and Alex Horton
description: Abena Patrice Sanders and Richard Alex Horton were married Saturday in Decatur, Ga. The Rev. Samuel J. Horowitz, a priest of the Anglican Church in North America, performed the ceremony at the Julia Thompson Smith Chapel at Agnes Scott College.

title: Sabrina Hyman, Aidan Flax-Clark
description: Sabrina Faye Hyman and Aidan Flax-Clark were married Saturday in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Cody R. Lindquist, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Universal Life Church to perform the ceremony, officiated.

title: Thomas Ryan, Thierry Chauvaud
description: Thomas Jay Ryan and Thierry Chauvaud were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator at the bureau, officiated.

title: Sujatha Murali, Anand Patel
description: Dr. Sujatha Murali and Dr. Anand Natvarlal Patel were married Friday in Las Vegas. Panditji Gopalakrishna Panchangam performed the ceremony at the Hindu Temple of Las Vegas.

title: Julia Palmer, Adam Wright
description: Julia Hunter Palmer and Adam John Wright were married Saturday in Boca Grande, Fla. The Rev. James R. Becherer, a retired Roman Catholic priest, led a nondenominational ceremony at the Gasparilla Inn and Club.

title: Margaret Rimsky, Benjamin Richards
description: Margaret Ellen Rimsky and Benjamin Charles Richards were married Saturday evening at the Harvard Club in New York. Rabbi Dan Ain officiated.

title: Sridhar Rao, Jason Bratcher
description: Sridhar Rao, the son of Anu Rao and B. Prithvidhar Rao of Mechanicsburg, Pa., was married Saturday to Dr. Jason Michael Bratcher, a son of Cheryl L. Bratcher and Ronnie D. Bratcher of Artesia, N.M. Alison Gerig, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Hotel on Rivington in New York. Earlier, Mr. Raos mother led a Hindu prayer.

title: Suzanne Skinner, Stephen Forster
description: Suzanne Kenny Skinner and Stephen Peter Forster were married Saturday at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. John C. Cregan, the churchs pastor.

title: Alexis Swift, Albert Sindall III
description: Alexis Lauren Judge Swift, the daughter of Nancy J. Swift and Robert F. Swift of Brick Township, N.J., was married Saturday to Albert Peter Sindall III, the son of Kathleen M. Sindall and Dr. Albert P. Sindall Jr. of Severna Park, Md. The Rev. Laurie Matarazzo, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N.J.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures, Oct. 14-20
description: A look back at the week in politics.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: GAVIN MCCARNEY The junior totaled 510 total yards and 5 touchdowns to power Colgate past Georgetown, 57-36. Colgate set a team record with 707 yards of total offense.

title: Maggots in the Pasta: Europe Screens Tainted Chinese Food
description: HONG KONG  Cypriot inspectors found arsenic in the frozen calamari. The Italians discovered maggots in the pasta. There were glass chips in the pumpkin seeds bound for Denmark, and Spanish regulators blocked a shipment of frozen duck meat because of forged papers. It has been a rough year for Chinese food exports to Europe.

title: Resting Several Starters, Knicks Have Little Time to Develop Chemistry
description: ALBANY  Knicks Coach Mike Woodson had conflicting thoughts.

title: Red Sox Hire Blue Jays Farrell as Their New Manager
description: The Red Sox have hired John Farrell as their new manager, according to a report on the teams Web site late Saturday.

title: CMJ: Onstage After a Comrades Loss
description: Every so often, even at CMJ, the real world imposes itself, as it did at Cameo Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, late Friday night. On stage was Pegasus Warning, whose frontman is the jazz drummer and sometime performance artist Guillermo E. Brown. The show, he said, was in memory of David S. Ware, a teacher and a mentor and an experimenter in sound. Mr. Ware, the widely admired free jazz saxophonist, died on Thursday.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: In a piece in Tehelka titled Moment of the Muckraker, Ashok Malik examines the role of activists like Arvind Kejriwal in Indian public life. Mr. Malik compares them to the so-called muckrakers who emerged in America a century ago, in response to the excesses of the Gilded Age  writers and activists who delivered caustic critiques of corrupt institutions and powerful people. Such attacks were loathed by the political leadership of the time, but the muckrakers served a purpose by keeping crony capitalism and graft in check. Mr. Malik poses a timely question: while the allegations made by Arvind Kejriwal and India Against Corruption in the past few months have shed light on various issues, have they served any lasting purpose?

title: Egyptian Abortion, American Choice
description: Most of our friends in Egypt had experienced some form of a pregnancy loss, and we knew this going in. Here, pesticide use is rumored to be responsible for the staggering number of miscarriages, birth defects and stillbirths. Still, when I became pregnant for the third time, during my husbands first tour with the State Department and our second year living in Cairo, I was thrilled. And when I reached the end of the first trimester, we believed that we had overcome whatever the odds were. I was confident as I lay next to the ultrasound machine. I was also alone. I had done this twice before and didnt think my husband needed to battle Cairo traffic to be there with me.

title: George McGovern Dies at 90, a Liberal Trounced but Never Silenced
description: George McGovern, the United States senator who won the Democratic Partys presidential nomination in 1972 as an opponent of the war in Vietnam and a champion of liberal causes, and who was then trounced by President Richard M. Nixon in the general election, died early Sunday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 90.

title: George McGovern Dies at 90
description: In a statement, President Obama called Mr. McGovern a champion for peace who was a statesman of great conscience and conviction.

title: Reinhart, Rogoff, and Latvia
description: OK, the recent Reinhart-Rogoff protest against gross misinterpretations of the facts on financial crises doesnt actually say anything about Latvia. But the points R-R make in taking on the US crisis denialists apply with equal force to the weird phenomenon of Baltic triumphalism.

title: Angry Lebanese Attempt to Storm Government Offices
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanons jittery composure throughout the long Syrian uprising wobbled but held on Sunday, as political and religious leaders quelled street protests that erupted after the emotional funeral of a security chief whose killing in a car bombing was widely blamed on the Syrian government.

title: Pope Canonizes 7 Saints, Including 2 Women With New York Ties
description: VATICAN CITY  Tens of thousands of faithful, some wearing feathered headdresses and beads, others in colorful Hawaiian shirts and leis, turned out Sunday as Pope Benedict XVI canonized seven saints, including the first American Indian one as well as a 19th-century nun who tended to patients with leprosy in Hawaii.

title: Louis C. K. to Host Saturday Night Live
description: He may not have succeeded in his quest to take over from David Letterman at CBSs Late Show, at least not in the fictional world of his FX comedy series, but in real life Louis C. K. has landed another highly coveted late-night television gig: he will be the host of Saturday Night Live on NBC on Nov. 3. Louis C. K., the pioneering standup comedian and writer, director and star of FXs Louie, will be joined by the pop-rock trio Fun. when he makes his hosting debut on S.N.L. This booking comes in the middle of a national standup tour that Louis C. K. embarked upon without the help of a third-party ticketing service, and it will follow a seven-night, 14-show stand at New York City Center starting Monday. While he infrequently acts outside of projects that he has written himself, Louis C. K. has made exceptions; he has appeared as a recurring character on NBCs Parks and Recreation and also has a role in an as-yet untitled Woody Allen movie. Saturday Night Live has a long tradition of featuring standup comedians as hosts, from its first episode in 1975, hosted by George Carlin, to more recent episodes hosted by Louis C. K.s sometime rival Dane Cook.

title: A Debate Partner Who Could Become Secretary of State
description: To prepare for his debates, the president tapped a Senate veteran who knew the other partys nominee well and could play the part with precision. By the end of their sessions, the president was seriously thinking about his debate practice partner for secretary of state.

title: Disruptions: A Tiny Camera for the Stratosphere
description: There have been two major milestones in narcissistic photography in the last century. The first was the invention of the self-timer, which Kodak began selling during World War I. The second came a few years ago, as teenagers stood at mirrors taking pictures of themselves with camera phones to share online.

title: The Lost World of George McGovern
description: GEORGE S. McGOVERN is, in some sense, the reason I exist. My parents met as radical community organizers in their early 20s, an idealistic honey-haired student at the University of California, Santa Cruz, and a scraggly wannabe farm boy from Brown University, knocking on doors for the now defunct Acorn.

title: George McGovern on Op-Ed
description: George S. McGovern, a former senator from South Dakota and the 1972 Democratic presidential nominee, wrote several Op-Eds over the years. Here is a sample of some of those articles.

title: The Moral Clarity of George McGovern
description: EVERYBODY noticed George S. McGoverns decency. Robert F. Kennedy called him the most decent man in the Senate. But during the 1972 presidential campaign, political pundits assumed that a man who was that nice could not possibly be the strong leader Americans required. Few predicted that he would still be standing after the early primaries.

title: Stumbling Upon a Little Diner in Elyria
description: Last week, The Times published a special presentation of Dan Barrys This Land column, centered around the town of Elyria, Ohio. The five-part multimedia series, with stories, photos, audio and video, ended Thursday. The Times staff photographer Nicole Bengiveno, who works with Mr. Barry on This Land columns, shot stills and video for this project, which was six months in the making. She spoke with James Estrin this week about her approach. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: Paranormal Activity 4 Leads Box Office
description: The Paranormal Activity horror series took a terrifying tumble over the weekend, as its fourth installment proved sharply less popular with North American ticket buyers than its franchise predecessor. Paranormal Activity 4 (Paramount) took in about $30.2 million, or 42 percent less than Paranormal Activity 3 managed over its first three days last year. Copycat movies, franchise fatigue and dismal reviews probably contributed to the result. Still, this movie only cost $5 million to make and took in an additional $26.5 million overseas, a stronger-than-expected tally.

title: Mondays Debate Puts Focus on Foreign Policy Clashes
description: When President Obama and Mitt Romney sit down Monday night for the last of their three debates, two things should be immediately evident: there should be no pacing the stage or candidates getting into each others space, and there should be no veering into arguments over taxes.

title: An Elite Obsession
description: David Dayen makes a very good point, which I missed: during the Hofstra debate, in which questions were posed by members of the public rather than the Beltway elite, there wasnt a single question about the deficit. Not one. The public really doesnt care.

title: Bloomberg Raises Socialism Label in Discussing Warren
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has just started a new super PAC, did not reserve his strong words to President Obama and Mitt Romney during his 40-minute interview with The New York Times on Friday. Speaking at the uptown headquarters of his private foundation, he also discussed the Massachusetts Democrat running for the Senate, Elizabeth Warren, in the context of communism, his support for the man she is seeking to unseat, Senator Scott P. Brown, a Republican, and a range of other issues.

title: At Technology High School, Goal Isnt to Finish in 4 Years
description: Flakes of green paint are peeling from the third-floor windowsills. Some desks are patched with tape, others etched with graffiti. The view across the street is of a row of boarded-up brownstones.

title: Looking in the Fridge and Finding Some Poetry
description: Take away this pudding, Winston Churchill reportedly said. It has no theme.

title: E. Donnall Thomas, Who Advanced Bone Marrow Transplants, Dies at 92
description: Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, who showed that it was possible to transplant bone marrow to save the lives of patients dying from blood cancer and other blood disorders, a discovery that earned him a Nobel Prize, died on Saturday in Seattle. He was 92.

title: Choosing a Flaky Morsel for Armageddon Brunch
description: Let it be said henceforth that a quiche is nothing to sneeze at. Oh, I know, youve always thought of quiches as silly cuisine, fit to be served only at that silliest of meals, brunch. How wrong you were. A quiche is a mighty thing, as powerful and blessed as womanhood itself.

title: Stoudemire Will Miss Start of Season With Knee Injury
description: SYRACUSE  Another knee injury will force Amare Stoudemire to miss the start of the regular season. The Knicks announced Sunday that Stoudemire had ruptured a popliteal cyst behind his left knee. It was unclear if Stoudemire was injured during the Knicks game against the Toronto Raptors on Friday, the only time he has played this preseason, or if his knee worsened over time.

title: A Lifetime of Regret, Born in a Moment
description: A Summer Day, the emotionally stark one-act by the Norwegian playwright Jon Fosse, may seem an odd vehicle for Karen Allen, an actress best known for her feisty film portrayals, most notably Marion Ravenwood in Raiders of the Lost Ark. Ms. Allens unnamed character in the play  which opens Thursday at the Cherry Lane Theater  revisits a painful afternoon, decades earlier, when her husband took a small boat into the bay near their isolated country house and never returned.

title: Another Kind of String Theory, Plinking Up Where Tiny Tim Left Off
description: What was the tipping point that touched off the ukuleles current vogue? For rockers, perhaps it was the Pearl Jam singer Eddie Vedders most recent solo album, Ukulele Songs, and its corresponding tour. The young virtuoso Jake Shimabukuro has surely made an impact among admirers of instrumental prowess. For indie-rock fans theres Arone Dyer of the gangly, effusive duo Buke and Gase; for the rest of the world, Zooey Deschanel.

title: Relative Rarities by Mozart, Solemn and Spirited
description: Leaving a concert at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Wednesday evening, I replied to a text message from a musician friend asking what had been on the program.

title: Report on Iran Talks Reverberates on Sunday Shows
description: Foreshadowing what could be fierce lines of argument in Mondays final presidential debate, spokesmen for the two candidates jousted on Sunday over whether the United States should seek to engage Iran in one-on-one talks over its nuclear program, or whether Tehran was simply playing for time.

title: A Football Draw for Romneys Staff and the Press
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.  Mitt Romney will be participating in his own political version of Monday Night Football when he faces off against President Obama in their final debate of the campaign cycle. But on Sunday morning, Mr. Romney took a break from debate preparation to make a stop at a gridiron of a different sort  a flag football beach face-off between members of the news media and members of Mr. Romneys staff.

title: Fresh Windows, but Wheres the Start Button?
description: Over the years, Keith McCarthy has become used to a certain way of doing things on his personal computers, which, like most others on the planet, have long run on Microsofts Windows software.

title: Moderator Keeps a Low Profile Before Final Debate
description: Before Candy Crowleys turn as the moderator of the second presidential debate, the veteran CNN political correspondent treated her coming role much like an actress would a new film release.

title: Shirtless Men Cloaked in Drama
description: An audience members brain could be forgiven, while weathering Thursday nights nearly three-hour Stars of the 21st Century ballet gala at the David H. Koch Theater, for certain paranoid flights of fancy. At some point, confronted by yet another instantly forgettable heterosexual melodrama of a duet, one might easily convince oneself that all these international luminaries were in fact performing the same dance. How else to explain the preponderance of shirtless men, bastardized classical themes, tepidly simulated sex, hyperextended legs and spotlights?

title: A Little Lascivious Music (Send in Attila the Hun)
description: Tucked into the saucy cabaret revue Vienna to Weimar, a survey of Austrian and German songs from operetta through the Weimar era at the Triad, is a guilty pleasure titled A Little Attila. Composed in 1922 by Rudolf Nelson and translated into English by Jeremy Lawrence, the song is a politically incorrect rape fantasy focused on Attila the Hun, whom the song describes as a cute little brute whos selfish and oblivious, lascivious and lewd. The narrator declares, I dont need a flotilla or a villa by the sea/but oh for a scintilla of some virility.

title: Manning Isnt at His Best Until Giants Need It Most
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants quarterback Eli Manning let go of the ball and was immediately buried, his body disappearing beneath a white Washington Redskins jersey like a child slipping under a sheet.

title: Three Killed in Shooting at Spa in Wisconsin
description: BROOKFIELD, Wis.  A gunman opened fire inside a day spa in this Milwaukee suburb on Sunday morning, killing three women, forcing others  some bloodied and still in bathrobes  to flee into nearby streets, and sending the authorities on a tense hunt that was slowed by fears of explosives and ended hours later with the discovery of the gunmans body.

title: Sleight of the Invisible Hand
description: Much has been made of Paul Ryans devotion to, and timely disavowal of, Ayn Rand and her work, but little has been said about the Scottish philosopher he and Mitt Romney have cited as the ideological embodiment of whats at stake in this election. I think Adam Smith was right, Romney affirmed in a January debate. And Im going to stand and defend capitalism across this country, throughout the campaign.

title: Illuminating Charpentier at the White Light Festival
description: Art, like life, provides few certainties, but a performance by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants featuring music of the French Baroque is as close to a sure thing as you can get. Mr. Christie, an American conductor, harpsichordist and scholar who has made a home in France since 1970, has long been a towering authority on music from the time of Louis XIV. With Les Arts Florissants, his extraordinary ensemble, he has helped to revitalize the reputations of worthy composers like Lully, Charpentier and Rameau.

title: NBC Finds Itself in Unfamiliar Territory: On Top
description: The television network landscape has an upside-down look this fall: NBC, last among younger viewers for a decade, is suddenly on top.

title: Glum Teenager Flies Pink-Painted Coop
description: Unwitting moviegoers who drop into Sassy Pants may be forgiven for wondering if they have accidentally stumbled into the kingdom of John Waters. Its low-rent Southern California setting may not be Baltimore, but the movies writer and director, Coley Sohn, has a similar fascination with the ethos associated with The Jerry Springer Show.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released will include new home sales for September (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, durable goods for September and pending home sales for September (Thursday); and third-quarter gross domestic product and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for October (Friday).

title: Maximizing Performers and History
description: The repertory for American Ballet Theaters recent weeklong season at New York City Center consisted of just seven performances, featuring six ballets, each by a different choreographer, and one pas de deux. (Or two if you include the pas de deux from James Kudelkas Cruel World, performed at the opening-night gala but, mercifully, not again.) The choreography spanned 70 years.

title: Lawsuits Claim Knoedler Made Huge Profits on Fakes
description: For more than a dozen years the Upper East Side gallery Knoedler & Company was substantially dependent on profits it made from selling a mysterious collection of artwork that is at the center of a federal forgery investigation, former clients of this former gallery have charged in court papers.

title: Gender Gap Near Historic Highs
description: 2:43 a.m. | Updated  If only women voted, President Obama would be on track for a landslide re-election, equaling or exceeding his margin of victory over John McCain in 2008. Mr. Obama would be an overwhelming favorite in Ohio, Florida, Virginia and most every other place that is conventionally considered a swing state. The only question would be whether he could forge ahead into traditionally red states, like Georgia, Montana and Arizona.

title: Sting Operative
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Did everyone enjoy the Sunday puzzle contest? Before we talk about todays puzzle, I just want to remind everyone to please remember not to post any spoilers about the puzzle, since the contest runs until 6 p.m. Tuesday. There will be a special contest-related post going live at 6:15 p.m. where you will be able to talk as you like about the puzzle and your experience solving it.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Red Bulls Playoff Possibilities
description: The Red Bulls Saturday night clinched a berth in the Eastern Conference playoffs in Major League Soccer.

title: Cacophonous Declarations of Independents
description: Bonanza and glut, harbinger and revival, party and business meeting, auditions and acclamations, a random sample of whats new: the CMJ Music Marathon is all of them at once. At the 31st annual CMJ, from Tuesday through Saturday, about 1,300 acts took their turns during official showcases  usually a set lasting half an hour or less  across Manhattan and Brooklyn. Many of them went on to play again and again through the festival, sometimes for hundreds of people, sometimes for barely a few dozen.

title: Cavendish Invitational Tournament in Monaco
description: One of the true arts of defensive play in bridge is helping your partner to avoid an error. Norberto Bocchi from Italy did exactly that in the diagramed deal from the Cavendish Teams in Monaco last week.

title: Leon Jaroff, Editor at Time and Discover Magazines, Dies at 85
description: Leon Jaroff, a science writer and editor who persuaded Time Inc. to start Discover magazine in 1980, became its top editor and for many years wrote the popular Skeptical Eye column challenging pseudosciences, died Saturday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 85.

title: U.S. and Iran Deny Plan for Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The question of whether the United States should seek to engage Iran in one-on-one talks on its nuclear program joined the likely topics for Mondays final presidential debate as supporters of President Obama and Mitt Romney jousted on Sunday over the issue.

title: A Revolutionary War General Escapes Historys Margins
description: Mention the Victor at Saratoga and people may think that you are talking about a horse. Yet that so-called victor, Gen. Horatio Gates, the commander of the American forces at the Battle of Saratoga, played a crucial role in the triumph there over the British forces of Gen. John Burgoyne in October 1777.

title: AMC Networks and Dish Reach Deal for Return of Channels
description: A suite of cable channels operated by AMC Networks is coming back on the Dish Network, ending a blackout of months that had affected millions of customers.

title: Sharpening the Message for the Final Push
description: In the closing days of the 2012 presidential campaign, President Obama and Mitt Romney are finding sharper, punchier ways to communicate their basic arguments.

title: CMJ Music Marathon
description: Scenes from concerts across Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Giants Ahmad Bradshaw Not Happy With Rough Day
description: A capsule look at the Giants 27-23 victory over Washington on Sunday:

title: American Ballet Theater
description: Photos of the company in performance.

title: A New Book Is Due From Elizabeth Strout
description: Random House announced on Sunday that it would publish a new work by Elizabeth Strout in March. The book, The Burgess Boys, will be her first since the 2008 release of her interconnected short-story collection, Olive Kitteridge, which won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction in 2009. In a news release the publisher said that Ms. Strouts novel would focus on two brothers in Brooklyn who are called back to Maine by their sister because of a family scandal.

title: Footnote
description: The Joyce Theater is to announce on Monday its lineup for the spring season. Highlights include Ice Hot: A Nordic Dance Festival with performances by Tero Saarinen Company, Danish Dance Theater and Carte Blanche (March 6 to 17); the New York premiere of A Bend in the River, performed by the Cambodian Khmer Arts Ensemble with choreography by Sophiline Cheam Shapiro (April 9 to 14); and Ballet v6.0, a festival designed to recognize dancers and choreographers who create work outside of larger, more traditional companies (Aug. 6 to 17).

title: Archer Daniels Offers $2.8 Billion for GrainCorp
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company has bid $2.76 billion for an Australian rival, GrainCorp, as it seeks to bulk up its global operations.

title: Playwright Challenges Racial Casting Practices
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Bruce Norris has called for a boycott in Germany of theater productions in which white actors are cast in roles explicitly written for black performers. In a letter addressed to fellow members of the Dramatists Guild, a trade association for writers, Mr. Norris condemned such casting, which he described as widespread in Germany.

title: Disney, Struggling to Find Its Digital Footing, Overhauls Disney.com
description: LOS ANGELES  Trying to finally master the Internet the way it has theme parks or animated films, the Walt Disney Company has redesigned its Web site, Disney.com, for the third time in five years.

title: Jordan Says 11 Plotted a Series of Attacks
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordanian officials said Sunday that they had foiled a major terrorist plot, arresting 11 people who they said had been planning since June to attack shopping malls and diplomatic targets in the country.

title: Getting to Know Windows 8

title: Two Campaigns Skirt Talk of Tough Choices in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. described the Obama administrations latest war strategy in deliberately stark terms in his debate with Representative Paul D. Ryan: We are leaving Afghanistan in 2014, period. Mr. Ryan did not dispute that deadline, but insisted on a little wiggle room, saying that Mitt Romney would consult with his generals about the timing and resources and conditions on the ground, to avoid imperiling Americas gains in a war that began in 2001.

title: A Sale Gives a Magazine on Healthy Eating a New Lease on Life
description: SHELBURNE, Vt.  Employees at Eating Well magazine sometimes dont quite believe their good fortune. Since the Meredith Corporation bought the magazine last year for $29 million, it moved out of the drafty warehouse offices it shared with curtain-climbing raccoons and a squirrel skilled at stealing bread loaves, and into a new $500,000 space with views of the Adirondacks and room to grow an edible garden. And the staff can now consult with Meredith editors at magazines like Every Day With Rachael Ray and Family Circle to brainstorm about test kitchens and effective covers.

title: Russian Forces Kill 49 Rebels in North Caucasus Strike
description: MOSCOW  Russias security services have killed 49 rebels and captured dozens more in a counterterrorism offensive that officials called a considerable blow to the insurgency in the North Caucasus region, the Russian National Anti-Terrorism Committee announced on Sunday.

description: The highest payroll in baseball did not help the Yankees in their failed bid to make the World Series. Charging as much as $58 to park has not helped the company that runs the parking lots around Yankee Stadium, either.

description: AL BIREH, West Bank  More than half the Palestinians who participated in municipal elections on Saturday said they did so because they saw voting as a civic duty, twice the portion giving the next most popular reason.

For the first time since negotiations began last summer, public opinion seemed to have shifted: many fans, who had been blaming Commissioner Gary Bettman and the owners for the impasse, started to blame Fehr and the players.

title: Patriots Have the Final Word in Overtime
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Jets afternoon at Gillette Stadium began just as their week did, with Rex Ryan opening his mouth. On his way out of the tunnel and onto the field, Ryan took a moment to bark at some New England fans. He might have been provoked, but leading up to Sunday he rarely was. Ryan is consumed by all things Patriots  their championships, their coach, their quarterback  and he relished reminding them that the Jets had beaten them three times in the last three seasons and, even more, that they would do so again.

description: KOUNTZE, Tex.  In a barrage of recent e-mails, telephone calls and letters to his office, Kevin Weldon has been called some of the worst things a Christian man in this predominantly Christian town can be called: un-Christian, and even anti-Christian.

description: NOT content to just hand out Skittles and escort trick-or-treaters, adults are celebrating Halloween themselves. This year, 36 percent of adults are planning to host or attend a Halloween party, up from 25 percent in 2005, according to the National Retail Federation.

title: The Secret of Our Non-Success
description: The U.S. economy finally seems to be recovering in earnest, with housing on the rebound and job creation outpacing growth in the working-age population. But the news is good, not great  it will still take years to restore full employment  and it has been a very long time coming. Why has the slump been so protracted?

title: Presidential Mitt
description: IN the closing weeks of debates, rallies and advertising, Mitt Romney has reinvented himself, or re-re-reinvented himself, as a technocrat with a heart. Gone from the stage is the ideologue he portrayed in his quest for the nomination. Some see the current rendering as the authentic Mitt. Others see a soulless opportunist. My own suspicion is that Romney has the instincts of a center-right pragmatist, but that if elected he will be hostage to the same far-right forces he kowtowed to in the primaries.

description: When the football team of Kountze High School in East Texas runs on the field for games this season, the players burst through banners carrying words from the Bible. To the schools cheerleaders, the banners are personal statements, sharing messages of inspiration. They say the banners are a form of free speech and religious expression protected by the Texas Constitution and Texas statutes.

title: The Oldest N.B.A. Rookie in 40 Years Is Actually a Seasoned Professional

Prigioni, in Spain, needed advice this summer  about the N.B.A., the Knicks and the United States  so he reached out to his friend Luis Scola to talk about a tough decision. Prigioni remembered that Scola faced a similar choice five years ago, and for Scola, the decision to join an N.B.A. team had been an easy one, because that was his dream.

title: At Kansas State, Team Goals and an Individual Honor Mesh
description: When Bill Snyder arrived at Kansas State in 1989, he brought his 16 Goals for Success. In 1998, at the height of his programs success, he would quiz his quarterback, Michael Bishop, at their weekly team meetings each Friday. Meticulous in his approach, Snyder would present Bishop, or any player for that matter, with a situation  for example, its third down, the defense is playing a Cover-3, and the cornerbacks are readying to jam the receivers at the line of scrimmage  and ask: What play do we call?

title: The Yellow Doc Raiders
description: In the small northern Arkansas town of Des Arc, dozens of local boys in the fall of 1862 came under the influence of a young Confederate recruiter named Howell A. Rayburn. His delicate physique and long tawny hair made him look innocent, like a child. But a streak of darkness lurked in his wild blue eyes, which, as one historian noted, seemed at times to have lost every vestige of tenderness, compassion and mercy, especially for those who differed with his views.

title: Service With a Smile
description: The Japanese company Arts & Science specializes in luxurious necessities without the frills: utilitarian tunics and work pants, Lodge cast-iron frying pans, Leather Master high-tech cleaning wipes. So when the companys owner and creative director, Sonya Park, noticed how much trash was accumulating from the staffs fast-food takeout lunches, she applied her no-nonsense aesthetic to opening a restaurant. Located underneath two of the Arts & Science shops in the Aoyama neighborhood of Tokyo, Down the Stairs (110 Palace Aoyama, 6-1-6 Minami Aoyama, Minato-ku) is both a staff canteen and a logical extension of the brand. Afternoon tea sets by the London designer Steve Harrison, lunch plates by Astier de Villatte of Paris and glassware by the Japanese artist Kazumi Tsuji complement noodles that are handmade by one employees uncle, paella from anothers favorite recipe, local eggs, Sekiguchi Bakery bread and hand-drip coffee. I wanted people to eat and fuss about their food as much as they do about what they wear, Park says.

title: Multifaceted

For more information, go to  lasvit.com.

title: BP Strikes a Deal in Russia
description: BP REACHES DEAL WITH ROSNEFT | BP announced on Monday that it had reached a deal with Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, to sell its 50 percent stake in the Russian joint venture TNK-BP. Under the agreement, BP would receive Rosneft shares and $17.1 billion in cash, and would ultimately hold a 19.75 percent stake in Rosneft. BP said it expected to gain two seats on Rosnefts board.

title: At a Church Downtown, Two Revolutions Intersect
description: Descendants of an old American revolution crossed paths on Sunday with some people who fancy themselves as progenitors of a new one. The first revolution was fought long ago by men who took up arms. This latest one, if it can even be called a revolution without distorting the meaning of that word beyond recognition, is conducted by men and women who take up sidewalk space.

title: Four Legs Very, Very Good: Andy Serkis Plans Motion-Capture Animal Farm
description: Having portrayed such memorable motion-capture creatures as Caesar, the rebellious chimpanzee of Rise of the Planet of the Apes; the titular primate in Peter Jacksons remake of King Kong; and whatever the heck Gollum is in the Lord of the Rings movies, Andy Serkis is continuing to add to his onscreen menagerie. His performance-capture studio, called the Imaginarium, said that it has acquired the rights to George Orwells parable Animal Farm for a film that Mr. Serkis will direct and act in; he will also produce the film with the studios co-founder, Jonathan Cavendish.

title: Daily Report: Windows Makeover May Cause Head-Scratching
description: Microsoft Windows, which has more than a billion users around the world, is getting a radical makeover, a rare move for a product with such vast reach, Nick Wingfield reports in The New York Times. The new design is likely to cause some head-scratching for those who buy the latest machines when Windows 8 goes on sale this Friday.

title: Better Schooling for More, Sure, but at Whose Expense?
description: The historic buildings and immaculate green lawns of Britains elite private high schools may feel a world away from Londons gritty Underground. But 23 top institutions have been using advertisements on the citys subway system to alert commuters that financial aid is available to gifted students from less privileged families, D.D. Guttenplan writes from London.

It was cordoned off, as it had been for two days; several police buses were parked nearby  down from dozens earlier in the day. Clumps of people crowded at two large white tents. The stage at one end of the square was lit but empty. 1980s music popular with the protest crowd continued to blare.

title: Q&A: Back to the Future With Environmental Bipartisanship

Its purpose, like that of some earlier alliances, is to counter the political polarization that now characterizes most debates about clean air, clean water, habitats for plants and animals and, in particular, climate change.

title: Breakfast Meeting: The Poetry of Print
description: Newsweeks impending demise in print  it will live on in digital editions only beginning in January  is a reminder that sometimes instincts and timing are crucial in the magazine world, David Carr writes in his Media Equation column in The Times. Felix Dennis, the British magazine owner, has had impeccable timing, selling his publications at the height of their value, and his success has made him determined to prove there is still some life in print.

title: Things That Arent Bubbles
description: Noah Smith, who is a better human being than I am, wades through an anti-Krugman rant to find an interesting nugget: the claim that money is a bubble. It isnt, of course; but my explanation of why it isnt is a bit different from his, and has wider implications.

title: Former U.S. Attorney Joins Skadden
description: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who as the United States attorney in Chicago oversaw the prosecutions of two Illinois governors and a former Bush administration White House aide, I. Lewis Libby Jr., is joining Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: Indias Common Man Activist on Tireless Publicity Campaign
description: A roadside sit-in protest of a few hundred electric company workers with labor complaints wouldnt normally be enough to attract Indias national television stations and newspapers.

title: Steering Issues Prompt Recall of Nissan Altimas and Investigation of Hyundai Santa Fe
description: 11:24 a.m. | Updated

title: Bidding Farewell to a Citys Precious Stone
description: Brownstones occupy a unique place in the New York City psyche, as one of the citys most prototypical signposts, like yellow cabs and fast walkers, yet are able to stir aching desire and teeth-baring jealousy. Everybody wants one.

title: Get a Grip on These
description: Jessica Ahnert Davis, a designer and blogger, has introduced a small line of cabinet hardware in brass and acrylic that features more angles than curves.

title: In Istanbul, Li Forestalls Thoughts of Future
description: ISTANBUL  Li Na, the 2011 French Open champion, was the last of the eight players to qualify for the WTA Championships, securing her spot in October when she made the semifinals of the China Open in Beijing.

title: Toyota Industries to Buy Cascade for $759 Million
description: The Japanese auto parts maker Toyota Industries said on Monday that it planned to buy the Cascade Corporation for $759 million in cash as part of an effort to expand globally.

title: A Final Push
description: Business Day Live: A foreign policy debate through an economic lens. | Microsoft hopes Windows 8 will bolster the PC market. | The Weather Channel seeks reinvention as a multimedia enterprise.

title: Can The Electoral College Survive?
description: As the prospect of a replay of 2000s electoral/popular vote split looms up before us, National Reviews Dan Foster arguesthat conservatives should resist the temptation to join the electoral colleges critics in the event that a Romney popular-vote victory still leaves the Republican nominee a few electoral votes short.

title: My AdWords Debacle: Dumb and Happy
description: Im going to tell you a story. Its a narrative that is built around a set of facts and events that happened over the last six months. I am starting with this explanation because, in the end, the problem I confronted was how to understand what was going on. And Im still not certain that I really know what happened.

title: Erranis Surprise Season Lifts Career
description: ISTANBUL  Though diminutive by tennis standards, the 5-foot-5 Sara Errani of Italy is clearly the biggest surprise in the field of the WTA Championships, an elite season-ending tournament restricted to only the top eight women players of the year.

title: Pump Boys and Dinettes Returning to Broadway
description: The 1980s musical Pump Boys and Dinettes will return to Broadway next spring in a new production featuring direction and musical staging by John Doyle (Sweeney Todd), the producers said on Monday. The new production is conceived and written by the original team of John Foley, Mark Hardwick, Debra Monk, Cass Morgan, John Schimmel and Jim Wann. A theater will be announced later, as will dates and casting.

title: Russell Means, Who Clashed With Law as He Fought for Indians, Is Dead at 72
description: Russell C. Means, the charismatic Oglala Sioux who helped revive the warrior image of the American Indian in the 1970s with guerrilla-tactic protests that called attention to the nations history of injustices against its indigenous peoples, died on Monday at his ranch in Porcupine, S.D., on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. He was 72.

title: Street Style: Dressed Up Sweats
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Oct. 15.

title: Kvitova Aims to End Season on the Rise Again
description: ISTANBUL  Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic broke onto the top level of the WTA Tour in a big way in 2011, rising from outside the top 30 at the beginning of the year to a career-high ranking of No. 2. She won at Wimbledon, Madrid, Brisbane, Paris, and Linz, as well as the WTA Championships, where she will be defending champion this week.

title: Where to Go to See Stolen Art
description: PARIS  When a valuable painting is stolen it leaves scars that can linger for generations. The financial loss is searing, but the theft of a painting also takes an emotional toll on the victims of plunder, holding them in its grip, creating obsessions.

title: Now Measuring | Indochinos Traveling Tailor
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Kerber Hopes to Close Out Long, Successful Year
description: ISTANBUL  Angelique Kerber of Germany has come out of nowhere to reach her No. 5 ranking, racking up a lot of mileage and vaulting her into her first WTA Championships.

title: Springsteen to Give Free Concert in Virginia to Support Obama
description: Bruce Springsteen announced on Sunday that he is taking his support of President Obama to a new level: he will give a free concert on Tuesday in the swing state of Virginia as part of a get-out-the-vote campaign.

title: Business Day Live: Economics of the Foreign Policy Debate
description: A foreign policy debate through an economic lens. | Microsoft hopes Windows 8 will bolster the PC market. | The Weather Channel seeks reinvention as a multimedia enterprise.

title: CMJ: The Final Playlists
description: The 31st annual CMJ Music Marathon wrapped up in New York over the weekend. More than 1,300 acts from all over the globe performed in Manhattan and Brooklyn during the festival.

title: Call It an Uncertainty Fund, Not an Emergency Fund
On Our Radar: Vast Ivory Cache Reaches Hong Kong
description: Customs officials in Hong Kong confiscate over 1,200 pieces of elephant tusk smuggled in from Tanzania and Kenya, one of the largest ivory seizures ever in the region. [Phys.org]

title: Image of the Day: Oct. 22
A Different Team When Facing Elimination
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Winner take all. Do or die. Lose and go home. For all the marbles.

title: Oct. 21: Uncertainty Clouds Polling, but Obama Remains Electoral College Favorite
description: The bad news for President Obama: its been almost a week since the second presidential debate, in Hempstead, N.Y., one that instant-reaction polls said was a narrow victory for him. But there is little sign that this has translated into a bounce for Mr. Obama in his head-to-head polls against Mitt Romney. Instead, the presidential race may have settled into a period of relative stability.

title: Long-Distance Lobsters
description: Q. Do lobsters have lungs? If not, how do they survive the long drive from Maine perched on a pile of seaweed in the cooler?

title: Another Game 7 Opportunity for Beltran
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Its a rainy day in late October and the home team, fresh from defeating the St. Louis Cardinals and their ace, Chris Carpenter, in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series, is one victory from a World Series berth opposite the Detroit Tigers.

title: Whole-Grain Pancakes: Not Just for Breakfast Anymore
description: In many households, pancakes are a treat saved for the weekend, when theres time for a leisurely breakfast. But for years Ive been making large batches of whole-wheat buttermilk pancakes every few weeks, freezing them in packets of three or four and thawing them on school days for my sons breakfast. It takes five minutes to pull them from the freezer, thaw them in the microwave and warm some pure maple syrup  not as quick as a bowl of cereal, but easy.

title: Martin Gardner: The Two Child Problem
description: This week we continue to celebrate the life of recreational mathematician Martin Gardner, who would have been 98 on Sunday, Oct. 21. This weeks puzzle is one of my favorites from Mr. Gardner. The puzzle is seemingly simple, slightly ambiguous and astonishingly difficult. Stanford faculty member Nick McKeown puts it well: We humans just havent evolved to solve this kind of problem.

title: With Subtlety Rather than Power, Radwanska Tries to Hold her Own
description: ISTANBUL  With her subtle style of filleting opponents with chips and slices, fourth-ranked Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland wounds her opponents with the tennis equivalent of paper cuts, a far cry from the bruising marks preferred by more percussive opponents. Radwanskas deft swordsmanship has proven incredibly effective in 2012, winning titles in Dubai and Miami and reaching the final of Wimbledon  her first appearance in the last stage of a Grand Slam.

title: In Elimination Games, Fans Win
description: Baseball has spent its off-season perfecting the art of the elimination game: rolling out the one-game wild-card free-for-all, having all four of its division series go the full five-game distance, and now standing back and admiring its work as the National League Championship Series barrels to a Game 7 Monday night. It offers the we-do-elimination-games-for-fun Giants and the spunky Cardinals doing their best Monty Python lines (Were not dead yet!) and putting on a spectacle for all to see.

title: Finding Zen in a Patch of Nature
description: SEWANEE, Tenn.  It is afternoon in a hardwood forest on the edge of the Cumberland Plateau, and the cicadas are singing.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Voting on Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Debate Rise of China; China Debates Reform
description: Monday nights presidential debate will include a 10-minute segment on the rise of China and tomorrows world. Expect harsh word from Mitt Romney about trade practices, the value of the renminbi , Chinese financing of the deficit and the need to increase military spending to strengthen the pivot to Asia.

title: An Unseen Force Looms Large Over the Race
description: He does not speak on the stump or appear in television ads. Campaign audiences rarely hear his name.

title: Serena Williamss Return to Dominance Took a Toll
description: ISTANBUL  Not all of Serena Williamss recent layoff was planned  she got sick at the Beijing Open in late September and withdrew  but its hard to argue it wasnt well-earned.

title: Rotterdam Museum Says Deactivated Lock Helped Thieves
description: PARIS  The Kunsthal museum in Rotterdam, facing strong criticism over its security measures after seven valuable paintings were stolen last week, on Monday issued a statement explaining that the thieves were able to snatch the artworks swiftly after an alarm briefly deactivated a rear doors electronic lock.

title: Jordanian Soldier Killed in Syrian Border Clash
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Islamic extremists attacked Jordanian soldiers on the border with Syria on Sunday night, killing a corporal, hours after the government announced that it had foiled a major terrorist plot against foreign diplomats and tourists here, officials said on Monday.

title: Little Bear, Sal and One Unforgettable Forgettable Day
description: Little Sals mother slowly backed away. (She was old enough to be shy of bears, even very small bears like Little Bear.) Then she turned and walked away quickly to look for Little Sal. Blueberries for Sal, by Robert McCloskey

title: An Issue Whose Time Has Passed
description: Chinese currency manipulation may come up in tonights debate  and as someone who wanted the US to take a tougher line back in 2010, I guess I should weigh in.

title: Monday Motorsports: DeltaWing Finds Redemption and Lola-Toyota a Victory at Petit Le Mans
description: Rebellion Racing avoided the snags and skids that befell its competitors in the Prototype I class, winning the Petit Le Mans on Saturday at Road Atlanta by a margin of three laps.

title: The Uncomfortable Truth About American Wages
description: Michael Greenstone is director of the Hamilton Project and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. He is also the 3M Professor of Environmental Economics at M.I.T. Adam Looney is policy director of the Hamilton Project and a senior fellow at Brookings.

title: Look of The Moment | Robert Pattinson
description: The Look: Biting. A trim loden suit paired with a foulard shirt make a scruffy face and mane look sharp, not disheveled.

title: Plush Pets That Parrot Your Speaking
description: Toys like Barbie, G.I. Joe and Lego have inspired apps, so it was probably a matter of time before an app inspired a physical toy.

title: Jazz & Colors Announces Its Lineup
description: The saxophonist J.D. Allen, the pianist Marc Cary and the Mingus Big Band will be among the 30 jazz acts appearing in Central Park on Nov. 10 during the free Jazz & Colors concert, organizers said on Monday.

title: The Uncertainty Scam
description: One of the central talking points of right-wing economists is that uncertainty caused by Obama is holding the economy back; they cite, again and again, a paper by Bloom et al purporting to find a relationship between uncertainty and jobs, with uncertainty measured via such things as article counts.

title: Chinas Bid for Nexen May Survive a Rejection
description: OTTAWA  The rejection of a major energy industry takeover by Canadian government may not indicate that it is adopting a harder line on mergers involving foreign companies.

title: International Documentary Association Announces Award Nominees
description: LOS ANGELES  While the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences sorts out changing rules for its documentaries Oscars  having delayed the deadline for voting on its short list of candidates until Nov. 26  the International Documentary Association is marching ahead with its own awards process.

title: Monster Energy Drink Cited in Deaths
description: Five people may have died over the past three years after drinking Monster Energy, a popular energy drink that is high in caffeine, according to incident reports recently released by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Train or Plane? More Travelers Choose Both
description: Air travelers in Canada, France, Germany and Spain may increasingly find that they are doing part of their journey on the ground, as airlines work with rail companies to sell tickets for combined trips.

title: Peanut Butter Takes On an Unlikely Best Friend
description: LIKE Krazy and Ignatz, Carville and Matalin, Cupid and Psyche or Alison Krauss and Robert Plant, the peanut butter and pickle sandwich is one of those unlikely pairings that shouldnt work, but does.

title: Just a Minute
description: Brian Stelter on debates, football and double-screen viewing.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Harley Block joined Rokkan, New York, in a new post, executive director for marketing and communications. He had been senior manager for communications at R/GA, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, handling tasks like managing the New York communications team.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Home Affordability Still Elusive in Some Major Markets
description: Despite a drop in prices since the housing market crash and historically low mortgage rates, many families still cant afford to buy a home in many major cities, a new analysis finds.

title: From the Lens Blog: Looking Presidential
Farallon Capitals Founder to Step Down This Year
description: 9:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Just a Minute: 3 Screens for 3 Televised Matchups
description: Brian Stelter has a solution for television viewers who think they have to choose among Monday nights presidential debate, baseball playoff game and Monday Night Football: watch all three.

title: A Marathon Sponsorship for a, Well, Marathon
description: The saying What do you do for an encore? has taken on added resonance for Madison Avenue in a real-time, always-on world of instant gratification, particularly when many consumers are apt to ask marketers, What have you done for me lately?

title: Benghazi, Again
description: At tonights debate, Mitt Romney will almost certainly criticize President Obama, again, over Benghazi. Republicans seem to have settled on the attack there as the greatest national security failure of our time (a rather odd notion in the post-9/11 world), perhaps because they think it distracts voters from the fact that, as the vice president likes to say, General Motors is alive and Osama bin Laden is dead.

title: Brown Rice, Sesame, Spinach and Scallion Pancakes
description: With only one test of these hearty pancakes, theyve turned into a favorite lunch, snack and dinner in our house. Try them heated with a little grated cheese on top, or serve with yogurt. These look prettiest when you use black sesame seeds.

title: Protecting a Wolf of a Salmon
description: They call them river wolves  hundred-pound salmon large enough to snack on ducklings and on mice and muskrats fording the rivers. Five species of these huge fish inhabit the river waters of China, Mongolia, and eastern Russia, and all of them are finally on the red list of species compiled by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

title: Silvery Fish Elude Predators With Light-Bending
description: Silvery fish like sardines and Atlantic herring are masters of camouflage. A new study explains how the fish use their silvery skin to stay invisible to predators from nearly every angle.

title: Twitters Content Ban
description: TimesCast Media + Tech: Twitter blocks content in Europe. | Getting to know Windows 8. | Deb Roy and the future of social TV analytics.

title: Chinas Doldrums Put Pressure on U.S. Exporters
description: As Chinas economy cools, American exporters are increasingly feeling the chill.

title: 9 Justices Who Sit in the Eye of Storms
description: With its landmark 5-to-4 vote last June to uphold President Obamas health care reform law, the Supreme Court once again became the focus of a national debate that centered on its pivotal  and political  role in an increasingly partisan America, with public approval of the highest court in the land sinking to 41 percent in July. The courts evolving internal dynamics under the stewardship of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and its relationship with President Obama are the subjects of Jeffrey Toobins useful new book, The Oath: a follow-up to his 2007 best seller, The Nine, and a reminder that the presidential election in two weeks is likely to determine the ideological makeup of what has been a narrowly divided court in years to come.

title: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
description: This weeks list of the well known with birthdays is unusually short, although there are two biggies.

title: TimesCast Media + Tech: Twitters Content Ban
description: Twitter blocks content in Europe. Getting to know Windows 8. Deb Roy and the future of social TV analytics.

title: French Elegance, Payard Style, to Return to the Upper East Side
description: Franois Payard and his partner, Marlon Abela, are returning to the Upper East Side, just steps from the original Payard patisserie and restaurant, which closed in 2009. The new place is all Parisian elegance.

title: A Slice of a House in Poland
description: A Polish architect became fascinated by the space between two apartment buildings and decided to build a home there.

title: Filling a Void in Warsaw
description: THREE years ago, Jakub Szczesny, a Polish architect, was walking through the old Jewish ghetto in Warsaw when he came upon what he described as an appealing cushion of air between a prewar apartment building and an 11-story postwar co-op.

title: Trailer: 'The Snorks'
description: Inside the film, "The Snorks," narrated by David Lynch.

title: Foreign Policy Debate Puts Focus on Leadership
description: For 90 minutes tonight, President Obama and Mitt Romney will clash over specific foreign policy issues, their differences heightened by a debate intended to draw out sharp contrasts ahead of Election Day in two weeks.

title: A 5-2 Team That Sure Doesnt Look It
description: When the Baltimore Ravens won the Super Bowl after the 2000 season, their offense, it was frequently mentioned, did not score a touchdown in five consecutive games. In every year since, it has seemed, the Ravens have tried to make up for that, constructing an offense bit by bit, acquiring assets like Joe Flacco, Ray Rice, Anquan Boldin and Torrey Smith. Many years from now, the Ravens identity will most likely still be colored by Ray Lewiss eye black and the ferocity of the defense in its heyday, but it will almost certainly be the offense that takes Baltimore back to the Super Bowl, if it is to get there.

title: At WTA Championships, Sharapova Gets Help From the Draw
description: ISTANBUL  Sitting in the front row of the draw ceremony for the WTA Championships along the other seven players in the field, the normally steely Maria Sharapova showed a side of herself she rarely does around her peers and competitors. She was giggling and rolling her head back with laughter as she whispered with Serena Williams.

title: Open Wide, Baby Coua! We Want to Look in Your Mouth
description: Some of the most interesting animal stuff at the zoo goes on behind the scenes. Todays (non-)exhibit: a baby crested coua, born last month and being hand-reared out of public view at the Central Park Zoo.

title: True Blue Stands Out in an Earthy Crowd
description: For the French Fauvist painter and color gourmand Raoul Dufy, blue was the only color with enough strength of character to remain blue in all its tones. Darkened red looks brown and whitened red turns pink, Dufy said, while yellow blackens with shading and fades away in the light. But blue can be brightened or dimmed, the artist said, and it will always stay blue.

title: Mile 14: Halfway There
description: The Pulaski Bridge, which connects Brooklyn and Queens, is named for a Polish hero of the American Revolution. But in the vernacular of the New York City Marathon, the words translate roughly to this: halfway point to a major accomplishment.

title: Blue Through the Centuries: Sacred and Sought After
description: However inspired they may have been by the immaculate beauty of the sky and water they saw every day, prehistoric artists had no way to render the color blue with paint. As Heinz Berke of the University of Zurich has pointed out, the famous cave paintings at Lascaux and surrounding sites, which date back some 20,000 years, are notably lacking in blue.

title: Bilingual Lies
description: Mitt Romney has a new Spanish-language campaign ad, about immigration reform, thats misleading and fraudulent even by his own slippery standards. Univision, among others, conducted a fact-check that reveals how the ad uses vagueness, misdirection and omission to create the false impression that a President Romney would enact reforms that immigrants favor.

title: Irans Political Infighting Erupts in Full View
description: TEHRAN  A long and bitter rivalry between Irans president and an influential band of brothers in the political hierarchy exploded into the open on Monday, signaling new fractures in the facade of unity as the country confronts worsening economic conditions and isolation over the disputed Iranian nuclear program.

title: The Blues Have It
description: The color blue in its many forms  both natural and artificial  has shaped our notions of mood, social class, truth and even divinity.

title: Showtime Orders Third Season of Homeland
description: To the surprise of almost no one in television, Showtime announced Monday that it had ordered a third season of its Emmy-winning drama Homeland.

title: Despite Push for Austerity, European Debt Has Soared
description: LONDON  As Greece and its international lenders continue tense talks on reducing the Greek budget deficit, new data from the European Union on Monday underscored the potentially Sisyphean nature of such efforts.

title: Eastern Seaboard: Snakes Serve as a Safe Winter Home for a Deadly Mosquito-Borne Virus
description: A mosquito-borne virus that is rare but kills some horses and humans along the Eastern Seaboard every year almost certainly survives winters inside snakes, a new study has found.

title: Graphics: Sales by BP, and Ranking the Top Oil Companies
description: BILLION-DOLLAR SALES BY BP BP began a series of divestitures in 2010 to pay for its oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Despite paying at least $38 billion for the spill, the British energy giant remains committed to high-risk exploration in deepwater fields. From Australia to Texas, the company has been selling older, smaller assets considered to be low-growth potential.

title: Lonely Male Orangutans Travel Far Afield to Mate
description: There are only about 6,600 orangutans left in Sumatra. Once found throughout the Indonesian island, the orangutans now live in just a few forest patches on the northern tip of the island.

title: Thinking Twice About Health Checkups
description: In an analysis of studies including more than 180,000 subjects, researchers have found that general health checkups  like annual physicals or other visits to the doctor by asymptomatic people  are ineffective and possibly harmful.

title: European Proposal to Get More Women on Boards Faces Test
description: BRUSSELS  A proposal to require company boards to be made up of at least 40 percent women is set to face a big test Tuesday when the European Commission plans to decide whether to keep the measure alive despite resistance from some countries and senior E.U. officials.

title: Changes Afoot at TKTS Booth
description: The popular TKTS booth in Times Square, which sells discount tickets for Broadway and Off Broadway shows, is expanding its box office services in an effort to provide more options to theater-goers who line up daily for deals, executives said on Monday.

title: Really? The Mothers Kiss Is an Effective Home Remedy
description: THE FACTS

title: Study Questions Benefit of Extra Vitamin D
description: Although some observational studies have suggested that supplements of vitamin D reduce the risk of vascular disease and mortality, a new placebo-controlled, randomized trial has found that the supplements have no effect on the most common blood markers for cardiovascular risk and death.

title: Off the Deep End | Loris Grauds The Snorks
description: The French artist Loris Graud likes to ask difficult questions: What does the surface of Mars smell like? How does the orgasm appear when filmed as light? What happens when you stage a fireworks show underground? My work stems from the answers I receive, says the prolific 32-year-old, and more often than not those answers come from scientists.

title: The Tight Choreography of the Town Hall
description: The town hall format is meant to give voters a rare chance for direct contact with the candidates. But every moment of televised town hall debates is tightly controlled and choreographed.

title: The Small S.U.V.s of So Paulo: VW Previews the Taigun, and Nissan Shows the Extrem
description: The downsizing trend for crossovers and S.U.V.s has arrived at Volkswagen Group and Nissan, which on Monday previewed the Taigun and Extrem concepts in conjunction with the So Paulo auto show, where previews are scheduled to begin on Tuesday.

title: Proximity to Livestock Raises a MRSA Risk
description: People living near large concentrations of farm animals are at increased risk for carrying livestock-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or LA-MRSA, even if they have had no direct contact with animals, a new study has found.

title: How to Read Like the Ethicist
description: Chuck Klosterman writes The Ethicist for the magazine.

title: An Insider Trading Case That Puts 2 Defendants at Odds
description: The insider trading charges against Anthony Chiasson, a co-founder of Level Global Investors, and Todd Newman, a former portfolio manager at Diamondback Capital Management, has put the two defendants at odds and may end up with one implicating the other as part of a defense strategy.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: Bruno Pavlovsky, the president of fashion at Chanel, talks to the Business of Fashion about balancing the companys growth while maintaining a traditionally low business profile, its acquisitions and other topics.

title: If Smart Is the Norm, Stupidity Gets More Interesting
description: Few of us are as smart as wed like to be. Youre sharper than Jim (maybe) but dull next to Jane. Human intelligence varies. And this matters, because smarter people generally earn more money, enjoy better health, raise smarter children, feel happier and, just to rub it in, live longer as well.

title: In With Good and Out With Bad Memories
description: Most people have a moment or two they would rather not remember. The brain has two opposite ways of dealing with those memories, researchers report in a new study.

title: Amazon Cloud Service Goes Down and Takes Popular Sites With It
description: 7:11 p.m. | Updated  Updated throughout.Some services at Amazon.coms data centers went down Monday afternoon, taking with them a number of popular Web sites and services, including Flipboard and Foursquare.

title: Attending Fashion University
description: On Sunday, 525 high school and college students completed Teen Vogues annual Fashion University, a weekend of fashion education for the next generation of Anna Wintours, Grace Coddingtons and Eva Chens. Attendees, up from 502 last year, came from throughout the United States and from 26 countries.

title: The Megawatt Hour Responds to Reader Comments on Its Web Site
