description: Carol Muller speaks about the reach of Graceland as a Global Project from South Africa to the United States.

title: Britain Leads Resistance to a Stronger European Union
description: LONDON  In the calculations of Europes cohesion  or lack of it  British euroskepticism has always seemed a brake on closer integration of the kind frequently advocated by the big powers across the Channel.

title: A Fashion Repeat, Wet Hair and Necktie Nattering
description: Much as the tone of the presidential debates has evolved over the last few weeks, discussion of the fashion choices of the candidates and their wives has also become almost artificially overheated, probably because of our own high expectations that Michelle Obama and Ann Romney will settle this whole thing by wearing a really knockout dress. Still, it didnt happen.

title: Sondheims Lost Quiche Lyric?
description: David Tanis begins his latest column, on the joys of quiche done right, with a lyric from The Ladies Who Lunch (ladies and gentlemen, Elaine Stritch), from Stephen Sondheims musical Company: Does anyone still wear a hat? Ill drink to that.

title: Central Park Draws a Huge Gift From a Fan in High Finance
description: Central Park has long been a favorite cause for the financial world. Now one of the most prominent names in high finance has given Manhattans largest park a record gift.

title: France to Back Peugeot With 7 Billion Euros in Credit Guarantees
description: PARIS  The French government is preparing to announce that it will provide PSA Peugeot Citron with credit guarantees worth as much as 7 billion in exchange for sparing some of the 8,000 jobs it was planning to cut, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said Tuesday.

title: Completing Mitts Makeover
description: If you score last nights faceoff in Boca on debating points, Obama won. He should have. Hes been navigating the complexities of foreign policy for nearly four years, and while even admirers of his presidency can list disappointments, on his watch we brought our troops home from Iraq, charted a route home from Afghanistan, mobilized strong international pressure against Irans nuclear program, eroded the leadership of Al Qaeda and helped rid the world of Muammar Qaddafi. The presidents best lines were obviously scripted, he was allowed to evade some important questions, but he projected confidence and seriousness of purpose.

title: Mauled by Attack Ads, Incumbents Weigh Tighter Rules
description: WASHINGTON  An onslaught of negative political advertisements in Congressional races has left many incumbents, including some Republicans long opposed to restrictions on campaign spending, concluding that legislative measures may be in order to curtail the power of the outside groups behind most of the attacks.

title: Attack. Then Attack Some More.
description: A few examples of the negative ads in 2012 House races from outside sources.

title: On Twitter and Google, Signs of Less Interest in the Final Presidential Debate
description: All the presidents horses and all the presidents men could not get Twitter users to break a record again during last nights final debate. Even if they had been carrying bayonets.

title: No Pizza on the Piazza?
description: ROMEStefano, look! Theres another eater, one police officer said to another, dapper as ever in their bleached white shirts and matching caps. The culprits, a couple of foreign tourists, had settled down on the Spanish Steps, one of Romes most famous landmarks. In their hands were the offending items: sandwiches.

title: Nassau Police Officer and 2nd Man Are Killed in Rampage at Citys Edge
description: It was hard to miss the silver-colored Honda, driving away from an accident with its tires blown out, rims scratching the pavement. Its driver, the police said, was about to lay down a far bloodier wake.

title: Updates From Apples Product Event
description: Apple unveiled a smaller iPad, a new iMac and other revamped products on Tuesday at an event at the California Theater in San Jose, Calif. I filed updates from the event, and my colleagues Brian X. Chen and Nick Bilton in San Jose, and Nick Wingfield in New York, pitched in with commentary.

title: China and the U.S. Presidential Election
description: Jane Perlez, The Times chief diplomatic correspondent in Beijing, explains the Chinese interest in the American presidential election.

title: And God Spoke to Abraham (Lincoln)
description: In early October 1862, Abraham Lincoln received a letter from God.

title: Watching U.S. Race, Other Nations See Themselves
description: MOSCOW  For weeks, coverage of the United States presidential race in Russias state-controlled media has been obscured by a layer of derision, cast by top commentators as a mud-slinging brawl or a beauty contest in which candidates vie for the loyalty of voting blocs, some who love ample, fatty brunettes  and some preferring skinny anorexics.

title: Odd Couples
description: Just as soon as we posted Dwight Garners article on the pleasures of the peanut butter and pickle sandwich, our readers jumped in to share their favorite peanut butter combinations via e-mail, Facebook and Twitter. Heres one e-mail we received from a reader who puts a different spin on the authors sandwich:

title: Invasive Grasses as Biofuel? Scientists Protest
description: More than 200 scientists from across the country have sent a letter to the Obama administration urging the Environmental Protection Agency to reconsider a rule, in the final approval stages, that would allow two invasive grasses, Arundo donax and Pennisetum purpureum, to qualify as advanced biofuel feedstock under the nations renewable fuel standard.

title: A World Series With a Venezuelan Accent
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  As Marco Scutaro stared into the falling rain and prepared to glove the pop-up that would be the last out of the National League Championship Series on Monday night, the television announcer here crowed, It had to be a Venezuelan!

title: Was There a Bankruptcy Alternative for the Automakers?
description: Some months ago, I predicted that we would finally move on from the overheated rhetoric surrounding the automotive bankruptcy cases. After all, even Paul D. Ryan supported the Obama administration on this point.

title: NBC Continues Its Unlikely Run Atop in the Ratings
description: NBC made it four weeks in a row as the top-rated network in prime time among viewers most prized by advertisers, edging CBS by one-tenth of a point, according to the official Nielsen weekly numbers released Tuesday.

title: Maple Pecan Pancakes
description: Instead of using only wheat flour in these pancakes, Ive combined whole-wheat flour and almond flour. The almond flour makes for a very moist and delicate pancake. Almond flour is high in vitamin E, calcium, magnesium and copper.

title: A Eurail Pass Now to Include Turkey
description: Travelers planning to tour Europe on a Eurail Pass next year will be able for the first time to use it to visit Turkey.

title: Using Crowdfunding to Start a Company With a Cause
description: Two sisters, Kara Gorski and Kristin Gembala, have developed a bra designed to help breast cancer survivors who have had mastectomies and reconstructive surgery. So far, the sisters, who invested $25,000 from their savings, have designed and patented two styles and built a Web site. Currently, they are trying to raise money to begin manufacturing through a new crowdfunding platform.

title: Styled To a T | Johanna Meyer-Grohbrgge & Sam Chermayeff
description: The Architects

title: Lulu as Operatic Melting Pot
description: BERLIN  What would music be like if every note of every piece were thought up by composers from scratch, the product of purely original creativity? Much impoverished, to be sure. From Renaissance composers, who created imposing masses with popular songs at their cores, to Bach and his contrapuntal masterpieces inspired by chorale tunes, right down to the present, composers have found the prospect of elaborating on the work of their predecessors irresistible. Allusions to other composers enhance many of the Austrian composer Olga Neuwirths instrumental works and are sometimes their raison dtre. Her opera Lost Highway, based on David Lynchs film, demonstrates her predilection for reworking nonmusical ideas as well.

title: G.M. Plans a Software Patch to Address Stalling Chevrolet Volts
description: 9:54 a.m. | Updated

title: A Portal Into History
description: Though it is celebrated widely, few people know how the song "Hava Nagila" traveled over the years from Ukraine to YouTube.

title: Obamas Remark Aside, No Imminent Deal on Fiscal Cliff
description: President Obama set heads spinning on Capitol Hill when he declared on Monday night during the final presidential debate that sequestration  $1 trillion in across-the-board spending cuts over the next decade  will not happen.

title: Big Hit Lifts Cutlers Reputation
description: Now that the Bears are leading the N.F.C. North at 5-1 and Jay Cutler hasnt thrown a tantrum or a game-killing interception in awhile, Chicago fans are starting to warm to their prickly quarterback again and he actually helped his own cause in Monday nights 13-7 victory over the Lions by getting crushed by a hit from Detroits Ndamukong Suh.

title: The Campaign Moves to the Final Sprint
description: TimesCast Politics: Reaction to the final presidential debate. | The all-important female vote. | The latest on the race for the Senate.

title: Couple Talks About Romneys Aid to Their Son in New Crossroads Ad
description: One of the more compelling stories from Mitt Romneys time as a senior member of the Mormon Church is the subject of a new television commercial produced by a super PAC that has, until now, supported the Republican nominee mostly through attack ads.

title: Candy Gets a Healthful Upgrade
description: Whats in that trick-or-treat bag? Candymakers, even those who sell their products on the mass market, are upgrading their confections by reducing sugar and by eliminating transfats, corn syrup and artificial flavors and colors.

title: On Our Radar: Climate of Doubt
description: Climate of Doubt, a Frontline documentary that airs Tuesday night on PBS, explores how a movement mobilized to undermine public acceptance of the scientific consensus on global warming and on how human activity contributes to climate change. The conservative Heartland Institute, which has played a prominent role in seeking to discredit climate science, pre-emptively issues a statement denying that a scientific consensus exists and predicting that the documentary will be unfair. [PBS, Heartland Institute]

title: Debates Over, the Final Decision Awaits
description: To the Editor:

title: To Go, but Far From Pedestrian
description: David Bouleys Brushstroke, which opened about a year and a half ago, has evolved almost from the start. New this week is sushi to go. But if you are thinking of a plastic container packed with tuna and cucumber rolls, think again.

title: Mile 15: Where Old-Timers Appreciate the New
description: Tommy Ledden has lived since 1940 in Long Island City, the Queens neighborhood that marathoners wind their way through in the 14th and 15th miles.

title: Googles Earnings Incident Shines Light on a Stealth Industry
description: A little-known fact regarding corporate earnings was unexpectedly revealed last week when the third-quarter earnings for Google were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission several hours ahead of schedule.

title: TimesCast Politics: Campaign Moves to the Final Sprint
description: Damon Winter/The New York Times

title: Log Cabin Republicans Endorse Romney
description: I have always admired the tenacity of the Log Cabin Republicans, who believed they could work from within the G.O.P. to change the partys views on gay rights. Until they endorsed Mitt Romney for president.

title: If You Like Stevie Wonder. . .
description: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to music of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Two Shining Moments on the Red Carpet at the Hollywood Film Awards
description: It is no surprise that two fashion darlings were the highlight of the Hollywood Film Awards on Monday night in Beverly Hills, Calif. Kerry Washington (left), the star of the ABC series Scandal, wore a paint-splashed Monique Lhuillier dress from the 2012 spring collection with Louis Vuitton pumps.

title: A New Solera Bourbon Stands Out
description: The Hillrock Distillery is just the latest entrant in the fast-growing Hudson Valley liquor industry, which in the last decade has begun producing gin, rum, whiskey, vodka and applejack with abandon. But the new concern, located in Ancram, N.Y., has found a few ways to stand out.

title: Times Must Aggressively Cover Mark Thompsons Role in BBCs Troubles
description: October 24, 10:11 a.m. | Updated One of the most difficult challenges for news organizations is reporting on what goes on inside their own corporate walls. Two global media companies, the BBC and The New York Times, are dealing with that challenge right now, as a complicated sexual abuse scandal  with a media scandal component  unfolds in Britain.

title: Keeping Score: Ace on the Mound, an Out at the Plate
description: 9:26 p.m. | Updated Justin Verlanders commitment to keeping the basepaths clear of runners has never been doubted.

title: From Local Motors and Dominos Pizza, an Ultimate Ride for Packing Pies
description: Local Motors, the open-source community of car designers and fabricators, has identified what it called the ultimate pizza delivery vehicle.

title: Former C.I.A. Operative Pleads Guilty in Leak of Colleagues Name
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Less than two months after the Justice Department announced that it would not charge Central Intelligence Agency officials who participated in the brutal interrogation of detainees during the Bush administration, prosecutors on Tuesday won the conviction of a former C.I.A. counterterrorism operative who told a reporter the name of a covert C.I.A. officer involved in the program.

title: Massacre at Syrian Bakery Dims Hopes for a Holiday Truce
description: Syrian artillery gunners shelled a bread bakery full of workers and customers on Tuesday in an insurgent-held neighborhood of Aleppo, Syrias largest city, killing at least 20 people and wounding more than 30 in what activists and videographers described as a sudden and devastating attack.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 23
description: A view of the day in sports, from a farewell at the Open 500 Valencia to Usain Bolts trademark pose.

title: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: What is wrong with the Lions? Is there any hope for the Chiefs? What do the Giants have to do to beat the Cowboys? Just how good is Brandon Marshall? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

title: Apple, Facing Competition, Introduces a Smaller iPad
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Steve Jobs once mocked  tablets with small screens, saying they would need to come with sandpaper so people could sand down their fingertips to use them. But that didnt stop his company from shrinking the iPad.

title: Teff and Oatmeal Pancakes
description: Teff is a tiny, nutrient-dense grain native to Ethiopia. Its calcium content is higher than that of any other grain, and its an excellent source of vitamin C. It has a low glycemic index and is gluten-free, though these pancakes are not. I grind the tiny grains into flour in my spice mill, but you can also find teff flour in whole-foods stores.

title: Umami Burger Is Coming to New York
description: The symbiosis between New York and Los Angeles plays out on the food front. Lox and bagels and pastrami sandwiches make pulses race in Studio City. And Los Angeles will soon return the favor with its iconic Umami Burger.

title: The Envelope, Please: Thanh-Tran Nguyen
description: Thanh-Tran Nguyen, a student at Lakeside School in Seattle, writes, Itd be unwise of me to just jump onto campus without at least getting to know the college face-to-face.

title: True Grit
description: Last year, on a residency in Jaipur, India, the Swiss designers Lovis Caputo and Sarah Kueng began experimenting with sand and pigment on a small scale, making objects and baking them in a microwave. Back in Zurich, they perfected a no-bake recipe. Their Sand series, a collection of unique stools that can be used indoors or out, is available through Salon 94 in New York City.

title: Savory Cottage Cheese Pancakes With Indian Spices, Cauliflower and Carrots
description: We eat these Indian-spiced pancakes for dinner, along with a green salad. They dont even need a topping. If you do want to top them with something, a cucumber raita or plain yogurt would work well.

title: Consumer Bureau Is Seeking Credit-Reporting Complaints
description: Have a gripe about a your credit report, or a credit reporting bureaulike Equifax, TransUnion or Experian? The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is now accepting complaints about credit reporting.

title: The Issue That Dare Not Speak Its Name
description: A mountain of scientific evidence points to climate change as a serious risk for the human future. The Pentagon sees it as a threat to national security. Arctic sea ice hit a record low this summer. In some low-lying countries threatened by sea level rise, evacuation planning has already begun.

title: Dumplings to Die For
description: New and exciting variations on the classic dumpling have recently appeared on menus in New York City. Meet some of the people behind a few of these delicious creations.

title: 50 Years Later: The Cuban Missile Crisis Remembered
description: Fifty years ago this week, the United States and the Soviet Union narrowly averted catastrophe over the presence of nuclear missiles in Soviet-backed Cuba.

title: Lessons for Madison Avenue From Real-Time Olympics
description: The World Series is about to begin, but for the experts at the Nielsen Sports Forum Tuesday morning the focus was on the Summer Games in London and the lessons for marketers who sponsor live sports events.

title: Europe Postpones Vote on Gender Quota Plan
description: BRUSSELS  A proposal to require company boards to be made up of at least 40 percent women was set aside on Tuesday by the European Commission because of concerns about its legality and tough opposition from across the European Union.

title: Dumplings Reimagined
description: In New York, the humble dumpling is getting a high-end makeover.

title: Good Thing, Small Package
description: IF by chance you are a lover of dumplings (and really, Anthony Bourdain might have to mount a search party to find someone who isnt), then consider this a very good time to be a New Yorker.

title: Qatars Emir Visits Gaza, Pledging $400 Million to Hamas
description: JERUSALEM  The emir of Qatar on Tuesday became the first head of state to visit the Gaza Strip since Hamas took full control of it in 2007, the latest step in an ambitious campaign by the tiny Persian Gulf nation to leverage its outsize pocketbook in support of Islamists across the region  and one that threatened to widen the rift between rival Palestinian factions.

title: South Africas  Zuma, Tested by Mining Crisis, Faces Scandal Close to Home
description: NKANDLA, South Africa  On a pair of hilltops in this rolling, verdant corner of Zululand, two traditional family compounds owned by septuagenarian patriarchs square off. On one lies the tidy spread of a resolutely middle class family, the Sitholes: eight slightly lumpy hand-built structures, a vegetable patch and pens for cows, goats and chickens, the fruit of four decades of hard work and frugal living.

title: Why Arizona Isnt a Battleground State (and Why It May Be Soon)
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each states political landscape and how its changing. Here is Arizona, the Grand Canyon State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Bruce Merrill, David Berman and Joseph Garcia of Arizona State Universitys Morrison Institute for Public Policy. Mr. Merrill and Mr. Berman are senior research fellows, and Mr. Garcia is the director of the institutes Latino Public Policy Center. FiveThirtyEight also spoke with Chip Scutari and Dave Cieslak, co-founders of the political consulting firm Scutari & Cieslak Public Relations.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: This week: geoengineering in the Pacific, deep contemplation of the forest, and the genes that make us smart...or not so much.

title: A Drink For October (That Isnt Pumpkin Ale!)
description: In October, there are some people who look forward to nothing quite so much as a pint or two of pumpkin ale. I am not one of those people. I like pumpkins (to look at, anyway), and I like ale. But putting them together is just not my thing. (I feel the same about dinner theater. I like both constituent parts, just not the sum.)

title: One Year After MF Global, New Protections for Customer Money
description: Nearly a year after MF Global raided customer accounts in a failed bid to survive, regulators moved this week to tighten restrictions for brokerage firms and adopt new safeguards for client money.

title: Walkabout  10/23: Guides to Foliage, Hot Chocolate, Neon Signs and Pork Buns
description: The Lost Colony London-based photographer Robert Leslie documents his road trip across America. Above, Highway 98 in Florida. (The New York Times)

title: When Free Stuff Leads You Astray
description: We all like freebies. But sometimes, free stuff can lure you into making choices that may not really be best. I learned that lesson anew last week, while on a road trip that took me through rural parts of Arkansas and Missouri.

title: Creating Big Datas Talent Mart
description: Companies without enough data scientists, meet lots of analysts willing to take your work.

title: Three Women
description: An excerpt of Three Women, a silent work by Bill Viola, who is a pioneer in video art. He gave his performers minimal instructions, recording their gasping reactions of astonishment or euphoria.

title: Spains Troubles Catch Up With a Storied Newspaper
description: MADRID  El Pas established itself as the leading newspaper in Spain in the late 1970s, serving as a front-line witness to the period in which Spain returned to democracy after the death of the dictator Francisco Franco. Now the newspaper is going through turbulent times of its own.

title: Giants Midseason Deal Keeps Getting Better
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Marco Scutaros final hit as a member of the Colorado Rockies was on July 27, against Reds reliever Alfredo Simon. It raised his batting average to .271. Scutaro may not have known it at the time, but those were his final moments as Clark Kent.

title: Mining Truth From Data Babel
description: A friend who was a pioneer in the computer games business used to marvel at how her company handled its projections of costs and revenue. We performed exhaustive calculations, analyses and revisions, she would tell me. And we somehow always ended with numbers that justified our hiring the people and producing the games we had wanted to all along. Those forecasts rarely proved accurate, but as long as the games were reasonably profitable, she said, youd keep your job and get to create more unfounded projections for the next endeavor.

title: Cuban Missile Crisis, 50 Years Ago, Had the City and the World Worried
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  Eyeball to eyeball in a hangar jammed with old warplanes, they embraced, two men in crisp colonel uniforms  one who had been in the United States Army, the other in the Soviet Army during those 13 days when a nervous world waited and worried.

title: App Snapshot: House  and Palace  Intrigue
description: Though Republicans appear likely to hold on to the House, some individual contests have captured our attention, and there are also hints of post-vote intrigue among House Democratic leadership. Weve collected the most interesting stories about the House race  from The Times and other top sources around the Web  in the Election 2012 app, where were continuously curating the latest political news.

title: Part 2: Answers to Readers Questions About the SAT and ACT
description: Updated: We are no longer taking questions for this session.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefits

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: After Consolidation at Simon & Schuster, Top Two at Free Press Are Leaving
description: 5:40 p.m. | Updated The top two executives at Free Press, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, are leaving the company as a result of the reorganization of the companys adult publishing divisions, which will consolidate its imprints from six groups into four.

title: Facebook Revenue Surpasses Forecasts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, told Wall Street on Tuesday that his company was on its way to cracking the mobile puzzle.

title: Flash Points: Searching for Modern Lessons in the Cuban Missile Crisis
description: Overview | Fifty years ago this week, the United States and Soviet Union narrowly averted catastrophe over the presence of nuclear missiles in Soviet-backed Cuba. But just how close did we come to an unintended nuclear war, and could a similar incident happen again?

title: Chefs Back Measure on Labeling G.M.O.s
description: More than 700 of the nations chefs and professional foodies, from prominent names like David Bouley to up-and-comers like the chef Bryant Terry of Oakland, have lined up to support a California ballot measure that would require food companies to label products containing genetically engineered ingredients.

title: Marlins Fire Guillen After Only One Season
description: In their grandiose visions from last off-season, the Miami Marlins could have dreamed of a different way to spend Tuesday. With their many changes, the Marlins considered themselves a strong contender to host postseason games at their stylish new ballpark.

title: The Songs of a King, Still Played Today
description: In a country where eliminating public support for the arts can be used as a campaign stop applause line, it may seem unthinkable, but there was a time when a court prima donna pulled a greater government salary than a cabinet minister.

title: Glenn Beck Isnt Happy
description: Glenn Beck felt really irritated by Mitt Romneys performance at the third presidential debate last night. And who can blame him. As Mr. Beck said on Twitter: I am glad to know that Mitt agrees with Obama so much. No, really. Why vote?

title: Netflix Shares Slide as Subscriber Goal Falls Short
description: Netflix has reached a milestone: its streaming video service now has 25 million subscribing households in the United States, nearly a third of the homes that have broadband.

title: Better Ways to Deal With China
description: Less than a year into a new administration, the nations trade deficit is soaring. Manufacturers are complaining bitterly that an overvalued dollar is destroying the economy, driving businesses abroad. Congress is bubbling with proposals to punish countries that are flooding the United States with cheaper exports.

title: Yes We Chant
description: The Gregory Brothers present a musical mash-up video of the final presidential debate between President Obama and Mitt Romney.

title: Few Winners in Heated Cellphone Wars
description: If you are wondering who will be your cellphone provider next year, so are the cellphone companies. Maneuvers by American cellphone providers to acquire one another are threatening to erupt into all-out war. And the question is not only which ones will survive, but whether the survivors will be ruined by the prey they are rushing to swallow, leaving consumers by the wayside.

title: Yes We Chant
description: After a bizarrely dull first debate, President Obama came out firing in the town-hall-style follow-up. That brought a sudden reversal in public opinion on his debating acumen, as the editorial page of this newspaper noted that Obama regained full command of his vision and his legacy, leaving Mitt Romney sputtering.

title: Weekly Reader: Vampires, Park Slope, Men and Marshmallows
description: Some weeks, all my reading happens online. Other times, its print magazines and newspapers, of the kind that litter our couch and populate our recycling bins. Of late, though, its been books. People send me books, people give me books, and Im known at the bookstore for the optimistic stacks with which I approach the register. Heres a look at what Im reading. Whats on your nightstand?

title: Another Pricey Watch Disappears in Russia
description: Six months after the Russian Orthodox Church admitted that it had altered a photo on its Web site to remove what looked like an expensive watch worn by its leader, Patriarch Kirill, another fancy watch has disappeared from a portrait of a leading Russian  this time, the president of Udmurtia, a small ethnic republic in Russias Volga district.

title: Ringing in New Works to Celebrate Longevity
description: Now this is the way for an ensemble to celebrate an anniversary. The New York Virtuoso Singers, founded 25 years ago by the conductor Harold Rosenbaum, are an invaluable professional chamber choir that focuses on American contemporary music. For the groups anniversary Mr. Rosenbaum commissioned 25 composers to write 25 works. On Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall he and his 16-voice ensemble presented the premieres of 12 of these pieces. The other 13 are to be introduced at Merkin in March. Previously the group had a list of more than 50 works it had commissioned over the years. In one season it will up that number by half. Not bad.

title: Life, When All Thats Left Is Your Neil Diamond CD
description: In the superb and sweetly funny Other Josh Cohen, at the SoHo Playhouse, the unendingly unlucky title mensch comes home a little before Valentines Day to find his New York apartment robbed  swabbed so clean by his industrious intruder that even his Bundt cake has been pilfered. All that the meticulous burglar left behind was one Neil Diamond CD (which, Josh hastens to add, he actually got free). He isnt sure if the orphaned disc was an oversight or an indictment of his taste.

title: Redgrave To Direct Stage Version of a Beirut Memoir
description: Vanessa Redgrave and Mariam C. Said, the widow of Edward W. Said, the prominent Columbia University scholar, have teamed up for a theatrical piece based on the life and times of Ms. Saids mother in Beirut, the producers said on Tuesday.

title: In Istanbul, Radwanska Defeats Kvitova
description: ISTANBULFor more than two years, Petra Kvitova had been able to make any court with a roof and a solid floor her home. compiling a 29-0 record on indoor hard courts dating back to the beginning of 2011. That streak included several titles, including the 2011 TEB BNP Paribas WTA Championships Istanbul, at which she began her title defense Tuesday afternoon.

title: Table Talk | The Pines in Brooklyn
description: While the pressed tin ceilings, weathered wood floors and mismatched fixtures at the Pines, a new restaurant in Gowanus, Brooklyn, may look and feel familiar, theres one thing that doesnt ring a bell: the food. We want you to trust us, and our flavor profiles, says the chef Angelo Romano (formerly at Robertas and Masten Lake), of his creative and original menu approach.

title: A Pop Culture Father Figure, as Mellow as His Tone
description: A recurrent image in The Zen of Bennett, Unjoo Moons tender, touching documentary portrait of the singer Tony Bennett, now 86, is of an unblinking eye in the sky gazing through turbulent clouds. It is as good a visual metaphor as any for the career of a singer who has flourished by keeping a steady focus on what has mattered most to him for more than six decades: the American Songbook.

title: About Those Horses and Bayonets
description: Yes, the American military still uses bayonets, and quite a few. There are horses too.

title: Writer of Spider-Man Musical Signs a Book Deal
description: Glen Berger, the Off-Broadway playwright whose plum assignment to collaborate with Bono and the Edge of U2 on a Broadway musical turned into the media circus known as Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, has signed with Simon & Schuster to write a book about his experience, the publisher said on Tuesday.

title: Unexpected Accents in Familiar Brahms
description: Since its founding in 1904, the London Symphony Orchestra has been self-governing. Perhaps having the authority to choose their own conductors empowers the players to be, in the best sense, responsive and adaptable.

title: News Were Reading Now: Dior Mascara Ad Banned
description: Usually when a beauty advertisement is banned, its because of heavy digital photo manipulation that promotes unattainable beauty ideals, an often torrid topic. New York Magazines The Cut reported that Britains Advertising Standards Authority has banned Diors Diorshow New Look Lash-Multiplying Mascara ads, featuring Natalie Portman, because of LOreal U.K.s claim that the ad was promoting results misleading to consumers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Florida and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Florida, Israel, Russia and Syria.

title: Serena Williams Defeats Kerber in Straight Sets
description: ISTANBULIt had been 44 days since Serena Williams had played a tennis match, and her first round-robin match Tuesday at the TEB BNP Paribas WTA Championships Istanbul against Angelique Kerber arrived not a day too soon

title: You Will Love So Paulo. (Please?)
description: So Paulo, Brazil, is my second home. As second homes go, its problematic: the city of 11 million is a grimy, dangerous megalopolis, as aesthetically pleasing as a bunion and harder to navigate than the Strait of Magellan. No one asks someone with a pied--terre in the Latin Quarter Why do you love Paris so much? Lots of people ask me Why do you love So Paulo so much? Including some people from So Paulo.

title: After Princeton, Looking at Fickle Fates
description: In Paul David Youngs In the Summer Pavilion, three recent Princeton grads examine the road not taken. Actually, make that roads, plural, not taken, or at least not yet taken.

title: Sale Brings Former Owner Back to the Essex House
description: When the Essex House, the Art Deco hotel on Manhattans Central Park South, changed hands last month, it was a homecoming for two major players in the hotel industry.

title: 4 Playwrights Among Winners of 2012 Whiting Awards
description: The winners of the 2012 Whiting Writers Awards were announced on Tuesday. Each of the 10 chosen writers receives a cash award of $50,000. The honors, issued annually since 1985, are given not for a specific work, but for the abundant promise of future work, said Barbara Bristol, director of the Whiting writers program.

title: With Election Nearing, Wall Street Ponders a Romney Presidency
description: With the presidential election drawing near, and the Republican candidate Mitt Romney surging in some polls, Wall Street may be cheering on the sidelines.

title: Final Debate Draws Nearly 60 Million Viewers
description: Nearly 60 million television viewers at home tuned into the final presidential debate between President Obama and Mitt Romney on Monday night, despite stiff competition from two big sporting events.
Inside the restaurant that serves as a sepia-toned playpen for adults.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facial Recognition Rules and Photoshop Ghosts
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: In Oil-Rich Iran, Natural Gas Turns Wheels
description: TEHRAN

title: A Public Display of Affection
description: READERS who look forward to the dark thrill of a public execution on days when there are no stars attached to this column should turn elsewhere to satisfy their blood lust. This is going to be a kind of love letter to a restaurant where the food is largely forgettable and the prices are almost always unwarranted.

title: 2012 Crossword Puzzle Contest: How Did You Do?
description: Administrivial Update Alert! There is an apparent discrepancy between the ultimate number of contest winners in the PDF and elsewhere. A total of 50 winners will be selected.

title: After Federal Jolt, Clean Energy Seeks New Spark
description: WASHINGTON  PRESIDENT OBAMAS 2009 stimulus package included the largest single piece of energy legislation in American history, a $90 billion money pile for energy projects from the mundane to the exotic.

title: Press Release: $100 Million Gift to Central Park
description: John A. Paulson, a billionaire hedge fund manager, gave $100 million to the Central Park Conservancy, the largest gift ever to be given to a public park.

title: Gay Marriage Withstands Legal Threat
description: New Yorks highest court declined on Tuesday to hear a challenge to the states gay-marriage law, ending the only significant legal threat to same-sex weddings in the state.

title: The Big New Push to Export Americas Gas Bounty
description: JUST off the coast of Texas, Excelerate Energy is hoping to strike it big.

title: Editing Bolsters Obamas Role in SEALs Film
description: LOS ANGELES  Thanks to the magic of editing, President Obama will have a starring role in a television drama about one of his biggest accomplishments  the killing of Osama bin Laden  that will be shown just two nights before the presidential election.

title: Sharapova Cruises by Errani
description: ISTANBULPlayers criticized the court for being slower and grittier than in years past on the first day of the 2012 TEB BNP Paribas WTA Championships Istanbul, but Maria Sharapova had no complaints.

title: Technology Turns Brand Loyalty List Topsy-Turvy
description: The 2012 edition of the top 100 loyalty leaders list compiled by Brand Keys, a New York company that specializes in brand and customer-loyalty consulting, is significantly different from the lists of the last two years because of the continuous pace of change in technology.

title: Bigger Than Either of Them?
description: DRILL, baby, drill. It is among the best-remembered lines of the 2008 presidential campaign, colorfully capturing the desire of many Americans for cheap, reliable energy produced at home rather than in unpredictable places like Iran or Venezuela.

title: Ruling Raises Questions About List of Unsafe Consumer Products
description: Consumer groups said Tuesday that a federal court decision could threaten the effectiveness of saferproducts.gov, a relatively new federal database of unsafe products.

title: Mel Karmazin to Step Down as Chief of Sirius
description: Mel Karmazin will step down as chief executive of Sirius XM Radio on Feb. 1, as the company prepares to be taken over by Liberty Media, its biggest investor, Sirius announced Tuesday.

title: Corn Ethanol Makers Weigh Switch to Butanol
description: NEARLY a decade after the adoption of federal renewable fuel standards led to a sharp increase in production of ethanol, some producers in the Corn Belt are considering making a different fuel. The fuel, butyl alcohol, or butanol, is worth more to refiners because it has more energy than ethanol, is easier to handle and more of it can be blended into each gallon of gasoline. But producing it will require costly retrofitting of ethanol plants, and plant capacity will be reduced.

title: The iPad Mini and Its Competition
description: The iPad Mini was announced Tuesday, with a retail price starting at $329. How it compares with other small tablet models currently available:

title: Have You Seen This Tabby? (Check Your Carry-On)
description: Iris Yu left a lot behind when she left Queens to care for her ailing father in Taiwan 10 months ago. But she was finally set to reunite with her cat, Xiaohwa, courtesy of a friend who was leaving for Taiwan last Thursday and agreed to take the cat to her.

title: Aging and Expensive, Reactors Face Mothballs
description: THE conventional wisdom about nuclear reactors is that they are expensive to build but cheap to run.

title: Income Stagnation and Inequality
description: Median income has fallen over the last decade, widening the gap between the highest and lowest earners.

title: Providence Equitys Richardson to Assume Senior Adviser Role
description: Julie G. Richardson, a managing director at Providence Equity Partners and one of the most prominent female private equity executives, is cutting back on her responsibilities by becoming a senior adviser, the firm said on Tuesday.

title: Champions League: Matchday 3(A)
description: With games on Matchday 3(A) of the group stage of the UEFA Champions League on Tuesday, we continue a new featurette in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

title: Zynga Announces Layoffs and Closing of Older Games
description: Zynga, the social gaming company that has seen its fortunes slide over the last six months, announced cutbacks Tuesday just before what promises to be a dismal earnings report. The retrenching includes the dismissal of about 5 percent of Zyngas work force, or 150 people, and the closing of 13 older games.

title: Nancy J. Ruddy
description: Ms. Ruddy is a founder and managing principal, with her husband, John Cetra, of the architectural firm CetraRuddy. The New York company has been involved in restoration and conversion work on buildings like Barbizon 63, Walker Tower and Cipriani on 42nd Street.

title: Irans Warning to Oil Market Fails to Send Prices Higher
description: Iran threatened on Tuesday to halt all its oil exports if the Wests antinuclear sanctions on the country are strengthened, apparently in the hope that such a warning would spook the international petroleum market by raising prices and reminding the world of Irans potential to wreak havoc with the global economy.

title: Campaign Tries to Help Defuse Bullying
description: TAUNTING and aggressive teasing have long been seen as disagreeable rites of adolescence, until a string of suicides by bullied students raised awareness of the destructive consequences. A new campaign by a coalition of organizations is aiming to eliminate, or at least curb, bullying by urging parents to teach their children to face down such behavior.

title: University of Chicago Works on Its Neighborhood
description: CHICAGO  The University of Chicago is midway through what it characterizes as a once in a generation community redevelopment effort aimed at revitalizing 53rd Street, a blighted retail district several blocks north of its historic Hyde Park campus here.

title: Among Americans in Israel, More Forceful Backing for Romney
description: JERUSALEM  Americans living in Israel went to the polls this week, dropping sealed envelopes into improvised ballot boxes at community centers in this city and at other locations around the country. Instead of a unifying experience, though, participating in the November presidential elections from afar seemed to accentuate the distance between the American Jewish voters here and those back in the United States.

title: Cities Enticed by Pay-if-You-Save Energy Deals
description: WHEN the city of Brea, Calif., about 25 miles southeast of Los Angeles, set out to reduce its carbon emissions and save money on energy costs, the challenge was the same faced by many other cities nationwide: allocating the funds to pay for the program.

title: Maybe Not a Must Win, but Ohio Is Surely a Vital Prize
description: The supposition that Ohio is the most important state in presidential elections is not always true. The decisive state in the 2000 election, of course, was Florida. Al Gore also could have won by carrying New Hampshire or Missouri, both of which were slightly closer than Ohio that year.

title: 4 Children Killed in Afghanistan Firefight
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A firefight that raged for an hour between international forces and the Taliban in eastern Afghanistan killed four children who were in the area grazing their sheep and goats, local officials said.

title: College Football Rankers by the Dozen Ask the No. 1 Question
description: Every college football fan has an opinion on who the best teams are, based on observation or perhaps gut instinct.

title: Wallace Hopes to Scrimmage by Friday
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rasheed Wallace knows there is a difference between running a mile on a treadmill and running a mile on the track in competition.

title: Report Faults French Police Over Killings
description: PARIS  In a highly critical report made public on Tuesday, police inspectors detailed a string of objective failures by French security and intelligence services regarding Mohammed Merah, the self-proclaimed jihadist who shot and killed seven people in southern France in March.

title: Credit Card Data Breach at Barnes & Noble Stores

description: CARLOS F. COIMBRA knew from the outset that he would have to crack the code of clouds. As an engineering professor new to the University of Californias campus in Merced, he led a successful drive to get 15 percent of the schools power from an array of solar panels.

title: Safety Becomes a Concern With High-Caffeine Drinks
description: Among the latest entrants in the energy industrys caffeine race is a pocket-size squeeze bottle called Mio Energy.

title: The Whiff of Conflict Grows in Mali
description: BAMAKO, Mali  A military strike to recapture Malis Islamist-held north is growing more likely, according to Western powers, regional bodies and the United Nations  a pronounced shift after months of hesitation and hopes that negotiations might end what is now seen as a far-reaching jihadist threat.

title: Questions Linger on Battery Prices in Electric Cars
description: THE battery maker A123, a producer of lithium-ion cells for hybrid cars made by General Motors and Fisker Automotive that was founded in 2001 by MIT scientists, filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 16. ReVolt Technology, a maker of zinc-air batteries with a North American headquarters in Portland, Ore., called it quits last week. Another battery company, Ener1, went bankrupt in January.

title: Candidate Defeated in Primary for Assembly Seeks New Vote
description: Updated Wednesday, 1:10 p.m. |  A candidate who said that a state assemblywoman had committed rampant and aggressive electioneering in and around polling places in the Bronx on Primary Day asked an appeals court panel on Tuesday to grant his request for a new vote.

title: Apple Has Only One Place to Go: Your Wall
description: Apple sure sells a lot of different-sized rectangles.

title: Egyptian Court Declines to Rule on the Legality of Drafting a New Constitution
description: CAIRO  A court declined on Tuesday to rule on the legality of the committee drafting Egypts Constitution, dealing a setback to critics who have called the committee unrepresentative and too heavily dominated by Islamists.

title: Louisiana: Racially Based Attack Is Debunked
description: A 20-year-old black woman who was found badly burned in a park in northern Louisiana on Sunday night had tried to make the episode appear to be a racially motivated attack, the authorities said on Tuesday. The police in Winnsboro said in a news conference Tuesday that an investigation showed that her injuries had been self-inflicted and that her DNA had been found on a bottle of lighter fluid used to start a fire, but they did not give details or a motive. The woman had told authorities that three men had doused her with a flammable liquid and set her on fire. The letters KKK and a racial slur were scrawled on the hood of her car. The woman, Sharmeka Moffitt, is hospitalized in critical condition.

title: Paul Kurtz, 86, Humanist Publisher, Dies
description: Paul Kurtz, a philosopher whose advocacy of reason ahead of faith helped define contemporary secular humanism, died on Saturday at his home in Amherst, N.Y. He was 86.

title: Canadas New Pipeline Woes
description: OTTAWA  AND you thought pipeline politics in the United States were treacherous. Rebuffed by Washington on bringing the Keystone XL pipeline down through the western United States, Canada now finds that its Plan B  to build a pipeline to its west coast for shipping to Asia  has become mired in domestic politics thick enough to rival the tarlike oil it hopes to sell.

description: Jerusalem

title: Getting More Bang for the Feds Buck
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: A Humane Medicare Rule Change
description: A proposed settlement of a nationwide class-action lawsuit should make it easier for tens of thousands of disabled and chronically ill people to qualify for Medicare coverage. It is clearly the humane thing to do for desperately sick people with little hope of recovery.

title: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader was Abused, Groups Say
description: MOSCOW  Human rights officials said Tuesday that a jailed political opposition leader was held in a basement and denied food and water for more than two days and was forced to confess to charges of plotting mass riots in Russia, after being kidnapped from the streets of Kiev, Ukraine, where he had fled to avoid arrest.

title: On Wounded Knee
description: Russell Means, the Oglala Lakota Sioux protester, organizer and actor who led the American Indian Movement through an era of vivid, often violent protests in the 1970s, didnt win much in the way of fundamental political and social change. AIM had too much chaos and infighting for that. He didnt lead a life of exemplary activism: too many courtroom battles and bar brawls, too many guns. When he died on Monday, at age 72, few could look back at his turbulent living and showmanship and setbacks and render any verdict but: Mixed.

title: Court Upholds the Taxation of Lap Dances
description: Nite Moves, a strip club in Latham, N.Y., may have mastered the moves needed to extract dollar bills from its customers. But it had trouble with the moves that would block state tax officials from extracting dollar bills from its own bank account. A lot of dollar bills  124,921, to be exact.

description: A list of 63 Barnes & Noble locations where hackers are said to have gained customers credit card information as recently as September.

title: Pence Has the Giants Along for the Ride
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Outfielder Hunter Pence is the human defibrillator that shocked the World Series-bound Giants back to life with his motivational speeches in their division series victory against the Cincinnati Reds and with his bat in Mondays decisive game of the National League Championship Series against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Italy: Officials Quit Over Punishment of Quake Experts
description: Several members of Italys National Commission for the Forecast and Prevention of Major Risks resigned Tuesday after the conviction of six scientists and a public official on manslaughter charges for failing to give adequate warning to the residents of a seismically active area before an earthquake that killed more than 300 people. Luciano Maiani, a physicist, resigned as president of the commission, along with several other members in protest over Mondays ruling, in which the defendants have drawn six-year prison sentences. The commission cant carry out its functions in this situation, which borders on intimidation, he said in an interview. Its impossible to work with serenity if youre afraid that if you give an opinion that turns out not to be right you can be punished.

title: Russia: Draft Law Aims at Antigovernment Activity
description: Russias lower house of Parliament approved a draft law on Tuesday that would expand the definition of high treason and espionage, adding to a series of measures aimed at reining in antigovernment activity. Under the legislation, treason includes the transfer of sensitive information not only to foreign governments, but also to international or foreign organizations and their representatives. It adds an article to the criminal code that would criminalize the act of obtaining state secrets through means including deception, bribery, and coercion. People who obtain such information would face fines of $5,000 to $12,000 and prison sentences of up to eight years. The legislation needs approval from the upper house, where it is expected to pass.

title: Buying the Vote on G.M.O.s
description: Supporters of ingredients derived from genetically modified foods, which hereafter Ill call G.M.O.s  genetically modified organisms  are mostly the chemical companies who make them or other people who make money from them. They assert that a) theres no proof that G.M.O.s are harmful to humans, and b) studies demonstrating that they might be are largely flawed [1]. Point B might even be true, although since the chemical companies largely control the research, its hard to tell.

title: Sleek Tablet, but Clumsy Software
description: How would you like to move into a stunning mansion on a bluff overlooking the sea  in Somalia? Or would you like the chance to own a new Ferrari  that has to be refueled every three miles? Would you take a job that pays $1 million a year  cutting football fields with toenail clippers?

title: Appeal in Insider Trading Case Centers on Wiretap
description: In March 2008, the Justice Department made an extraordinary request: It asked a judge for permission to record secretly the phone conversations of Raj Rajaratnam, a billionaire hedge fund manager.

title: Our Secret Sauce
description: It was striking how much Mondays presidential debate on foreign policy came down to two subjects: America and the Middle East. The two actually provide some instructive contrasts, starting with one that Ive noted since the onset of this campaign: the contrast between the high degree of American pluralism and trust that makes our country work, and the near total absence of it in the Middle East, the region most vexing us and most likely to blow up on the next president. Muslims are killing Muslims across the Middle East and Central Asia today: Sunnis versus Shiites, Pashtuns versus Pashtuns and Kurds versus Turks. Christians are not faring well there, either. The absence of pluralism and the prevalence of rule or die politics  either my sect or party is in power or Im dead  is the dominant political trend in the Arab-Muslim region today. Nobody trusts anybody, but it is impossible to build a modern state or an innovation economy without trust. Meanwhile, here in America, we are debating whether to replace our first black president  whose middle name is Hussein and whose grandfather was a Muslim  with a Mormon! Who does that? Nobody else. That radical pluralism is the secret of our sauce, and blessedly so. America, take a bow.

title: Does a Fallen Leader Crush His Cause?
Obama and Romney Offer Competing Visions in Dueling Ads
description: With all three debates in the rearview mirror and two weeks to go until Election Day, each campaign turned on Tuesday to making its most persuasive case, in 60-second ads, for why its candidate deserves the presidency.

title: The Austerity Trap
description: In Monday nights presidential debate, Mitt Romney echoed other Republican politicians, saying that under President Obamas economic policies, the United States is heading toward Greece. Mr. Romney was invoking Greece apparently to make the point that deep and swift budget cuts are needed in the United States to avoid a debt crisis.

description: The hackers picked the one day of the year they knew they could inflict the most damage on the worlds most valuable company, Saudi Aramco.

description: Depending on who is doing the talking these days, New York State is either a national model of how to curb Medicaid spending, or the nations prime example of Medicaid abuse.

description: DOVER, N.H.  The agenda for the Oct. 1 school board meeting did not call for anything particularly exciting. But during a segment called Matters of Interest, Paul Butler, a retired doctor and relative newcomer to the board, floated an idea: end the football program at Dover High School.

title: U.S. Disavows Patent at Center of Apple-Samsung Dispute

title: Simple but Local, Queens Slots Are Hurting Gambling Meccas
description: A casino that opened a year ago at the fading Aqueduct horse racing track in Queens has emerged as the countrys highest-grossing slot parlor, helping to reshape the gambling landscape in the Northeast as patrons chose less opulent, more local casinos instead of traditional gambling meccas in Atlantic City and Connecticut.

description: For a moment it looked as if Mitt Romneys chances of becoming the next president were up, way up.

Herndon gave the ball to the Tigers closer, Willie Hernandez, but wears his championship ring every day.

title: Your Mom Just Died. Lets Go to Disney World.

Gils mother is dead too, but his life is no fairy tale. At 40 hes still recovering from a breakup with a boyfriend, hes all but given up on his career as an actor, and hes the sourpuss spreading gloom at Disney World.

description: The body in extreme states  of power, of virtuosity, of distress  is a potent, politically charged metaphor in hip-hop. Though the culture has long since become a worldwide pop phenomenon, its South Bronx roots are inextricably bound with histories of resistance, struggle and celebration.

In Neutral Hero, the remarkable new play that opened on Tuesday night at the Kitchen, Mr. Maxwell is hunting for the epic in the Everyday.

They had picked up the skill living in parts of the Middle East where alcohol was banned. It was pretty good, and Mr. Hindy learned to make it himself when he and his family moved back to New York in 1984. Their old neighborhood on the Upper West Side of Manhattan had gotten too expensive, so they found a two-bedroom apartment in a part of the city that a family with young children could afford. It was Park Slope.

title: China: Tibetan Advocates Report Self-Immolation

Tibetan activist groups contend that the Chinese government represses the Tibetan people and denies them religious freedom, allegations that Beijing officials strongly deny. The self-immolations this week followed dozens of others by Tibetans since 2009.

title: Sanctuary for Abused Bears in Vietnam Is Facing Eviction

And all manner of animal organs and body parts are still prized in traditional medicines  tiger penis, deer musk and antlers, snake blood and hearts, bear bile and paws. Elephants in Vietnam have been hunted so aggressively for their ivory that only a few dozen remain.

title: The Island Where People Forget to Die
description: In 1943, a Greek war veteran named Stamatis Moraitis came to the United States for treatment of a combat-mangled arm. Hed survived a gunshot wound, escaped to Turkey and eventually talked his way onto the Queen Elizabeth, then serving as a troopship, to cross the Atlantic. Moraitis settled in Port Jefferson, N.Y., an enclave of countrymen from his native island, Ikaria. He quickly landed a job doing manual labor. Later, he moved to Boynton Beach, Fla. Along the way, Moraitis married a Greek-American woman, had three children and bought a three-bedroom house and a 1951 Chevrolet.

description: Two years ago, when Google first advertised Chromebooks  laptops that store everything online, without a hard drive or desktop software  the tagline at the end of the ad was, Ready when you are.

title: Heart of Brass
description: Carl Aubck has a venerable history and more than 4,500 products to its name, yet the century-old Viennese design company remains relatively obscure. It always struck me as strange that people in design who seem to know everything about everything dont know anything about this, says Brian Janusiak of Project No. 8, who worked with the Austrian photographer Clemens Kois on Carl Aubck: The Workshop, out this month from powerHouse Books. Even those who have made a sport of hunting for Aubcks signature brass hands and bookends may be surprised to learn that since 1912, the company has been led by four Carl Aubcks, one of whom palled around with Walter Gropius. Or that their wares encompass a staggering range of typologies, from paperweights to oddities like sculptural pipe racks, cookie holders and paintbrush stands. As Kois points out, after World War II we werent allowed to be loud. No one realized we were making such cool things.

title: Big Data in More Hands
description: Business people, Big Data is coming for you.

title: The Family Doctor, Minus the M.D.
description: The Family Health Clinic of Carroll County, in Delphi, Ind., and its smaller sibling about 40 minutes away in Monon provide full-service health care for about 10,000 people a year, most of them farmers or employees of the local pork production plant. About half the patients are Hispanic but there are also many German Baptist Brethren. Most of the patients are uninsured, and pay according to their income  the vast majority paying the $20 minimum charge for an appointment. About 30 percent are on Medicaid. The clinics, which are part of Purdue Universitys School of Nursing, offer family care, pediatrics, mental health and pregnancy care. Many patients come in for chronic problems: obesity, diabetes, hypertension, depression, alcoholism.

title: Envoy Announces Tentative Cease-Fire in Syria, but Doubts Remain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lakhdar Brahimi, the envoy trying to broker a peace deal in Syria, on Wednesday announced a seemingly unlikely cease-fire between the two sides to mark the main Muslim holiday of the year, and the United Nations Security Council unanimously endorsed his effort.

title: Collective Rebuttal Delivered in Third-Party Debate
description: Even though a debate featuring third-party presidential candidates was supposed to highlight the breadth of ideological diversity in American politics, Larry King, the moderator, had to remind the four nominees that they had to actually disagree about something to issue a rebuttal.

title: The Economic Consequences of Mr. Osborne
description: Schularick and Taylor have an update to their article on post-crisis economic performance. They previously showed that the United States is doing a bit better than one might have expected from the historical record. Now they show that the UK is doing significantly worse:

title: Streaming Me
description: Ill be live at Huffington Post at 10:30. Then off to Lubbock.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama as Star in SEAL Team Six
description: SEAL Team Six, the television drama about the raid on Osama bin Ladens compound that will be broadcast on National Geographic Channel two days before the election, gives President Obama a starring role in the events, Michael Cieply writes in The Times. The film, which was purchased by Harvey Weinstein and re-edited under his supervision, is bound to be criticized by conservatives as favoritism and hagiography.

title: Transit Initiatives Are Giving a Boost to Businesses, a Report Says
description: The Bloomberg administration has long trumpeted the safety benefits of its many roadway initiatives, hoping to rebuff critics who consider the policies to be undue interventions from a meddling city.

title: Malis Storytellers
description: BAMAKO, Mali  I had been waiting close to an hour for my coffee date when I ran into the colonel. Like many of Bamakos power brokers, the 50-something officer, who is a friend, often conducts business on the broad terrace of the Lebanese caf where we met. He always wears spotless gowns of the richest fabric and expensive European cologne.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Observer: Why Il Mulinos fickle magic works on the Upper East Side but less so in places like Houston or Chicago.  Susan Edgerley

title: Visa Names JPMorgans Scharf as Its New Chief
description: Visa announced on Wednesday that it had named Charles W. Scharf, a former head of JPMorgan Chases vast retail arm, as its new chief executive, as Visas current leader prepares for retirement next year.

title: For Whom Golden Parachutes Shine
description: Golden parachutes, those packages that reward top executives if their company is acquired, have attracted much attention from investors and public officials for more than two decades. Defenders of golden parachutes believe that they provide executives with incentives to facilitate a sale of their companies. While the evidence confirms this, it indicates that golden parachutes have significant costs as well and might fail to serve the interests of shareholders over all.

title: Human-Size Meals to Satisfy Hobbit Hungers
description: When your hobbit-hole has been used as a stomping ground by 13 unruly dwarves and an enigmatic wizard, and your weeks of wild adventures with them have introduced you to goblins, trolls, elves, wargs, Gollum and a sinister dragon, what you need next is a big breakfast. For those fans of J. R. R. Tolkiens fantasy novel The Hobbit  whose appetites have been whetted by months of promotion for Peter Jacksons coming film adaptation but cannot wait for the Dec. 14 release date of the first movie (of three)  the restaurant chain Dennys has stepped in to fill the void with a promotional menu offering food that they may or may not really have been eaten in Middle-earth. Is it nice, my precious? Is it juicy? Is it scrumptiously crunchable? Well, according to the science-fiction and pop-culture Web site io9.com, this special Dennys menu features authentic items like Bilbos Berry Smoothie; Gandalfs Gobble Melt (a turkey sandwich); Radagasts Red Velvet Pancake Puppies; and the Ring Burger (topped with what appear to be three onion rings to rule them all). Now, one does not simply walk into Dennys and order these Hobbit-related foodstuffs  at least not until Nov. 6, when participating restaurants will start offering them.

title: An Inspired and Personal Tempest Makes Met Debut
description: Getting a new opera to take hold is always hard. There are many stories of new works that were introduced by an opera company  maybe two or three companies, if the project is a joint commission  only to languish afterward, even when the public and critical reception was encouraging.

title: Leading Off: Welcome to Manager Roulette
description: It is that time of year, of course, when managers rise above their spot on the dugout steps, elevated to savior or run out of town with flaming torches and blamed for everything that went wrong in their now disgruntled city, including traffic accidents. The ones in between are getting those sideways glances from their employers, who wonder if there isnt a better one lurking around the corner.

title: Obama Camp Seizes on Republicans Abortion Comments
description: A revised version of this post is available here.

title: From Frontline, a Look at the Skeptics Advance
description: Less than 24 hours after the final presidential debate ended with the words climate change left unsaid, PBS aired a report that essentially explains the omission.

title: Solid Profit for AT&T Despite a Setback
description: AT&T says it is facing a temporary setback in growth partly because there arent enough new iPhones to go around. But it still made a solid profit in the latest quarter, and along with its main rival, Verizon Wireless, it remains a dominant force in the American wireless industry.

title: Be Brave, Little One
description: Next week is Halloween, and while the holiday is now more about accumulated treats than fearsome tricks, young children still think of it as a special occasion to feel scared. Not that they need one. The dark and frightful are daily occurrences. Two new books pay tribute to those little ones who manage to be braver than you might expect.

title: Greece Reaches Agreement With International Lenders
description: ATHENS  Greece has reached an agreement with its international lenders on a harsh new austerity package and a brace of controversial labor market reforms, the countrys finance minister said Wednesday.

title: Many in Middle Class Guess on Retirement Needs
description: Three-fourths of middle-class Americans say their estimate of what theyll need to live on in retirement is based on some sort of guess, a new survey finds.

title: Scratch the Surface, Two Picassos Revealed
description: Picassos Woman Ironing was recently cleaned and restored by  the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York. Click and drag your mouse over the painting to see what was hidden beneath it.

title: Under One Picasso, Another
description: Picasso was just 22 through most of 1904, the year he is thought to have painted Woman Ironing, a haunting image in muted tones of blue and gray of a skeletal woman, her eyes hollow, her cheeks sunken, pressing down on an iron with all her might. Money was tight for him. He was living in Paris, and he would often start a painting, abandon it and begin another using the same canvas, a practice he continued throughout his career.

title: Send Us Your Halloween Pumpkin Photos
description: Updated  We are no longer accepting submissions.

title: Fuse Sets Dec. 7 Return for Billy on the Street
description: Being accosted on the street by a crazy person who shouts in your face? Thats a standard, everyday occurrence in New York. Being stopped by a crazy comedian who shouts pop-culture trivia questions at you and occasionally offers you cash prizes and other random rewards? Thats a television show.

title: Art in Residence
description: Undulating and forbidding, Oscar Niemeyers 1966 Edifcio Copan in the heart of downtown So Paulo is one of the largest residential buildings in the world. It is home to thousands of people, about 70 businesses, and, as of September, a contemporary art center, Piv. The space was abandoned for the last 20 years, says the artist Fernanda Brenner, who founded Piv with a small team that includes the art historian Marta Ramos  and the producer Tyaga Sa Brito. The labyrinthine layout, pieced together from a former storage space, a dental clinic and a storefront, may have made the location a hard sell, but at 38,000 square feet, it is an interesting place to display artwork. For the first round of shows, Piv enlisted two local galleries and an independent curator to present projects that largely respond to or intervene with the architecture of the site. Piv is dedicated to process and experimentation rather than to finished products, Brenner says, and to promoting a dialogue between contemporary art and its place in the city.

title: Brooklyn Lures a Second Team to Barclays Center
description: Brooklyn, which has been without a professional sports team for half a century, is suddenly home to two after the announcement on Wednesday that the New York Islanders would leave suburban Nassau County for the new Barclays Center in 2015.

title: A Security Breach
description: Business Day Live: Hackers attack Barnes & Noble. | Safety of some energy drinks becomes a concern. | Selling coffee in a Starbucks world. | Corporate Americas wariness over the economy.

title: Hoping to Skip Japan League for U.S.
description: In their own ways, Masanori Murakami, Hideo Nomo and Hideki Irabu broke ground by leaving Japan to pitch in the United States. Shohei Otani wants to join the list of pioneering pitchers.

title: Democratic Party Official in Queens Faces Corruption Charges
description: Updated, 9 p.m. |  A Queens district leader and two-time candidate for the City Council surrendered to federal authorities on Wednesday to face corruption charges, including mail-fraud conspiracy and obstruction of justice, stemming from what prosecutors said were campaign-finance improprieties.

title: Wheelies: The $272,000 Question Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Nathan Lane Will Return to Broadway in The Nance
description: Lincoln Center Theater made it official on Wednesday and announced that it would present Nathan Lane in Douglas Carter Beanes play The Nance, marking Mr. Lanes return to Broadway after a two-year absence. Mr. Lane, a two-time Tony Award winner, last appeared on Broadway in 2011 in The Addams Family, and said in June that the new play by Mr. Beane (the author of The Little Dog Laughed and book writer for Xanadu and Lysistrata Jones) would probably be his next project.

title: White House Releases Transcript of Talk With Des Moines Register
description: How badly does President Obama want to win The Des Moines Registers endorsement?

title: A Pizzeria Owner Learns the Value of Watching the Books
description: Pizza shop owners rarely are celebrated for their innovative company cultures, but Nick Sarillo is an exception. His use of open-book management, his efforts to help community groups raise money and his development of what he calls a trust-and-track management style have spawned a cover article in Inc. magazine and his own recently published book, A Slice of the Pie: How to Build a Big Little Business.

title: Business Day Live: Credit Card Data Breach at Barnes & Noble Stores
description: Hackers attack Barnes & Noble. | Safety of some energy drinks becomes a concern. | Selling coffee in a Starbucks world. | Corporate Americas wariness over the economy.

title: Boeing Posts Better-Than-Expected Profit and Raises Forecast for a 3rd Time
description: Boeing reported third-quarter profits on Wednesday that were better than analysts had expected because of sharp increases in aircraft deliveries. It also raised its earnings forecast for 2012 for the third time.

title: On Our Radar: Greening Formula One
description: As with so many other sprawling events, the challenge of limiting fossil fuel emissions related to the Formula One Grand Prix next month in Austin is limited by an inescapable fact: many thousands of people will fly in for the race, helping to generate emissions. [StateImpact Texas]

title: Reporting a Fearful Rift Between Afghans and Americans
description: SISAY OUTPOST, Afghanistan  How far is Kabul from the war? These days, if you drive south or west, no more than an hour and a half. You can go and be back for dinner  if you arent kidnapped or blown up.

title: What Price Growth?
description: Nick Sarillos dad always warned him about the dangers of trying to manage more than one restaurant location.

title: The Tempest at the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera introduced its production of Thomas Adss work on Oct. 23.

title: Channel Surfing: Mystified by Happy Endings
description: Happy Endings fans, help me out here. What am I missing? I see a situation comedy that has dispensed not just with jokes, but also, for the most part, with any straight-ahead attempt at comedy. Yet the show has survived into its third season, which began Tuesday night on ABC.

title: Oil Refinings Fortunes Rise
description: THREE RIVERS, Tex.  The refinery business has long been the difficult stepchild of the oil industry, expensive to run, prone to accidents and a low-margin headache for executives who preferred drilling for gushers.

title: Should the Islanders Keep Their Name?
description: With the news on Wednesday that the Islanders plan to move to Barclays Center in Brooklyn for the 2015-16 season, Slap Shot wants to know: Should the team keep its name? If not, what should the Islanders be called?

title: Part 3: Answers to Readers Questions About the SAT and ACT
description: Updated: We are no longer taking questions for this session.

title: The Burden of Justice: Louise Erdrich Talks About The Round House
description: Louise Erdrichs 14th novel, The Round House, was recently named a finalist for the National Book Award. Its set on the North Dakota Ojibwe reservation that is so familiar to her readers, and it tells the story of Joe, a 13-year-old who seeks justice after his mother is brutally attacked. In her review, Michiko Kakutani wrote that the novel opens out to become a detective story and a coming-of-age story, a story about how Joe is initiated into the sadnesses and disillusionments of grown-up life and the somber realities of his peoples history. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Erdrich discussed the difficulty of obtaining justice on reservations, the influence of her father on her fiction and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Nations With Difficulties Sag in Survey of Brand Images
description: In an annual study that ranks perceptions of the worlds nations as if they were consumer product brands, nations with problems have suffered dents to their images.

title: Foundation Cites Design Work That Benefits Society
description: Five firms from Brooklyn to Ramallah will share equally in an award devoted to the concept of design as a force for social good. The Curry Stone Foundation has announced that its 2012 Curry Stone Design Prize will for the first time be distributed among five recipients, in honor of the fifth anniversary of the award, which celebrates design as a critical force for improving lives and strengthening communities.

title: Second Finale for David Coulthard Lacks a Storybook Ending
description: Somewhat obscured in the close championship battle that concluded on Sunday, the season finale of the Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters series, was the retirement of David Coulthard from racing.

title: American Ballet Theater Signs On for Three Years at the David H. Koch Theater
description: American Ballet Theater, which presents a spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, will have a second Lincoln Center home starting next fall. The company announced yesterday that it would move its fall season from New York City Center to the David H. Koch Theater, also home to New York City Ballet. The move is part of a three-year agreement under which the company will present two weeks of performances at the theater every fall through 2015. The first season, which includes 12 performances, runs from Oct. 30 to Nov. 10, 2013. The move was hinted at in May.

title: Obama Kicks Off Eight-State Campaign Tour
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  Air Force One landed at Quad Cities International Airport at 9 a.m. Central Time on Wednesday, to begin President Obamas two-day round-the-clock attack on swing states. The 747 is scheduled to touch down at Andrews Air Force Base just before midnight Eastern Time on Thursday.

title: Hurry Up and Wait and Play Ball!
description: As hundreds of thousands of Billy Yanks and Johnny Rebs enlisted in the Union and Confederate Armies during 1861 and 1862, military and civilian officials and journalists from both sides recognized that soldiers who trained for deadly combat would need relief from their endless drills and chores. Among other activities, people on both sides urged soldiers to take up the relatively new sport of baseball.

title: Confused About Pensions? A Help Desk
description: Our expert this week, Mary Williams Walsh, will be answering questions people have about their pension plans. Ms. Walsh, a reporter for The New York Times since 2000, in Business Day, has written about how companies manage their pension plans; what happens when companies go bankrupt; public workers pensions and how they may affect state and local finances; and Chapter 9 municipal bankruptcy.

title: U.S. Accuses Bank of America of a Brazen Mortgage Fraud
description: 9:34 p.m. | Updated

title: College Financial Aid and the Older Parent
Penalties Will Draw Flags of a Different Color
