title: Eyeing 13 Mayoral Bid, de Blasio Focuses on Small-Business Issues
description: Bill de Blasio was pacing the conference room, listening to small-business owners in Long Island City, Queens, bemoaning municipal red tape, when he relayed the tale of a frustrated laundromat owner whose water bill was inflated, erroneously, by an extra zero.

title: Brother Against Microbe
description: On Oct. 27, 1862, the Confederate cavalry commander Jo Shelby filed a report on his brigades recent operations in Missouri. The colonel concluded with a sobering assessment of his troopers physical condition. Our men, from being so poorly clad, and owing to the excessive duties that they have been compelled to perform, are rapidly becoming unfit for service, he wrote. Our brigade reports now some 500 sick. We have a great many men without a blanket, overcoat, shoes, or socks. When the brigade was first organized, he went on, it numbered 2,319 men, and the greater portion were reported for duty until within the last few days. Since this cold spell of weather set in, our reports show but 1,068 men for duty. The increase in sickness in Jeans and Gordons regiments is 100 per day.

title: The Company Romney Keeps
description: The saying goes: A man is known by the company he keeps.

title: 4 Powerful Messages That Stand Out in a Sea of Advertisements
description: The number of presidential campaign ads that ran across the country in the last week was a staggering 80,000.

title: For Romney, Ties That Bind
description: In 1999, when Mitt Romney was put in charge of organizing the 2002 Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City, there was an unusual company among those angling to be Olympic sponsors. Along with the Coca-Colas and the McDonalds, there was a company called Nu Skin, based in Provo, Utah, that sold anti-aging products and nutritional supplements. Its distribution network is what is called, in the industry, multilevel marketing. Critics have another name for that kind of business: a pyramid scheme.

title: California Redistricting Fuels Competitive Races That Lure Outside Funds
description: ELK GROVE, Calif.  President Obama enjoys a gigantic lead in the polls in California, but perhaps nowhere is the fight over the House of Representatives fiercer and closer than in the nations most populous state.

title: Slow but Steady Improvement
description: The slow pace of the nations economic recovery has picked up a bit lately. In the third quarter, the economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent, beating expectations and the dismal 1.3 percent growth in the second quarter. Over the past year, the growth rate has been 2.3 percent. At that pace, theres enough momentum to keep unemployment, currently 7.8 percent, from getting much worse, but not enough to spur big job gains.

title: Mutual Fund Leaders Aim to End Jam Over Rules
description: Worried about a regulatory crackdown, mutual fund executives are pushing for limited restrictions on a controversial type of fund in an effort to end a bitter dispute between the government and the financial industry.

title: Obtaining Financial Records in China
description: Chinas political system is not very transparent, but corporate and financial information is often readily available to the public.

title: 5,800 Miles From New York, Ranger Finds Hockey and More
description: If a Rangers defenseman was in Astana, Kazakhstan, 5,800 miles and 10 time zones from New York, what would he expect to find? Probably not a mall with a beach inside.

title: Making Revolution Work
description: In Tripoli this week, there was no water for at least five days, huge heaps of garbage lined the highways and thousands of young men, most of them heavily armed, lacked meaningful work. As Libya reached the one-year anniversary of the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his regime, the countrys new leaders are not delivering on the revolutions promise and many Libyans are souring on democracy.

title: England: Belarussian Is Granted Asylum
description: Britain has granted political asylum to a prominent Belarussian dissident and former presidential candidate, Andrei Sannikov, his wife said Friday. Mr. Sannikov, who was imprisoned for 15 months after challenging Belaruss autocratic president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, in presidential elections in 2010, told the Charter 97 news service that he had fled the country in order to avoid arrest. Mr. Sannikovs wife, Iryna Khalip, has been barred from traveling outside Belarus.

title: China: Two Tibetan Self-Immolations
description: Free Tibet, a London-based activist group, said that Lhamo Tseten, 24, burned himself to death on Friday. It was the fourth self-immolation this week in an area that Tibetans call Sangchu County, and that the Chinese identify as Xiahe in Gansu Province. On Saturday, another activist group reported a fifth self-immolation. China has offered a reward of $7,700 for information about anyone orchestrating the immolations.

title: Races for House Offer Little Suspense but Lots of Odd Back Stories
description: WASHINGTON  In Michigan, a House candidate confessed that he had difficulty telling whether or not he is, in fact, Santa Claus. In Tennessee, a freshman Republican who is a doctor stands accused of impregnating a patient, then pressuring her to have an abortion.

title: Rise in Household Debt Might Be Sign of a Strengthening Recovery

title: Means to Enlightenment

Arent we supposed to labor intensely over the Saturday grid, sweating our way through the cryptically worded clues, setting off in numerous wrong directions, erasing and overwriting, only to land, exhausted but triumphant, on the hard-won completed puzzle?

title: Life Was in Chaos for Nanny Accused of Killing 2 Children
description: She was unraveling. Yoselyn Ortegas home was an overcrowded tenement that she yearned to leave. She shared the apartment with her teenage son, a sister and a niece, and roamed the halls selling cheap cosmetics and jewelry for extra money. She had been forced to relinquish a new apartment for her and her son and move back. A woman had chiseled her on a debt. Neighbors found her sulky and remote. She seemed to be losing weight.

title: Piecework and the Horror of the Jets
description: Halloween holds no fear for the childrens book author R. L. Stine, 69, who has said that nothing scares him. He has been writing fright into his books for 20 years with his Goosebumps series, which has sold more than 300 million copies. In addition to his other series, which include Fear Street, Rotten School and The Nightmare Room, the prolific Mr. Stine has written a new horror novel for adults, Red Rain, which is out this month. On Sundays, he sticks close to home on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jane, and their 6-year-old Cavalier King Charles spaniel, Minnie.

title: Tracking the Future of Satellites
description: Polar satellites, which orbit the earth from pole to pole, are a useful tool for forecasting major storms. But existing polar satellites are nearing or beyond their life expectancies.

title: Nanny Searches, Already Intense, May Become More So

description: The assault conviction of a Brooklyn man was reversed on Friday after a special investigation by the Brooklyn district attorneys office revealed he was the victim of mistaken eyewitness testimony and innocent of the crime for which he had already served two years in prison.

title: A Blended Clientele
description: Grata, a less-than-year-old restaurant on First Avenue near the Queensboro Bridge, has an elegant cuisine that blends the flavors of Italy and France, and one of those improbable New York clienteles that blends the personalities of its two owners: Mirso Lekic, a restaurateur who has been working in the neighborhood for 20 years; and John Cenatiempo, a stuntman and actor who can be seen these days in the Miami gangster drama Magic City on the Starz network. On any given night, the darkly sophisticated dining room might host stylish Sutton Place couples, professional mixed-martial artists, visiting Hollywood types, dancers from the strip club Scores down the street or  as on a recent evening  a multigenerational dinner party of Wall Streeters.

title: Art That Irked Energy Executives Is Gone, but Wyoming Dispute Whirls On
description: LARAMIE, Wyo.  The idea behind the sculpture that appeared on the University of Wyoming campus about 16 months ago was simple but provocative: a swirl of dead wood and lumps of coal, intended to show the link between global warming and the pine beetle infestation that has ravaged forests across the Rockies.

title: 2 Arrested in Shooting of an Off-Duty Officer
description: Two men wanted in the shooting of an off-duty officer who tried to foil their robbery attempt in the Bronx have been arrested and charged with attempted murder, the authorities said Friday.

title: Boyfriend Is Questioned in Killing of Woman and Death of a Baby
description: Though she was a petite woman, Luisa Rodriguez usually carried her newborn daughter by herself, in a large stroller, up four flights of stairs to their apartment in the Kingsbridge neighborhood in the Bronx, neighbors said.

title: Students Account Has Rape in Spotlight
description: AMHERST, Mass.  This year has brought news of student athletes charged with sex crimes at Boston University and at Temple, along with countless other less publicized cases. There have been claims that Wesleyan University tolerated a fraternity house where the abuse of women was common. A gang rape at the University of Massachusetts was reported just this week.

title: A Ducks Odd Path to Prestige
description: EUGENE, Ore.  After practice Tuesday, Kenjon Barner climbed inside his Camaro, an audacious combination of burnt orange and black stripes with No. 24 decals on the taillights. The engine purred. The bass thumped. Barner, a muscular running back with a Mohawk, pointed the car toward campus.

title: Qatar Is Becoming a Player in French Sports
description: PARIS  Long an underwhelming also-ran of European soccer, underloved by most everyone but the French, Frances top league has entered what seems a new era, one of eye-popping salaries and international attention. Behind the shift is a tiny desert peninsula in the Persian Gulf, Qatar, a nation with little inherent interest in French soccer but with outsize ambitions and the oil money to pursue them.

title: Where the Bones of Ships Are Laid to Rest
description: Stretching more than 21 acres along the Arthur Kill tidal strait, a salvage yard is the final resting place for several dozen ships.

title: A Death in Custody Puts Focus on Police
description: MILWAUKEE  Before he died, Derek Williams pleaded with police officers for help. For about 10 minutes, Mr. Williams, shirtless and handcuffed on suspicion of robbery, claimed he could not breathe, and then collapsed in the back seat of a police cruiser. Finally, the officers began to give CPR. By then it was too late.

title: Scandal Hints at Decline of U.S. Denominations
description: When World magazine, an evangelical Christian publication, reported last week that Dinesh DSouza, the outspoken conservative and president of the Kings College, a small Christian liberal arts institution in Manhattan, had checked into a South Carolina motel with a woman who was not his wife, the first obvious question was how a smart man could do something so ill-considered.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Oct. 27
description: Consumers are feeling wealthier, so they are still out there spending.

title: Depleted Knicks Take Closer Look at Wallace
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With the Knicks frontcourt becoming more and more depleted, Coach Mike Woodson could need significant playing time in the teams season opener Thursday from the most unlikely source on the roster: Rasheed Wallace.

title: South Carolina: State Computer System Is Hacked
description: A hacker broke into the states computer system, exposing 3.6 million Social Security numbers and 387,000 credit and debit card numbers, state officials said Friday. Gov. Nikki R. Haley said a hacker in another country had staged several cyberattacks on the State Department of Revenue since August. The authorities are urging anyone who has filed a South Carolina tax return since 1998 to contact state law enforcement officials to try to prevent identity theft. Ms. Haley said the authorities were working to find the hacker. My instructions to them were to slam him to the wall, she said at a news conference. All but 16,000 of the credit card numbers are protected by encryption, but hackers may be able to decrypt them, the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division said.

title: Teo and Toma Brought a Friendship to Notre Dame
description: All right, Manti Teo said to Robby Toma, before announcing to the world that he would play linebacker at Notre Dame, this is where we go our separate ways.

title: Pennsylvania: Judge Rules Against State Utility Panel
description: An appeals court judge on Friday ordered the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to cease its review of zoning ordinances in four townships, a process that has held up payments from a statewide levy on gas drilling to the municipalities, which are challenging a law restricting local control over the natural gas industry. Judge Keith B. Quigley of Commonwealth Court, who previously ruled that the law was unconstitutional, said the earlier ruling barred the commission from its review. Jennifer Kocher, a spokeswoman for the regulator, said it was reviewing the courts ruling.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,125 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Princeton Tops the Ivy League After 2 Dismal Seasons
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  It was midterm week on Princetons leaf-littered campus, heaping another layer of distraction onto a team suddenly burdened with expectations. Homecoming weekend had passed. A long bus ride to a road game loomed. And a newfound obstacle emerged for Coach Bob Surace and his staff: handling success.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Poets Gather in Exile, in Queens
description: ON a miserable rainy night on the outskirts of Jackson Heights, Queens, a couple of dozen people were gathered for an informal cultural experiment: How do you create a literary community in a place that does not even have a decent English-language bookstore?

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: John Johansen, 96, Last of Harvard Five Architects, Is Dead
description: John M. Johansen, a celebrated Modernist architect and the last surviving member of the Harvard Five, a group that made New Canaan, Conn., a hotbed of architectural experimentation in the 1950s and 60s, died on Friday in Brewster, Mass. He was 96.

title: Many Fleas, Growing Market
description: Two Brooklyn entrepreneurs, expanding a market whose vendors sold knickknacks and food, have built up a large business by providing platforms for small ones.

title: Eloy Gutirrez-Menoyo, Cuban Dissident, Dies at 77
description: Eloy Gutirrez-Menoyo, who went from fighting beside Fidel Castro as a rebel commander to spending 22 years in prison for trying to topple him, died on Friday in Havana, where he had lived his last years as a tolerated dissident. He was 77.

title: Saturdays College Football Matchups
description: Eleven unbeaten teams are left in the Football Bowl Subdivision. One is Ohio State, but because the Buckeyes are ineligible for a Bowl Championship Series game, lets consider them pigskina non grata. Not so for the teams involved in this weeks biggest matchups.

title: Kings of a Small-Batch Empire in Brooklyn
description: IN between bites of broccoli pecorino and sweet corn jalapeo fritters, Jonathan Butler and Eric Demby considered the candidate standing over the sizzling griddle in a conference room in Dumbo this month. They mulled her sauces and her sources.

title: Respecting A-Rods Feelings
description: Joe Girardi was so sensitive to Alex Rodriguezs feelings about being replaced by a pinch-hitter that Girardi made a call to the press box to tell the public-address announcer not to mention Rodriguezs name during that switch.

title: The 80-Year-Old Marathon Man
description: EVERY morning, Otto Mond, 80, gets out of bed and runs a mini-marathon at home.

title: The Long Run
description: Otto Mond, 80, plans to run in his 19th New York City Marathon this year.

title: When Crimes Feed Our Worst Fears
description: In the spring of last year, over the course of five days, several burglaries occurred in Brooklyn Heights, a neighborhood so untouched by disruptive incident that about the same time, I found a lost billfold in front of a brownstone; it had managed to spend the entire night on the stoop unmolested. As I learned when I opened it, the wallet, containing a credit card and about $60, belonged to the teenage son of my real estate broker.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: MIND GAMES Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why Diabolique (1955), Henri-Georges Clouzots thriller about the cruel headmaster of a boarding school (Paul Meurisse) whose wife (Vra Clouzot, above left with Simone Signoret) and mistress (Signoret) plot to kill him, is required viewing. The women drug him, then drown him in a bathtub and dump the body in a pool. But when the pool is drained, the body is gone. It is easy to see why the films distributors are earnestly asking audiences not to reveal how it ends, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. And it isnt only in the last reel that the surprises and the excitement are in evidence. The morbid fascination starts building before the picture is 10 minutes gone. By the time it is rolling toward a climax it is spreading the most delicious chills. It is a pip of a murder thriller, ghost story and character play rolled into one. The evening continues with Games (1967), at 10, starring Signoret as an aging cosmetics saleswoman and amateur medium who joins two Manhattan socialites (James Caan and Katharine Ross) in a series of novel pastimes, this one involving the seduction of an adolescent delivery boy (Don Stroud). And in Whats the Matter With Helen? (1971), at midnight, two mothers (Debbie Reynolds and Shelley Winters) move to Hollywood to start a talent school after their sons are convicted of murder.

title: How to Buy Art When Traveling Abroad
description: The Travel sections Emily Brennan sat down with Barbara Gladstone, owner of two art galleries in New York and one in Brussels that represent artists in London, Germany and Italy.

title: IHT Quick Read: Saturday, Oct. 27
description: NEWS  Sectarian violence in Myanmars western state of Rakhine has surged again in recent days, with 64 people reported killed in clashes between Buddhist and minority Muslim communities. More Muslims fled to overcrowded refugee camps, and the U.N. secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Myanmars transition to democracy could be jeopardized if vigilante attacks, targeted threats and extremist rhetoric are not stopped. Thomas Fuller reports.

title: Bangalores Female Trash Pickers
description: New rules that require Bangalores residents to sort their garbage aim to reduce inefficiencies in a system that has the city teeming with open dumps. The dumps attract cows, stray dogs and rats, and are a surprising sight in a city that prides itself as the Silicon Valley of India.

title: The Weekend Word: Tactics
description: Todays Times

title: One On One: Andy Greenberg, Author, This Machine Kills Secrets
description: Andy Greenberg is the author of This Machine Kills Secrets: How WikiLeakers, Cypherpunks, and Hacktivists Aim to Free the Worlds Information, published by Dutton Publishing. Mr. Greenberg, a Forbes writer, interviewed WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange three weeks before he leaked 250,000 State Department files, the largest release of classified materials in history. In that interview, Mr. Assange alluded to another leak  this time involving a major bank  that he likened to the Enron e-mails. Speculation that Assange was referring to Bank of America shaved $3.5 billion off the banks market capitalization. But that release never happened. Mr. Greenberg said he wrote the book, in part, to find out why. He traveled to cypherpunk hangouts all over the country and then the world  Iceland, Sweden, Bulgaria, Berlin  to meet Julian Assanges predecessors and those who seek to build the next WikiLeaks. The following is an edited interview about information and the subculture whose members fight  often among themselves  to free it.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Beekeeping is picking up in the state after years of decline, The Indian Express reported. Honey output has jumped from 300 tons to 597 tons since 2010, according to the article. Apiculture is creating job opportunities, state officials said.

title: The End of the Berlusconi Era, Maybe
description: LONDON  Berlusconi, Game Over, was the possibly premature headline on the Web site of Christian Family, an Italian Catholic weekly, as it recorded the nations shame at the fraud sentence handed down Friday to its most notorious politician and media mogul.

title: The Rite of Spring Still Grist for Discussion
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  It is a big weekend on the campus of the University of North Carolina here, and not only because the football Tar Heels host the archrival North Carolina State Wolfpack (to whom, ahem, they have lost in each of the last five years) on Saturday. Carolina Performing Arts Rite of Spring at 100, a season-long celebration of Igor Stravinsky and Sergei Diaghilevs epochal ballet, which had its premiere in Paris in May 1913, reached an early climax.

title: Groups in Florida Look to Highlight Changes as Early Voting Begins
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Before the supervisor of elections opened the main polling site here in Duval County at 7 a.m., a line of almost 100 people had already formed, snaking its way along the sidewalk of a strip-mall parking lot.

title: The New Physiocrats
description: Both Dean Baker and Josh Bivens weigh in Robert Samuelsons outburst at the New York Times for saying that the government can too create jobs. (He went so far as to call it flat-earth thinking). Sadly, Samuelsons attitude is widely shared  even, at least rhetorically, by Barack Obama.

title: Fortune Favors the Brave
description: For a few days there the Romney campaign was boasting a lot about having Big Mo  and the press corps actually fell for it, briefly. At this point, however, the reality seems to be sinking in: if Romney has Big Mo, it looks like this:

title: Floridas Voter Registration Statistics
description: As Floridas highly coveted voters began going to the polls on Saturday for the first day of in-person early voting at sites across the state, the state released new voter registration statistics that provided reasons for optimism and pessimism for both the Romney and Obama campaigns.

title: Urgent Warnings as Hurricane Sandy Heads to Northeast
description: More than 50 million people from the mid-Atlantic to New England braced Saturday for a potentially massive storm, as Hurricane Sandy churned northward on a collision course with another storm system that is sweeping in from the west.

title: Denial of Economics
description: Brad DeLong points us to Howard Davies, who accuses economists of being in denial, and of having had nothing useful to say in the crisis. The first part is definitely true for much of the profession; the second charge is just false. The truth is that basic macroeconomics, the stuff that is still taught in textbooks, has been very, very useful in this crisis. The problem is that half the profession and most policy makers turned their back on this kind of economics.

title: Highlights and Analysis: College Football Saturday
Two Teams That Have Seen It All (on Film)
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For many N.F.L. players, preparing for a division opponent is like studying for a drivers license test in a new state. Yes, a few tweaks or changes have been made since the last time they took the exam (no texting behind the wheel, please), but driving will always be driving and, for the Giants at least, the Dallas Cowboys will always be the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Variety: Ring Toss
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Confession: I love these. As with the acrostics, I love a puzzle where I can toggle back and forth between clues and answers, filling in the parts I know and reasoning my way through the rest of them based on my progress thus far.

title: New Giants No Longer Rely on One Player
description: Detroit

title: The 1912 World Series: Game 8 Lingers in Lore
description: A season whose start included a Red Sox home game played amid great pageantry to celebrate Fenway Parks centennial is concluding in historically circular fashion with a World Series involving the Giants, Bostons opponent in the 1912 World Series.

title: Major Power Failures Expected Across Northeast
description: Last Updated, 4:05 p.m. With high winds and heavy rain from Hurricane Sandy expected to topple trees and down power lines even before it is projected to make landfall late Monday or early Tuesday, utility companies and emergency management officials are urging people to prepare for widespread power failures that could last more than a week in some areas.

title: Romney Seeks Support in Coal Country
description: Mr. Romneys campaign is aggressively tapping into anger at President Obamas environmental policies throughout the Appalachian counties where the states coal miners live.

title: During Lockout, N.H.L. Coaches Try to Fill Free Time
description: SYOSSET, N.Y.  The Islanders Jack Capuano was back on the ice Monday with his assistant coaches for a practice that included drills and a spirited scrimmage. Only the Islanders were missing.

title: Kansas City Fans Witness Just How Far Midfielder Has Come
description: It has been a long ascent up soccers Mount Olympus for Graham Zusi.

title: In Dairy Industry Consolidation, Lush Paydays
description: THERE was a time not long ago when Gregg L. Engles was considered a genius in the dairy industry, a shrewd C.E.O. who had cobbled together a string of local businesses to create the nations largest milk bottler, Dean Foods.

title: In Final Days of the Race, Fighting County by County
description: WESTERVILLE, Ohio  President Obama and Mitt Romney are plunging into the final nine days of a multibillion-dollar presidential race focused not only on the seven most competitive states, but also on battleground counties within them that could tip the balance of an exceedingly close contest.

title: How the Jets Scored a Touchdown When Practice Didnt Make Perfect
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It is second-and-6 for the Jets from the New England 7. They trail the Patriots by 10 points with 5 minutes 49 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter. They do not want a field goal. They want a touchdown. They need a touchdown.

title: Fiorenzo Magni, Italian Cyclist, Dies at 91
description: Fiorenzo Magni, a bicycle racing champion whose fearlessness on descents and fortitude in difficult conditions earned him victories in Europes most prominent road races in the postwar years, often described as Italian cyclings golden age, died on Oct. 19 in Monza, Italy, north of Milan. He was 91.

title: Its Easy Being King
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: In Syria, Cease-Fire for Holiday Falls Apart
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The already tenuous truce called in Syria to observe the most important Muslim holiday of the year eroded markedly on Saturday as renewed armed clashes prompted each side to accuse the other of breaking the cease-fire.

title: Hitting the Reset Button on the Campaign
description: Its been a little more than a month since Mitt Romneys presidential campaign conspicuously declared a reset, when he was lagging in the polls and his prospects seemed grim. Its been a little more than three weeks since the first debate at the University of Denver, where Mr. Romney brimmed with confidence against a somnolent commander in chief and seemingly turned his election narrative around. In the second debate, Mr. Romney seemed to struggle to hold his own against a more forceful President Obama, who may have benefited from an assist from the moderator, Candy Crowley. The third debate, in which the topics were ostensibly restricted to foreign policy, took place last Monday at Lynn University in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Obama Abandoned Americans Killed at Consulate, Lawmaker Says at Romney Rally
description: PENSACOLA, Fla.  At a rally for Mitt Romney on Saturday, Representative Jeff Miller, a Republican from Florida, suggested that President Obama had abandoned the American ambassador to Libya and the employees killed in an attack on a consulate there last month.

title: U.S. Set to Sponsor Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will soon take on a new role as the sponsor of at least two nationwide health insurance plans to be operated under contract with the federal government and offered to consumers in every state.

title: Mistakes Are O.K., but Never, Ever Lose Your Passion
description: This interview with  Kevin Liles, founder and C.E.O. of KWL Enterprises, a talent management and brand development firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Perils of Feeding a Bloated Industry
description: THEY say the wheels of justice grind slowly, but should it really have taken more than five years for the Justice Department to discover that Countrywide Financial, the mortgage manias top creator of risky loans, dumped a load of that junk on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac?

title: Sunday Dialogue: Rethinking Marriage
description: Readers debate the roles of the state and religion in weddings.

title: Anxiety: My Monster, My Self
description: Artists illustrate what scares us.

title: Pentagon Reopens Program Allowing Immigrants With Special Skills to Enlist
description: Thousands of immigrants were so eager to enlist in the American military during the last two years, despite the strong odds that they could be sent to combat zones, that they signed a petition on Facebook asking the Pentagon to let them join.

title: From Calm Leadership, Lasting Change
description: SHE was a slight, soft-spoken woman who preferred walking the Maine shoreline to stalking the corridors of power. And yet Rachel Carson, the author of Silent Spring, played a central role in starting the environmental movement, by forcing government and business to confront the dangers of pesticides.

title: Williams Will Face Sharapova in Final
description: ISTANBUL  Faced with more of the best competition the professional tour has to offer, Serena Williams cruised again Saturday at the WTA Championships.

title: Fiscal Stimulus, Praised and Panned
description: To the Editor:

title: Innovation Also Means Finding Ways to Adapt
description: WHEN asked how the Elephant Trunk, a large, lockable mailbox, got its name, Vanessa Troyer laughed and rolled her eyes. You could tell she had been asked the question many times.

title: Summoning the Power of the Crowd
description: LAST time, this column ended with an unusual plea to Radio Shack. It was prompted by a publicist in the companys headquarters who had ceased all communications with the Haggler after corresponding, via e-mail, about an irate customer.

title: Welcome to America. Take a Number.
description: This fall my newspaper sent me to the United States to cover the elections. I brought my wife and two daughters, ages 8 and 9, with me.

title: Obamas Squandered Advantages
description: AFTER a couple of Cadillacs, a summer belly-flop abroad, a dismissive swipe at 47 percent of the population and a convention best remembered for Clint Eastwoods chat with a chair, Mitt Romney is seemingly tied with President Obama. He has a real chance. Its a remarkable turn of events, given how many errors hes made and how ill suited he is to this particular juncture in the American story. And to size up the situation honestly is to consider one conclusion as seriously as any other:

title: Here a Cliff, There a Cliff. But Then Theres the Fed.
description: ANYWHERE investors turned last week, they seemed to be approaching a cliff. But the Federal Reserve provided a margin of safety, and said it stood ready to do so for many months to come.

title: When Low Taxes Dont Help the Rich
description: AT first glance, moneys growing influence in politics appears impossible to challenge because of a powerful positive-feedback loop. Yet hope remains.

title: Crossing the Ocean to See a One-of-a-Kind Horse
description: BERKSHIRE, England  At Ascot Racecourse, celebrations of a horses performance can be subdued compared with the happy hollering at big races in the United States.

title: She Went for Broke, and Found a Job
description: I FOUND my dream job in New York after writing an e-mail version of one of those half-court basketball shots. In a state of post-graduation anxiety early this year, I had paused from my rsum tweaking and cover-letter editing to acknowledge that I was at a loss. Thats when my gut persuaded me to e-mail an author I had never met, and to ask her for advice.

title: Critical Thinkers
description: The prophetic tradition of speaking truth to power, regardless of political winds or social pressures, has a long history.

title: Storm Forces Romney to Cancel Sunday Events in Virginia
description: PENSACOLA, Fla.  The Romney campaign has abruptly canceled a busy day of rallies scheduled for Sunday in Virginia as a major storm approaching the East Coast began to significantly disrupt the final days of a closely contested presidential race.

title: Drumming for the Stars
description: I GREW up in Chevy Chase, Md., in a musical household. My mother sang and danced at Arena Stage in Washington, my brother played the trumpet, and my sister played the flute. When I was 10, a kid in the next cabin at summer camp had a pair of drumsticks and a practice pad that I thought were cool. I asked my parents to buy them for me, but I had studied and dropped both trumpet and piano, so my father made me earn half the money first.

title: My Monster, My Self
description: In the spring, Edvard Munchs 1895 work The Scream, one of the artists now-iconic depictions of terror, sold for $119.9 million at Sothebys, setting a record for any work of art sold at auction. This was no Water Lilies. We obviously put a high price on our sense of dread.

title: Geoengineering: Testing the Waters
description: FOR almost 20 years, Ive been spending time on a craggy stretch of British Columbias shoreline called the Sunshine Coast. This summer, I had an experience that reminded me why I love this place, and why I chose to have a child in this sparsely populated part of the world.

title: Beating Odds in a Season of Improbable Comebacks
description: Brian Billick once received as a gift a book by Knute Rockne. Rockne, who developed a passing offense that helped ignite footballs early appeal, wrote that if coaches had to choose between a good offense and a good defense, they should always choose offense, said Billick, a former Baltimore Ravens coach and current NFL Network and Fox analyst. Rocknes reasoning resonates even 80 years after his death: with a good offense, a team is never out of a game.

title: Four Myths About Doctor-Assisted Suicide
description: Philadelphia

title: The European Left and Its Trouble With Jews
description: LONDON

title: European Union Exit? Concerns Grow for Britain
description: LONDON  Is Britain moving inexorably toward the European Unions exit door?

title: New Jersey Governor on Hurricane Sandy
description: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie held a news conference Saturday announcing mandatory evacuations along the Jersey Shore ahead of Hurricane Sandy.

title: How Prisoners Make Us Look Good
description: A FEW years ago, the sociologists Becky Pettit and Bryan Sykes tried to quantify a worrisome phenomenon: the growing proportion of black men imprisoned by age 20. Focusing on those born between 1975 and 1979 who later dropped out of high school, they noticed an anomaly. Our initial efforts, Dr. Pettit recalls, implied that more young, black, low-skill men had been to prison than were alive.

title: For Obama, a Balancing Act of Campaigning and Preparing for a Big Storm
description: NASHUA, N.H.  With 10 days to go until Election Day, President Obama stuck to his plans Saturday and exhorted supporters at a rally here to help him win this states tiny but potentially significant four Electoral College votes.

title: Teaching Lessons
description: How do we help students achieve academically and socially? As a teacher, I have lofty answers. But challenges  and questions  arise when I try to translate my ideas (and ideals) into concrete lessons, delivered in 90-minute increments to a very particular set of sixth graders, each as individual and evanescent as a snowflake.

title: Will Snakes Inherit the Earth?
description: NAMED P-52, as if she were a fighter plane or a precious fragment of papyrus, the Burmese python recently found in the Everglades weighed 165 pounds and stretched 17 feet in length  a local record. (Not a world record  that was set by a 403-pound, 27-foot-long python living in an Illinois zoo.) A tan beauty, with black splotches, dry satiny skin, and a body like a firm eraser, P-52 had a pyramidal head, a brain surging with raw instinct and tiny black Sen-Sen eyes. In her heyday, she could squeeze the life out of an alligator or a panther. And she was pregnant.

title: Russian Billionaire Says He Will Concentrate on Politics
description: MOSCOW  Amid heightening pressure on leaders of Moscow street protests, the billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov announced on Saturday that he was setting aside his business interests altogether to devote his attention to politics.

title: Saving Your Own Skin
description: Pittsburgh

title: John Terry: Chelseas Dark Knight
description: LONDON  John Terry has played soccer for Chelsea for 14 years, eight of them as captain, at a time when the team has never been more successful. He hates to miss a match. He plays injured. He plays hard. He plays as if every moment mattered more than every other moment. He plays with a fierceness and a focus that do not waver even when he is being baited and taunted by opposing fans, which is often the case. When he plays, even in away matches, Chelsea fans proudly unfurl a banner: JT: Captain, Leader, Legend.

title: Prince & the Panda: A Not-So-Grimm World Series Fairy Tale
description: ONCE upon a time, 29 long years ago, a baseball player named Cecil Fielder sat one evening by his hearth and poked the fire, while his wife sat opposite, spinning. He said, What a sad thing it is that we have no children.

title: 30 Seconds With Karl Nelson
description: Karl Nelson was a key member of the offensive line on the 1986 Giants team that won Super Bowl XXI. He was found to have Hodgkins disease, a cancer of the lymphatic system, and missed the next season. Nelson retired from the N.F.L. in 1989.

title: President in Shining Armor
description: FAR in the future, long after todays partisan passions have cooled, some enterprising womens studies doctoral student will be able to write a fascinating dissertation on the rhetoric and iconography surrounding gender in Barack Obamas 2012 campaign.

title: Recap: Philadelphia 0, Red Bulls 3
description: 6:40 p.m. | Updated With D.C. United Result At least for two hours Saturday afternoon, the Red Bulls nosed their way into second place in the Eastern Conference of Major League soccer. But it didnt last.

title: Of Mad Men, Mad Women and Meat Loaf
description: WASHINGTON

title: Why I Am Pro-Life
description: HARD-LINE conservatives have gone to new extremes lately in opposing abortion. Last week, Richard Mourdock, the Tea Party-backed Republican Senate candidate in Indiana, declared during a debate that he was against abortion even in the event of rape because after much thought he came to realize that life is that gift from God. And even when life begins in that horrible situation of rape, that it is something that God intended to happen. That came on the heels of the Tea Party-backed Republican Representative Joe Walsh of Illinois saying after a recent debate that he opposed abortion even in cases where the life of the mother is in danger, because with modern technology and science, you cant find one instance in which a woman would not survive without an abortion. Health of the mother has become a tool for abortions anytime, for any reason, Walsh said. That came in the wake of the Senate hopeful in Missouri, Representative Todd Akin, remarking that pregnancy as a result of legitimate rape is rare because the female body has ways to try and shut that whole thing down.

title: Want a Real Reason to Be Outraged?
description: THE silliness began when Todd Akin claimed during his Senate campaign in Missouri that in the case of legitimate rape, women shut that whole thing down to prevent pregnancy. Then, a few days ago, Richard Mourdock of Indiana seemed to blame God for such pregnancies, saying this was something God intended to happen. I think God should sue him for defamation.

title: M.T.A. Chief Announces Storm Plan for Subways, Buses and Commuter Trains
description: Updated, 8:20 a.m. Sunday |  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Saturday directed the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to begin planning for an orderly suspension of all subway, bus, and commuter rail service  a process that would begin at 7 p.m. on Sunday if a decision is made to shut down the system because of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Mile 19: Where Good Times Become Great Times
description: By the time the masses begin the 19th mile around East 97th Street, elite runners will have been resting comfortably for some time beyond the finish, perhaps enjoying lunch or a nice massage.

title: A Part-Time Life, as Hours Shrink and Shift
description: SPRING VALLEY, Calif.  Since the Fresh & Easy grocery chain was founded five years ago, it has opened 150 stores in California and positioned itself as a hip, socially responsible company.

title: Part Time, by Necessity
description: Tamara Green is one of the eight million part-time workers in the United States who would prefer full-time employment, and her shifts have been getting shorter and shorter.

title: Signs and Portents
description: If you drive around Princeton right now, you may notice a curious thing: there are a lot of Romney/Ryan signs, very few Obama/Biden signs. Now, Princeton does have a fair number of investment bankers in residence, but its nonetheless a pretty liberal town. Whats going on?

title: List of Swiss Accounts Turns Up the Heat in Greece
description: ATHENS  A former Greek culture minister, several employees of the Finance Ministry and a number of business leaders are on a list of more than 2,000 Greeks said to have accounts in a Swiss bank, according to a respected investigative magazine. The Greek magazine, Hot Doc, published the list on Saturday, raising the stakes in a heated battle over which current and former government officials had seen the original list passed on by France two years ago  and whether they had used it to check for possible tax evasion.

title: Missouri Senate Poll Shows McCaskills Lead Narrowing
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Missouri Senate race has narrowed to a dead heat, according to a new poll released on Saturday, a drastic turnaround since Representative Todd Akin, the Republican challenging incumbent Senator Claire McCaskill, upended the race with controversial comments about rape two months ago.

title: Matchup: Dolphins (3-3) at Jets (3-4)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Let It Snow
description: The ball was pink, the color of Breast Cancer Awareness month. The grass was green  and white.

title: Plight of the Part-Timers
description: In recent years, companies have increasingly used part-time workers who would prefer to work full time, especially in the retail and hospitality industries.

title: The Price of a Black President
description: WHEN African-Americans go to the polls next week, they are likely to support Barack Obama at a level approaching the 95 percent share of the black vote he received in 2008. As well they should, given the symbolic exceptionalism of his presidency and the modern Republican Partys utter disregard for economic justice, civil rights and the social safety net.

title: Matchup: Giants (5-2) at Cowboys (3-3)
description: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: New York Times Endorsements Through the Ages
description: A collection of The Timess endorsements for the presidency, from Abraham Lincoln in 1860 through the editorial boards choice of President Obama this year.

title: Barack Obama for Re-election
description: The economy is slowly recovering from the 2008 meltdown, and the country could suffer another recession if the wrong policies take hold. The United States is embroiled in unstable regions that could easily explode into full-blown disaster. An ideological assault from the right has started to undermine the vital health reform law passed in 2010. Those forces are eroding womens access to health care, and their right to control their lives. Nearly 50 years after passage of the Civil Rights Act, all Americans rights are cheapened by the right wings determination to deny marriage benefits to a selected group of us. Astonishingly, even the very right to vote is being challenged.

title: Tracking Voters Clicks Online to Try to Sway Them
description: A few weeks ago, Thomas Goddard, a community college student in Santa Clara, Calif., and a devoted supporter of President Obama, clicked on mittromney.com to check out the candidates position on abortion.

title: Mutant Verbs
description: What verb describes the act of creating a new verb from another part of speech? Verbify, of course  or, simply, verb. Both of these words are autological  that is, they exemplify what they describe. (Other examples of autological words: pentasyllabic, adjectival, nominalization.)

title: An Opinion to Consider Before You Vote
description: WHEN Jill Abramson, the executive editor, answered questions from readers this month on the Times Web site, she gave an unequivocal answer to a question about Times editorials.

title: If You Think Politicians Comments on Rape Are Silly, Look at their Policies
description: My Sunday column argues that if were going to be indignant about recent candidates offensive comments on rape, we should be even more outraged by offensive policies. Those comments reflect something broader and more insidious: an attitude that is skeptical of rape unless the victim is Snow White and she has been attacked by a stranger. Just look at the recent case of an Amherst student who says she was told not to worry, in effect, about being raped and not to try to change dorms.

title: Steven Yeun
description: Steven Yeun is a Korean-American actor who plays Glenn Rhee, a pizza delivery guy turned survivalist in The Walking Dead, an apocalyptic zombie drama on AMC, which has drawn the largest audience of any television series this fall.

title: Lakers Ensemble Cast Has Blinding Star Power
description: LOS ANGELES  A constellation of plastic is how Norman Mailer once described this city, and Dwight Howard, the Lakers big off-season acquisition, said he initially saw Los Angeles as many outsiders do: as a movie set populated by residents striving not to break character.

title: Oct. 26: State Poll Averages Usually Call Election Right
description: The FiveThirtyEight forecast model has found the past several days of battleground state polling to be reasonably strong for Barack Obama, with his chances of winning the Electoral College increasing as a result. The intuition behind this ought to be very simple: Mr. Obama is maintaining leads in the polls in Ohio and other states that are sufficient for him to win 270 electoral votes.

title: Cities Disagree on Texting-Driving Ban
description: Barbara Graff, an Odessa city councilwoman, knows the dangers of distracted driving. But that does not mean she wants to pass a law against it.

title: When Mass Hysteria Convicted 5 Teenagers
description: Mass hysteria always makes perfect sense when we are trapped in it. It can take decades  or even longer  before the crazed irrationality of a particular episode shows itself for what it was. That realization comes through with considerable force in a new documentary about the case of the five black and Hispanic teenagers who were wrongly convicted in the beating and rape of a young, white jogger in Central Park in the spring of 1989.

title: The Dead Have Something to Tell You
description: Seattle

title: What the
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  No, Michael Sharp and Caleb Madison do not have speech impediments. What they have for us today is a fun and punny theme wherein the word THE is inserted into phrases to give them a totally different meaning.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 28
description: Time is running out for President Obama and Mitt Romney to make their case and encourage their supporters to turn out to vote. With the polls showing a tight race, all eyes are on the swing states that could make or break the candidates.

title: Preparing for Sandy
description: Residents prepared on Saturday for Hurricane Sandy and the storm system that are threatening to batter the East Coast with persistent winds, drenching rains, extreme tides and heavy flooding.

title: Cubans and Tourists Recover From Sandy
description: Residents and tourists in Santiago, Cuba, try to return to normal life after Hurricane Sandy leaves a trail of destruction on its way north. Sandys winds and rains were blamed for 11 deaths in Cuba.

title: Protests Against Expansion of China Chemical Plant Turn Violent
description: BEIJING  A week of protests against the planned expansion of a petrochemical plant in the port city of Ningbo turned violent on Friday and Saturday when demonstrators attacked police cars and tossed bricks and water bottles at officers, according to accounts from participants posted on the Internet.

title: Al Qaeda-Inspired Groups, Minus Goal of Striking U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  One of the currents running through the presidential campaign has been a tacit but fundamental question: After 11 years of the war on terror, what kind of threat does Al Qaeda pose to America?

title: Who Had the Last Hit of the 1984 World Series? The Giants Manager
description: DETROIT  It was a hopeless cause for the San Diego Padres. Kirk Gibson had just launched a three-run homer to the upper deck at Tiger Stadium, punctuating a season of dominance for the Detroit Tigers. All that remained was the formality of the ninth inning to finish off the fifth and final game of the 1984 World Series.

title: A Deadly City for Migratory Birds
description: Toronto is one of the worlds most dangerous cities for migratory birds, with an estimated nine million dying each year after crashing into the citys glass towers.

title: New Museum Shows Off Las Vegass Neon Side
description: LAS VEGAS  On a night of proclamations crammed with the word whereas, a retired neon sign designer named Brian Leming offered a moment of levity.

title: Iraqi Sects Join Battle in Syria on Both Sides
description: BAGHDAD  Militant Sunnis from Iraq have been going to Syria to fight against President Bashar al-Assad for months. Now Iraqi Shiites are joining the battle in increasing numbers, but on the governments side, transplanting Iraqs explosive sectarian conflict to a civil war that is increasingly fueled by religious rivalry.

title: When Buildings Take Birds From the Sky
description: The Fatal Light Awareness Program estimates that one million to nine million birds die every year from run-ins with buildings in Toronto and surrounding areas. Here are studio portraits of some of the birds collected on Torontos sidewalks on Oct. 8.

title: Vegas, in Neon
description: The open-air Neon Museum in Las Vegas opened on Saturday after more than 15 years of effort.

title: Casualties of Torontos Urban Skies
description: TORONTO  In the shadow of the massive black towers of a banks downtown headquarters here was an almost indistinguishable puff of dark gray fluff on the sidewalk.

title: Coastal Surge Forecast From Hurricane Sandy Prompts Evacuations
description: The computer models  forecasting the track of Hurricane Sandy over the next three days are converging upon a landing around southern New Jersey that could create record coastal flooding and a big enough storm surge that state and local officials have ordered mandatory and voluntary evacuations along the coast from Delaware to Connecticut.

title: Highlights and Analysis of Game 3: Giants 2, Tigers 0
In Nevada Senate Race, Ethics Inquiry Looms Large
description: RENO, Nev.  Representative Shelley Berkley, battling for a Senate seat, flew to northern Nevada hours after appearing with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a rally in her Las Vegas district. On Oct. 19, before returning south for the start of early voting, Ms. Berkley crisscrossed Washoe County, the battleground where her image has been largely shaped by a barrage of television advertisements from her rival attacking her ethics.

title: Rubios Daughter Hurt in Accident
description: LAKEWOOD CREST, Fla.  Senator Marco Rubios 12-year-old daughter was involved in a car accident in Miami on Saturday, prompting the lawmaker to abruptly leave Mitt Romneys motorcade along a highway here.

title: No Charges Yet for Hospitalized Nanny
description: Law enforcement officials say there is little, if any, doubt that Yoselyn Ortega, a nanny for three children in Manhattan, fatally stabbed two of those children inside their Upper West Side apartment.

title: Shooting in Brooklyn Leaves 1 Dead and 1 Wounded
description: A man was fatally shot and another was wounded near the border of Gowanus and Boerum Hill in Brooklyn on Saturday morning, the police said.

title: An Alert Officer Foiled a Bank Heist
description: Suspicious behavior outside of a bank branch on the Upper West Side, a glimpse of an odd-looking gold-colored card used to withdraw money from an automated teller machine and a stealthy pursuit led to the arrests of two Canadian men on Friday night who, the police said, were carrying about 250 fraudulent A.T.M. cards and more than $50,000 in cash.

title: Potential Natural Disaster Plays Havoc With Candidates Plans
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Hurricane Sandys approach toward land on Saturday began to scramble the final full week before the presidential election, forcing Mitt Romney to call off a swing through Virginia and raising questions about how President Obama would balance governing and campaigning in the event of a potentially devastating natural disaster.

title: Mistakes Finally Catch Up to Florida, to Its Rivals Delight
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Like a dormant virus, Floridas flaws were always there, the inefficiencies waiting to infect the loss column.

title: Man Is Arrested in Killing of Woman and Baby in the Bronx
description: Police on Saturday arrested a 21-year-old man and charged him with murdering a woman and her 1-month-old daughter and then setting their Bronx apartment on fire last week.

title: Things I Saw  No. 39
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Three Talents Dominate the Young Generation
description: There was a time when a player who broke into the top 50 when he was a teenager or in his early 20s was regarded as a potential world champion. That was two decades ago. Now, even though there are more than a dozen young players among the worlds elite, few are considered championship material.

title: Texas Top 10 College Entry Rule Can Be Foiled by Reality
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: A Village Rape Shatters a Family, and Indias Traditional Silence
description: DABRA, India  One after the other, the men raped her. They had dragged the girl into a darkened stone shelter at the edge of the fields, eight men, maybe more, reeking of pesticide and cheap whiskey. They assaulted her for nearly three hours. She was 16 years old.

title: An Artists New Direction and the Bathroom Tile
description: HOUSTON  Trenton Doyle Hancock stood at the back of his art studio, a warehouse space in the Acres Homes neighborhood that is filled with piles of cut-up paintings that he has been recycling since his career began 12 years ago.

title: Des Moines Register Endorses Romney
description: Mitt Romney won the endorsement of The Des Moines Register on Saturday evening, becoming the first Republican presidential candidate to capture the newspapers recommendation to Iowa voters since Richard Nixon in 1972.

title: Knicks Rookie Realizes His Dream
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Chris Copeland had thought of the moment before, but he didnt want to think about it too much the past few days. He had impressed Coach Mike Woodson and his Knicks teammates, and he played well during the preseason.

title: Tea Party Senator Turns His Focus to Education
description: Senator Dan Patrick has a talk radio hosts comfort with publicly aired complaints.

title: Buckeyes Make the Most Out of Nothing to Gain
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Penn State fans wore white jerseys and white T-shirts and white ball caps to Beaver Stadium on Saturday. They carried white signs. They shook white pom-poms. They waved white towels.

title: Leyland Tells Tigers to Seize the Moment
description: DETROIT  Detroit Manager Jim Leyland said before Game 3 that he wanted his players to enjoy the moment of playing in the World Series and not be overwhelmed by facing a 2-0 deficit in the best-of-seven series. He told them to remember how much fun they had playing baseball as children, and how it should be almost the easiest thing for them to do because they have been doing it so long.

title: Giants Are Comfortable at Comerica
description: DETROIT  Lack of familiarity with Comerica Park should not be an issue for the Giants, who played a three-game interleague series here last season.San Francisco won two of three, including a 15-3 rout on July 2 when Pablo Sandoval and Brandon Crawford homered in a five-run first inning against Max Scherzer, who is scheduled to start for the Tigers in Game 4 of the World Series on Sunday. Barry Zito pitched six scoreless innings that day.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: October 28, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Troubleshooting Wingman Plotting Romneys Trajectory
description: BOSTON  When Mitt Romneys record at Bain Capital first came under assault, his beleaguered campaign staff turned to Bob White, an informal adviser. He quickly recruited researchers to conduct a deal-by-deal autopsy, searching for uplifting examples to share with voters to counter rivals accounts of exploitative ones.

title: Ex-Outsiders, Running on Record in Congress
description: MOLINE, Ill.  Congressional incumbency has its blessings, but in so many ways it was easier for Representative Bobby Schilling to run for the House two years ago, when he was slinging dough at his familys pizza place and tossing around barbs about Washington in his bid to be the first Republican to represent his corner of Illinois in a generation.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Oct. 28
description: Its almost like sharecropping  if you have a lot of farmers with small plots of land, they work very hard to produce in that limited amount of land.

title: On the Campaign Trail
description: President Obama and Mitt Romney are starting a 10-day sprint to the finish line in a contest increasingly about momentum versus math.

title: Chinese Premiers Family Disputes Article on Riches
description: HONG KONG  Two lawyers who said they represented the family of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China have issued a statement disputing aspects of a New York Times article about the familys wealth, a rare instance of a powerful Chinese political family responding directly to a foreign media report.

title: Second Opinion on Stoudemire Similar to First
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The timetable for Amare Stoudemires return to the Knicks remained unclear Saturday. But Dr. Thomas Carter, whom Stoudemire consulted for a second opinion on the ruptured cyst in his left knee, mainly agreed with the Knicks medical staff: Stoudemire should be healthy by roughly the end of November.

description: Among the key moments of the day, Marcus Lattimore left South Carolinas game on a stretcher, and Florida was upset by Georgia.
