title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures, Oct. 21-27
description: A look back at the week in politics.

title: What Is Momentum? Giants Seem to Own It
description: DETROIT

title: Irish Continue Quest for Perfection, Knocking Off Sooners
description: NORMAN, Okla.  Of course Manti Teo was there. Oklahoma quarterback Landry Jones had looked left  to Jalen Saunders, his go-to receiver all night  and tried to hit Saunderss midsection with a tight spiral. As the ball arrived, a Notre Dame defender rocked Saunders from behind, the ball ricocheted into the air and a stadium held its breath as Teo (who else?) dived and hugged the ball to his chest.

title: Chinese Censors Work to Quash Story on Vast Wealth of Prime Ministers Relatives
description: HONG KONG  Two attorneys in Beijing have released a statement challenging a story in The New York Times that documents some $2.7 billion in assets held by relatives of Wen Jiabao, the Chinese prime minister.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: JORDAN LYNCH The junior threw four touchdown passes and ran for two more scores, leading Northern Illinois to a 48-34 victory over Western Michigan. Lynch was 18 for 28 for 274 yards and no interceptions and carried 21 times for 136 yards for the Huskies, who have won eight in a row.

title: World Series Replay: Game 3
description: After a 2-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers, they have taken an authoritative three-games-to-none lead in the World Series.

title: Tie for Earthquakes, and for Wondolowski
description: Chris Wondolowski grabbed a piece of M.L.S. history for himself on Saturday night. But only a piece.

title: Giants Lincecum Is Special Weapon in Bullpen
description: DETROIT  Players love watching their managers postgame news conference on television after a winning World Series game. Tim Lincecum, the struggling regular-season starter turned unhittable postseason reliever, didnt need a TV to monitor Manager Bruce Bochys comments after Game 3 on Saturday night. He sat right in the interview room, waiting his turn at the podium with the winning pitcher, Ryan Vogelsong.

title: John Terry: Chelseas Dark Knight
description: Sarah Lyall profiles Chelsea defender John Terry in Sundays Times, taking a long look at a rare one-club man who also may be the most reviled man in English soccer. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 5 P.M. (BBC America) THE SECRET OF CRICKLEY HALL Based on the novel by James Herbert, this thriller begins a year after the disappearance of Cam, the son of Gabe Caleigh (Tom Ellis) and his wife, Eve (Suranne Jones, above), who are trying to start life anew with their two daughters in a seemingly perfect country house. But when cellar doors start to open on their own, the wailing of children echoes in the night and a cane-wielding specter makes its presence known, the family realizes the house isnt so idyllic after all. Just as they are about to move out, Eve hears Cams cries, and a desperate race to find the connection between him and the house ensues. This three-hour presentation delivers exactly what the phrase British mini-series promises for the American viewer: an old-fashioned story, ever so slightly dull but directed with a polish and restraint were not used to and with convincing performances from top to bottom, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. The story moves on parallel tracks 60 years apart  the haunted house and how it got that way  and while the devices are familiar (whining dogs, self-opening doors) and the plot twists unsurprising, the whole enterprise is so sufficiently literate and well acted that its easy to hang around to find out whos dead, whos alive and who will remain so. Among the weekends treats, Crickley Hall is the one you wouldnt want to trade with your brother when you got home.

title: In Cabinet Reshuffle, a Focus on Youth
description: In an effort to improve the electoral prospects of the governing United Progressive Alliance, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India inducted 22 new members into his cabinet, which was dominated by long-time party stalwarts, on Sunday.

title: Plot on U.S. Targets Cited in 11 Arrests by Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian counterterrorism police conducted a series of raids over the weekend leading to the arrests of 11 people accused of planning terrorist attacks on several high-profile targets, including the American Embassy here.

title: Arrest of 70s Rock Star Widens Sexual Abuse Case Tied to BBC
description: LONDON  The sexual abuse scandal surrounding the late television host Jimmy Savile widened Sunday after the British police arrested a former pop star in connection with the case.

title: What Color Is Your Princess?
description: Last Halloween, my 3-year-old son wanted to be a princess. Assuming this was similar to his robot and rock star phases, I broached the subject again a few days after his initial declaration. Bug, what do you want to be for Halloween?

title: Protests Over Chemical Plant Force Chinese Officials to Back Down
description: BEIJING  Officials in the coastal city of Ningbo, China, promised on Sunday night to halt the expansion of a petrochemical plant after thousands of demonstrators clashed with the police during three days of protests that spotlighted the publics mounting discontent with industrial pollution.

title: More Financial Crisis Denialism
description: I managed to avoid reading this Times profile of Glenn Hubbard until now. Wow. But let me leave the consulting stuff to others, and talk about the bad economics.

title: Sharp Warnings as Hurricane Churns In
description: Hurricane Sandy, a menacing monster of a storm that forecasters said would bring life-threatening flooding, churned toward some of the nations most densely populated areas on Sunday, prompting widespread evacuations and the shutdown of the New York City transit system.

title: Tracking the Storm
description: Millions of people across the mid-Atlantic region struggled to recover from widespread storm damage on Tuesday amid power failures, high winds, downed trees and powerful flooding. Transit shutdowns and school closings continued, the death toll from the storm rose, and people in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and elsewhere began assessing the aftermath.

title: Talk of a Wind Subsidy Phaseout
description: The wind industry, fighting to hold onto a generous tax credit set to expire in December, has been arguing that it does not need the support forever  just a little while longer, until it can compete with fossil fuels on its own.

title: Greenwich Village Spider to Emerge From Slumber to Bless a Halloween Parade
description: Not every spider hibernates. But the giant creature that dwells at the Jefferson Market Library in Greenwich Village, appearing once a year to climb the clock tower during the Village Halloween Parade, went into hiding after 2009, when scaffolding covered the library as part of a renovation project.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Whether it is Communist China or democratic, socialist India, corruption by top politicians seems to follow the same path, use the same techniques and yield the same results  politicians and their family members suddenly become rich as they become powerful.

title: Cloud Atlas Disappoints on Quiet Weekend at the Box Office
description: Moviegoing faltered over the weekend, as viewers turned their backs on a host of new films, from the silly (the Halloween romp Fun Size) to the surreal (the ambitious, soul-traveling epic Cloud Atlas). Argo, a hostage-crisis drama from Warner Brothers, now in theaters for its third week, had $12.4 million in domestic ticket sales, for a total of $60.8 million; it ranked first with an audience that barely turned out. Revenue for all films was down about 10.3 percent, to about $94 million from $104.8 million, compared with the same weekend last year, according to weekly estimates from Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office reports.

title: Hurricane Sandy Approaches East Coast
description: Forecasters warned of a life-threatening storm surge early Sunday.

title: Greek Editor Is Arrested After Publishing a List of Swiss Bank Accounts
description: ATHENS  The Greek police arrested and then quickly released the owner and editor of a respected investigative magazine on Sunday morning hours after he published a list of more than 2,000 Greeks who were said to have accounts at a bank in Switzerland, throwing new controversy into a scandal over whether the government is actively pursuing suspected tax cheats.

title: Band Tries to Stay Intimate, Even in a Cavernous Hall
description: From the grandiose movie-palace stage of the Paradise Theater in the Bronx on Friday night, Oliver Sim of the xx kept marveling at the size of the place. He recalled the Mercury Lounge show on the bands first New York City visit and addressed fans in the balcony as a million miles away. By now the xx has played festivals and other large gigs. But proportion and intimacy are crucial to the xxs songs, and with the release of its second album, Coexist (Young Turks/XL), the band is figuring out how to scale up as its audience grows.

title: Mind Games and Trash Talk in India, as Vettel Wins and Alonso Brags
description: NEW DELHI  A curious thing happened this weekend at the Indian Grand Prix outside New Delhi. Each successive victory by Sebastian Vettel of Red Bull seemed to imbue Fernando Alonso of Ferrari with ever more confidence.

title: I.B.M. Reports Nanotube Chip Breakthrough
description: SAN FRANCISCO  I.B.M. scientists are reporting progress in a chip-making technology that is likely to ensure that the basic digital switch at the heart of modern microchips will continue to shrink for more than a decade.

title: Hurricane Sandy: Covering the Storm
description: A 13-day chronicle of the devastating East Coast storm and its aftermath that killed more than 100 people, left tens of thousands homeless, crippled mass transit, triggered paralyzing gas shortages, inflicted billions of dollars in infrastructure damage and cut power to more than 8 million homes.

title: Knocking Out a Seat-of the-Pants Musical
description: Sometimes a movie is so awful that you worry you are doing yourself some form of harm simply by watching it. Combining painfully bad theater with awkward filmmaking, In the Night, Gtz Neumanns backstage musical, provided employment to actors and a crew, which is perhaps the best that can be said.

title: Recap: Chelsea 2, Manchester United 3
description: Wow. We will say it again. Wow.

title: Beyond Detroits Economic Woes and Series Deficits
description: This is more like it. This is the kind of place that can turn a disastrous World Series around for a Detroit Tigers fan. Its called the Motor City Bar, tucked into a vale of saloons on Manhattans Lower East Side, its walls covered with stuff guaranteed to thrum a native Detroiters heart strings  signs for Vernors ginger ale, the Bob-Lo Boat, the Bridge to Canada. Bolted into the bar are the chrome nameplates of Detroit cars that are music to any gearheads ears: Torino, Galaxie and Eldorado, Skylark and Valiant. The handles to the restroom doors are steering wheels from muscle cars. The only TV in the place is a battered little box perched on the bar. Enough said.

title: News Corp. May Bid for Penguin for Publishing Spinoff
description: Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, the parent company of HarperCollins, is exploring a cash bid for Pearson PLCs Penguin book division, a step that could ignite a bidding war for Penguin as the publishing industry begins to move toward consolidation.

title: Hurricane Sandy Darkens Broadway and Other Stages
description: 4:35 p.m. | Updated The impending arrival of Hurricane Sandy has led to widespread cancellations of performances around the region. All Sunday and Monday night Broadway performances have been called off, according to a spokeswoman for the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. Tickets purchased through Ticketmaster or Telecharge will be automatically refunded within 10 business days. Tickets purchased at theater box offices can be refunded or exchanged, subject to availability, at the original point of purchase.

title: Oct. 27: Minnesota Moonlights as Swing State, but Ohio and Virginia Are More Crucial
description: With the election so close, Saturday is no longer a day of rest for pollsters. Eight polls were released from potentially competitive states:

title: Junk Bonds Grow More Popular and Turn Even Riskier
description: Junk bonds are living up to their name again.

title: The Coast Empties Out as the Storm Moves In
description: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del.  Soon there will be nothing left to do here but welcome Hurricane Sandy.

title: The War on Objectivity
description: Brad DeLong points me to this National Review attack on Nate Silver, which I think of as illustrating an important aspect of whats really happening in America.

title: New York City Hurricane Evacuation Zones
description: There are three evacuation zones in New York City that are based on the strength of the hurricane making landfall. Mayor Bloomberg has issued a mandatory evacuation of Zone A.

title: Skewering Madison Avenue for 60 Years
description: FOR six decades, a magazine has been putting the Mad in Madison Avenue by lampooning  and frequently harpooning  the huckstering of the advertising industry.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Economic information to be released this week includes personal income and spending for September and the Chicago Federal Reserve Midwest manufacturing index (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index for August and consumer confidence for October (Tuesday); the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for October, construction spending for September, weekly jobless claims, retail sales for October and ADP employment for October (Thursday); and unemployment for October (Friday).

title: Complex Bach Is Illuminated
description: When the pianist Andrs Schiff took a break halfway through his magnificent performance of Bachs Well-Tempered Clavier, Book I, on Saturday night at the 92nd Street Y, the intermission seemed more for the benefit of his audience than for himself. This seminal Bach work has 24 paired preludes and fugues, one pair for each of the major and minor keys. Performing these intricately contrapuntal works from memory, Mr. Schiff played them almost without pausing, taking only enough time to set the mood for each piece.

title: With Each Step and Note, a Japanese Tradition Lives On
description: Folk performing arts are always in danger of disappearing, and dance in particular is at risk. After all, dance is largely an oral tradition; its survival depends on one generation passing knowledge onto the next. After the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan, alarm bells went off for the specific practice of Kuromori Kagura, which dates back more than 300 years and is named after a mountain and a shrine.

title: 100 Voices, but Only 2 Pairs of Ears
description: In creating Dispatches From (A)mended America two actor-playwrights  Brandt Adams and Godfrey L. Simmons Jr.  used the eve of Barack Obamas inauguration in 2009 as a moment to interview a hundred Southerners about race. As they present their findings, we learn about teary-eyed YouTube searches and racially motivated muggings, the Uncle Remus Museum in Georgia and the racist turducken of a holiday in Virginia that for a time commemorated Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. all at once. The problem is that those reminiscences all come from either Mr. Adams or Mr. Simmons.

title: The #Frankenstorm in Climate Context
description: As communities from the Carolinas to Maine brace for high storm surges, winds and downpours, theres a growing climate discussion building around #Frankenstorm, which is the favored Twitter handle for the extraordinarily vast and potent noreaster that is evolving as Hurricane Sandy, already a killer, collides with an Arctic cold front.

title: Channeling Coltrane With Sweep and Verve
description: To nonjazz musicians John Coltrane is spirit; to jazz musicians, he is grammar. To the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra he is both of those things and an opportunity  a way to display what it can do through flexible big-band reinventions and guest soloists. Although The Genius of John Coltrane, presented over the weekend at the Rose Theater with the saxophonist Joshua Redman as guest soloist, wasnt all new work  much of it has appeared in previous Coltrane concerts at Jazz at Lincoln Center  it served a useful example of what the institution does well, 25 years since its founding.

title: Boundaries? Dont Bother
description: Just off the coast of mainstream America is a land called Brooklyn, where life is devoted to creative pursuits, and cartographers are unemployed because residents  some native, but many settled in from far-flung origins  seem to reject the notion of boundaries.

title: Lots of Deep-Down Rumbles to Salute the Man of Bronze
description: A deep, satisfying rumble anchored the home stretch of Scott Robinsons first set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night. It came from a few different sources, including a theme terra, the sub-woofing bass drum rarely heard outside of Brazilian samba troupes, and an upright bass, expertly bowed to produce a drone. But its primary engine was the hulking contrabass saxophone to which Mr. Robinson was attached, and which had previously sat untouched onstage with the mute, conspicuous presence of a bodyguard.

title: While He Can Still Remember
description: Not many authors explain their reasons for writing books as bluntly as Neil Young does in Waging Heavy Peace. First of all theres the thing now known as the Keith Richards phenomenon: there turns out to be a large and lucrative market for memoirs from rock stars. In a two-page chapter called Why This Book Exists Mr. Young explains that his book will be a goose that lays a golden egg. Hes writing it because it will earn him enough money to stay off the stage for a while, which he badly needs to do for mental and physical reasons. It all started when I broke my toe at the pool, he explains.

title: Disruptions: You Know You Cant Live Without Apples Latest Glass Rectangle
description: Philip W. Schiller, Apples vice president for marketing, strode across the stage of the California Theater in San Jose last week trumpeting the virtues of new Apple products. As he caressed the side of the latest iMac personal computer, he noted how thin it was  five millimeters, 80 percent thinner than the last one. Then he said, with an air of surprise, as if hed just thought of it: Isnt it amazing how something new makes the previous thing instantly look old?

title: Nuclear Reactors Await Hurricane Sandy
description: Among the various immobile pieces of infrastructure in the path of the East Coast hurricane are around 20 nuclear reactors, from Calvert Cliffs in southern Maryland to Pilgrim in Plymouth, Mass., and Vermont Yankee, just north of the Massachusetts line in Vernon, Vt. But the industry and regulatory officials say that this is an anticipated challenge.

title: Reverting to Another Time to Revitalize Mozart Opera
description: Jonathan Millers 1998 production of Mozarts Nozze di Figaro, traditional in its look yet fresh and insightful, returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night with a good cast and the dynamic conductor David Robertson. So there is much to talk about.

title: Can Neuroscience Challenge Roe V. Wade?
description: When I was asked this summer to serve as an expert witness in an appellate case that some think could lead to the next Supreme Court test of Roe v. Wade, I was surprised.

title: Data-Gathering via Apps Presents a Gray Legal Area
description: BERLIN  Angry Birds, the top-selling paid mobile app for the iPhone in the United States and Europe, has been downloaded more than a billion times by devoted game players around the world, who often spend hours slinging squawking fowl at groups of egg-stealing pigs.

title: A Flop in All Phases
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Leading up to Sundays game against Miami, Rex Ryan issued daily reminders of its importance. It was big. Then it was critical. And then it was huge. The Jets, he said, absolutely needed to win.

title: Wall Street Prepares to Work From Home as Storm Approaches
description: 10:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Movies Try to Escape Cultural Irrelevance
description: LOS ANGELES  On Feb. 24 Hollywood will turn out for the Oscars.

title: Going Beyond Cultural Kid Stuff With a Wary Sense of Adventure
description: Good, better, best, bested. How do you like that for a declension, young man? Eh?

title: A Cozy Celebration of Brittens Centenary, With Strings and Context
description: When it came to his contemporaries Benjamin Britten could be prickly, refusing to be drafted into an avant-garde whose music was of no practical use to the public. Yet for all his loyalty to classical forms and tonal harmonies, the same prickliness injects a certain asperity into even his most lyrical moments. Thursday nights performance of Brittens String Quartet No. 2 by the formidable Escher String Quartet brought out the autumnal beauty and structural rigor in the chamber music of that British composer, still best known for his operas. It was the first of three concerts presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to celebrate the 2013 Britten centenary.

title: Mile 20: A Much-Maligned Bridge
description: We are here today to defend the honor of the Willis Avenue Bridge.

title: Bracing for Storm, U.S. Stock Markets to Close
description: 12:50 a.m. | Updated

title: Big Grant for the Joyce
description: The Joyce Theater is to announce on Monday a new artist-in-residence program designed to help choreographers in their artistic efforts as part of a $750,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. The first recipient will be Stephen Petronio, whose dance company is scheduled for its 19th season at the Joyce this spring. The appointment will last for two years and will provide a rehearsal studio, administrative space, office services and an annual salary with benefits.

title: Knicks Keep Close Eye on Storm
description: The Knicks are taking the same precautions for Hurricane Sandy as other residents in the New York area.

title: Italian Clubs Championships in Salsomaggiore
description: The 96-board Italian Clubs Championship final was played over the last four days of September in Salsomaggiore.

title: Storytelling Rappers, Cool and Hot
description: In one corner is Kendrick Lamar, from Compton, Calif., one of the most daring and sometimes vexing rappers of the day and one who is inverting the gang-rap legacy of his hometown while working under the auspices of one of its founding fathers, Dr. Dre.

title: Porkys Porcine Sweetie
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Its rare to see a double theme, especially on a Monday, but that is precisely what we have here, courtesy of Gareth Bain, erudite South African veterinarian and man about town.

title: Famous for Gaffes, a Candidate in Missouri Learns to Watch His Words
description: WEST PLAINS, Mo.  Todd Akin was revving up his stump speech here the other day, recycling an applause line that Senator Claire McCaskill was President Obamas strong right arm when a supporter seconded him with a disparaging description of her: lap dog.

title: Le Nozze di Figaro
description: Scenes from the production at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: On the Trail With Todd Akin
description: With less than two weeks left until Election Day, Representative Todd Akin is spending a lot of time traveling across Missouri and shaking hands with voters.

title: Poll Watch: Track the Polls In the Races Final Days
description: Less than two weeks to Election Day, national polls are showing a close race between President Obama and Mitt Romney among likely voters in a number of polls. Check back here daily to track the race as it heads into its final days.

title: N.F.L. Photo Replay: Week 8
description: The days games included one played in London, and another featuring throwback jerseys.

title: OpenX Acquires JumpTime
description: Publishers, in print and online, have long sold space to advertisers based on the perceived value of the publishers audience. The quality of that audience, in turn, was based on its location, income, education level and propensity to buy the product the advertiser sold.

title: Oxens Fate Is Embattled as the Abattoir Awaits
description: POULTNEY, Vt.  Just past the village here is the farm at Green Mountain College, where chickens roam free and solar panels heat a greenhouse. The idea of sustainability runs so deep that instead of machines fueled by diesel, a pair of working oxen have tilled the fields for the better part of a decade, a rare evocation of a New England agricultural tradition.

title: India Reshuffles Cabinet, as Chance of Early Elections Grows
description: NEW DELHI  Indias governing coalition announced a reshuffled cabinet Sunday in yet another effort to shake off nearly a year of paralysis and prepare for elections that may come sooner than their scheduled date in 2014.

title: Univision to Start Its First Digital Network
description: Univision and other Spanish language networks have long attributed their high ratings among Latinos to the fact that viewers watch their programming live.

title: Yellow Taxis, Rare Brooklyn Sightings, Multiply on Event Nights at New Arena
description: The yellowing of Flatbush Avenue began just before 10 p.m., greeting the areas revelers as they lumbered out of the neighborhoods new nerve center with beer on their breath and their teams logo on their chests.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Knicks Finally Practice at Renovated Madison Square Garden
description: The Knicks dribbled, shot jumpers and looked around at the additions to their home. With the regular season approaching, they finally stepped on the Madison Square Garden court Sunday for a light walk-through, becoming the last N.B.A. team to practice at its own arena this preseason.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Ontario City Shares Detroits Thrills (Tigers) and Ills (Auto Industry)
description: WINDSOR, Ontario  One of the little oddities of Detroit is that the quickest way to Canada is south, to Windsor, a border town tethered to its more imposing northern neighbor by bridge, tunnel and the Detroit Tigers.

title: What Works in a Campaign Commercial? Ad Executives Offer Their Take
description: Madison Avenue and Pennsylvania Avenue do not intersect. And often the kind of advertising that sells presidential candidates has almost nothing in common with the kind that makes consumers crave breakfast cereal or a certain kind of beer.

title: Hans Werner Henze, Composer, Dies at 86
description: Hans Werner Henze, a prolific German composer who came of age in the Nazi era and grew estranged from his country while gaining renown for richly imaginative operas and orchestral works, died on Saturday in Dresden, Germany, where he was due to attend the premiere that evening of a ballet set to one of his scores. He was 86.

title: As Obama Accepts Offers, Late-Night Television Longs for Romney
description: The week after the first presidential debate, with Mitt Romney riding a surge in the polls, Lorne Michaels believed he was close to achieving one of the perennial objectives of an election year for the celebrated television show he created and still produces, Saturday Night Live.

title: The Billionaires Club
description: As the rich grow richer, so does the coverage of their fortunes.

title: Now 12, California Boy Comes to Trial in Killing of Neo-Nazi Father
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  Both the prosecution and the defense involved in a trial set to start here on Monday basically agree on the following: Before dawn on May 1, 2011, 10-year-old Joseph Hall went to his familys living room armed with a snub-nosed revolver, pointed it at his fathers head as he lay sleeping on the couch, and shot and killed him.

title: World Series Game 4 Highlights and Analysis
description: Pat Borzi provided updates for Sundays Game 4 between the Giants and the Tigers. For a pitch-by-pitch recap of the game, check out the live game-tracker.

title: When Afghans Look to Border With Pakistan, They Dont See a Fixed Line
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It is perhaps a measure of the growing anxiety in Afghanistan that an American envoys seemingly innocuous comments about a border first laid down in the 19th century could provoke a week of defiant missives from Afghan officials and fearful murmurings about conspiracies being hatched in Washington and Islamabad.

title: Silos Loom as Death Traps on American Farms
description: STERLING, Mich.  Tommy Osier, 18, a popular but indifferent student, was still a year from graduating from high school, and that was no sure thing. Farm work paid him $7.40 an hour, taught him discipline and gave him new skills. He had begun talking about making a life in farming.

title: Soccer Arena Rouses Fans, and Russia, Over Its Cost
description: MOSCOW  A project to build a state-of-the-art soccer arena on the Neva River in St. Petersburg, envisioned as the jewel of Russias stadiums when the nation holds the World Cup in 2018, now stands to be scrutinized by auditors as part of a high-level inquiry into why it has repeatedly and drastically exceeded its budget.

title: Obama Is Even in TV Ad Race Despite PACs
description: Maybe the super PACs were not so super after all.

title: Williams Ends Season With Win and Fist Pump
description: ISTANBUL  After smacking her 40th and final winner of the match on a forehand service return on championship point, Serena Williams clenched her left fist, then punched the air with her right. She then skipped to the net as winner of the WTA Championships for the third time, having defeated Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-3, in the final Sunday.

title: At Fox News, a Liberal Pundit Finds the Spotlight
description: Sally Kohn is a former community organizer who prefers baggy clothes and doesnt own a television. She, her partner and their 4-year-old daughter live in the liberal bastion of Park Slope in Brooklyn, and she recently proudly posted on Twitter her new status as co-squad leader at the Park Slope Food Coop. Absolutely nothing about her screams obvious contributor to the Fox News Channel.

title: A Trade Molded to Sterns Design
description: In the darkest, dreariest hours of last years N.B.A. lockout, when the rhetoric had gone cold and faces had turned numb, league officials clung tightly to two goals: lower costs and competitive balance.

title: Advertising Relearned for Mobile
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Say you are in a strange city and need a hotel for the night. You pull out your phone, search for hotels on Google and see a nearby one listed at the top of the rankings, with a little phone icon that says, Call. You tap it, reach the hotel and ask for a room.

title: Rural Ohio Is Startled Host to Diverted G.O.P. Ticket
description: CELINA, Ohio  The last time that anyone can remember a presidential candidate traveling to this postage stamp of a town in rural northwestern Ohio (size: 4.4 square miles) was in 1988. Even then, it was a running mate, Dan Quayle, who breezed through.

title: In Middle of a Messy Election, a Nightmare Makes Landfall
description: WASHINGTON  In the dark of night, when they get what little sleep they get these days, the people running the campaigns for president have more than enough fodder for nightmares. Worse, come daybreak, they realize their worst fears may yet come true.

title: Governments Role in Creating Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Femininity and Politics: What the Research Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: Sick Leave Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Silence on Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgages and the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: At New Jerseys Southern Tip, Dire Forecasts Are Met With Irritation and Defiance
description: CAPE MAY, N.J.  Ed Johnston agreed to make only one concession to Hurricane Sandy: He would close his oceanside restaurant three hours early.

title: Chasing Armstrong With Truth
description: The Web is full of outliers who are constantly posting about vast conspiracies, advanced by powerful interests and enabled by the mainstream media. The truth, they say, is out there in plain sight.

title: Expecting the Worst, Utilities Will Focus on a Rapid Recovery
description: Coping with Hurricane Sandy is a battle that utility companies in the New York metropolitan area will have to fight on two fronts: at the level of their power lines, which the storms strong winds will threaten to rip down, and along the waterfront, where surging waters could flood critical equipment.

title: Olympics
description: The super PAC Restore Our Future created an ad highlighting Mitt Romneys tenure with the Salt Lake City olympics.

title: Tough Choices to Save Eagles, and Reids Job
description: By the time the Fire Andy chant began Sunday afternoon, the rain was already falling on Philadelphia, the sky as angry as the small clutch of fans that remained to welcome a hurricane and send off Andy Reid. Reids fate after this season is as uncertain as the weather, but the Eagles 30-17 loss to the Atlanta Falcons after a dramatic bye week solidified one thing.

title: Shallow Waters and Unusual Path May Worsen the Surge
description: Like a hand pushing water in a bathtub, the winds of a hurricane push the water of the Atlantic Ocean. When the windblown water runs up against land, the water piles up and flows inland. That describes a storm surge.

title: Science Is the Key to Growth
description: Houston

title: Giants Hang On to Victory, by a Finger
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On one sideline, the Dallas Cowboys players bounced around anxiously, hoping their miracle had come true. On the other, the Giants players waited nervously, praying they had not been beaten by the unlikeliest of desperation plays.

title: The No Agenda Myth
description: I feel a rising tide of ennui. America is in the last, numbing days of an excruciating slog to Election Day and some of my tribe  the jaded scribes, the blogging sages and caffeinated cable chatterers  have run out of patience, poor babies. Searching for the source of their malaise, beyond the dubious science of the polls and the mean spirits of the campaigns and the emptiness of the slogans and our own limited attention spans, those of my ilk have come up with this high-minded diagnosis: the candidates have No Agenda.

title: Panicked Evacuations Mix With Nonchalance in Hurricane Sandys Path
description: They streamed out of low-lying New York apartments and grand Connecticut shore homes, a steady, often reluctant parade of evacuees with rolling suitcases and duffel bags; birds and cats in cages; Fruit Roll-Ups and stacks of magazines.

title: Governing Party Claims Victory in Ukraine Elections
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The governing party of President Viktor F. Yanukovich declared victory in Ukraines parliamentary elections on Sunday, based on preliminary exit polls that also showed opposition parties making strong gains, including an unexpectedly strong rise in support for an ultranationalist party with a leader who is known for anti-Semitic and racist views.

title: Marathon Officials Preparing for Potential Race-Week Disruptions
description: Hurricane Sandy will have passed by the time the New York City Marathon begins next Sunday, but preparations may be affected by the storm.

title: An Extra Week to Rest, and Stew, for the Jets
description: A capsule look at the Jets 30-9 loss to Miami:

title: Medicaid on the Ballot
description: Theres a lot we dont know about what Mitt Romney would do if he won. He refuses to say which tax loopholes he would close to make up for $5 trillion in tax cuts; his economic plan is an empty shell.

title: With Less Time for Voting, Black Churches Redouble Their Efforts
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Rev. Eugene W. Diamond of the Abyssinia Missionary Baptist Church here rarely pays attention to the clock when the spirit moves him to preach, but midsermon on Sunday, he said something unusual to his flock of hundreds: Timing is critical, so let me hustle.

title: Deal With Premier League Gives NBC 380 Games
description: NBC Universals three-year deal with Englands Premier League, which starts in 2013, will let the company televise up to 380 games a season on the NBC broadcast network, the NBC Sports Network and at least two other cable networks.

title: Surveillance and Accountability
description: Nearly seven years after the disclosure of President George W. Bushs secret program of spying on Americans without a warrant, the Supreme Court is about to hear arguments on whether judges can even consider the constitutionality of doing this kind of dragnet surveillance without adequate rules to protect peoples rights.

title: Dark Money in Montana
description: In 2010, a group now called American Tradition Partnership brought a lawsuit against Montana, seeking to throw out the states anticorruption law. It argued that the law, which barred corporate spending on candidates campaigns, was unconstitutional under the Supreme Courts Citizens United ruling. In June, the Supreme Courts conservative majority obliged and handed the group a big victory by blocking the state law.

title: A Chance to Save the Southern Ocean
description: The Southern Ocean circles Antarctica and remains one of the most pristine and ecologically rich oceans on earth. Its richness has attracted a growing number of industrial fishing fleets, which are harvesting toothfish and krill, the tiny shrimplike creatures that are the foundation of the Antarctics marine life. Add to that a growing interest in the mineral resources of the Southern Ocean and you have the same kind of commercial pressure that is threatening the ecological balance of nearly every ocean on the planet.

title: With Displays, Pumpkins Get Their 15 Minutes
description: Forget jack-o-lanterns and even the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown. With Halloween on the horizon, pumpkins have become objects of spectacle, showmanship and competition, as displays across the New York region strive to be bigger, better and more bravura in their use of the no-longer-humble member of the gourd family.

title: Leading the Irish Is a Hands-On Learning Experience
description: NORMAN, Okla.  There sat Notre Dames pillar of consistency, Manti Teo, espousing the reasons the Fighting Irish had been unbeaten and planned to remain so: determination, attention to detail, humility. Barreling into running backs or angling into coverage, he has been ever-present and ever dependable for a defense that had routinely saved the Notre Dame offense. Until Saturday night.

title: Woolly Bears
description: When I first moved to this farm 15 years ago, I tried to identify everything: trees, shrubs, weeds, mammals, birds  everything but nematodes and bacteria it seemed. Some were easy (turkey, bobcat) and some were not (which goldenrod is that?).

title: Contract With Merit Pay, Backed by Union Chiefs, Is Tough Sell for Newark Teachers
description: NEWARK  On one side of the table was the union firebrand Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers. On the other was the state education commissioner handpicked by Gov. Chris Christie, who became a star among fellow Republicans for aggressively taking on public employee unions.

title: Try as They Might, Tigers Suffer Offensive Slump With Odd Echo
description: DETROIT  The futility of the Detroit Tigers offense reached a new low late Saturday in their lifeless Game 3 loss to the San Francisco Giants at Comerica Park.

title: Massachusetts Orders Another Pharmacy to Close
description: BOSTON  Massachusetts shut down another compounding pharmacy after a surprise inspection last week found conditions that called into question the sterility of its products, state officials said Sunday.

title: Miamis Punt Block Results in a Score and Sets the Tone
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jets punter Robert Malone estimated that the ball was five feet off his right foot when he first saw the Dolphins pressure collapse the gray sky around him.

title: Reviewing Week 8 in the N.F.L.
description: DAYS BESTReceiver Titus Young, stepping into a void left by the injured Nate Burleson and the ineffective Calvin Johnson, caught two touchdown passes, including a diving 1-yarder with 20 seconds left that lifted the Lions over the Seahawks, 28-24. Young finished with nine catches for 100 yards, both career highs.

title: Trading With the Enemy
description: Gen. Ulysses S. Grant took command of the Department of Tennessee on Oct. 25, 1862, and immediately started planning to capture Vicksburg, Miss., the principal remaining Confederate stronghold on the Mississippi River. In doing so, he came face to face with the dangerous consequences of a surprising fact of the Civil War: the semi-illicit trade in cotton between North and South. Northern merchants paid well, and often in gold, for the Southern crop; the Confederates then used that gold to buy new weapons, sometimes from clandestine suppliers in Northern or occupied cities like Cincinnati and Memphis. Grant soon found himself confronting rebel troops sustained by such trade, including cavalry armed with modern breech-loading carbines.

title: Edible Selby | The Thin Man
description: In New York City, a tiny pizza shop serving thin-crust pies would scarcely be cause for buzz. In Chicago, land of the deep dish and the generously proportioned Midwestern restaurant, such an establishment is almost an oddity. But novelty isnt the only reason Great Lake, a 14-seat spot started by Nick Lessins and Lydia Esparza in the Andersonville neighborhood, has been drawing crowds. Its tightly edited and fast-changing menu, featuring only three or four kinds of pies a night, incorporates the unexpected, like corn, cream and chives, or, on another, a tomatillo-based sauce  a tribute to Esparzas Mexican lineage. Rather than mozzarella di bufala, Lessins has taken to using sheeps milk cheese, sourced from a dairy in northern Wisconsin. I tried to come up with something that would fill a niche in the city, Lessins says. But I spent the most amount of time trying to get the crust right. There just wasnt enough attention being paid to making a really good crust. More

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Random House-Penguin Merger, and Romneys Straight Face

Under the merger the parent companies would share executive control, with Markus Dohle of Random House serving as chief executive and John Makinson of Penguin becoming the chairman. Still, Bertelsmann would control 53 percent of the merged publishers, in an attempt to avoid the complications of an even split. The combined company would have around 25 percent of the consumer publishing business in markets like the United States; as a result lawyers for both companies are already strategizing how to navigate regulatory approval.

title: Giant Gollum Sculpture Unveiled at Wellington Airport

But clearly the artists at Weta Workshop, the New Zealand-based company that has designed props and special effects for Peter Jacksons Hobbit and Lord of the Rings movies, had other ideas: the Wellington International Airport has recently unveiled this larger-than-life sculpture of Gollum, designed by Weta Workshop to mark the coming release of The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey and celebrate New Zealands involvement in Mr. Jacksons movies.

title: Doris, R.I.P. (Personal)
description: Some readers may know that for a long time Robin and I have had two sibling cats, Albert Einstein and Doris Lessing, both 19. Well, Doris  who had a lot of health problems over the years, but always managed to hold up  has had a tumor on her liver for several months. We babied her along, getting her to eat by feeding her special treats, and she held up much longer than the vet expected. But several days ago she stopped eating and drinking, seeming increasingly uncomfortable, and this morning we did the necessary and had her put to sleep.

title: The Get | Harry Winstons Hope Collection Bracelet
description: Its common knowledge that Harry Winston makes some of the most dazzling jewels for the red carpet (and for red carpet worthy clients), but few know about the companys recent philanthropic efforts. When we celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Hope diamond donation in 2010, we decided to renew our commitment to giving back by launching the Harry Winston Brilliant Futures Charitable Program, says Frdric de Narp, Harry Winstons president and CEO. Through this initiative, we continue to focus on giving back to and supporting charitable partners that inspire and instill hope in individuals around the world. In stores on November 1st, the Hope bracelet  an understated but elegant piece in white gold with a mother-of-pearl dial and a single signature Winston diamond  will be sold exclusively at Harry Winstons seven United States boutiques at a limited edition of 200. With 100 percent of the sale  $2,500, to be exact  benefiting local causes including the Society of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in New York and the Rehabilitation Hospital of the Pacific Foundation in Honolulu. The bracelet represents a full commitment on our part to provide long term support to organizations that are meaningful to our local communities, says de Narp.

They could have brought out the true, scrappy, resourceful, spunky, every-hop-goes-our way quality that the Giants used to captivate baseball fans in their postseason run. title: Contract Agreement for Cleveland Orchestra
description: The Cleveland Orchestra musicians and management agreed on a new contract this weekend, making it the second of the top United States orchestras to settle on financial terms recently mid a season of disputes in the symphony world. The deal in Cleveland, which spans this season and the next two, calls for no raise the first year, a 1 percent increase in the second and a 2 percent raise in the third, according to a joint statement released on Monday. Meanwhile, the players will have to pay more for health insurance and agreed to play four services likely to be fundraising or free concerts a year without pay. (They provided four such services last year.) They also agreed to be more flexible in the broadcast or recording of performances. The Chicago Symphony reached a three-year contract last month after a two-day strike. Labor disputes have also hit the orchestras in Atlanta, Indianapolis, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Seattle as managers and boards have tried to reduce compensation for the players, saying they need to cut costs.

title: Ford Continues Slide in Reliability Survey; Japanese Brands on Top

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

description: Dave Abrass joined Frank Unlimited, Seattle, as director for client services, assuming the account duties of Susana Cascais, managing director, who is leaving, the agency said, to return to her native Portugal. Mr. Abrass had been senior account director at the Garrigan Lyman Group, Seattle.

title: Goodbye, Gourmet; Hello, Food Fanatics
description: Newsweek has decided to end its print edition, and other publications like Gourmet, PC Magazine, SmartMoney and U.S. News & World Report are now only in digital formats. So it is perhaps not surprising that a new print magazine is being brought out by a company that specializes in food service products rather than journalism.

title: In Argentina, the Superclsico Returns
description: BUENOS AIRES  Boca Juniors faced River Plate on Sunday at Monumental Stadium in Buenos Aires, after a 530-day hiatus after River was relegated. After being dominated for most of the match, visiting Boca rallied from a 0-2 deficit to tie it, 2-2, with goals in the 75th and 91st minutes.

title: America Ferrera to Star in New Play for Womens Project Theater
description: America Ferrera, who won an Emmy Award for playing the title character in ABCs comedy Ugly Betty, will star in Bethany, a dark comedy by Laura Marks that will open the new season at the Womens Project Theater, the company announced on Monday.

description: 2:23 p.m. | Updated The arrival of Hurricane Sandy changed plans Monday for several television shows that tape in New York.

description: Barnes & Noble said on Monday it would begin its first advertising campaign in Britain, focusing on its Nook reader with built-in light as a way to grab customers before Christmastime.

title: For Fans, No Words Can Soothe Sting of Tigers Defeat
description: They say theres romance to losing. Theyre wrong. After watching my beloved Detroit Tigers be swept out of the World Series, I can fairly report that losing stinks. And of all the purple prose that has been written about the glory of losing at baseball, heres some of the purplest:

title: Revisiting a Famous Meal, Soup to Nuts
description: By the age of 42 (in an era in which life expectancy was 40), Leonardo da Vinci had yet to create anything commensurate with his lofty ambitions. At that point, Ross King writes in his new book, Leonardo and The Last Supper, he had produced only a few scattered paintings, a bizarre-looking music instrument, some ephemeral decorations for masques and festivals and many hundreds of pages of notes and drawings for studies he had not yet published, or for inventions he had not yet built. Too many of his projects  like creating a gigantic bronze horse on commission for Lodovico Sforza, the ruler of Milan  had gone unfinished; other projects having to do with architecture, military engineering and urban planning had not found patrons.

title: Do You Want to Be Careful, or Do You Want to Be Friends?
description: Being careful is not as much fun as being friends, said Frances. Do you want to be careful, or do you want to be friends? A Bargain for Frances, by Russell Hoban

title: Obama Ad Criticizes Romney Campaign Over Bailout Ad
description: As the presidential campaigns intensified their fight over the auto bailout, the Obama campaign released a new ad on Monday that criticized Mitt Romneys campaign for running an ad that it says misleadingly implies that Chrysler, a bailout recipient, is moving jobs to China from Toledo, Ohio.

description: THE FACTS

title: In Syria, Failed Truce and No Lull in Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The declared four-day holiday truce between the warring factions in Syria ended on Monday much as it had begun  with airstrikes, artillery barrages and other firefights around the country that made a mockery of the cease-fire.

title: Update on Hurricane Sandy  1 P.M.
description: TimesCast: Live updates on the storm from The New York Times newsroom at 1 p.m.

title: Beetles Affinity for Dung May Keep Them Cool
description: Ball-rolling dung beetles in the savannas of South Africa roll their prizes away to safe, secure locations, away from competition. These fresh, moist balls of dung contain nutritious liquid that the beetles feed on, but researchers have discovered something more: They may also be keeping the beetles cool.

title: For New York, the Issue of Steps Not Taken
description: With the last hurricane to directly hit New York City dating back to the 1800s, residents have so far lacked the impetus to demand concrete strategies for dealing with the potential devastation to housing, the subway system and the electrical infrastructure from a major modern-day storm. Now Hurricane Sandy threatens major flooding from a storm surge that could reach up to 14 feet above the average sea level here.

title: Ghana: A Grant Meant to Curb Infant Mortality Focuses on Getting Mothers to the Hospital
description: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has given a $5 million grant to a Massachusetts nonprofit group to work on a very specific problem: how to get new mothers in Ghana to hospitals.

title: Behind an Estimated $30 Trillion Drain on Banks, a Lot of Hypotheticals
description: Imagine a situation in which the worlds banks have to find as much as $30 trillion to comply with just one new regulation. That might be something of a stretch, given that the gross domestic product of the United States is only $15.8 trillion, and the worlds 10 largest banks hold only $25 trillion of assets.

title: Obama Speaks on Hurricane Sandy
description: President Obama, echoing mayors and governors across the Northeast, urged people in evacuation zones to get out of the way of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
description: Among those with birthdays this week are the director of some very fine movies; editors of two of the most influential magazines in the country, David Remnick of the New Yorker and Anna Wintour of Vogue; our second baby boomer first lady; and the musician Lyle Lovett, who, poor man, will go to his grave accompanied by the phrase, briefly married to Julia Roberts.

title: Theyre Eating Out of the Palm of His Hand
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Italy and Spain Defer Use of Bond Plan
description: MADRID  The leaders of Spain and Italy insisted on Monday that neither country had near-term plans to use the bond-buying program that the European Central Bank had offered, nor to support a recent proposal for a supercommissioner who might intervene in national budgets.

title: Back Home in Brooklyn, Marv Albert Welcomes a New Resident
description: The Nets have come to Brooklyn, where I grew up. And even after nearly 50 years of calling basketball games, I cant wait.

title: Fridays Data on Joblessness, Eagerly Awaited by Campaigns, Could Be Delayed by Storm
description: WASHINGTON  Hurricane Sandy might force the Labor Department to delay the release of the monthly report on the nations unemployment, due Friday morning, the most hotly anticipated piece of economic data to come out before the election.

title: Khaled Hosseini Plans New Novel Next May
description: 4:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Google Signs Deal With Warner Music Group
description: Google got one of the key pieces of its digital music puzzle in place over the weekend when it finally signed a deal to bring the catalog of the Warner Music Group  with Green Day, Madonna, Neil Young, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and hundreds of other acts  to its Play store.

title: When Hacking Was in Its Infancy
description: Was Peter G. Neumann the worlds first white hat computer hacker? The term hacker was popularized in Steven Levys 1984 book Hackers: Heroes of the Computer Revolution. It described an early generation of M.I.T. students who did not break into computers and networks  or black hats  but instead were passionate programmers and hardware tinkerers.

title: As Sandy Takes Its Time, TV News Is an Endless Loop of Anticipation
description: One of the blessings of Hurricane Sandy, if there are any, is its status as a very slow moving weather event.

title: Peter G. Neumann on Cyber Security
description: Computer scientist Peter G. Neumann talks about his research to create more secure software and hardware.

title: Street Style: Motorcycle-Inspired
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Oct. 22.

title: Four Preseason Surprises
description: The prescription that teams follow in the preseason is practically written in stone: round the rotation players into form, build that elusive ingredient known as chemistry, avoid major injuries and, finally, expose young players to the rigors of N.B.A. action. With most teams possessing few available roster spots, second-round draft picks and undrafted free agents are usually camp fodder. But here are four hidden gems who, against the odds, have emerged from the scrum to not only earn a spot on the roster, but are positioned to become valued contributors this season.

title: Face Time | Natalie Coughlin
description: It was hard to pass up a few moments chatting with the very pretty, 12-time Olympic medalist in swimming Natalie Coughlin. Though enjoying some time off, post-Olympics, shes been keeping busy traveling and working on various projects and partnerships. As one of the few athletes to who has not had corrective vision surgery, Natalie has recently teamed up with LensCrafters, and is helping get the word out about vision care and living a healthy lifestyle. Read on to find out which is her favorite mascara to adorn her healthy eyes, plus some great fitness and diet tips.

title: Killing the Computer to Save It
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Many people cite Albert Einsteins aphorism Everything should be made as simple as possible, but no simpler. Only a handful, however, have had the opportunity to discuss the concept with the physicist over breakfast.

title: No Longer Under the Radar
description: The hand-wringing in Philadelphia began before the Eagles loss to the Atlanta Falcons was even complete, and accelerated only when the dejected quarterback Michael Vick sounded as if he was prepared to concede his job to a rookie backup.

title: Taylor Swift to Co-Host the Grammy Nominations Show
description: Taylor Swift will be the co-host for an hourlong televised concert at which the nominees for the next Grammy Awards will be announced.

title: Early Voters, and a Hurricane, Change the Rhythm of the Campaign
description: With more than one in three votes likely to be cast before Election Day this year, Republicans are stepping up their efforts to chip away at what has been a Democratic advantage in early voting in vital battlegrounds like Ohio and North Carolina.

title: Milkens Past Invoked in Gupta Sentencing
description: More than two decades after pleading guilty to securities fraud, the financier Michael Milken still looms large. The demand for junk bonds, a market that he helped create, have touched record levels this year. A number of his disciples, like Leon Black of Apollo Global Management, are among the most powerful players on Wall Street.

title: On Instagram, 10 Photos a Second of #sandy
description: As Hurricane Sandy  churns its way through the Atlantic, those in its path are turning to their smartphones, and specifically Instagram, to document and share their experiences. Their output runs the gamut, from shocking to silly.

title: For Dakota Paleontologist, It All Started With a Turtle
description: MARMARTH, N.D.  It is not uncommon for young girls and boys to ask their parents for a pet turtle. But how many children collect dead ones?

title: Aided by Growing Sales, Chrysler Profit Increases 80%
description: DETROIT  Chrysler, the third-largest Detroit automaker, said on Monday that its third-quarter profit rose 80 percent on the strength of new models, less debt and steadily growing sales in both American and international markets.

title: Observers Denounce Ukrainian Election, Citing Abuses by Rulers
description: KIEV, Ukraine  International observers delivered scathing criticism on Monday of Ukraines parliamentary election, saying the vote was heavily tilted in favor of President Viktor F. Yanukovichs Party of Regions through the abuse of government resources, the dominance of media coverage and the jailing of two prominent opposition leaders.

title: Storm Puts Up Obstacles on Road to Marathon
description: Hurricane Sandy will have passed through New York by the start of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, but the storm is taking a toll on the weeklong schedule leading up to the race.

title: A New Bank Lets You Choose Charity for Rewards
description: A new online bank is hoping that better-than-average savings rates, and the lure of charitable giving, will attract new deposits.

title: Low Voter Turnout in Sicily Suggests Anger at Politicians
description: ROME  Sicilians shunned regional elections to renew the islands Parliament on Sunday in record numbers, in an unequivocal signal of growing disaffection with Italys political class, even as the center-left wrested control from center-right parties that had governed the region since 2000.

title: Scenes Along the Hudson River
description: Midday scenes along the Hudson River, with drivers trying to get through the Holland Tunnel before it closed.

title: Program and Ticket Price Recall an Ensembles Start
description: A dollar fifty doesnt even cover the cost of intermission chocolates at Carnegie Hall these days, but it was enough to attend the American Symphony Orchestras 50th-anniversary concert there on Friday evening.

title: Chancellor Merkels Chance to Push Russia
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel is off to Russia in a few weeks. There, she will attend the regular Petersburg Dialogue.

title: Update on Hurricane Sandy  3 P.M.
description: TimesCast: Live updates on Hurricane Sandy from The New York Times newsroom at 3 p.m.

title: Nurses, Addicted to Helping People
description: When a book is heavy with glossy photographs, you seldom expect too much from its words. In The American Nurse, though, its the narrative that hits you in the solar plexus.

title: Trading Hotel Rooms for the Guest Room
description: Under pressure to hold down costs, some business travelers are finding that the best way to save on a hotel is not to stay in one at all.

title: David Barboza Answers Reader Questions on Reporting in China
description: The Timess Shanghai bureau chief, David Barboza, reported last week that close relatives of Wen Jiabao, the prime minister of China, hold billions of dollars in hidden riches. Here are his answers to questions from readers prompted by the article.

title: Hybrids and Electric Vehicles Do Well in Reliability Survey
description: Hybrid vehicles, and those powered by electricity in one form or another, have good predicted reliability in the Consumer Reports 2012 Annual Auto Reliability Survey.

title: Mayor Bloomberg on Hurricane Sandy
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke from the Office of Emergency Management in Brooklyn.

title: Gov. Cuomo on Hurricane Sandy
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo addresses reporters late Monday morning on New York states preparations and the seriousness of the situation.

title: Smoke-Free Workplace Leads to Fewer Heart Attacks
description: A new study has found the strongest evidence yet that smoke-free workplace laws that reduce secondhand smoke inhalation can lead to reductions in heart attacks.

description: Left. Right. Left-right-left. And-a-left-and-a-right.
