description: Residents of Far Rockaway, Queens, embraced the flooding and waves as Hurricane Sandy arrived.

title: App Snapshot: Romneys Move to the Middle and What Happens After Jan. 20
description: The presidential candidates suspended their campaign activities on Monday because of the major Atlantic storm barreling into the East Coast. Voters can take advantage of the down time to examine the candidates statements  in the past and about the future  a bit more closely. In any weather, were collecting the most important politics news in the Election 2012 app.

title: Training the Dirty Harry Stare on an Unruly Flight Mate
description: MY first flight was right after I graduated from high school. I went to Hawaii. I started off by myself, stepping outside my comfort zone, and ended up meeting a lot of great people and seeing a lot of amazing sights. I grew up on Chicagos South Side, and my mom helped put some funds together to help me go on this trip. It turned into the most amazing thing I ever experienced.

title: How to Drink Like Hemingway
description: Even a casual student of the novelist Ernest Hemingway knows the man liked to drink. But a quick skimming of Philip Greenes new book, To Have and Have Another: A Hemingway Cocktail Companion, reveals exactly how much the man enjoyed his cups.

title: On Electoral Map, the Green Is Obscured
description: If you are already dismayed at the spending and tactics that have characterized this election season, better stay away from Tuesdays episode of Frontline on PBS. The piece, Big Sky, Big Money, looks at the shenanigans in Montana in the last four years, and the picture it paints of American electioneering certainly suggests a beast out of control.

title: Gov. Christie on Hurricane Sandy
description: Gov. Chris Christie addresses the press early Monday afternoon on the status of Hurricane Sandy.

title: With Obama Tending to Storm, Clinton Campaigns for Him in Florida
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  With Hurricane Sandy barreling toward the Northeast on Monday, former President Bill Clinton played stand-in for President Obama at a campaign rally here at the University of Central Florida.

title: A Playwrights Wonderland, Inspired by Alice
description: AliceGraceAnon, a meandering theatrical essay accompanied by a dutiful rock band, is not a title that trips off the tongue or sticks in your head. Its like the play itself: a collection of parts jammed together to form an ungainly whole.

title: Crane Is Dangling Off Luxury High-Rise
description: The crane atop one of Manhattans most prestigious addresses remained dangling precariously 1,000 feet above the ground on Tuesday as officials tried to determine how to safely secure it.

title: After Accusations of Insider Trading, a Profession of Innocence
description: A Denver businessman who was arrested on Friday on insider trading charges e-mailed his family and friends over the weekend, proclaiming his innocence and comparing his plight to challenges faced by Nelson Mandela and Steven P. Jobs.

title: More Storm-Related Cancellations on Broadway, at Lincoln Center and Elsewhere
description: 7:01 p.m. | Updated Lincoln Center announced more storm-related cancellations for Tuesday. According to a Lincoln Center spokeswoman, the Film Society abandoned screenings; Juilliard cancelled classes, rehearsals and performances; the New York Philharmonic cancelled a rehearsal; and a performance of music by Stockhausen at Alice Tully Hall was also suspended.

title: Sandy Attacks
description: OK, power line down across our driveway; the tree that took it down also took down our Fios connection to the outside world. Im blogging using my iPad as a hot spot, but linkage may be iffy  were sort of in the Bermuda triangle of cell access, and at the moment I have only one bar.

title: Greece Moves Quickly to Put Editor on Trial
description: ATHENS  Prosecutors on Monday set a fast-track trial date for the investigative journalist arrested last weekend after publishing a politically sensitive list of Greeks said to have Swiss bank accounts.

title: Hes Still Searching His Heart
description: NEIL YOUNG

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Wireless Light Bulbs and Windows 8 Hardware
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently.See more here.

title: Cooped Up at Home, Energetic Children and Their Anxious Parents
description: The boys were playing computer games, the girls were playing board games, and the moms were in a Brooklyn kitchen playing a game of their own, though one tinged with dread.

title: Cliff Confusions
description: While I have access, let me point you to an excellent post by Suzy Khimm making a point I should have made: the only reason to worry about the fiscal cliff is if youre a Keynesian, who thinks that bringing down the budget deficit when the economy is already depressed makes the depression deeper. And the same logic actually says that we should not just avoid spending cuts, we should raise spending right now.

title: Microsoft Seeks an Edge in Analyzing Big Data
description: SEATTLE  Eric Horvitz joined Microsoft Research 20 years ago with a medical degree, a Ph.D. in computer science and no plans to stay. I thought Id be here six months, he said.

title: Colorado Race Turns Fierce After Republicans Anti-Obama Remark
description: AURORA, Colo.  In his former, overwhelmingly Republican district, Representative Mike Coffmans remark that President Obama was just not an American might not have caused much of a stir. His aides note that registered independents in that deep-red territory were mainly those who considered Republicans too liberal.

title: In Shake-Up, Apples Mobile Software and Retail Chiefs to Depart
description: 8:24 p.m. | Updated  Apple fired the executives in charge of the companys mobile software efforts and retail stores, in a management shake-up aimed at making the companys divisions work more harmoniously together.

title: Adios, Arpaio?
description: Election Day brings with it the tantalizing possibility that voters in Arizona will do what should have been done years ago: end the career of Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, the self-appointed, self-promoting scourge of illegal immigrants whose five-term reign has been a disaster for law enforcement, county budgets, the lives of immigrants and Latinos and the rule of law.

title: Lean Airlines in Poor Shape to Handle Passenger Backlog
description: AIR travelers have probably already figured this out, but Im going to say it anyway: They are facing days of frustration as disruptions from the virtual shutdown of the air travel system in the Northeast ripple out nationally and the airlines struggle to put the pieces back together.

title: Calendar Says October; Retailers Say Its Christmas
description: COME the hell of political ads or the high water of Hurricane Sandy, many retailers still plan to begin their Christmas shopping campaigns this week.

title: Chasing Heartache and Grief With Song
description: Life shows you who youve become when theres no more mystery in the fading light. The more you consider that somber observation from Mary Chapin Carpenters song Chasing Whats Already Gone, the more deeply it resonates. That reflection, from Ms. Carpenters recent album Ashes and Roses, was the opening number of her memorable Friday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall, part of the White Light Festival.

title: On Frankenstorms, Climate Science and Reverse Tribalism
description: [Technical note. Power and Internet out where I live so comment moderation likely to be slow. Patience appreciated.]In e-mail exchanges earlier this year, Thomas Crowley, a retired climate scientist whos been a longtime source, proposed the term reverse tribalism for a trait in some people studying and communicating about human-driven climate change.

title: The Caucus Click: Biden and Clinton in Ohio
Question for Justices: Do Aldo and Frankys Noses Always Know?
description: WASHINGTON  Every dog has its day, but not every dog has its day in court.

title: As if the Ottoman Period Never Ended
description: ISTANBUL  Since the lavish, feel-good Turkish epic Conquest 1453 had its premiere this year, its tale of the taking of Constantinople by the 21-year-old Sultan Mehmet II has become the highest-grossing film in Turkeys history, released in 12 countries across the Middle East and in Germany and the United States. But its biggest impact may be the cultural triumphalism it has magnified at home.

title: A Stylistic Chameleon Stays in Camouflage
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Benjamin Millepied  who emerged as one of the last dancers to work with Jerome Robbins and then came to fame as a strikingly assured, handsome principal with New York City Ballet  has been an enigmatic choreographer for years. What style of dancing does he like? What images of energy does he present? What ideas of humanity does he believe in? His ballets give no clear answers to those questions, though several of his dances show compositional skills beyond those of many other choreographers.

title: Ambitious, With Ives Anchoring
description: Two symphonies by Charles Ives were being played simultaneously at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. The American Composers Orchestra performed his Third Symphony in Zankel Hall, while the American Symphony Orchestra played the Fourth upstairs in the Stern Auditorium.

title: ATLANTA SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA AND CHORUS
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Justices Weigh Case on Imported Textbooks
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in a copyright case about the sale of imported textbooks on eBay that has wide-ranging implications for many products made abroad and sold in the United States.

title: Music In Review
description: MARLIS PETERSEN

title: Up-and-Coming Runner Catches Eye of a Coaching Great
description: This summer, Mary Cain faced a difficult decision. She wanted to advance her successful running career, but she had outgrown her coaches at Bronxville High School. She also wanted to continue to live at home, not move elsewhere to work with a coach.

title: Pictures of the Day: Connecticut and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Connecticut, New York, Washington and Afghanistan.

title: Inside the Silo
description: Silos teeming with corn, wheat or soybeans become death traps when grain cascades out of control, asphyxiating or crushing their victims.

title: Update on Hurricane Sandy  5:30 P.M.
description: TimesCast: Live updates on Hurricane Sandy from The New York Times newsroom at 5:30 p.m.

title: China: Military Shake-Up Continues
description: A former deputy chief of the armys general staff, Lt. Gen. Wei Fenghe, has been promoted to commander of the Second Artillery Corps, home of the strategic missile force, the Defense Ministry said Monday. The new position, as head of one of Chinas most important military units, is part of a major turnover in Chinas armed forces and almost certainly assures General Wei a seat on the Central Military Commission, the militarys top decision-making body. The commission will oversee the rapid modernization of Chinas military.

title: Israel: Arrests for Rebuilding Hamas
description: Israels security service, Shin Bet, has arrested about 30 Palestinians in the West Bank over the past few months on suspicion of working to rebuild the local infrastructure of Hamas, the Islamic militant group, according to a statement issued Monday. Hamas won legislative elections in the West Bank and Gaza in 2006 and took full control of Gaza a year later. Its rival, the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, has limited control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and has also worked to suppress Hamas there. Israeli security officials said those arrested were members of a field command responsible for strengthening Hamass presence in some West Bank universities.

title: Pounded by the Storm
At Election Time, a Plea to Remember the Hungry
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Retailers Prepare for After the Deluge
description: For retailers that sell home repair items and emergency supplies, a storm like Hurricane Sandy represents a logistical puzzle and a big sales opportunity.

title: Protests in Guatemala
description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Day Off
description: At the Brooklyn Promenade, New Yorkers watched the waves and rain come in as warnings about Hurricane Sandy's arrival blanketed the news.

title: Cities Unserved by Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting Art From Visitors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Week Before the Day of Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: An Oyster in the Storm
description: DOWN here at the end of Manhattan, on the border between evacuation zones B and C, Im prepared, mostly. My bathtub is full of water, as is every container I own. My flashlights are battery-ed up, the pantry is crammed with canned goods and I even roasted a pork shoulder that I plan to gnaw on in the darkness if ConEd shuts down the power.

title: The Damage Done: Hurricanes in New Yorks History
description: A brief photographic history of major storms in New York City and the region.

title: Time to Get Tough on Iraq
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Poll Watch: Track the Polls In the Races Final Days
description: With just more than a week until Election Day, national polls are showing a close race between President Obama and Mitt Romney among likely voters in a number of polls. Check back here daily to track the race as it heads into its final days.

title: First Outing for SpaceX
description: The first commercial spacecraft to carry cargo to the International Space Station splashed down in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday, completing a three-week mission that was mostly successful though far from flawless. A small California technology company, Space Exploration Technologies, or SpaceX, launched its cargo-carrying capsule atop its Falcon 9 rocket on Oct. 7 and almost immediately encountered a problem when one of the rockets nine engines shut down shortly after liftoff.

title: Called Third Strike Is a Rare Way to End World Series
description: When Miguel Cabrera stared at strike three from Sergio Romo in the bottom of the 10th inning of Game 4 of the World Series, ending the Detroit Tigers season, Twitter exploded with hundreds, possibly thousands, of people saying the same thing: Beltrand. With a better knowledge of history, they would have been saying: Goslind.

title: A Dance Is a Dance
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled last week that Nite Moves, a strip club near Albany, must pay sales tax on admissions fees it collects from customers. State law exempts from sales tax dramatic or musical arts performances, including choreographic performances. The question was whether a private lap dance or a pole dance qualifies as a dance. Clearly, they should.

title: Greece Arrests the Messenger
description: Greeces slow and cumbersome justice system moved with stunning swiftness over the weekend to arrest and charge a respected investigative journalist who published a list of prominent people with Swiss bank accounts. Contrast that with the two years that Greek tax authorities sat on that same list after the French government, which had seized it in a criminal investigation, turned it over to Greece to determine whether some of those Swiss accounts were possibly linked to tax evasion.

title: A Big Storm Requires Big Government
description: Most Americans have never heard of the National Response Coordination Center, but theyre lucky it exists on days of lethal winds and flood tides. The center is the war room of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, where officials gather to decide where rescuers should go, where drinking water should be shipped, and how to assist hospitals that have to evacuate.

title: Insurers Estimate $10 Billion in Damages
description: The insurance industry could be responsible for paying for $5 billion to $10 billion in property and casualty claims from Hurricane Sandy, but it has the resources to make the payouts, industry experts said Monday.

title: In Turkey, a Break From the Past Plays Out in the Streets
description: ISTANBUL  At a reception on Monday evening at the presidents mansion to celebrate Turkeys founding 89 years ago, something previously unheard of occurred: the countrys top military commander stood alongside the wives of the president and prime minister, even while the women wore Islamic headscarves.

title: Sandy the Soothsayer
description: If youve watched whole sections of your home sail away, been stranded in a shelter or cant make contact with a loved one whose safety isnt certain, its probably unsettling at best  and galling at worst  to hear Sandy referred to as an October surprise, on a par with a bimbo eruption or corruption scandal, wreaking havoc on the presidential race above all else.

title: Mystic River Rising in Connecticut
description: The storm surge from Hurricane Sandy is expected to coincide with the full moon tide, causing the Mystic River to overflow.

title: Baffert, at Santa Anita, Has a Home-Track Edge
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  The trainer Bob Baffert was the picture of contentment Monday as he shielded his eyes from the sun and watched one after another of his gleaming starters in the Breeders Cup World Championships train at Santa Anita Park.

title: The Argo Caper
description: I saw Ben Afflecks movie Argo the other day, and ever since Ive been wondering why its gotten such good reviews and has even, as some of the reviewers breathlessly say, been generating Oscar buzz. Its not a bad movie; watching it is not a chore; its just that Id seen it done before and done better.

title: Villagers in Morocco Drive Out Prostitutes
description: AIN LEUH, Morocco  For years, this mountain village with its crumbling whitewashed walls was known locally as the place to go for sex. Women  some dressed in tight jogging suits, some in dressing gowns  dallied in the tiled doorways off the main square, offering a Moroccan version of Amsterdams red-light district.

title: The Upside of Opportunism
description: Lets try to imagine what the world would look like if President Obama is re-elected.

title: Jets Plan to Use Bye Week to Hit Reset on Their Season
description: In the ever-changing world of the N.F.L., no team is static. From week to week, it improves or regresses, nothing else. The verdict on these Jets was delivered twice, in different fashions, in the last two days.

title: Behind the Inscrutable Mien, Clues to Merkels Methods
description: CHISINAU, Moldova  On a blazing afternoon, as the euro crisis was surging back from summer vacation, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany descended on this impoverished sliver of a nation in her continuing quest to expand the European family. Folk costumes, children proffering roses and an honor guard figured in a welcome that evoked faded Communist pomp and still more distant Hapsburg glory. In a land that the chancellor acknowledged had once suffered the dictatorship of Nazi Germany, the scene unfurled before a mighty Airbus with Luftwaffe emblazoned on its tail.

title: If Canceled, N.H.L. Will Not Reschedule Winter Classic
description: If the N.H.L. cancels the Winter Classic, it has no plans to reschedule the event for this season, even if there is a prompt settlement to the lockout, said Bill Daly, the deputy commissioner.

title: Bloomberg Continues to Warn New Yorkers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg encourages New Yorkers to stay inside and stay safe, and looks to the cleanup ahead.

title: Should the Adoption Tax Credit Be Renewed?
Libya Warnings Were Plentiful, but Unspecific
description: WASHINGTON  In the months leading up to the Sept. 11 attacks on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, the Obama administration received intelligence reports that Islamic extremist groups were operating training camps in the mountains near the Libyan city and that some of the fighters were Al Qaeda-leaning, according to American and European officials.

title: A Dubious Case Found Lawyers Eager to Make Some Money
description: It always seemed like a scam.

title: Taxis, but Not as Many as Usual, Are Among Only Options
description: The taxis gathered outside of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, as if out of habit, waiting for passengers whose rides to New York had never materialized. Wayfarers slogged up a ghostly Broadway, its lights dimmed beneath the graying sky, or squinted through full-body ponchos as they churned their bicycles to get to work. And a curious few breached the barricades outside of New York Citys subway stations, sneaking a peek at the system that never sleeps, sleeping.

title: Fun on the Farm
description: Corn mazes have become big business night and day at some farms. In Milton, Tenn., Stan Vaught runs a corn maze on his family farm.

title: Yet Another Blow to Haiti From a Natural Disaster
description: MEXICO CITY  At the edge of disaster, a few days of rain can be lethal.

title: Buster Posey, the Champions Champion
description: DETROIT

title: Day-Lewis Gives Parents Papers to Oxford
description: Sometimes history gives to Daniel Day-Lewis, and sometimes he gives back. In this case, Mr. Day-Lewis, who plays the 16th President of the United States in the coming Steven Spielberg film Lincoln, is on the giving end and is donating the papers of his parents to the Bodleian Libraries at Oxford University.

title: Farmers Find Path Out of Hardship in Corn Mazes
description: MILTON, Tenn.  Over the course of a month, Stan Vaughts two sons will make more money letting people walk through a maze carved from 10 acres of corn than he will raising cattle and soybeans on the other 190 acres of his familys farmland.

title: Power Failures and Furious Flooding Overwhelm Lower Manhattan and Red Hook
description: With rapids-like fury, water piled out of New York Harbor on Monday night and flooded scores of city streets, venturing far deeper into neighborhoods than anyone could remember. Red Hook in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan seemed to bear the brunt of the onslaught, though similar scenes unfolded in Queens and in Upper Manhattan.

title: In Seattle, Virtual University Will Have a Physical Campus, Too
description: SEATTLE  With name tags clipped on and PowerPoint at the ready, officials from Northeastern University invited prospective students in one night last week for a peek at a new extension campus, 2,500 miles from the schools home in Boston and about as far northwest as you can get in the lower 48 without swim fins. It is a trend that many colleges and universities have embraced in recent years  remote campuses to extend the brand and the flow of tuition checks.

title: Seems Awfully Smooth for a Wild Ride
description: The conventional wisdom about this years presidential race is that it has broken out of stasis to become wildly unpredictable.

title: Now Enjoying Continual Success, the Giants Will Honor Their Roots
description: DETROIT  It has become Mike Murphys new biennial tradition. When the Giants win the World Series, he immediately calls Willie Mays. And then he calls his wife.

title: Three Leaders, All Comfortable, Put Three Different Faces on Storm Response
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg played the stern parent, chiding the kids not to surf and offering sensible suggestions like staying home to eat a sandwich.

title: With No One Looking, a Hurt Stays Hidden
description: Weve seen it hundreds of times. An athlete is injured and within seconds is surrounded by an armada of medical personnel: trainers, assistant trainers, team doctors. The athlete is helped off the field, given a diagnosis, treated and sent to physical therapy, often to return miraculously in a week or two.

title: Giants Appreciate Their Resiliency, if Not Their Efficiency
description: With the Giants ahead by 23 points early in the second quarter Sunday, the only issue that appeared to be decided was whether they could beat Hurricane Sandy back to Newark Liberty International Airport.

title: Central Park Gets More, While the Citys Poorer Parks, Well, They Just Get By
description: It was a munificent gift, just superb.

title: Judge in Trayvon Martin Case Denies Request for Silence
description: MIAMI  The judge in the Trayvon Martin murder case on Monday denied a prosecution request to bar lawyers for George Zimmerman from using a Web site about legal issues, as well as social and traditional news media, to comment about the case.

title: The Right Man for the Job?
description: The position of chief executive of The New York Times Company is not the easiest to fill.

title: Empty of Gamblers and Full of Water, Atlantic City Reels
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The weather chased them in all its steadfast fury, as if mocking them at every haven they tried. The four of them  a mother, two children and a cousin  thought they could wait the monster out, ride the luck that Atlantic City promises.

title: Breaking Down Dez Bryants Overturned Touchdown
Storm Is Expected to Be Less Powerful, and Less Drenching, as It Moves Inland
description: WILKES-BARRE, Pa.  The monster storm that has battered and drenched the coastline of the northeastern United States is likely to become less monstrous as it moves inland. Hurricanes and tropical storms generally lose strength once they move over land, and this storm should be no exception, said Brian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami.

title: G.O.P. Turns Fire on Obama Pillar, the Auto Bailout
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  The ad from Mitt Romney showed up on televisions here early Saturday morning without the usual public announcement that both campaigns typically use to herald their latest commercials: Chrysler, a bailout recipient, is going to begin producing Jeeps in China, an announcer says, leaving the misleading impression that the move would come at the expense of jobs here.

title: City Ends Sibling-Preference Rule in Gifted Admissions
description: New York City education officials are rolling out several changes to the admissions process for gifted programs as they confront an explosion in the number of children qualifying for seats.

title: The Danger of Voter Fraud Vigilantes
description: In 2008, Montana was the canary in the coal mine. About a month before the election, a local citizen named Jacob Eaton formally challenged Kevin Fureys voter registration, swearing that he was no longer eligible to vote. Furey had asked the post office to change his address from Helena to Missoula. Eaton asked local election officials to take Furey off the Helena rolls.

title: Hurricane Sandy a Chance at Redemption for FEMA
description: WASHINGTON  As Hurricane Sandy approached landfall Monday, Federal Emergency Management Agency officials here were struggling with the question of how to deploy resources in the face of a powerful, far-reaching storm that was bearing down on a string of the nations largest metropolitan areas.

title: Long Island Envisions Life After the Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Once the nonpareil of suburbia, Long Island has been losing jobs and drawing crime. Taxes are among the highest in the country, yet here in Nassau County finances are so bad that a state-appointed committee must oversee them.

title: Lottery Numbers
Challenge to Wiretaps is Heard by Justices
description: WASHINGTON  A challenge to a federal law that authorized intercepting international communications involving Americans appeared to face an uphill climb at the Supreme Court on Monday, but not one quite as steep as many had anticipated.

title: Yankees Pick Up Options on Granderson and Cano
description: DETROIT  The Yankees picked up the $15 million options on second baseman Robinson Cano and center fielder Curtis Granderson on Monday. The moves were not unexpected.

title: In San Diego, Gay Republican Finds He Cant Count on Gay and Lesbian Vote
description: SAN DIEGO  A victory for Carl DeMaio, who is locked in a tight mayoral race, would make San Diego the second-largest city in the country to elect an openly gay mayor, and by far the largest to elect a gay Republican.

title: Senator Scott Brown Pulls Out of Debate
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Browns campaign announced Monday afternoon that he would not participate in his fourth and final debate with Elizabeth Warren, his Democratic challenger, on Tuesday night, citing Hurricane Sandy.

title: In Political Sign Battle, Thievery, Acid and Jelly
description: SOUTH MIAMI, Fla.  Two weeks ago, Hillary Wiseheart plunged an Obama-Biden campaign sign into her front lawn, a defiant stance amid the riot of Romney-Ryan signs in her well-kept neighborhood. The next day, it was gone.

title: Something That Makes Stops on the Ocean
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  The country will be voting in the presidential election soon, and while we make a concerted effort to remain apolitical here at the Wordplay offices (well, I do, but I cant speak for the emus), Alex Vratsanos is making it very difficult for us today.

title: Hurricane Sandy Pounds New York City as It Moves Inland
description: Hurricane Sandy, a monstrous storm all but without precedent on the East Coast, cut a devastating path.

description: FRONT PAGE

description: anoint \-nint\ verb

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Oct. 30
description: The city is under siege. Sandy is pretty furious at Atlantic City. She must have lost a bet or something.

title: A Closer Look at the American Pivot
description: HONG KONG  The United States still has tens of thousands of troops based in Europe, a full withdrawal from Afghanistan is two years away, Irans nuclear program appears to be a crisis-in-waiting and the Middle East remains highly combustible. But as a senior American diplomat says, the history of the 21st century is going to be written in the Asia-Pacific region, which presents the opportunity for an absolutely unique American role.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ELLEN DeGENERES: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Ms. DeGeneres, the 15th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored, above, at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony taped on Oct. 22. Her career has traversed comedy clubs in her hometown, New Orleans; the sitcom Ellen, which received Peabody and Emmy Awards in 1997 for the episode in which she came out as gay to 46 million viewers; The Ellen DeGeneres Show, a daytime talk show; and roles as a host of Oscar, Emmy and Grammy ceremonies. Among the friends and colleagues cheering her here are Kristin Chenoweth, Steve Harvey, Sean Hayes, Jimmy Kimmel, John Krasinski, Jason Mraz and Lily Tomlin. Its such an honor to receive the Mark Twain Prize, Ms. DeGeneres said when she was notified of the distinction. To get the same award that has been given to people like Bill Cosby, Tina Fey and Will Ferrell, it really makes me wonder ... why didnt I get this sooner?

title: If You Like Carly Simon. . .
Patients Evacuated From City Medical Center After Power Failure
description: A backup power system failed at one of New York Citys premier medical centers on Monday night, forcing the evacuation of all patients to nearby hospitals amid the storms strong gusts, officials said.

title: News Quiz | October 30, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Is Indias Rising Billionaire Wealth Bad for the Country?
description: The strength and direction of the Indian economy may be up for debate, but one remarkable fact is not: There has been massive growth in the number and wealth of billionaires in India since the economic liberalization measures in 1991.

description: NEWS Updates on the destruction and havoc caused by Hurricane Sandy in the northeastern United States. James Barron reports from New York.

description: More than six million customers lost power Monday as Hurricane Sandy felled trees, downed power lines and flooded substations.

title: Mining Coal and Melting Ice
description: David Breashears couldnt be reached a number of days ago when wed hoped to speak over the phone. He was in Kathmandu, dealing with something of a mountaineering crisis.

title: Still Waiting for the Narrator in Chief
description: Presidents generally dont like to admit mistakes, so it was interesting when Barack Obama owned up to one during an interview with Charlie Rose on CBS last summer. It was the job of the president, Obama said, to tell a story to the American people that gives them a sense of unity and purpose and optimism, and it was on this score that he had fallen short. Conservatives gleefully mocked the president, saying that the country needed jobs more than it needed stories, and the remark did seem to hint at some genuine denial. After 40-plus months of high unemployment, a president who thinks his mistakes rest not in his policy choices but rather in his ability to articulate them is probably telling himself a story, if no one else.

title: Should Athletes Who Dope Have to Forfeit Their Titles and Medals?
description: Lance Armstrong was stripped of his seven Tour de France titles last week after the International Cycling Union decided that he was a ringleader of a doping program on his winning cycling team. Armstrong became a heroic figure for many, not just because of his cycling feats, but also because he is a cancer survivor and the founder of the highly respected Livestrong cancer foundation.

title: On Facebook, Gay Politics Quickly Gets Personal
description: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Part 2: Answers to Readers Questions About Early Admissions
description: The Choice has invited Greg W. Roberts, the dean of admission at the University of Virginia, to answer your questions about applying early in the blogs Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

title: The Real Barrier to Tax Reform
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: After the Devastation, a Daunting Recovery
description: The New York region began the daunting process on Tuesday of rebuilding in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, a storm that remade the landscape and rewrote the record books as it left behind a tableau of damage, destruction and grief.

title: Q&A: Moving Pictures on the Web
description: Q.

title: What You Need to Know About Merchant Cash Advances
description: Every morning, before I start my day, I stop for a cup of coffee and a bagel near my office. I have to choose between the local Dunkin Donuts franchise and Maguires, a boutique sandwich shop. Invariably, I pick the sandwich shop. I know the owner, Joe Maguire, and I like to support him. Also, his coffee is great.

title: Cyclone Nilam Lurks off South Indian Coast
description: As the east coast of the United States grapples with Hurricane Sandy, Cyclone Nilam is swirling about 500 kilometers, or 310 miles, off the east coast of southern India.

title: Tuesday Reading: Scientists Have Long-Lasting Flu Vaccine in Sight
An Update for the Corporate Help Desk
description: BMC Software, which makes products for managing corporate computers and employee help desks, is releasing a product that personalizes delivery of things like documents and corporate software to personal devices. People will be able to use it to order their own computers, automatically know if something urgent is going on in their businesses, or make appointments to talk to a help desk, instead of just waiting on the phone to describe a problem.

title: Bayer to Buy Schiff Nutrition for $1.2 Billion
description: LONDON  The German pharmaceutical company Bayer agreed on Tuesday to acquire the nutritional supplement company Schiff Nutrition International for $1.2 billion.

title: Daily Report: A Shake-Up at Apple
description: Apple fired the executives in charge of the companys mobile software efforts and retail stores, reportNick Wingfield and Nick Bilton in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: BP Returns to Profitability and Plans to Raise Its Dividend
description: LONDON  The oil giant BP returned to profitability with a better-than-expected third-quarter profit, prompting it to raise its dividend.

title: From One Mine, the Gold of Pop History
description: In the recorded-music business, most of the recent headline numbers havent been good. Sales are down, layoffs are up. Dont even ask how many people downloaded the latest Katy Perry album illegally.

title: Subjunctivitis
description: I try not to dwell on the subjunctive. Its grim terrain. Usually one rant a year or so is all I can muster, and Ive covered my quota for this year.

title: Markets Remain Shut
description: MARKETS REMAIN SHUT | Stock markets will be closed Tuesday for a second day, as New York deals with the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. While the New York Stock Exchange currently plans to be back in business on Wednesday, it may have to rely entirely on electronic trading, the exchange said late Monday, adding that the physical floor had not been damaged by the storm. This is the first time since 1888 that weather has forced markets to go dark for consecutive days.

title: Carlyle to Buy Diversey Japan for $377 Million
description: The Carlyle Group agreed on Tuesday to buy a Japanese sanitation business from the Sealed Air Corporation for $377 million.

description: Update: Please see our full collection, Teaching Hurricane Sandy: Ideas and Resources

title: Sandy Dominates European Headlines
description: LONDON  Four thousand miles away  and more  in Europe, the winds from Hurricane Sandy were strong enough to blow most other news off front pages and news bulletins on Tuesday.

title: Storm Sandy Impacts U.S. Presidential Election
description: Storm Sandy has disrupted the final week of polling and canvassing before next Tuesdays election.

title: Data Show Weakening in Euro Zone Economy
description: PARIS  Germanys chancellor and the leaders of five international economic organizations called on government leaders Tuesday to take decisive action to help spur growth in the 17 euro zone countries and elsewhere in the global economy.

title: On a Night Without Audiences, the Show Goes On for Letterman and Fallon
description: While Hurricane Sandy shut down new late-night broadcasts from Jon Stewart, Stephen Colbert and Jimmy Kimmel (who brought his program to Brooklyn from Los Angeles for the week), two of their New York comedy colleagues were determined that the show must go on. David Letterman and Jimmy Fallon (and their very understanding crew members and celebrity guests) went ahead with their tapings, despite the absence of studio audiences and key personnel, lending an eerie intimacy to the otherwise entertaining proceedings.

title: Weakness in Europe Undercuts Fords Profit
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said it expected its profits in North America to support the rest of the company for the foreseeable future as it struggles with losses in Europe and mixed results elsewhere.

description: One thing is for sure: No New Yorkers can say they werent warned about the potentially devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy and the need to take precautions. Yet some bristled at the cascades of warnings that went on for days. This is New York, after all.

title: Storm Pushes Aside Presidential Politics, Mostly
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Perhaps nothing better encapsulated the tricky calculus of running for president in the midst of a natural disaster than the mixed messages flashing on a giant screen here Tuesday at an event for Mitt Romney.

description: ISTANBUL  After a satisfying lunch of meze and fish, a body needs a demitasse of thick Turkish coffee. But in this case it was not to be.

title: NBC Is Not Moving Ahead With Office Spinoff The Farm
description: NBC isnt buying The Farm, but, in another sense, The Farm has bought the farm: this proposed spinoff of The Office, which would have starred Rainn Wilson as the eccentric Dunder Mifflin underling Dwight Schrute, will not be produced as a series for the network. In a post on his Twitter account, Mr. Wilson wrote, Farm Update: NBC has passed on moving forward with The Farm TV show. Had a blast making the pilot  onwards & upwards! He added: PS Keep watching the AWESOME final season of The Office. Many surprises & hilariousities coming!

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Publishing Consolidates, and Creeping Christmas Creep
description: Despite the storm, David Letterman broadcast from Midtown Manhattan on Monday night, without a studio audience. Above, Denzel Washington braved the elements to appear on the show, entering in a yellow slicker while the band played Bob Dylans song Hurricane, which did double duty for Mr. Washington, who portrayed the boxer Rubin Carter in the film The Hurricane.

title: Afghans Say Presidential Election Date Is Set for April 2014
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai took a step toward fulfilling his pledge to hold Afghanistans presidential election on time, as officials said Tuesday that the vote had been officially set for April 5, 2014.

title: Obama Diverts From Politics to Oversee  Disaster Response
description: 12:25 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON  President Obama worked through Tuesday morning and much of Monday night to oversee the federal response to the storm that ravaged much of the East Coast.

title: Ex-Envoy Says U.S. Stirs China-Japan Tensions
description: HONG KONG  A longtime Chinese diplomat warned Tuesday that the United States is using Japan as a strategic tool in its effort to mount a comeback in Asia, a policy that he said is serving to heighten tensions between China and Japan.

title: Secret Surveillance
description: At the Supreme Court on Monday, Solicitor General Donald Verrilli Jr. told the justices that they should not allow judicial review of a secret surveillance program in order to preserve the separation of powers among the governments three branches. But if the court lets the executive branch prevail in this dispute, its power will be almost unlimited for surveillance and the power of the judiciary will be gutted: it is possible no court will ever rule on the constitutionality of the program.

title: A Gift So Tasty, You Might Keep It
description: NOW is the season for pears of all types, but Seckel pears are particularly charming behind glass. About 3 inches tall and perfectly shaped, they layer into a jar halved and cored without any cramming.

title: Hurricane Sandy Knocks Out Gawker and Other News Sites
description: The power failures that swept through the East Coast, including large swaths of Manhattan, in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, darkened millions of homes, as well as several major Web sites, including the hive of sites in the Gawker Media network, including Jezebel and Gizmodo. The Huffington Post and social media news site Buzzfeed also went dark.

title: In Wake of Storm, Christie Breaks From Attacks to Praise Obama
description: Chris Christie was supposed to be one of Mitt Romneys most aggressive surrogates, constantly attacking President Obama in the waning days of the presidential campaign.

title: Icy Beer Before Its Put on Ice
description: Weizeneisbock is an intense style of wheat beer that was developed in Bavaria in the 19th century. The word eis buried in the name refers to the practice, which started accidentally, of freezing the beer during aging to concentrate the alcohol and flavor. (Think eiswein, or ice wine, made from frozen grapes.) Only a handful of German brewers make it, and now Gordon Biersch Brewery in San Jose, Calif., has started producing its own version. The beer, 10 percent alcohol, has a toasty, malty flavor perfumed with bananas and cloves, so typical of German wheat beers.

title: Post-Sandy Weekly Reader: Mix It Up at Lunch  Day, Flu Vaccines, and Minecraft
description: Scientists Move Closer to Lasting Flu Vaccine. My children, reluctant recipients of flu shots since their arrivals in our family, will celebrate this one. Which reminds me to ask my annual question: Have you had yours? The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends them for nearly everyone, and reminds us that you cannot get the flu from the inactive viruses in the shot, and that reliable blind studies have borne that out. In an odd way, I appreciate the lesson that the voluntary flu shot offers kids: sometimes, the right choice isnt the pleasant one.

title: Biscotti With a Changed Personality
description: Bonnie Lynn Tempesta, once the American biscotti queen, is back, but not with La Tempesta, which she started in 1983 in San Francisco and then sold 15 years ago. Her new biscotti, called Boncora, are made in Sonoma, Calif., and are smaller, denser and not as sweet as the Americanized version she made popular. Studded with whole toasted almonds, they come plain or coated with chocolate, a blend of milk and semisweet from Guittard in San Francisco. Their somewhat rustic texture, color and flavor result from a special blend of flour, with spelt in the mix.

title: A Far-Reaching System Leaves 8 Million Without Power

title: Granny Smiths Little Sibling
description: You can find apples in small sizes, like some Macouns, at farm stands. But Manhattan Fruit Exchange now sells Granny Smiths and Braeburns in an uncommonly small size  about half as big as a typical apple. Though somewhat larger than traditional lady apples, they are perfect to tuck into a lunchbox or to bake whole to garnish a pork roast.

title: The Making of Angela Merkel
description: PARIS I have long been fascinated by Angela Merkel  a woman who has risen to power in a conservative country where most women still find it hard to get to the top; an East German who seemed untrammeled by the mediocrity, the torpor and the generally loathsome atmosphere of mistrust that permeated that drab Communist state. I spent many years covering the Soviet bloc, relishing the great friendship and conversation you could enjoy behind closed doors. I am also married to a Russian pianist and composer, Sergei Dreznin, and I had the great good fortune to be in East Berlin the night the wall fell in 1989, 23 years ago next week. Probably it was all that  and Ms. Merkels intelligence  that led me to want to know more about how she came from small-town surroundings to the pinnacle of German politics.

title: Oct. 29: Polling Slows as Storm Wreaks Havoc
description: The effects of Hurricane Sandy on next Tuesdays election are hard to predict. But the storm is likely to have an impact on the volume of polling in the meantime.

title: Vietnam Sentences 2 Musicians to Prison Terms on Propaganda Charges
description: A court in Vietnam has sentenced two musicians to prison for writing and distributing protest songs, a decision that drew fire from the United States and international human-rights groups, The Associated Press reported. The musicians, Vo Minh Tri and Tran Vu Anh Binh, were convicted on Tuesday of spreading propaganda against the state after a half-day trial in Ho Chi Minh City, a defense lawyer said. Mr. Tri received four years in prison, Mr. Binh six.

title: A Refresher on Hurricane Deductibles and Flood Coverage
description: Updated / 7:54 a.m. to add that hurricane deductibles will not be used in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: New York Marathon Officials Determining How to Proceed
description: As officials evaluated widespread storm damage, organizers for the New York City Marathon began work Tuesday to determine how Sundays race might be affected by flooding and power outages.

title: Reader Photos of the Storms Aftermath
description: Pictures of Hurricane Sandy and the damage it inflicted, taken by readers of The New York Times.

title: Where Do You Come From?
description: Dear Diary:

title: Life on Wheels
description: Alex Watters had an accident during his freshman year of college. Nothing was ever the same.

title: ABCs of Accommodations
description: ACCORDING to the most recent government figures, about 11 percent of undergraduates, or over two million students, have a disability. Most have learning disabilities, like dyslexia or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, but 15 percent have an orthopedic or mobility impairment; 6 percent have a hearing impairment; and 3 percent are blind or visually impaired.

title: Campus as Obstacle Course
description: THE specially equipped Dodge Sprinter pulled into the Morningside College parking lot, transporting my campus guide and his Quickie 646 SE motorized wheelchair. Alex Watters was returning to this small liberal arts college in Sioux City, Iowa, for a wheelchair tour of the campus he had navigated as an undergraduate. Our mission was to understand some of the challenges faced by students with a physical disability for a book I was writing on the first-year college experience.

title: Flooding in Stonington
description: After evacuating their home in Stonington, Conn., as Hurricane Sandy came through, Mary and Don Roy had to return to their flooded home to retrieve some needed items.

title: Jeep Production Isnt Moving to China, Chrysler Chief Says
description: Chryslers chief executive on Tuesday strongly refuted claims that production of Jeeps would shift to China, an insistence that cast further doubt on the Romney campaigns recent efforts to undercut President Obamas support for the auto industry as it fights for Ohios 18 electoral votes.

title: Apocalypse Now
description: The presidential candidates have told us many times that this election is vitally important and have stressed the dire consequences of voting for the other guy. President Obama says the poor will suffer while rich people will prosper if Mitt Romney wins. Mr. Romney counters that Mr. Obama will destroy the economy, coddle terrorists and betray Israel.

title: After Hurricane Sandy, Stock Exchanges Prepare to Open
description: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Nets Opener Against Knicks on Thursday Will Be Played
description: The most anticipated Brooklyn sports event in a half-century  the Nets debut at Barclays Center  will unfold as planned, despite lingering concerns in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Distribution of Billions in Aid to Storm Victims Will Test FEMA
description: WASHINGTON  With state and local governments handling the bulk of the immediate response to Hurricane Sandy, federal officials here were left with one critical role: bankrolling the effort.

title: Remaining Undeclared While Enjoying Senior Year
description: I have been thinking a lot lately about my major. I am nowhere near the right amount of decisiveness to choose a major, though I have been noting my feelings toward certain things I do in my life.

title: New Poll Gives Warren the Edge in Massachusetts Senate Race
description: BOSTON  A poll released Tuesday by Suffolk University shows Elizabeth Warren with the support of 53 percent of likely voters compared with 46 percent for Senator Scott P. Brown in the hard-fought Massachusetts Senate race.

title: Citing Violence, Bahrain Bans All Protests in New Crackdown
description: CAIRO  Citing recent episodes of violence, the government of Bahrain on Tuesday banned all public rallies and demonstrations, a move that drew swift condemnation from human rights groups and opposition activists who said it was intended solely to stifle criticism of the ruling monarchy in the tiny Persian Gulf nation.

title: Back in the Mix: New England Rum
description: NEWPORT, R.I.

title: Fates of Three Key Jets Are Intertwined
description: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

title: A Devastating Storm Hits New York
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg describes Sandy as a devastating storm, saying it may be the worst that New York City has ever seen.

title: Storm Aftermath: Live Updates
description: Coverage from October 29 and 30, 2012, of the storm that disrupted power and transportation for millions of people in more than a half-dozen states.

title: A Storm Update and the Political Fallout
description: TimesCast: Latest on the storm damage and power outages. | Obama and Romneys differing responses. | The potential for even more election day complications.

title: Mother and Son: Richard Russo Talks About Elsewhere
description: Richard Russos first memoir, Elsewhere, tells the story of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelists loving and difficult relationship with his mother, Jean. Mr. Russos parents separated when he was a child in upstate New York. Raised by his mother, he served as her emotional wellspring, for better and worse. As Mr. Russo became a professor and a successful novelist, he remained deeply devoted to Jean, bringing her with him to Arizona and then back to the East Coast. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Russo discussed his decision to write about his mother, the autobiographical elements of his fiction and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Takes Nascar Points Lead
description: The balance of power shifted atop the Nascar season standings, after five-time series champion Jimmie Johnson took the points lead with a victory at Martinsville Speedway.

title: Polish Newspaper Report on 2010 Crash Causes Furor
description: MOSCOW  Suspicions among some in Poland that a 2010 plane crash that killed President Lech Kaczynski and much of the countrys senior leadership was not an accident were revived on Tuesday by a disputed newspaper report suggesting that traces of explosives may have been found in the wreckage in western Russia.

title: Digital Gains Help Newspaper Circulation Figures
description: A steady increase in digital circulation has helped newspapers combat the pressures on their print issues, with average daily and Sunday circulation remaining essentially flat for the sixth-month period ending Sept. 30.

title: EMC Acquires Silver Tail Systems
description: The data storage giant EMC said Tuesday that it had acquired Silver Tail Systems, an antifraud start-up.

title: Spago 2.0
description: A tour of celebrity chef Wolfgang Pucks newly renovated flagship restaurant, the Beverly Hills Spago.

title: The Once and Future Spago
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: District of Columbia Area Escapes Major Storm Damage
description: WASHINGTON  As Hurricane Sandy blew through the Washington area Monday on its way north, businesses and government were virtually closed, but the high winds and heavy rains left the area with surprisingly little damage.

title: Critics Boycott Breeders Cup After Drug Ban
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Call it uncharted territory, as some horse trainers here have, or the new facts of life, as many breeders and drug reformers prefer, but for the first time in the history of the event, 2-year-old horses at this weekends Breeders Cup world championships will not be allowed to be injected with a drug that is intended to restrict pulmonary bleeding.

title: Soup, Charity and the American Way
description: On a day when millions of Americans face serious hardship as they recover from Hurricane Sandys damage, Mitt Romney clearly decided it would be crass to campaign in a conventional way. So he turned a scheduled rally in Kettering, Ohio, this morning into a storm relief event, and posed before piles of donated canned goods.

title: A Battered Red Hook
description: A look at the outcome of the flooding that resulted from a crippling storm in the Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: A Shortcut for Hailing Taxis in European Cities
description: Finding a reliable taxi with a fair price is usually a skill tourists end up mastering only by the time they are on their way out of an unfamiliar city. But now visitors to Europe have a shortcut: a new travel booking service called Cabforce.

title: Working Through Hurricane Sandy
description: Some New Yorkers in Midtown Manhattan worked overtime during Hurricane Sandy.

title: Australias Sermanni Named Coach of U.S. Women
description: Tom Sermanni, the longtime coach of Australias womens national team and a former coach in the Womens United Soccer Association, has been named head coach of the United States womens national team.

title: Marathon Survival Strategies
description: I spoke with a proper runner the other day  you know, the kind who just took up running and completed her first marathon in 3 hours 15 minutes. She said it was easy. She was annoying.

title: Capturing the Crown Again in a Familys Last Tractor Restoration
description: This years Delo Tractor Restoration Competition, held last week at the 85th National FFA Convention in Indianapolis, represented a couple of significant milestones for the Haass family of Devine, Tex.

title: Fiat Keeps Italian Factories Open, Turning Focus to High-End Models
description: FRANKFURT  Defying the worst European auto sales in 20 years and deepening losses in the region, the chief executive of Fiat said Tuesday that he would not close any of the carmakers underused factories in Italy and vowed to repeat the turnaround he has already led at Chrysler.

title: Obama and Christie to Assess Damage in New Jersey
description: President Obama will join Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, in viewing damage from the storm on Wednesday, the White House announced on Tuesday as Mr. Obama praised relief efforts at a Red Cross headquarters in Washington.

title: Romney Campaign Doubles Down on Auto Bailout Attacks
description: The Romney campaign is continuing to attack President Obamas effort to rescue the auto industry, arguing in a new radio commercial that the federal governments $80 billion assistance plan actually helped China more than it did the United States.

title: Prospect Park After Hurricane Sandy
description: Stephen Farrell reports on the damage to the Brooklyn park.

title: NY1 Becomes a Prime-Time Anchor in the Tumult of the Storm
description: Just before 7 on Monday night, the worst of Hurricane Sandy was still largely theoretical and NY1 was broadcasting its viewer-participation show The Call. There was anxiety in the air, but the coverage was still loose, experts sharing airtime with local residents. One viewer called in from the Lower East Side, awe in his voice at what was on the horizon, something his agitated pet seemed already prepared for  I should have listened to my dog!

title: A Clash Across Europe Over the Value of a Click
description: PARIS  Google got rich by selling a simple proposition: The links it provides to other Web sites are worth a lot of money, so much that millions of advertisers are willing to pay the company billions of dollars for them.

title: Lawyer Withdraws From Case by Man Claiming Facebook Ownership
description: The lawyer representing a man claiming to own a substantial stake in Facebook withdrew from the case on Tuesday, just a day after he defended his client in an interview with The New York Times.

title: Scene City: Art Stars Steal Hollywood Spotlight, Briefly
description: Art and film worlds converge at Lacmas second annual gala.

title: In L.A., Art + Film + Fashion
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Aftermath of Hurricane Sandy in New York City
description: The damage and flooding from Hurricane Sandy in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Three Travel Tips to Navigate the Storm
description: Here are three fast and free ways to keep tabs on the airlines and your flights in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.

title: The Risks of Tapping Your Retirement Fund for an Alternative Use
description: Retirement funds are being used increasingly for anything but retirement. Instead, 401(k)s and individual retirement accounts are becoming money pots used to invest in business start-ups, speculate in gold and buy private equity investments.

title: Community to Return From the Wilderness in February, NBC Announces
description: Community fans will finally get a chance to see their favorite again  and on a night when better ratings could still save it.

title: On Our Radar: Images From the Superstorm
description: The depressing superlatives that were laced through the coverage and commentary of Sandy (which acquired a hyphenated name when it came ashore as a post-tropical cyclone) were barely adequate in describing the storms impact. Images might do a better job. (Our colleagues at The Lede blog are also following Sandys devastation state by state.)

title: Help  My Daughter Wants to Make Movies
description: My daughters friend wants to be a speech therapist. Another is in an accelerated medical school program. Like my daughter, they will be college seniors this fall. Part of me envies their parents, as their children have a decent chance to earn a living. My daughter, on the other hand, wants to make movies.

title: Wealthy Donated Less but Volunteered More in 2011
description: The 1 percent have taken some lumps over the last year or so. But despite a dip in overall philanthropic giving, the majority of the wealthy donated a consistent proportion of their income to charity last year, a new study finds.

title: Settlement Talks Continue in Court Battle Over Spider-Man Musical
description: A legal settlement has still not been signed in the court fight between the producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark and their former director, Julie Taymor, despite a late-October deadline set by a federal judge overseeing the case, according to a spokesman for the show and two other people with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

title: The Caucus Click: For Biden, Its On to Florida
Disney Buying Lucasfilm for $4 Billion
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, in a move that gives it a commanding position in the world of fantasy movies, said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Lucasfilm from its founder, George Lucas, for $4.05 billion in stock and cash.

title: Just Outside the City, and Building Bedrooms
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Sitting in his office, surrounded by Halloween kitsch and posters of building designs, the mayor of Harrison talks like a man who has been selling an idea for a long time. After 15 years, his vision to transform this long-forsaken industrial town into a bedroom community for single, young professionals is finally taking shape.

title: Google Introduces New Emergency Resources in Response to Sandy
description: Google has scrambled to post online resources for people who want information about the deadly storm Sandy, including mapsshowing evacuation routes and shelters and a new service that sends emergency alerts to Google users.

title: Captured by a Camera, a Poetry of Lost and Missed Connections
description: Can you look sad? the photographer Gregory Crewdson asks a young mother as she gazes with delight on her gurgling newborn.

title: Pamela Liebman
description: Ms. Liebman, 50, is president and chief executive of the Corcoran Group, which is owned and operated by NRT, one of the nations largest residential brokerage companies with divisions including Citi Habitats.

title: With Digital Readership Up and Pay Wall Down, The Times Covers the Storm Robustly
description: The New York Times had many more readers than usual on Monday and early Tuesday as Hurricane Sandy devastated the metropolitan area and beyond.

title: Two Views of a Storm in Climate Context
description: 4:38 p.m. | Updated with more scientists input at the end. }In the hours before Hurricane Sandy thundered ashore, igniting power stations and Queens neighborhoods and darkening urban and rural communities alike, I filed two pieces for Dot Earth. The first, The #Frankenstorm in Climate Context, was on the storm in the context of climate history and the science pointing to greenhouse-driven climate change. The second was on the impact of our tribal nature on climate communication, including my own.

title: Talde
description: Inside Dale Taldes restaurant in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: A Wireless Charging Solution for the Leaf and Volt
description: Beginning in March, Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf owners will have the option of an aftermarket wireless charging solution for their cars. Wireless company Evatran, which makes chargers under the Plugless Power brand name, will shortly announce a partnership with SPX Service Solutions, an official charging supplier for the Chevrolet Volt, to provide residential installations.

title: A 41-Mile, 4-Day, Best-Brazil-Beach Quest
description: Four donkeys eat seaweed for breakfast. A teenager break dances in the surf. An old man nudges a coconut from a tree. And an entire town agrees on how to misspell crepes.

title: Lawsuit Seeking Greater Digital Royalties for Eminems Music Is Settled
description: A federal lawsuit that has been closely watched in the music industry because of its potential effect on the contentious issue of digital royalties has been settled.

title: After Weak Returns, the Endowment Fund Limits Withdrawals
description: The sales pitch for the fund was simple: a chance for individual investors to get in on the same high-octane private equity and hedge funds that have fueled successful returns for large university endowments for years.

title: Making First Impressions Last
description: CHARGING into a restaurant during its first weeks of life used to be an amateur move, guaranteeing long waits, clueless service and food that could generously be described as a work in progress. Diners with any wisdom and self-control waited a few months, or even years, while the place hit its stride.

title: Wandering Visionary in Maths Far Realms
description: When I find myself in the company of scientists, W. H. Auden wrote, I feel like a shabby curate who has strayed by mistake into a drawing room full of dukes. Benoit B. Mandelbrot (1924-2010) had the kind of beautiful, buzzing mind that made even gifted fellow scientists feel shabby around the edges. Mandelbrot is said to have revitalized visual geometry and coined the term fractal to refer to a new class of mathematical shapes that uncannily mimic the irregularities found in nature.

title: Arnold Greenberg, a Founder of Snapple, Dies at 80
description: Arnold Greenberg, who began his career selling pickles and herring from a New York City storefront and went on to become a founder of Snapple, the international beverage giant, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: With Lucasfilm Deal, Disney Spends Big to Land a Lucrative Franchise
description: With its $4.05 billion acquisition of Lucasfilm, the Walt Disney Company is proving yet again that it is willing to pay up to land a big franchise.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, New Jersey, Gaza City and Myanmar.

title: A Con Artist Loses Her Cool When Icy Hands Grip Her Throat
description: A drag act in Provincetown, Mass., usually involves a heavily made-up, loudly outfitted Amazon, of the kind rarely glimpsed in daylight, handing out fliers all afternoon on Commercial Street for an evening of bitchy banter and lip-synced songs. Not in the case of Jeffery T. Roberson, better known as his alter ego, Varla Jean Merman, who starred there this spring in Gian Carlo Menottis one-hour opera The Medium.

title: Lower Manhattan in the Wake of the Storm
description: A look at the effects of Hurricane Sandy in Lower Manhattan.

title: Lebbeus Woods, Architect of the Imaginary Realm, Dies
description: Lebbeus Woods, a New York architect who became a cult figure among students and academics for his signature drawings, died on Tuesday at age 72. His death was confirmed by his longtime friend and fellow architect Steven Holl.

title: Teaching Hurricane Sandy: Ideas and Resources
description: Updated | Nov. 12

title: Another Republican Group Buys Pennsylvania Air Time
description: Another major Republican player is making a big bet that Mitt Romney has a chance of winning Pennsylvania.

title: In Storm Deaths, Mystery, Fate and Bad Timing
description: They stepped in the wrong puddle. They walked the dog at the wrong moment. Or they did exactly what all the emergency experts instructed them to do  they huddled inside and waited for its anger to go away.

title: Its Bach, Without the Usual Stereotypes
description: The extravagantly talented organist Cameron Carpenter took the stage of Alice Tully Hall early Sunday evening, not quite dressed for Hurricane Sandy  he was wearing a black tank top, skintight iridescent pants and heeled shoes  but certainly aware of it.

title: Serendipitous Matchmaking of Art and Movement
description: PHILADELPHIA  Dancing Around the Bride, a new exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, assembles work by Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, John Cage and Merce Cunningham. The idea makes perfect sense. There used to be an organization that did such combining all the time. It was called the Merce Cunningham Dance Company.

title: Sometimes a Great Tribute Has Nothing to Do With the Subject
description: MEMPHIS  The Mississippi River, famous in song and literature, has also inspired choreography. At the end of Kansas City Ballets Tom Sawyer, new last year, the dancers embodied it. Now Ballet Memphis has taken up the theme with The River Project, a triple bill of new ballets honoring the Mississippis cultural importance.

title: Did Global Warming Contribute to Hurricane Sandys Devastation?
description: Was the bizarre storm called Sandy a product, in whole or in part, of human-induced climate change?

title: Stravinsky and Rite, Rigorously Rethought
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Stravinsky a sadist? Maybe, but only in the kindliest sense. Stravinsky a Fascist? No, but a sympathizer perhaps.

title: Rangers Defenseman Weighing Offer to Play Overseas
description: Defenseman Michael Del Zotto could soon become the fourth locked-out Ranger to make his way overseas. Del Zotto has until Thursday to decide whether to accept an offer to play with Rapperswil-Jona Lakers of the Swiss N.L.A., his agent, Mark Guy, said Tuesday.

title: Returning to Industrys Roots With Lessons in Branding
description: AFTER a career helping large brands define themselves, Ron Berger, the former top executive of Euro RSCG, one of the largest agencies in the world, has taken on a different mission: teaching. Last Wednesday, in a cramped glass-paneled conference room on East 19th Street in Manhattan, a group of about 15 students, many under 30, assembled for the first of two classes from Mr. Berger on how to build a valuable brand.

description: To the Editor:

title: Revitalizing a Dead Mall (Dont Expect Shoppers)
description: SAN ANTONIO  Where others saw an abandoned shopping mall with weeds growing in the parking lot, graffiti on the walls and homeless men camping out in what was once the food court, Graham Weston, chairman and co-founder of Rackspace, a Web hosting company here, envisioned a corporate headquarters.

title: Last-Minute Halloween Costume Inspirations
description: Hurricane Sandy has put a damper on Halloween this year. But dont let that put a damper on your costume. Here are some last-minute inspirations for the stylish.

title: Obama and Romney in Exceedingly Close Race, Poll Finds
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  President Obama and Mitt Romney enter the closing week of the campaign in an exceedingly narrow race, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News, with more voters now viewing Mr. Romney as a stronger leader on the economy and Mr. Obama as a better guardian of the middle class.

title: Fires Follow Hurricane Sandy
description: In the Breezy Point section of Queens, houses burned to the ground.
